reviews.review: Cultural ethnic of Vietnamese Women's Museum. Opening Hours: 8.00 am – 17.00 pm, everyday except Mondays .There is a souvenir shop in the museum and electronic tour guide that can be rented . The museum has a large parking lot and it seems there is no airconditoning in some space The Vietnamese Women’s Museum, in Hanoi, was founded by the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam in 1987The museum was reopened in 2010 after a period of 4 years of renovations. The museum has three main galleries and these present three main themes: Women in Family, Women in History and Women’s Fashion.

Great expose on Vietnamese women. Amazing. Loved the fact that in this strongly patriarchal society, there is this exhibition honouring women. It showed an insight into the important roles women have played in families, trade, society and war. An eye opener.
Touching . This is a must see when in Hanoi.Exhibitions are well set out. A mixture of emotions when walking through. Give yourself a good couple of hours to truly enjoy.

Vietnam Women's Museum is excellent!. I loved this museum and found it very well set out and very interesting. I also purchased the audio guide and the commentary was fascinating and enhanced the visit. There are three floors with a different theme on each floor: Women in History, Women in Family and Women in Fashion. Well worth a visit.
Womens History. Interesting to read about the history of Vietnamese women. Only had half an hour in here, more time is needed!!

you'll look differently at the vendors after visiting this museum. The museum provides a prospective that is easily missed in a general observation of the activity that occurs daily out on the streets. You'll find a depth of knowledge on these 5 floors that is well presented through visual and written explanations. For those who lived through the Viet Nam/American war - an entire floor is dedicated to this era - you'll find information that was never reported in western news reports.

well worth a visit. This is a fascinating place Tells the story of women place in Viet Nam including the war years It was interesting that the couple with us slept in the same cradles they had on show

something to do if the weathers bad. we went to the womens museum,its over 5 floors though we missed the top floor as it closes at 1pm for an hour,the museum tells of women at different ages,different types of traditonal dress and women involved in wars
Very well done. I really realy enjoyed this. It was a powerful experience. Three floors, each with a different genre.
Interesting take on Vietnamese Women. The museum gives a very different take on the position of women in Vietnamese society. Well worth a look irrespective of your gender.
Facinating. This museum provides a great insight into the life of women in Vietnam, covering the whole period of modern history
So Good. I particularly liked the fashion and art section and the top of the building. The war section also was fascinating indicating the significant role women played in the war.

Interesting. You need a couple of hours to see everything. Interesting bits about birth and marriage, costumes, religions, war mothers, a beautiful photographic exhibition of women's faces, some propaganda posters which are lovely and interesting. The day I visited there was a ' baby expo' in the forecourt. That's was fun too.

Great presentation of social history. Great exhibition depicting modern day life of women as well as traditional life and the brave women who fought for their country. Really nice an air conditioned too, so a good place to go in the middle of the day
Women museum. I would highly recommend getting the recording headset, as usual it will give you where more depth on the displays

Fascinating peak into the role of women. Really found this an interesting place. So many ethnic tribes were represented. It described the role of women from early times up to the wars with France and America. Such brave women. We had a guide from Hanoikids explain much of the artifacts which was helpful
Interesting. The museum is big with several exhibitions that give an insight on the women life and the different characteristics of the different tribes.

Interesting and somewhat informative. We spent two hours here and that was a bit too long. Lots of displays of women in history. Descriptions were good but I feel that many things were better explained in Vietnamese. I was bit disappointed given the many positive reviews it received.
DOn't miss this. I loved this Museum that was dedicated to highlighting the strength, resistance and beauty of the amazing women of Vietnam.
very interesting. A great place to visit to view the women's support during Vietnam War and how they supported the country

Awesome and informative!. Loved this place! It was so informative and some of the exhibitions were stunning, especially the traditional clothing/costumes.The only annoying part was the ticket booth being completely separate to the museum building, so we were told to walk back outside and to the street to purchase tickets rather than at the museum itself which made no sense. And there were two separate parking staff out the front who argued amongst themselves where we should park, a minor inconvenience really.
So many ethnic groups make up Northern Vietnam. A very worthwhile visit as it has covers so much of the complex history of Vietnam. Each ethnic group has its own colourful dress and cultural rules.
Really interesting. This was a great place to visit. Very interesting to learn about culture, fashion and the working life of Vietnamese Women. Highly recommend it.

An interesting museum on the role of women in Vietnam. Spent as easy couple of hours wandering around this museum. It was a fabulous insight into Vietnamese women past and present. Apart from their role in the various wars, it was really interesting to learn about the different ethnic groups and how they celebrate marriage. We were also lucky enough to visit whilst the museum had an exhibition of photographs of old aged women. The photos were just fantastic at capturing the personalities and lives of these women so well.

Insightful and very moving. Great to see Vietnam from a woman's perspective! The museum shows the historical and cultural side of Vietnam, focussing on the key areas of family, history and fashion. Allow plenty of time, as there is a lot to see. On the top floor there was an art exhibition with some contemporary pieces that challenged your thinking. I did the audio tour, and learned things I would have missed on my own.

Insights into a diverse heritage. This museum is a little gem I discovered on my previous trip to Hanoi. I loved learning about the diverse cultural groups and age old traditions as well as learning more about recent history and hearing the stories of these brave women. Well worth a visit.

Done . We went there because is one of the recommended things to do in Hanoi. Well I wouldn't recommend it. If you are bored or hot from strolling around absolutely otherwise the real Hanoi is much more Interesting

Wonderful. Beautifully curated, highly insightful and educational. Loved every minute!Tickets were super affordable. Be prepared for a lot of walking and being on your feet. Was a little hot that day and being inside with minimal a.c. was a little rough.Not a super modern or interactive exhibit, but still awesome.

Really interesting. We spent a morning here. It closes at 12.00 till about 1.30 for lunch. It was actually really interesting. There were displays on weddings, Motherhood, costumes, religion, daily life and women's role in the war effort and some modern art. It was easy to follow the arrows on the floor and the English signs about the displays were clear and informative. The entry price was very low too.

Modern, air conditioned and a testament to the strength of Vietnamese Women. We had already been to 2 museums, and were a little hot and tired. This museum was an incredible testament to the strength of Vietnamese women through the ages. I loved the fashion, the role many women played during the various wars, the way of life, and the exquisite artefacts and photos. Well worth your time.
Good explanation, must see. Beautiful photographers to start the exposition. Explanations in English, French and Vietnamese. Must visit in Hanoi!

Total surprise for two men visiting Hanoi. I know there are lots of positive reviews of this but it really is good. It gives you an insight into the culture through vietnams women. On reflection it's an excellent way to understand a society (and saying this as a man)
friendly. fantastic warm prople no problems all including the guys run the bats cafes night markets all helpfull 20000000000000000000000000%
Interesting! . The museum is well done and everything is translated in english. We spend here almost 2 hours and enjoyed it very much.

Very interesting . We thoroughly enjoyed our visit here. You get a very interesting idea of the history of the life of Vietnamese women. You learn about marriage, family life, the war and fashion. Fascinating stories and artefacts. This was actually one of my favourite things we did in Hanoi. Wonderful shop inside also where I got some beautiful and inexpensive artwork. We went on an incredibly hot morning so was great to be able to escape the heat in the air conditioning. Would highly recommend.

Must visit - surprisingly interesting. . You can definitely spend a good couple of hours here. The entrance fee is cheap at 30k VND and I would definitely recommend spending another 30k VND to get the audio guide too which tells you the fascinating stories related to each area. I particularly enjoyed the insight into the roles played by the Vietnamese woman during the war with America. A must visit in Hanoi. It's a short walk to Hoan Kiem lake after the museum or the Trang Tien Plaza - both literally around the corner.
Fantastic women's museum . If you have a few hours to spare and interested in the role women have played in the history of Vietnam then it is well worth a visit. Really found it very interesting.

Interesting and worth seeing. Shows what role the women has played in the story of Vietnam, can recommend to see the Prison before this one.This museum shows all from marriage, family, religion over fashion and daily life. Really worth seeing.There's a lot of reading so take this one in the beginning of the day.

One the most interesting museum I have ever seen. Certainly a museum that should be exemple for other countries. Very interesting, you can discover Vietnamese culture by watching the woman's statue in Vietnam, how they are making there clothes, the all kind of dress the different ethnicities are making. I was really surprised by the quality of the museum and what I learned about Vietnamese culture there. Very interesting, I highly recommend this place, much more interesting than hochiming museum

Include in your itinerary.. Make sure you swing by here on your travels.Very nicely presented exhibits. Plenty to see.Allow about at least 30-40 minutes to look around.The museum shop has some quite cool items relevant to the museum.A cafe in the front 'car park' sells the "weasel coffee" but they don't always have it available.
Could be improved. We visited the Vietnamese Women's museum on Sept. 2016 and thought it could still be improved if more details can be added in the displays. Information supplied was too little.

A lovely little museum. One of our favourites in Vietnam, the women's museum is excellent. Learn about the life of the street vendors in Hanoi, the marriage rites and rituals, the traditional clothing and, my personal favourite as a midwife, child birth and child rearing practices. It's well laid out, easy to find and the perfect size to stay engaged with all the displays. Worthwhile.

Very interesting museum, worth anvist. If you are looking for a museum that is less crowded than some of the bigger spots in Hanoi, this is the place. The most interesting part was the overview of women in Vietnamese history.Great gift shop as well

Empowering. A definite must see if you are into history! I found the Vietnamese Women's Museum to be super empowering (from a women's point of view)! Coming from Western society, we tend to forget that Vietnam also had a brutal past regarding oppression, war etc. There is a entire floor dedicated to the Vietnamese side of the American-Vietnam war... And the role the women played during that time!

Interesting perspective on women in Vietnam. This museum is near the South end of Hoan Kiem lake in Hanoi. Building is a bit rundown and tired, but the exhibits are good, each floor is devoted to a different view of women - family, religion, marriage, famous women, fashion. Well set out, good info in Vietnamese, English and French. Worth a look.

Would recommend. Enjoyed the museum alot.costs just a few vnd. Fours floors and each covers a different aspect from the different tribes to the north to clothing and dressage and roles played in the wars to the spiritual aspect
Very Interesting. A good selection of exhibits - I particularly enjoyed the section on Vietnam woman in war. Discounted tickets when you visit the prison first!
Special. Good location, good friendly staff and good food at this restaurant ! They put vegetable on the beef food and It was not the best but not bad.
great. best thing to see in Hanoi-l had no idea about the historical role of the women--the clothing etc also excellent

First class museum & fascinating content. Wonderful to learn about the role of women in Vietnam over the years. Outstandingly curated displays full of detailed explanations, objects, and labels. Great variety of exhibits that all showcase the strength, tenacity, and intelligence of the women in Vietnam in both rural and city areas as well during war and peace times. Even on a good weather day, I was happy to have visited this museum.

video worthwhile. The best part of this museum was watching the video on the local women who sell on the streets . This is located in an alcove maybe 2nd floor. It gave me a much better understanding of the lives of the women from the country areas highlight of the museum. The remainder of the museum was interesting but a lot was historical history or present customs of different ethnic groups in Vietnam. The role of women in the Vietnam/American war was enlightening they had a major role to play.

Best Museum in Hanoi. While taking in Hanoi I was disappointed to learn that most museums had limited information available in English. This was not the case for the women's museum which had lots of interesting information in english along with video documentaries and art displays. If you'd like to learn more about Vietnam and the role women play this is a must visit.
Very interesting. Heard about this from other tourists who had been. I found it very interesting and well worth a visit.

Don't miss this museum. This is a large museum which covers women's culture in Vietnam, and includes many different tribes in Vietnam, as well as going up to the participation of women on the American war.

Amazing insights into the lives of Vietnamese women. This excellent museum takes a social history approach that illuminates the lives of Vietnamese women and families. Curation is of a very high standard and the explanatory notes (in Vietnamese, English and French) are very helpful. There's a fascinating section on women's in the resistance and reunification movements. And don't miss the gift shop, which stocks a range of crafts, jewellery, books and delightful postcards of propaganda posters. A must see if you want understand Vietnam and all its ethnic variety.

Women Power. This museum says a lot about Vietnamese women who fought the war, the family lifestyle, marriages, cultures and how women survived during the hard times. There are 3 - 4 floors for visitation and it great to spend some time here to witness the women power of Vietnam and their contribution to their country which is so unique.
Vietnamese Women"s Museum. A great place to visit, it certainly shows the resilience of the women in this country. They certainly have had a tough life

Worth a visit. Can easily spend about 1.5 hrs here. Top level is an art gallery. Entrance fee is 30 000 dong and the ticketing office is near the gate. Once you enter the museum, you can rent the audio guide at the counter for another 30 000 dong. Do rent one so that it will be easier to understand the exhibits as the information board will not contain all information. There is a locker where you can keep your belongings for free. I walked from the top level down to each exhibition level. Very informative gallery which detailed the contributions of the vietnamese women from past to present on culture and history. The strength and resilience of vietnamese ladies shown during the war time can only be witnessed by us now in this museum. You may want to spend more time at the exhibition hall level which showcases the women who fought in the war. There is also a small gallery on the left of the exhibition hall door on each level. Do take the time to sit down and watch the videos in these galleries, especially the film on life of the women street vendors.
Great for understanding. This was a highlight of our trip. It was well laid out, informative and showed the strength of the Vietnamese women through the centuries.

Interesting and well worth the time. The displays at the Vietnamese Women's Museum are well documented in both English and French and there is plenty of useful information in this relatively small museum. From displays on the making and hand dyeing of fabric to the various roles of women in the war effort, there us something for everyone here and the museum is a great tribute to the women of Vietnam. Spend a rainy afternoon here.

I was amazed!. Visiting this museum was really interesting and enlightening. Good to see history from the women’s perspective. The exhibition was very easy so follow and I felt that I learned a lot and got insight in Vietnamese history and culture in a variety of aspects.
Truly worth a visit!

Must see!. Went to this museum after finding it as a suggested activity on the TA forums and so glad we did. So much to learn about customs and rituals from the many ethnic groups living in Vietnam. I found the section on the contribution of women in the war effort fascinating. Some fantastic photographs too (all child friendly). This would have to be my favourite museum so far. Do yourself a favour and check it out.
Very different and enjoyable. Well worth a visit, really interesting to learn about the different cultures across vietnam. Wedding costumes were a highlight.

Worth it. I was going to walk there from the Temple of Literature & National University but it was too hot and humid for that nonsense so I caught a taxi instead. The taxi fare was 34,000 VND including a 1,000 VND tip.My host recommended I visit this museum and I wasn't sure what to expect. To be honest I thought ‘oh no, not another museum’ and ‘what's so great about a women's museum anyway’? Lo and behold I was there for 2.5 hours and could have stayed longer but I had to get to work. Entry was 30,000 VND.It is an interesting display of a women's integral role in the family throughout history and their fashion based on their traditional culture, marriage customs and child birth. All the exhibits have good Vietnamese, English and French translations so there’s no need for a guide or the headsets. It's easy to navigate. I didn't get to see fashion floor because it was closed for maintenance. The museum is covered so it's great on a rainy day but the day I went the air conditioning wasn't working so they were relying on fans and it was still hot inside.Afterwards you may be in need of a tea or coffee and cake. Well across the road slightly to the left is a Madame Huong bakery that do yummy pastries and coffee. The service there is a little gruff but it’s a good place to take a load off and people watch for a bit. The price is probably expensive by local standards it cost 150,000 VND for 2 coffees and 2 cakes. It's probably best to get your pastries and order your coffee at the counter then sit down as I waited a very long time to be served and they only bring a drinks menu so you have to go and choose your cake anyway.I visited 8 September.

Needs a couple hours. We came here last minute and only had an hour. Should have made time to do it before with more time available. And also would do the audio tour. Some of the exhibits don't have a lot of explanations. Worth going.
Mother means everything. Mother seems more suitable than woman here.It was impressive to see how Vietnamese mothers have been through all the hardships and hassles.
Fascinating. Wonderful to see the hard work and dedication displayed at this museum . Our guide suggested it, we didn't know if it, well worth the visit
You have to go!. This is really good! We where not sure at first, but an old couple recommended us this museum so we went and it was really good!

Interesting. This museum provides an interesting history of women from typical jobs/roles to dress to wedding traditions. There are nice displays and a lot of great reading. The most touching to me was a video display of some of the women who sell in the markets and their lives and sacrifices and why they are separated from their families to do this. It was about $2 to enter and they have an audio guide for purchase.

A great rainy day activity!. We stumbled here quite by accident, but enjoyed the museum very much. Not something I might've looked for intentionally, but a nice find. It's very large and has some nice exhibits, but overall not wildly exciting. It was nice for free, though.
amazing. i loved this place and i highly recomment it ! a cultural tour to the Vietnamese tribe in two hours!

A rare worth visiting museum in Hanoi. So many of our Vietnamese Friends recommended this place, we've been there, through all 5 floors, it was very well set and have interesting exhibitions.
our kid loved the colors so much they didn't want to leave.

Enjoyable. I enjoyed my time at this museum, the hidden smiles photos in the foyer are beautiful. The section on women in war was truly fascinating, it's just a shame it was hidden on the higher floors, to me it was the highlight!

Not the best. After reading the reviews I expected this place to be awesome. I actually found it quite difficult to navigate and I wasn't sure if the message that it was trying to give.
It's very informative and there are lots of historical women's clothes that are on show.

Nice to see but not a must. . We aren't really the museum type , but you need a token visit to one and we figured given the strength of the Vietnamese woman this would be a good one. It's a great concept , quite poorly laid out though. All in all not bad but not Amazing. Eg in the lobby there is a collection of some of rehnahn's hidden smile photos ... And it's such a great story when you read up about But there wasn't any info on it on offer. Regardless , Vietnamese woman remain incredible ! An inspiration to us all
Knowing more about the Vietnamese culture . Very good museum in Hanoi. You can know more about their traditional customs (wedding, clothing style, etc.). I definitely recommend it !

A good museum to explore the life of women and traditions. This is a small museum but there plenty of costumes and traditions explained (english and french) and it is cool to visit. This is interesting and they talk about weddings, costumes, life, their places in the society.If it is raining outside it's a good option, not the best but if this kind of exhibition is for you go for it.Just one point one level was close for renovation and they don't tell us when we buy tickets ... too bad.Price in sept 2016 was 30 000 VND / person.

Worth a visit!. Great museum which gives interesting insight into the lives of ordinary women and families if Vietnam. Located 5 mins walk from the old prison so worth combining the two into a morning / afternoon of sightseeing!

Interesting and well documented compared to other SE Asian museums. I have been to this museum a few times over the years and the exhibits are well presented and generally well documented. I mainly go to see the textiles in the Costume section and I feel this exhibit could do with further informed documentation. The photos around the walls are very well documented but the actual different ethnic costumes on the models are all presented under the title of 'costume' with no reference to the particular ethnic group the costume comes from. This would not involve much extra effort as I'm sure the knowledge is locally available and for people like me it would add greatly to the learning experience. The full impact of the textile collection would be enhanced by these extra details.There is a very professional exhibition regarding the Mother Goddess on another floor which has a much more informed approach as does the exhibition regarding women's role in the defence of Vietnam and overall it's an interesting and informative place.Staff are mainly invisible and don't look at all interested in their jobs. I have met many young graduates on my trips to Vietnam who would make more of a contribution if they had the chance to work at such a place.

Worth a Visit. It's an ethnographic museum paying tribute to the different ethnicities of Vietnam. So you will find a lot of clothes, jewels and the tools women use for their everyday tasks in the fields or in the village.As for modern, urban Vietnam, unfortunately the section dedicated to the role of women in the making of the country was closed for maintenance.

Good museum with interesting facts. I have been here a few times and enjoy the little short films and displays. Do not expect a phenomenal day .. it will take 2 hours or so to go through. IT is a nice place if you have the time. The stories and traditions of the women are fascinating to some.

Informative and enjoyable. The focus is only on women, however it was extremely informative. I learnt about their lives and also about he different ethnic groups. Did not do an audio tour and don't think it's really necessary as everything is clearly labelled in english

Learned more here than all other museums combined. GET the audio guide, and then follow along. It's about women, but even more about the ethnography of some of the 24 ethnic groups in Vietnam, and the diversity of social conventions. Very powerful stories from women in the informal sector, and some very sobering participatory exhibits where you try to grind and carry things that are daily work for Vietnamese women, and laughably difficult for us to manage for even a few turns...
Very informative. Fantastic museum - very informative and a worthwile way to spend an afternoon to avoid peak sun or rain. Lots of variation both historical and cultural

One of a kind!. This musuem is unlike any other I've ever visited. The celebration of women was very inspiring to me, and I am still thinking about our visit days later. It was so insightful to learn more about women's role in vietnamese society, as well as their role in the countries history particularly to do with the war.I found the film about street sellers very sad, but important. I felt like this visit changed the way I felt about many aspects of my experience in vietnam and made me less ignorant which I'm very thankful for. An important attraction.
Very informative Museum. We really enjoy our visit to this attraction. We didn't have as much time here as we would have liked here but still well worth the visit.

Is wonderful modern museum in the heart of Hanoi. A very modern, air-conditioned museum in central Hanoi. The museum explores women's role in Vietnamese society - their work, cultural history and modern stories of the street vendors. Galleries include collections on wedding rituals from different cultures in Vietnam, birth practices, fashions and education. A really wonderful museum.

One I didn't expect. I had never previously considered the idea of a museum totally dedicated to women's history & this one proved to be quite an eye opener. The museum has displays & notes in Vietnamese, French & English which take you through the traditional customs & beliefs from a Vietnamese woman's perspective. Covering the marriage traditions through child birth & old age. There are a number of video interviews that give insight into the notion that there is no gender inequality in this country. The displays depicting the roles of women during the long periods of war & civil unrest can be a little confronting but understanding some of their history goes a long way to understanding the people.

Brilliant. This is a nice museum, interesting and informative. The layout flows very well and the information is clear and easy to follow. Clearly explained in English and French as well as Vietnamese. It shows the role of women at home, as emplyees and in Vietnam's history and religion

Great activity for a rainy day. Nicely curated museum with many interesting artifacts of traditional living, history and textile. Beautiful section with Vietnamese women clothing and dresses.A nice souvenir shop on the ground floor where I bought several silk scarves as a souvenir for my girlfriends.Additional bonus: there is a great bakery/ patisserie just on the other side of the street from the museum where you can grab lunch or afternoon snacks and coffee (do not miss it).Note: if you go to the Hao Lao Prison Museum first, you'll find there rebate coupons to visit the Women's Museum. Also make sure to request children/student rebates if you come with your children. We found that we had to always request those, otherwise we were all given adult tickets.

One of the best!. This is a fantastic experience. A museum with well written English, French and VIetnamese explanations of the exhibits. In fact these are so good that although the audio guide is inexpensive, it is not at all necessary. There are wonderful displays of ethnic clothing, a fascinating section on marriage ceremonies in different times and different ethnic groups, gorgeous photos of the various Vietnamese ethnic groups that I would love to own, interesting potted histories of women who have served their country in both the war with French colononial power and the "Vietnam" or "American" war (depending on your viewpoint). All in all well worth a couple of hours. A must do.

So interesting!. Start from the top floor and work your way down. A fantastic insight into the women of Vietnam, including their role in warfare, and some beautiful exhibits that capture the culture. Small enough to enjoy without being overwhelmed.

Fascinating museum. Well worth the visit, nice cool escape from the heat with such interesting rooms and facts about modern city women and women of the 50+ tribes on Vietnam. Really makes you rethink about the women selling on the streets of Hanoi... Some stay in $0.35 accomodations at night to make the couple of dollars a day. So next time a lady tries to sell you some fruit or bread, think twice, buy and don't haggle. Also full of info about strong women of the war, country side , family life and fashion

Good place to visit. In every culture, women may treated differently. The way they live, their status in family or society may different in every places. For me, it's more like reflection. I have a feeling that all women in this world have to appreciated properly. Just imagine when your mom already passed away and you see pictures of her struggling to earn some money just to make you live better. Even I almost cry everytime I saw pictures of women with their activities in this museum. But it's not only gallery to show you pictures, this museum also can give you a perspective about how Vietnamese people treat a women.

Kudos to women. It's an eye opener on women power on how many vietnamese women fought for the freedom of their country. The museum displays from child birth equipments used to marriage costumes. Audio tour is available as well.
very interesting. Very informative and revealing about daily life in Vietnam. We had preconceived thoughts about street sellers and after the museum we felt for the women selling fruit etc.

Worth a Visit. Visited this for an hour after a long day sightseeing. Lots of interesting information, worth going up the stairs to the top floor for the fashions through the ages and the different ethnic groups within Vietnam. Also good to see the roles of woman during the wars.

strong women. This museum made us realise how strong and courageous Vietnamese women are.There were interesting displays of all the various tribal women - their costume, daily life and standing in their society. Enjoyed this museum more than the Museum of Ethnology.

Recommend you visit. I really learned a lot about the historical roles of Vietnamese women and their contributions to society. I particularly liked learning about how women played such a critical role during the different wars. There are some videos that interview contemporary woman doing different jobs in various regions of Vietnam . It was very interesting to hear their stories. Many Vietnamese woman have a tough life even today .

Best museum I have ever been to . This was a highlight of our trip to Hanoi. It is very well designed, with a beautiful flow to the museum, lots of information available, written and pictorial. The stories were moving and inspiring and the audio guide also very well made. Highly recommended to spend a few hours here !

Interesting Museum - spend 1-2 hrs on a rainy dy. An interesting way to spend 1-2 hours in Hanoi, particularly on a wet afternoon. A number of exhibits in different themes. The fashion of the various ethnic groups that make up Viet Nam was fascinating. 30,000 dong entry (less than $2USD). Viet, English and French exhibit descriptions. Audio headsets as well.

So interesting!. Really well worth visiting. Not a far walk from the old quater. Such good value at 30,000 vnd, or 15000 with a student card plus 30,000 for the audio tour which i would defintely recommend! We spent nearly 3hours there when it rained.
Very interesting. Shows the history of the females in Vietnam throughout the time and well worth a look it is very interesting seeing history from a female perspective.

More than a history of just women in Vietnam, this place showcases the various Vietnamese ethnic cultures too. The museum is a good display of the place Vietnamese women have in their various ethnic groups and throughout history. It showcases how different areas of Vietnam have vastly different approaches to the role of women, and is a must-see if you are interested in understanding how the modern Vietnamese woman has found her standing in society.

Excellent and Informative. To be quite honest, I didn't really know what to expect, but what I got was great!The museum is set out over 3 floors I think with displays and info (in English, French and Vietnamese) on fashion, women's lives in Vietnam and the part they played in the wars...This was the highlight for me. It was very interesting and enlightening to read about all the key ladies and what they achieved and also very sad to read that most were executed. The floor on the war also includes poster propaganda examples and lots of bits and bobs to have a look at. There are audio guides if you like too.It costs 30,000 dong to get in here and is a bargain in my eyes.
Brilliant and moving. The audio guide is absolutely worthwhile and the stories moving. An excellent lens to bring to Vietnam's culture and history.
Amazing history story. Floor after floor of the history of Vietnamese women told in a most interesting way from custom to involvement in ALL wars in Vietnam. Courageous and loyal peoples.

A great museum. Rightly regarded as one of the best museums in Hanoi, this modern, well designed place is a great chance to catch up on Vietnamese women's history. It's not a huge place, it probably takes about an hour and a half to investigate it. It's a great bit of culture quite close to the lake and it's well worth a visit.

Great place for education. It different museum from othors because Vietnamese Woman's role still not that recognised :( You will love it with beautiful decor and stories along about Women revolutionary just not in war but nowaday!
Excellent museum . We all (2 adults, 2 kids) enjoyed this excellent museum. The film about the street vendors was a real eye-opener.

History of women in the making. A fantastic museum of history through the eyes of women. Their roles in war and in family. Cool in most parts, good toilets, nice gift shop. Most unique as most countries don't dedicate so much to women.

Day trip on acclimatisation day to Vietnam. Easily found from map. Bit of a walk from old town but could have taken a Cyclo. Museum all air conditioned and displays were quite interesting even for a man. Really nice to see and learn about the different peoples of Vietnam before heading north to meet them for real. The shop was also well stocked and not overly pricey according to our thrifty tastes.

It's okay. When we decided to go to this museum we were thinking that it would be about woman emancipation. Unfortunately there wasn't much about that. Only the 3rd floor was about woman in the vietnamese war. We liked that part the most and the rest was so so. It was about marriage and work the woman do. Maybe we just had the wrong expectations but it is not something I would higly recommend to do when in Hanoi.
Fascinating . This is an excellent museum and covers lots of Vietnamese history, culture and modern life. Don't be put off by the focus on women as it is really informative and interesting.
Big!. This is a very large museum spanning several floors. Plan on a few hours here and take advantage of the history in this museum.

Gave me more appreciation for the hard working women of Vietnam. Such a cool afternoon spent at the women's museum. It explores so many different aspects of the women's lives from marriage to work, revolutionary roles to fashion, etc. The artifacts and exhibits are really interesting. I highly recommend it for anyone looking to understand the women's important role in Vietnamese culture and society.

Vietnamese women amazing. Vietnamese women are inspirational and hardworking. Museum depicted the women beautifully. Very family oriented. Loved all the exhibits. Although small, definately worth a visit.
Very interesting . Rained when I was Hanoi so visted her for 2 hours and it was well laid out and informative. Easy to get to and not expensive to get in.

Really interesting . My girlfriend and I really enjoyed this. It was a fascinating insight into the role of Vietnamese women in society through the years. It touched on all aspects of life from the traditional tribal culture right through to the role of the Northern Vietnamese women through the French and American wars. We particularly liked the displays of Vietnamese clothes through the ages. Really good value for money.
Very interesting. Well worth a visit to learn more about the American war and women's role; and women's role in current Vietnamese society.

Vietnamese women are impressive.. We visited the women's museum on a rainy day when looking for some indoor activities.
It's quite a cool museum, well organised into different sections over 3 floors.
My favourite sections were the Street Vendors and Women of War. The Costumes were cool too.
Interesting. Modest size but very interesting. The fact it exists and the Vietnamese seem proud of it tells a story too

Understand the role of Vietnamese women, from the past to now. the content in the museum is divided into 3 themes: women in history, women in family and women fashion. It's easy to take a look at these themes because each floor follows one theme. what you receive when u go inside the museum? well, you can see by yourselves the hard life of Vietnamese women who ride bikes through the crowded streets to sell something, who sacrifice to take care of the family and so on. However, the objects on display mostly belonged to the past, so they may not truly reflect the modern life of Vietnamese people these days. The solution is to ask your tour guide to tell you about the changes in people's lifestyle and customs. You would be in awe if you happen to know the change. If you don't have a tour guide with you, rent a headphone available at the museum.There will be automatic explanations of the objects on display so you can understand the meaning and stories behind these objects. The ticket price is reasonable and worth your money. Overall, highly recommended. Take a visit to the museum to see the whole picture!

Brilliant. An excellent museum with exhibits clearly explained in English and French as well as Vietnamese. Very informative and interesting. Covers war years well and the ethnographic aspects and traditional regional marriage customs are very well outlined with good audio visuals. Audio guides available. A credit and great tribute to the very hard working women in this country. Well worth the small entry fee.

Educational museum. Worth a visit to see different ethnic groups and the influence of women in the last century or so. Some of the 'heroes' we found out from our guide as not been real - but communists propaganda - so that was an eye opener. Clothing and their important role in several wars were the highlights. A better air con would of been nice.

Excellent museum . We found this museum very interesting and informative. The layout flows very well and the information is clear and easy to follow. It shows the role of women in the home, as employees and in Vietnam's history and religion. I particularly liked the video about street vendors and their lives. Definitely worth a visit for an hour or two.

Very Interesting!. Awesome!It is worth a walk through if you have some spare time in Hanoi. It is very cheap, only $2-3US or 30,000dong. There were separate levels for marriage, war, and fashion. I admit that I got a little bored walking around the marriage and fashion levels, but they were worth a quick look. However, the war level was amazing. It was awesome to see how many female war hero there were and what they went through. A fascinating history for females. I enjoyed seeing what part women played in Vietnamese history and I recommend you taking an hour or 2 to visit here, whether it is raining or just extremely hot!Also, there is a elevator for people can't walk very far, or up many stairs.

Wonderful!. What a wonderful museum, it was packed with information, pictures, artefacts, traditional clothes, etc. You can really see the effort that has gone into honouring the women of the nation in this fantastically educational and interesting museum. Definitely worth visiting for a few hours to see it all. If you like museums, this one will be right up your street!
Worth a visit. Interesting to see the role of women in Vietnam and some of the traditions. Lots of great costumes and enjoyed the videos

Interesting and informative. Museum is beautiful and well-maintained.. Went to this museum on a rainy weekday afternoon and found it very interesting. There were several floors to explore, all about the women of Vietnam.

Beautiful, informative, and fascinating!. We went here on the recommendation of our street food tour guide and were so happy we went! The museum presents a multifaceted view into women's effect on and role in the history of Vietnam as well as contemporary societal structures (marriage, birth, the economy, etc.). Great narratives and historical relics abound. I was particularly interested in the section on the war between the U.S. and Vietnam as well as the documentary on women street merchants. Not going to lie, even the gift shop was great!
Museums in the afternoon . We really enjoyed our visit to the museum. It's packed full of interesting and we'll curated history. Highly recommended. -TBG

Loved this museum. Make sure to watch films on street vendors, weddings and read bios of women who fought in the wars.. Wonderful museum focused on contributions to Vietnam made by women in wartime, family life, medicine, fashion and other areas. Make sure to watch film on street vendors and the sacrifices they make to feed and educate their children.

Fascinating . Spent a great 2 hours here. The building is modern and cool and has 3 very different but interesting floors focusing on many aspects of vietnamese life. Entrance fee is very reasonable and this is definitely worth a visit to gain an insight into the life of women in vietnam.

Inspiring. What a culture of strength and creativity and honour for women. Was great to see traditional outfits, hear about customs and learn about historical influences women have had. Also great to see how women are progressing the nation today. Super for only 30000vnd!

Thoughtful history of women's role in building Vietnam. An excellent museum that tells the story of women in Vietnam's history including the American and French wars. Very detailed. Worth an hour or more of anyone's time I reckon...
Woman's museum . This wAs a beautiful tribute to woman in Vietnam. It was so informative and very interesting. They have done an excellent job at honouring woman from this nation.

Our favourite museum in Hanoi. We enjoyed this museum - worth a visit and the best 2 and half hours we spent in a museum. It is well labelled in English, so you really get a chance to learn about Vietnamese culture and the way different ethnic groups organise their social groups.

Worth a visit. This is a lovely museum. It is modern and beautifully laid out giving lots of information about women in Vietnamese history. Sections on women in the American War, rural life and fashion. Information given in English.It is open all day which is a bonus ! Give yourself 2/3 hours.

Worthy of a visit. While the museum obviously exaggerated the pro-woman aspects of Vietnam, it was worth the visit. As with all the propaganda in Vietnam, there not much that can be believed in this hotel about history, the actual displays were impressive. The best part was the fashions of Vietnam. Anyone into fashion should stop and take a look.
Nice Experience. Nice to know there is a museum dedicated to women!! a very modern look and feel of the place overall!
Interesting insight into Vietnam. A very well presented museum with lots to learn about Vietnamese history, not just the women in it. Easily spent 2-3 hours here.

Educational facts about women in the vietnam war!. It costs 30.000 dvn to enter, and another 30.000 to use the audio-guide, which I would recommend in order to get the best experience of the museum. The start had a lot of interesting facts about marriage and social life in different tribes and famillies in vietnam, but the part about women contributions during the war had the most impact on me! It was interesting and educational to view the war through these eyes. I can't believe the horrific struggle vietnamese people have been through. The guide was a little long though (2 hours and 30 minutes) so we skipped the audioguide for the last part because we got hungry.

Not to be missed. If you go to Hao Lo Orison before coming here be sure to pick up a 50% off voucher with free audio guide. The tour can take up to 2.5 hours if you use the audio guide but you can easily see it in less than an hour and a half ... The exhibits are labelled well in English. The clothing exhibition was interesting but we especially liked the section on female freedom fighters and the section on women and family. Some maps might have helped in order to see where the various ethic tribes originated etc. The Mother Goddess exhibition might have been given better context ... It required a fair bit of reading up and googling after our visit in order to clarify a number of the points.

Definitely go! . This museum provides a glimpse into the diverse roles women have played throughout history in Vietnam. It displays artefacts from the various ethnicities residing within Vietnam, and has exhibits on marriage, family life, mother goddesses, war, and more. It was exciting to see the role women played in the war, and how many of them were recognized heroines. It only takes between 1-3 hours of your day (depending on how much you read), and it will make you appreciate the culture, the street vendors, the fashion, and Vietnam so much more.
Very Interesting!. I enjoyed this museum and it is quite educational. My son really liked learning about the women's participation in the war.

Best attraction in Hanoi!. Great review of Vietnam history through the womens eyes. From 3 months husband hunting to war heroes to fashion fads such as black lacquered teeth this museum has it all. Take the audio tour. Good way to while away 2 hours.
Unique . Very interesting exhibit about women in Vietnam, their lives, roles and contributions. Clear explanations. Well worth a visit.

Interesting and enjoyable. Lots of interesting historical information. 30K vnd per adult kids free. Info on the participation of women in WW2 and the process of unification. The medals women got for military efforts and family contributions for supporting the reunification.

A must see attraction. This is an excellent museum,cataloging the diverse roles of women in Vietnam. I went with a local guide so didn't use the audio sets. It was so interesting I would go again and really soak it in using the head sets. The marriage and birth section were particularly fascinating for me and sparked an interesting discussion on this subject with the guide on how these customs relate to the modern Vietnamese. It is worth going for the visual appeal alone.
It was ok. I popped in here as I was in the area. It was ok. The costume displays were cool. Not really my cup of tea though

Very well set out. This is an unusual and well set out museum dedicated to women and their contribution to Vietnamese society. It made me think again about women through history generally and how their story is not often not told. The audio commentaries were in clear segments so you could choose which to listen to. Free lockers mean you can dump off your bag while wandering about. Allow sufficient time to do justice to this jewel of a museum.

Plenty here I never knew to ask about. This museum has at least 4 floors, including one on the family and another on women in combat and espionage, as well as videos playing interviews of some Vietnamese street vendors explaining how they support their families.

Well worth a visit. As a visitor and spending time in rural areas in Vietnam as well, it's really interesting to see the dominant role women play in Vietnamese society. The Women's Museum also demonstrated this. It is very well set out in subject areas, eg weddings, childbirth, clothes, and especially their role in the Vietnam war. You go around at your own pace and there's some really confronting areas, for instance the room with photos of women who'd lost husbands and multiple children in the war. I don't think it matters what your thoughts are on the War, the war section was the most interesting part of the museum for me, closely followed by the first section on marriage customs.

Truly inspiring . This has to be my favorite museum in Hanoi. I learnt a lot about the role of woman in Vietnam and their contribution to this country during the war. It was enriching to read how strong and hard they work to make ends meet. I was inspired by many stories. I think it will be worthwhile getting the audio tour, I didn't do this but I should have. Go and see it! Definitely worth your while.

Very well laid out and fascinating, but museums are just not for me. This was a fascinating museum, however being indoors in a city like Hanoi when the streets are alive with activity just did not feel right.I guess museums are not really my thing. If you are into museums there is a lot to look at and read, so maybe this is for you.
Excellent history and culture lesson. You won't mess with Vietnamese women after this... so many inspiring stories. And great to learn there are still matrilineal cultures live and thriving.

Inspiring and memorable. Loved this museum. A high light and so informational from the traditions of marriage, birth , beliefs and war heroines. Amazing strong female role models from the past war times, so much suffering and so much to admire and respect for the strength of the human Spirit and especially women who can do anything they need to do to survive and flourish.
Could not hold my attention.. Disappointing visit ,found it a little boring and reception was hardly inviting. Not my cup of tea but perhaps someone will find interesting.

An interesting insight into Vietnamese women and domestic life. I wish I had a little more time to spend here. We had already seen and heard a bit about the local culture but the displays and presentations made us realize what a significant part Vietnamese women play in history and development of the country. Allow at least a couple of hours for a look around.
Interesting . Mother and daughter enjoyed this visit more than dad and the boys who simply enjoyed the air conditioning. Would recommend to females on rainy or hot afternoon .

Fantastic Insight Offered.. This has to be one of my favourite museums. What a learning experience. Loved it. Each room told a different story and focused on a different aspect. Highly recommend this place.

Exceeded expectations!. We visited as part of a tour. I wouldn't of put it as a must on my list prior to going but glad we went. Learnt a lot about the women's part of everyday life through the ages which was good but it was especially interesting to see their part in the war. Spent around an hour to easily see everything.

Interesting and unusual free museum. There are several floors exhibiting different aspects of the Vietnamese women's cultures. I found the role of women during the American/Vietnamese War, and the top floor where students currently have a photography display most interesting. I found the clothing floor and the childbirth/family floors to be a little dull, as they did not detail each culture specifically in their brief placards and seemed to state the obvious. It's still definitely worth a visit, maybe allow an hour or 2 of your afternoon to take it all in. There is an option for audio commentary for 30 k Dong, so perhaps this details each culture more.

Get the audio guide. I think there's some real care put into this museum. The audio guide gives great context. My favourite is the touching stories on the history floor. Worth it!PS. The air con is hit and miss in the summer. Dress cool.

"I still remember how good it was after 3 years!". I went there as a second grader and the information, details, clothes were amazing! I really recommend it to children. i am visiting it again this Monday to my Japanese teacher and a friend. They are going to enjoy it so much! I am glad that there is such a museum there in Vietnam.

a very educational museum to visit. lovely and creative settings.. we went with our 1 year old daughter and even she can enjoy every bit of it.the building is well located and really nice inside out.They host events too.

Worthwhile to visit. it's very interesting to visit this one that would help you guys understanding more about Vietnamese culture throughout the images of the woman, specially understand how is roll of Vietnamese woman from the past up to now. This museum location is very close to Hanoi Hilton, your discovery Hanoi would saving time by visiting both

I felt proud to be a Vietnamese woman!. As a Vietnamese American woman this museum was breath taking. A different perspective on the history of my people. I was inspired by the fashion. I cried as I read stories of heroes dying for freedom. So much rich history here, I could have spent all day here.

Must visit!. This museum has a lot of information to understand Vietnamese Women's life style as well as them in history. Very impressive how actively they participate in family as well as social activities. It is not a big museum but well presented overall. I would recommend any adults and teenagers who visit Hanoi.
Very Good Museum. Had a great relaxed time wondering through this museum. Great displays, with signage in English also. Definitely worth a visit, on a cooler day as a lack of air conditioning!

Wonderful women and an insight into the cilture. Our daughter recommended this museum and were glad she did. It provided a real insight into vietnamese culture and the role of family men and women. It also covered differ cultures in Vietnam and all in all it was very interesting. There is a audio tour which suggests 2 1/2 hours but all signs have an english version and we took a litte over an hour to gave a look around and could have possibly taken longér if we had the tjme.

beautiful and poignant. A fascinating collection of photographs costumes, videos describing the life of Vietnamese women. A very poignant video relating the lives of female street vendors and the challenges they face.Don't miss it.

interesting insight into role of women in Vietnam. On five floors the role of women in Vietnamese society from the early days through the war tmes tonthe present days is displayed in deatail with interesting videos and a wonderful display of the intricately woven garments worn by the various minorities that make up Vietnam.

Good museum for a couple of hours. My sister and I visited the museum for a few hours after reading earlier trip advisor reviews. As suggested by others the audioguide is well worth the price as it gives some very informative information.We probably spent about 2 hours at the museum and didn't cover all the exhibits.My only complaint is the lack of air conditioning/fans/air flow. In patches it is great but in other parts it is ridiculously hot. Unfortunately that was the reason we left prior to seeing all the exhibits.Well worth the small price of admission and audio player

Really interesting museum . Considering it only costs 30,000 VD to get in this is a very nice museum! Really enjoyed the bit about women in history and the ground floor cartoon exhibition on gender inequality. Definitely worth a visit if you're in Hanoi
nice museum, an oath to the women of Vietnam. nice museum, enough things to see and read. friendly staff and fairly cheap. Nice thing to do if you have some spare time or if it is raining

Tribute to the Contribution of Women to Vietnam. This is a great place to see the contribution women have made to Vietnam. There are great phtographs and artifacts and clothes on display giving an historical overview. The museum is a short walk from the Old Quarter and close to the Hoa Lo Prison.

History through the bravery of Vietnamese women. It was an amazing facility, very informative as it's one of few that provide audio recorded details of the country and the many women participated in its journey to independence.

Beautiful and moving experience. This is a really good museum which exposes you to not just the history of Vietnamese women in their experiences and the changes in fashion over generations, but exposes the current experiences and challenges faced by young Vietnamese women, dealing with cultural pressures and expectations while wanted to succeed, explore the world and most of all simply be happy. I found this a very moving experience.

Cultural history . Fascinating museum. We learned a lot about the history, culture, religion, crafts and ethnic groups of Vietnam. Definitely worth the trip. English audio guides were nice but not required. Central location.

interesting. went there in the beginning of july with my family.Very interesting, with lots to see and beautiful set up. Many details about the different minorities in the northern part of Vietnam, and their different styles of clothing and customs. Nice little museum shop too. Everything is written in english at the different displays.

Interesting and Descriptive. An easy walk to reach the museum in the French Quarter. We went through all four floors but not the top fifth floor with the temporary exhibit. Very detailed explanations in English. discuss women role in society, families, marriage, and in war (female heroes), politics, female leaders. Vietnam apparently pushes gender equality. Had exhibits on female clothing and different ethnic groups. Indeed, some of the customs such as with regard to marriage may be different depending on the ethnic group.You buy the entrance ticket near the street about 30-40 meters from the entrance to the museum.Convenient location in the French Quarter. Just a 5-6 minute walk from the Sofitel Metropole hotel. We were staying in the Old Quarter, and took a very short taxi ride to the museum, and then walked back to the Old Quarter from the museum. Maybe 17-20 minutes max.

An hour wasn't really enough time. The exhibit on marriage customs was my favorite part. The museum took an interesting approach to telling the story of women in Vietnam. The room on birth and children had a lot more than I had time to go through, and I basically had to run through the fashion/traditional clothing exhibition. One part that didn't seem too interesting was the room with 'women in history,' which seemed more like a bunch of Vietnam War references/Communist propaganda than a real narrative about a wide range of historical figures, so we didn't spend much time in that one. There was a nook with audio stories about women in business in Vietnam, and that was significantly better.The gift shop was nice- maybe a little more expensive than most stores in Hanoi for fairly similar goods, but helpful clerks and some nice items. The whole museum was air conditioned and cool, and that was a nice change. Admission was definitely more than I expected, especially since we only had an hour to spend before we had to beat it back to our hotel and catch a shuttle to the airport. If I'd had the time to hang out there longer and get a little more out of the visit, then the price would probably have seemed more worth it. We didn't even consider springing for the extra audio tour, given how much the ticket price cost to begin with, but all the signage was in English, Vietnamese, and French, and it was even pretty clearly translated.

Beautiful memorial and reminder. My partner and I came here after reading about it online. It's a really fantastic celebration of the role women have played and continue to play in shaping Vietnam. The gift shop was excellent too. Highly recommended.

Very interesting museum. We ended up spending three hours in this museum, it was so interesting! We opted to get the audio guide which really enhanced the experience. I gained a much greater understanding of Vietnamese culture and the many varying beliefs and traditions of different ethnic groups within Vietnam. It was also insightful into the role of women nowadays and throughout history.

Great!. Really interesting and comprehensive introduction to women in Vietnam. Good value and I enjoyed it all. I especially enjoyed the info about women in history on level 2. I think that it's worth learning about. On a side note, I think the a/c could be improved - there were loads of units that were not turned on and it limited how much I enjoyed my visit. I was so preoccupied with being too warm that I didn't stay as long as I'd've liked. Would recommend though.

really interesting. Loads of interesting info.. we really enjoyed this museum and learned a lot. It also gave me a better appreciation of the hardship of the street sellers, and how much they go through and sacrifice for the small amount they earn. You'll learn about women in different cultures throughout Vietnam and history, their efforts in war times and more. Very educational and fascinating I (and my male friend) thought. Entry fee is cheap.
impressing. it shows the way women survived in Vietnam and that there are strong women who really help to build up their country.
A museum well worth visiting. This museum is really worth visiting it particularly highlights the customs and history of women in Vietnam and has beautiful displays of wedding and ceremonial dresses.

Worth a stop, and a great gift shop. Three floors of exhibits, with rotating topics. We saw cartoons regarding gender (in)equality, details on marital rites for patrilineal and matrilineal communities, tribal community dress, and women's contribution in the "American War".
An eye opener.. A fitting tribute to the women of Vietnam, who have sacrificed everything for their country and way of life. Indomitable women, to say the least. Well worth a visit.

Excellent museum!. This excellent, modern museum showcases women’s role in Vietnamese society and culture. It’s the memories of the wartime contribution by individual heroic women that are most poignant.

Interesting. Having just been to the North of Vietnam trekking made the museum even more interesting as they showed the rituals of the different tribes. The women who fought in the revolution were also very interesting. Good place to go to understand the history of women in Vietnam.

Interesting insight into Vietnamese history and culture . This museum has a 30,000 dong admission charge, and for another 30,000 dong there is an audio tour. The museum is just a few minutes walk from south end of Hoan Kiem lake. The museum is well laid out with several galleries. One is on women's fashion, another on family life and one on women's contribution during periods of conflict. There are lots of graphics and images as well as artefacts. It's a place where you could take children to escape the heat or rain. I found the displays well put together and learnt a lot.
Great!. My experience here was very educational I would recommend that everyone that comes to Hanoi go and check out this museum it sheds so much light on the way of life women in Vietnam live

Worth a Visit.. I really enjoyed my time exploring the different floors and themes at the Women's Museum. It was quite eye-opening as a westerner, and interesting to learn more about the tradition, culture, and sacrifices made by the Vietnamese Women.

Fantastic experience.. One of the best museums I have ever been to. I spent about two hours but you could spend the whole day there taking it all in. Great insight into Vietnamese culture, history and lifestyle presented in a very informative and entertaining way. Would recommend as a must see in Hanoi.

Very interesting museum. Enjoyed wandering through this museum - the street vendor video was hugely informative. Enjoyed how the museum is structured around different aspects of women's lives. My husband also enjoyed this museum indicating it is of general interest to men and women. The women in war section was very well done -more highlighting women's achievements rather than taking the opportunity to push propaganda/political messages

A must do!. A must do in Hanoi - very interesting and plenty to see over 4/5 floors on a range of topics. Quiet museum but inspiring! Certainly a welcome break from the hussle and bussle outside. Clean toilets and a cafe outside.

Girlpower. I was planning to visit this museum while in Hanoi but was running out of time and thought I would leave it out when my taxi driver asked if I had been and that I must go, conveniently we were close by and he dropped me right out the front.I'm glad he talked me back into taking a look, it was so informative and I had no idea Vietnamese women made such an impact not only as mother, workers, fighters (in the Vietnam war) and gods.It shows everything from family life, child birth, work, clothing, jewellery, customs, video's and many floors of information just about women! Every country needs one of these museums that's for sure.This museum is not just for the 'feminist' - it is for everybody!

Very interesting. We went with a couple of friends my personal experience is that I learned a lot of history of the Vietnamese women. They have been struggling through all the wars and been part of the guerilla fighting along side the men. It's incredible to see how these fantastic female figures. Also you learn a lot about different tribes, their cultures, traditions, what they wear etc.
Facinating. A must see when in Hanoi. Men and women alike enjoy this museum. I learnt a lot about the history of Vietnam and the vital role women played.

Inspirational & Informative. Every now and then, you happen upon a museum who's collection helps you understand the world a little better. The Vietnam Women's Museum is one of those. 4 levels plus an exhibition gallery at the top showcase the role of women in Vietnamese society, from birthing practices to the role of Vietnamese women in The Vietnam War. There were lots of videos including a small docu-series interviewing female street workers about how they ended up selling fruit or flowers or odd knick-knacks. I left the museum viewing my environment differently, and I strongly encourage anyone visiting Hanoi to make a stop here.
Awesome . Great range of displays covering Vietnamese history and impact of women. Really fascinating and well worth a visit. 30,000 VND to enter .
Amazing . Full of beautiful female culture. I learnt a lot it was well curated, air conditioned and not busy. Perfect museum in my opinion.
Nice museum. I had my expectations built up too much. This is a good museum. It's cheap with lots of content but it gets repetitive. Worth a look if you've done everything else.

Vietnamese Women's Museum....catchy title!. A LOT of people recommended this museum as a must see attraction. I was dubious as to how good it would be on the basis that generally the museums here are interesting but not particularly well laid out. This museum was by far the best of the 3 that I have visited. A great deal of thought and research went into the displays and I found it incredibly interesting to see how women have contributed to this country, the home and industry.The museum is well worth a visit and I guarantee you will be pleasantly surprised!

Disappointing. . Basically it's a big building and on each floor there are pictures of women who fought in the war. There are videos playing of traditional weddings type of clothes that have changed during the years etc.... we were done in an hour if you are a history buff this would be good otherwise it was OK but not something I would do again. There is a small fee to pay to enter and don't forget to pick up headphones.

Good for a look into Vietnamese life.. I liked it but my husband wasn't a fan. The first level about marriage and child birth was the best part in my opinion. Really interesting to get a glimpse into the life of Vietnamese women.
Very Interesting. For just a couple of dollars you can visit this great museum. It shows the hard life led by generations of women and their very important role in the various wars. A great insight
Adventures in Hanoi. This was value for money. Enjoyed every floor of history from the war to childbirth, the museum covered it all so well. Inspiring.

Surprisingly enjoyable and informative . I really didn't know what to expect, and I was pleasantly surprised.
Stories of amazingly brave hardworking woman, also stories of sacrifices made by women.
Information presented clearly with exhibits interesting about marriage and life in general for the different ethnic groups.
Can spend as much time as u like but u need at least an hour.
Interesting visit. We had a great visit going through the war history and family history sections of this museum. It was very insightful to Vietnamese history and culture. Well worth a visit for all.

Fascinating. It was interesting to see what life was like for women in Vietnam through different eras. A lot of it is cultural and fun - tribal costumes and wedding rituals - but there's also wealth of historical records around colonization and Vietnam/American war and the role of women. Definitely worth the time and small entrance fee.

A must see. To have a dedicated museum to women was truly special. I learned so much about their culture and history. Women in Vietnam do so much and deserve so much credit for how hard they work and all that they contribute to society.

This will change your thinking. We found this museum to be the most interesting (wth the Museum of Ethnology) place we visited in Hanoi. It covers subjects from marriage and birth, to the day-to-day life of ordinary VIetnamese women selling vegetables and artifacts on the streets of Hanoi. The video interviews of such women made us realise, as we really hadn't before, just how tough life can be for ordinary women and families in Vietnam. The room devoted to the role of women in the military (and in the 'American war', of course) was fascinating and moving. We had no idea that so many women were under arms, or that women attained high ranks in combat roles. This museum wasn't included in the pre-arranged tour we took in Hanoi, but we are very glad we visited it during a free morning. Don't miss it.

Interesting museum . I enjoyed my visit to this museum focusing on women's history in Vietnam. It's sad that we need a dedicated women's museum to actually learn about the powerful role women have played in that country but it is really one of the only ways to learn about women in Vietnam. I'm not a huge history buff in some ways and I learned quite a bit and found the information very accessible. I would recommend this attraction for sure!

A must see when in Hanoi. This museum was here in 1995 when we last visited and is a tribute to the women of Vietnam for very good reason.This museum celebrates the outstanding contribution the women of Vietnam have made to the country over the centuries.There is particular emphasis on their role in the resistance and independence movements.A very moving and awe enapiring experience
Great museum. The museum is very interesting showing how the Vietnamese women through history. Very interesting and so many displays to look at. Great to see

Interesting history section. My wife and I went here and we're quite interested in the women in war section. The family and marriage was a nice read... But lots to read and many traditions from so many parts of Vietnam.The war area certainly showed women's assistance and affect on the 'American war' and also civil wars. We were both blown away by the ages of the some of the women who were in command (18yo)! And sadly about their deaths.It brings home how different the world was only 40 years ago in these parts.I would put an hour aside for this activity, make sure you don't do it next to another museum or you will get bored and sweep through it
Excellent Museum. The museum is well-curated and contains many interesting aspects of Vietnamese women's lives from fashion, marriage, religion, all the way to activism. A must-see!

Must Go! . Museums are always places of wonder where you go back in time and can only be grateful for where you are now. It's a wonderful museum to explore the wonders that women are. They've got several different floors and each one has a charm of its own.

Lovely. One of the best museums in Hanoi. This has a much more modern feel to it than other museums in Hanoi, with well laid out exhibits, organised thematically. The exhibits themselves are poignant and thoughtful without being sentimental. Great museum.

Small but interesting museum + air conditioned!. My boyfriend and I thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Although small, it covers all aspects of women in Vietnam from marriages, to birth, ethnic minorities, to the important role they played in the resistance against the French in 1930s - 1950s and in the American War in 1960s - 1970s.Highly recommend paying the extra for the audio guide as it gives richer accounts and relevance to the exhibits. It took us about 2.5hrs to do the museum.In the 'Women in war' section, We found comfortable seats under the AIR CONDITIONING to listen to ALL the audio of a particular section and then went and looked at the exhibits. This kept us cool & saved our legs but meant we didn't miss anything.I also particularly loved the minority fashion on the top floor which explained key techniques - this info made my trip to Sapa even more rich and gave me a good appreciation of the costumes of each of the tribes.

Really interesting museum . The museum covers a great deal of topics and is incredibly informative on social conditions for women. The war time section was also very interesting with lots of real life stories. Make sure to get the audio guide!
A museum to pay a visit. In visiting this museum, you will understand the extremely important role played by vietnamese ladies in their country, thus especially since the fight for independence.

Fantastic! . Wow! This place was so great! I loved the displays and the videos were amazing! I really enjoyed that they had so many first hand accounts of lifestyles and traditions. I would love to go back some day!

Great museum. Went here today and it was great. We spent so much time there that we couldn't finish everything, even though we spent more than 2 hours than already. It's interesting to see how the woman emancipation in Vietnam started. Don't really need the audio, since there a lot of signs

Great to see history from a women's perspective for once. I've never been to a museum that focus on the history of women and showcases women's roles in history before here. It was a very pleasant and interesting experience. I got the audio and I would recommend it, it's very well done. You can learn about women's roles in different Vietnamese cultures, women's fashion through time, childbirth, war etc.

Interesting!. The trip to the museum (only 30,000d!) was brilliant. Impressive stories about women and womanhood in Vietnam then and now made us stay several hours. Inspiring art and clothing. Location of the museum is good, next to the central lake and the post office. Highly recommended!

My family's favorite museum in Hanoi and nice gift shop!. We always bring visitors here and it is great for everyone, kids, friends, grandparents. Good for Viet Nam history buffs too. Very inexpensive. Nice modern building, and small enough to not be tiring. Nice gift shop downstairs is well laid out and supports local arts & crafts.

WHAT A SURPRISE. Yeah, I was dragged there kicking and screaming by my lovely wife and I am now so pleased that she was so insistent. These are very cleverly assembled floors of exhibits and I learned so much about the history and culture of Vietnam, especially from the womens' perspective. Well worth a visit but allow a good amount of time to really absorb it all.

Excellent story of the role of woman in Modern Vietnam. A great emphasis on women's efforts in the founding of modern Vietnam -- so often, these stories are forgotten or glossed over in favor of the tales of the men who "led" the struggle; but not here. The museum also soberly shows you the traditional roles assumed for many women (through discussions/displays on marriage traditions among various Vietnamese ethnic groups) and the continuing struggle for women to find work to support themselves and their families. I don't want to make this sound dull or oppressive...it isn't!
Well worth it. Covers every aspect of Vietnamese life it was very informative. Souvenirs are extremely well priced and good quality.
A must see to understand the role of women in Vietnam. Highly recommend a visit. Great displays and explanations in French and English.Great to see a museum dedicated to women
