Incredibly moving. Brace yourself for what can be quite an emotional trip. Fascinating insight in to the beautiful , strong women of Vietnam. Respect on a new level for these people?

Excellent - wish we'd had longer. This museum started out with a large section on marriage practices, leading me to fear this was all that was to come. But it then transitioned into more interesting material on families, work, activism and fashion.A very informative, interesting museum. We only had an hour to an hour and a half - it could easily have taken longer than that.Aircon was a bit variable - not necessarily a cool place to retreat to on a hot day, but certainly better than being outside when it's in the mid 30s!

Informative and well presented displays. An interesting insight into the lives of Vietnamese women. I particularly enjoyed reading about marriage rituals and the role of women during various conflicts.It is air conditioned and only 30 000 VND to enter. Well worth a visit.
Great for learning more about Vietnam culture . A great museum. Much more to see than I expected there to be. Over four floors of information so you really learn about Vietnamese culture

Definitely worth a visit. Everything is beautifully organized and set up. All exhibits are described in Vietnamese, English and French. You don't need a guide for this but they do have audio guides for rent. The second floor was my favourite. It's great to see the country paying tribute to the women of Vietnam in this way.

You don't need a guide. The great thing about this museum is you don't need a guide, as a lot of information is provided on the walls. It's an interesting intro to many stages in women's lives, including work, marriage, and child birth.
Is interesting to visit it.... Is a beautiful place, there are like 4 or 5 floors and the things exhibiting are interesting, beauty and varied.
Eye opening. An amaxing insight into the suprisingly varied and active roles women have played in Vietnamese history.

Highly recommended. This museum is a must do! So much amazing history and it was so good to see so many strong women and everything they achieved during the Vietnam war. It was great to see the tribute to Vietnamese women.

Great museum. I would highly recommend this museum. There is a ton of information to absorb and it is allnvery well presented. You learn a lot about the role of women in many ethnic minorities of Vietnam and how they carried out tasks.

A TRIBUTE TO THE WOMEN OF VIETNAM. The Vietnam Women’s Museum delivers a beautifully presented tribute to the women of Vietnam across the ages. There are plenty of historical contexts alongside a wealth of information on today’s more modern Vietnamese woman.The museum is run by The Women’s Union of Vietnam which is recognised as one of the country’s most powerful movements.Inside the museum there is lots of narrative as women of the rice paddy fields, service workers, street vendors, female business leaders, academics and mothers are all well represented. Additionally there is plenty of information on everyday life including marriage, family life, fashion and life changing rituals. Interestingly, there are also exhibits on the part women played in Vietnam’s wars.Displays are very well presented in a storytelling format with signs also in English and French. Historic documentation including Taoist books of the Dao people and wedding cards from the Kinh community will give visitors an in-depth insight into better understanding the women of Vietnam. Photographs and film footage documenting the life of heroic mothers during wartime are moving exhibits that should not be missed.
Wonderful displays. This museum is well worth a visit. Women's involvement in daily life and in war is all recognized here with wonderful displays and photos. Start at the top floor and work down,

A rich and informative two hours on the history and life of Vietnamese women. This is a very well organised museum with much interest for visitors. It is well set out on three floors. The first on Women in Family - the marriage rituals, childbirth practices and family life. Second floor is women in History from 1930 to 1954 covering the resistance against the French and later their activities in the "American" war. We learned about the leading roles women took as fighters, protestors and healers. So many were commanders and leaders. Third floor covers women's fashions among the many ethnic groups that make up Vietnam. The audio guide is essential - it is concise, comprehensive, clear and intelligent. I can't recommend this museum highly enough. It's a proud and expansive exposition on the contribution of women in every aspect of life in Vietnam. The entry fee and audio guide are modest sums and worth the cost.

Fantastic . I thought this was a fabulous museum. I spent about three hours here and found ever single element of it interesting. I recommend paying the extra money for the Audio recording because it adds a lot of information. Overall the museum shows the pivotal role Vietnamese woman, past and present, play in society. I was also really surprised to learn about the role of women in the Viet cong and during the Vietnam war.
worth a visit. Learnt a lot about the role of woman in Vietnam very well done display and information I would highly recommend this museum to everyone coming to Hanoi.

Fabulous reminder of history and women's contributions. This museum is arguably the best we have visited in Vietnam. Apart from being well set out and structured, it tells an amazing story ... One that is often overlooked by other cultures and countries.Each of the five floors has a different focus, with notes about each exhibit in Vietnamese, English and French. It covers minority groups, the role women have played during the wars (and highlights a number of prominent women). The visual displays of clothing are stunning and capture both handicraft and fashion.This museum provides a great insight into culture, family life, food, marriage, religion and beliefs as well as history.It is well worth a visit and I'm really glad we took the time to visit, preferring it to the other 'major' tourist attractions.

Great insight into a Women's lives in Vietnam. My wife had a very enjoyable visit to this museum and left feeling we had a bit more insight into the life of women in Vietnam.I would call it a museum "light", as it is very compact and we took probably about 45 mins to cover the whole museum.It's well laid out and the section showing how hard some of today's women need to work today and the sacrifices they make to support their families was particularly moving.

Very interesting museum. This was a very well curated museum providing good historical perspective on women in Vietnam. Of particular interest were the sections on marriage and family from the perspective of different ethnic minorities.

Well Presented. Probably one of the best museums I've been to in Vietnam. Gives a great insight into the life of women from all regions of Vietnam. Very well presented museum. Would highly recommend a visit!
Very interesting and informative .. Gives good back ground to life for women in Vietnam especially if you don't know much to begin with . Exhibits well laid out .

Excellent expose of women in Vietnam; their contribution to culture, family and history.. The visit to Vietnamese Women's Museum was one of the highlights of our trip to Hanoi. It cost us about $AUD2.00 each to enter and we spent the next few hours in the three major exhibition floors. The top (4th floor) displayed Women's Fashion which highlighted the costumes of the 54 different minorities in Vietnam, the 3rd floor demonstrated the role of women in Vietnam's history particularly in times of conflict and the 2nd floor focused on life and family. The 1st level contained a small but enticing museum shop. The Fashion exhibition not only showed many costumes but also went into some depth on the techniques used to produce them, the history section covered much of the time when Vietnam was fighting for independence from the French and the objective to re-unify the country. Life and family focused on marriage and childbirth and demonstrated the mix of matriarchal and patriarchal communities that exist in Vietnam. Don't miss it when visiting Hanoi. It is only a short walk from the Lake of the Restored Sword.

If you are not MOVED by the Spirit of this Museum, you're not alive. Took my 20 year old college daughter, and we spent 3 hours here! we paid for the Audio Tour apparatus, which I highly recommend. We walked away very moved by the culture and the immense strength of the Vietnamese Women

Great place to start understating the history of Vietnam!. We also rented the audio tour, otherwise there is probably not much you can understand just by looking at things. We enjoyed it and give you a lot of infos about the Vietnamese culture and where it comes from!
Cool museum . Cool to see the Vietnam war from the Vietnamese perspective and see the roles women played in the nations history. One if the few good things to see in Hanoi.

Lots of interesting information, well set out and great price for what it is.. It cost 30,000 entry or 15,000 for students. 5 levels each level about something different e.g. Women in war,crash ion through the years, marriage and children the different customs they have. They gave plenty of information in English. Doesn't take too long to look through and for the price it's definitely worth the time if your interested.

Interesting but not riveting. Interesting culturally, but does not challenge politically or personally. Nonetheless it provides insights into Vietnamese life that added to my experience. No wow factor though.

Fascinating . Really enjoyed this museum. It gave a very good overview of life for women across Vietnam. It was nice to find a museum which seemed to tell a balanced and rounded picture of the subject matter.The area on women in the wars was one of the most interesting and unbiased representation of the subject we found in all of Vietnam. Well worth the audio tour for the stories of the women.

Vast museum depicting everything about the lives of Vietnamese women. Every aspect of life covered - resistance fighting women, elaborate marriage rituals of Vietnamese women and the heart braking toils of ordinary women having to sell goods in the street for money for their families. Very thorough museum and very colourful and well presented. Best bits are the mother goddess area explaining the prayers that many Vietnamese do (despite not being "religious in the traditional sense!") and the video diaries with the street vendor women which is eye opening. Be wary - this museum has about 5 floors and takes quite a lot of time to do properly. Good value at 40k dong

Herstory of Vietnam. Half of Vietnamese history (or herstory, rather) that you haven't heard, read about or seen! Well worth a visit. They have a lot of original costumes and jewelry from ethnic minority groups, a whole floor dedicated to Female revolutionaries, and a floor about wedding ceremony and family life. Well curated and designed, with video, audio and great signage in 3 languages.
A must see . I'm not a huge fan of museums but I think them women's museum is a must see! I had an amazing time. All the rooms have different themes. My favorite was about the street vendors.

Interesting Museum. A great place to spend a couple of hours for 30,000VND (less than £1). Interesting exhibits and videos and art work over 4 floors charting the history of women in Vietnamese society, including their importance in the 'American War'. The cafe outside is also nice for a drink (beer 30,000VND) and bowl of noodles (40,000 VND) ... £1 = 32,000VND May 2016)

Worth a look. We visited most of the museums in Hanoi and this was the best by far. Very interesting, well set out. It covers the life of women in Vietnam, in the past and present. It also covered the traditional and the political aspects. The museum was well set out and tnere were people on each floor that you could ask for help. Alth6ojgh some were a little more helpful than others
An outlook of woman role in Vietnam 's society . Provide English aid for foreigners  Give riceless knowledge about woman life in history and now .There is an art gallery on the 5th floor as well .
Very interesting . Make sure you purchase an audio device gives SO much more info. Small charge for entry but 3 hours of history.

A rich insight into Vietnamese history & culture. Everything in this museum was intensely interesting and provided a rich insight into Vietnamese history and culture. The stand out for me was the second floor which contained photos & short biographies of women who participated in the wars for Vietnamese independence. Each story further illuminated by a poignant collection of thepossessions that were part of their work and/or survival at that time. So moving to see: the stained shirt that had disguised a woman as mad person so as part of the resistance she could monitor & share enemy movements; or the embroidery sewn secretly for a year by a prisoner as a gift for her mother; or the meagre tool kits of a woman driver or the surgical tools of doctor Dang Thuy Tram whose journal has been published in 2005 with the title, 'Last night I dreamed of peace'. So moving and profound. I recommend hiring the audio guide from the front counter (at time of writing in Vietnamese, French & English) as it provided more and different detail than provided in the exhibits. You will need to leave id as a deposit, I used my drivers licence, I think it cost 50,000 dong (about the same price as coffee or a smoothie). Another standout exhibition was the film about the street vendors of Hanoi, contemporary & relevant. A must see museum, if you are in Hanoi.
Average. The museum has some interesting things on display to show the past life of the women in Vietnam. It is quite a small museum though and we didn't spend much time in here.

Wow, go girl power. Women were not the favourite child in a Vietnamese family structure, with male offspring the favoured. This museum is 3 floors filled with lots of well maintained artifacts, costumes and history pieces. Most interesting was the floor dedicated to the women and their efforts and huge involvement in the wars.
Fascinating . Provides a wonderful expose of women in Vietnam, present and past and an excellent display of life for indigenous women. Highly recommended

Super interesting! Vietnamese Women's Life from past to now!. A complete experience very well explained about all the story of the woman in Vietnam, it is an immersion in culture! The participation of women in the war and also the general life of woman since childhood until wedding and have a family.The way to live, traditional clothes, food, battles in war, the museum is modern full of videos and very nice structure with most of things in English.

A Celebration of Women's Contributions . It's admirable that this museum exists. Chronicles the backbone of Vietnam, specifically the women who do the bulk of the hard labor in Vietnam. Intriguing to see that they were even trained as guerrilla soldiers.

Valuable insights . This museum is so worth a few hours of your time whilst in Hanoi. The insights into the harsh life of a woman in so many areas of Vietnamese society was very humbling. The audio narration adds value by way of explaining the different minority's and their rituals. Women can be promised and married from 12 years old.

Womens History Museum recommendation. This museum is well located and a lovely half day visit. Plenty of interesting exhibits covering the history of Vietnamese family cultural traditions, marraige snd child rearing. Then there is a floor dedicated to the female resistance fighters which id s great education in Vietnamese history. A floor for contemporary art exhibits too. I recommend the audio guide.

Not only about woman!. The best museum of Hanoi I think! You will learn so many things! One visit I did without an audio guide, for about 4 hours. The next time I took an audio guide, which is different from what sou can read an gives you more insight. I stayed again 4 hours! And I'm sure I will come back again, because sou get to know so much about the culture, the minorities and about history.
Nice . If passing by you must pop in. There are some lovely exhibitions and great information regarding the wens struggles here. I loved the floor dedicated to marriage rituals.

Must go!!. By far the best place I went to in Hanoi. I learnt so much about the culture in Vietnam and some amazing facts about women's involvement in the war which was so so insane. This place is perfect all genders and ages - there's loads to see and learn. Couldn't recommend it enough. It probably takes about 1-2 hours to see and read it all. There are cool videos you can watch too. The museum is split into 5 sections and each is just as facinating as each other varying from information on history, culture, fashion, family life and art work.
Worth going. Learned a lot about cultural norms and some important women in history, the clothing part was a bit boring but I am a dude.

Very Well Done, Worth a Visit. Very few museums dedicate themselves to women, this one does in a very fine manner. It details the different tribe cultures as they relate to marriage and home keeping. It honours Vietnamese women heroes. It shows the development of women's fashion.I was impressed and thoroughly enjoyed myself.I highly recommend getting the earphones for a much better understanding, they only cost $1.50.
Wonderful museum. The museum has done a great job representing the women of Vietnam. I would suggest the audio tour which add such value to the beautiful exhibitions.

Brilliantly designed museum.. I got 50% off entry and a free audio guide with a voucher i got at the Prison (worth going there before here) so entry was only 15000 dong. Spent a good 2 hours working our way up the 3 floors of exhibitions that showed in fantastic detail the traditions of women in Vietnam, from marriage, childbirth, fashion etc aswell as they're involvement in the revolution against the French and during the American War. Fantastic show piece would definitely recommend!

Interesting but not the Louvre. It was interesting, next to Starbucks so we decided to stroll in. But it wasn't the Louvre. Not sure what I should have expected but I could have done without visiting it.

A good overview. The lowest floor provided a nice overview of women's daily lives - depicting dress, implements and great videos of various traditional occupations, weddings, agriculture, cooking, childbirth etc. The 3rd floor is about the role of women in the Vietnam wars - fascinating, well done - except for the airconditioning not working very well.

Informative and well laid out museum. This museum was really well laid out and all the information was presented in a clear, interesting and easy to read manner. It was very insightful and gave an interesting overview of the role of women in Vietnam's development.

Very interesting. Get the audio tour guide!. Very very interesting. Allow a good couple of hours and get the little audio tour guide device for 30k VND. It adds a whole new dimension to what you're looking at... The added personal stories are great. One of my highlights of Hanoi.

Interesting museum. The first time I came to this museum was in 2011 and it was boring. But last month my friend took me there again and it surprised me. It had a huge innovation in 2012 and now totally different, in a good way. This museum shows you about Vietnamese women : fighting in the war, family life, giving birth, making the living, and even fashion of Vietnamese women in different areas of Vietnam. Not so far away from the Old quarter of Hanoi, walking distance from the Hoan Kiem lake.

Happy in Hanoi. My husband and I both thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the museum. A good overview of the strength, endurance and tenacity of the Vietnamese woman. They manage to be loving mothers, have lead battles and work long hours to feed their families. I have a high respect for them all. An excellent exhibit!

Great little museum. This museum is a great introduction to aspects of the history of vietnam with a focus on women. The displays include ethnic minorities and the role of women in the american/vietnam war. Included are some wonderful short videos about the women who sell produce in the streets.

One of the highlights of my stay in Hanoi. I absolutely loved this museum and I am not a museum enthusiast. It really puts the condition of Vietnamese women into perspective. There are different floors dedicated to different topics. My favourite one was the floor dedicated to tribal/minority women and the section dedicated to the stories of women in modern day Vietnam.

Eye opening experience about Vietnamese culture. This museum is well worth a visit in a city lacking similar institutions for tourists interested to find out about Vietnamese culture (with the exception of the excellent enthnograohic museum which is a decent taxi ride away from the centre).There are many overlaps with the enthnograohic museum but of the 5 floors of exhibits it was the 4th which surveys the role of women in the American War that really captivated us. Incredible stories about compelling individuals and through these stories one could learn a great deal about the Vietnamese perspective on this chapter in their history.Located just south of the lake, this is an easy museum to get to and is a must if you are in town for a few days and not planning to get out to the (far more expansive) enthnograohic museum.

Get the Audio!. What makes this museum wonderful is not just the artifacts of these women that have been collected, but the stories behind them. You can hear these stories by getting the free audio guide! It comes with your entrance fee. If they don't have your language, the info is in English, French and Vietnamese. It is very well done, you learn a lot about Vietnamese culture from the Woman's perspective and their role in wartime efforts. Just take your time, lots of info but it is well worth it to make it to the Women in History section!Tip: if you go to the Hoa Lo Prison first, they have coupons for 50% off the entrance of the Women's museum!

The role of women in Vietnam spans centures. This is a particularly interesting museum filled with history, couture, life passages and the hugely important role of women as battlefield fighters. Not to be missed.
worth a look to see strong womens inflence with Vietnam history. This Museum, dedicated to womens achiements and contributions to Vietnams history a great visit and leeson

Well worth it . With 5 floors of interesting exhibitions . Through the history of vietnam for women . And only cost 30000 dong or $1.70 each . Well worth it and only 4 blocks walk from hoa lo prison .

A delightful and entertaining museum - not to be missed when in Hanoi. An excellent way to spend a few hours when its either too hot or drizzling outside is at the Women's Museum. The audio tour headsets are included in the entry cost and its amazingly informative and educational. I could have spent more time there learning about the culture and the instrumental role of women in Vietnamese society and culture.

Really interesting exhibition . Showcases women's role in Vietnamese society and culture. There were sections on the street vendors, birth, marriage, family life and work. Mother goddess worship traditional costume and a seperate section on Vietnamese women at war telling the stories of various individual women and their contribution to the war effort.We spent 2.50 hours here and left feeling very privileged to be living in the western world.

One of the better local museums. The name of the museum did not really tempt me to visit having seen many local museums, many of them rather derelict. However I was positively surprised. In an entertaining fashion the museum gives a fair review of the culture of the Vietnamese women and the hardships they endured. Of Course they could not avoid including the usual propaganda but it is a worth a visit if you are looking for one or two hours of entertainment.

So many great women who has built this country. Culture, traditions, wars and fights. All very well exposed in the light of how women have contributed, fought and had a key role. Ge there, very memorable.

Really interesting. Loads to look at and read about - not as much information as there could have done. We already knew about some of the women they covered and thought there was a lot more to be said about them. Definitely worth going to look at the photographs of women in traditional clothes and read the stories of their war contributions. Beautiful statue in the lobby as well.

A little gem!. This is a fascinating museum which have visited before. It has developed with time and it's a great place to see if you're interested in history, culture, ethnography, and, of course, the important role of women in Vietnamese life over the centuries.

Specialised museum. Entry VD30,000 which covers viewing of 3 floors of exhibits, namely women's fashion, women in history and women in family.All exhibits are well displayed and narrative is in 3 languages, Vietnamese/French/English. There are no interactive elements, all exhibits being of a static nature.Easily viewed within one hour.

Vivid displays, good overview, inspiring.. Particularly well presented displays cover many facets of Women's contributions to Vietnam's accomplishments. Each floor covers a different aspect of women in Vietnamese life; as brides, as mothers, as defenders, as revolutionaries, as heroes

Lovely Museum. Highly recommend walking to this museum from the old quarter for a few hours of information and insight into Vietnamese women. You'll view the ladies selling fruit and donuts on the streets with more understanding and empathy.

Worth 30,000 but over rated. Good museum but I felt it didn't focus enough on the Iives of the majority of women. The sections on the various ethnic groups was interesting but I would've like to have learned about equality in society more broadly -pay, violence, female leaders (politics and business). The statue at the entrance is cool and the art work on equality is well done.

not only about/for women. worth the trip for the moving video in which a few of the women street vendors tell about their lives; but there is more: nice tableaus,video's and photo's in which wedding ceremonies of difefrent minorities are documented (also matriarchal tribes!)

Get the headsets. We found this really good to go and see, to gain an understanding on the roles women Play in vietnam. however on entry we were handed a flyer and directed upstairs to the displays but a lot of other tourists had head sets that were explaining what the displays were which we didnt recieve so was a lot of reading, this would have been really helpful. Make sure you get the head sets if you go.

Fascinating Display of Culture. One of the two best museums in HaNoi. (The other is the Ethnography Museum.) Good displays of tools, artifacts, photos, and costumes, with informative labels. Audio tour (Vietnamese, French, or English) is available. The focus is, of closures, on women, but the displays teach a lot about Vietnamese culture and history. Nice gift shop with inexpensive handicrafts.

The cartoons were great.. I was glad that we visited the museum it does open your eyes to how hard it is for some families to get by. After we visited the museum I was much more receptive to the ladies selling cards and pineapples in the street. One of the best things in the museums were the cartoons made by locals depicting how women are at the bottom. The museum didn't seem to stick to the topic of women, some floors were more about religion. The sixth floor was selling bad art...maybe fund raising. Over all I thought it was a worthwhile visit. It's only 30 thousand dong to see it.

Interrsting, alot of knowldege about women of viet nam. The first sign, i was disappointed because the museum was too small for my imagine. However, there were many things to see and useful i formation. The ticket is not cheap.
Definitely worth a visit. I was very moved by this 5 floor exhibition and the incredible women that it focused on. I wish I'd had more time to spend there.

Good on a rainy day. The museum had a good stucture and with headphones you could choose whatever you would like to listen to.It was so much information and talking so we just did 2 out of 3 parts before we left. It was pretty interesting to see what the women did during the war and all that but some parts with clothes and such was not really my cup of tea.If you are interested it's a really good museum, but if you're not you can skip it.

Fantastic Museum . This museum is located close to the lake. The ticket costs 30000 dong which is very cheap. It is mind opening and shows how difficult the life of Vietnamese women is. I wish that I visited it earlier. It would have helped me to understand the women who sell fruit and other produce in the street and who may appear annoying to the tourists. There are 3 floors of interesting exibits - wedding ceremonies, mothers and babies, revolutionaries and beautiful costumes showing how the fashion has evolved over the years.

very intersting about the cultures that are used in Vietnam. the museum is modern and good to understand. One part is about wedding, an other about pregnancy and birth, another about family live, another about women in the resistance and the last about modern women. We were there 1,5 hours

Very Interesting. There are not a lot of museums dedicated to women's history in the world. This one was extremely interesting from its history of the different ethnic groups to the Viet Nam War. I would choose this over the Temple of Literature.
Good insight into the life of Vietmanese women. Learnt a lot of things here........especially how the women helped contribute to the effort in the war against America.

Excellent exhibits, worth the walk!. I visited this museum on my last morning in Hanoi and was really impressed by it. Split over a number of floors, with each showcasing a different aspect of the lives and experiences of Vietnamese women including marriage, motherhood, history and their involvement in Vietnam's cultural revolution and various conflicts.I particularly enjoyed the marriage exhibit and learning about how different ethnic groups within Vietnam celebrate the ceremony, how it is carried out, what they wear etc. I found the English translations to read very naturally too, which was not my experience in other Vietnamese museums.Overall my visit here was incredibly interesting and although the museum was a little walk away from the main tourist centre of Hanoi I felt it was well worth it and at a 30,000 VND entry fee (approximately £1) I really cannot think of any reason why one would not visit here, I highly recommend it.
Really enjoyed this museum. Plan to spend at least an hour and pay extra for the audio guide. Take your time and you will learn an amazing amount about tribal life in Vietnam.

Worthwhile stop whilst in Hanoi. I am glad that I took the time to visit this museum and learn more about the role Vietnamese women played in the history of Vietnam. Upon paying my admission fee I was offered the audio system and then asked to pay a deposit in VND or leave my passport as security. This was strongly queried by a fellow visitor as there were no signs about a fee for the audio system and I backed her up on this, we were told that this was a new policy and hence no signage. Am hopeful that the signage situation will be rectified for any future visits. In hindsight I should have refused the audio system - my opinion is that a personal audio system is not necessary to enjoy and get the maximum benefit out of this museum.

Interesting and informative . It was really interesting to learn about the specific women's traditions within local cultures, and the small amount of information there was on modern women in Vietnam was great, it would be great if there was more on that.We had a lovely time and spent a good hour and a half in there.

Brilliant Museum!. This is an amazing museum, the displays are modern, colourful and, in parts, interactive. The museum is very informative, although might overstretch the equality and modernisation of women's rights in Vietnam. There are lots of really interesting things to see. At 30,000 VMD it's well worth a look and we found it really enjoyable.

History with emphasis on women's role. Attractive building with exhibits on several floors. The focus is on women's roles, but the museum is a history of Vietnam and has exhibits on agricultural products such as rice, different kinds of dress, including examples of contemporary designers, and some propaganda. The shop has a good range of products.

This place is big. Usually in a museum I like to go through the whole audio guide since I find them very informative. This time however we didn't finish the last floor simply because there was so much information. It is probably because I was more tired because I arrived the same day with a sleeper bus but still I think its a lot to read and listen to. Doesn't have to be a bad sign though, the museum is divided into three levels with different info so you can easily choose whatever interests you.All in all it was a good museum and I recommend it even if I don't believe you have to go through all the material.

One of the best experience in Hanoi. Pay a visit to the women museum it worth it. I learnt the importance that women have in vietnam history . It's not included in city tour but it's very easy to reach on foot if you are located in the old quarter or close to the lake.

Interesting Museum. This is a great museum to learn about the life of Vietnamese women and their culture. We were not aware how active women were in the war. We saw beautiful handicrafts. Plan on spending a couple of hours in this museum!
Sad to see the rest of the world struggles with equality for women. ...but great to see Vietnam recognising it. Not a big museum but some interesting displays. Worth a visit
well worth a visit. You will learn a lot here.I was amazed at the leading roles women have played in recent vietnamese history.

Interesting as far as it goes. The museum provides a good introduction to the basics of life for ethnic minority women. And for this I recommend it. It also gives tribute to the women who made a difference in the 'war of aggression' (U.S. -As they call it.) It is disappointing in that the role of women in society now isn't addressed at all. With all that recognition for their roles in the war, you'd expect to at least try to address issues of today. The only hint was also the most disturbing--a film on the street vendors of Hanoi...they leave their villages for 10-14 days to work in the city and may only take home $20 for their labors. You can't look at them the same after seeing the film.
Very Good. Reasonably affordable, from memory 50.000VD. There were a few seats to sit down on for people who tired.

Great insight into women's role during the resistance war against America. A must visit to get a deep insight into the role of women during the resistance war against America and to understand the culture of the country.

Superb museum. This museum, dedicated to the women of Vietnam, is one of the best I have been in. It is well thought-out, the narratives are engaging and the short films really add value. It's a perspective on Vietnam that foreigners need to see.

Women's perspective on history. This was a compact size of museum which was good to take the family to. Enough of interest to hold the young adult sons but not too big that it took all day. Interesting mix of culture, history, politics, religion all from the woman's perspective.

Great Museum and A lot of History. I normally don't like museums but I really enjoyed this one and the photo gallery on the 5th floor. If you get a chance to check it out its only 30 VMD and well worth it.
Excellent!!. Well worth a visit - beautifully presented history of many aspects of the life of women in Vietnamese culture.

Rich historical introduction to the lives and culture of Vietnamese. I spent a whole morning here touring the three floors of exhibits and gained a lot of insights to the rich ethnic diversity of the Vietnamese people, their lives, culture and customs. It gets crowded with families in the early afternoon, so I'd recommend to visit here as soon as it opens. Admission fees were between USD 1 ~2 and the audio guide is highly recommended for its detailed descriptions to the exhibits. A great takeway for me was to learn how much the women contributed to the guerilla warfare in the Vietnam war, with their courage and ingenuity.

Lots and lots of items - not a great story behind it. This was a huge exhibition, well priced and had a lot of information. However for me it didn't really flow, I felt like there were just lots of exhibits and paraphernalia that had been lying around someone's garage and they had decided to make it into a museum. The concept is great, with a floor explaining a Vietnamese wedding, another floor for women fashion, but the narration taking you around the museum didn't quite flow and I found myself struggling to get any sense of a back story or understand around what the different items in the exhibits were used for.

Not to be missed. The 3 floors tell the amazing stories of women in vietnam; their contributions to the war and to their villages with their farming, cooking and art\craft skills. As a nurse, the section on childbirth and children was of special interest to me. The exhibition on fashion was fascinating and showcased amazing weaving, needlepoint and sewing skills. My partner enjoyed it as much as i did. Admission fee was minimal`
Oral History. great collection of traditional dress; excellent overview of wedding traditions; and several videos of oral histories from street sellers

Helpful, heartbreaking insights. We learned so much about the lives of Vietnamese women (and people in general) from this museum, including the struggles many women have to provide for their families. I highly recommend a visit.

Really informative. So much to see at this museum giving a lot of insight into both the day to day lives of Vietnamese women and the role they played in times of conflict. I particularly liked the exhibits of the women who were honoured and the accounts of individual contributions made.

Very Interesting. I found this museum surprising interesting and feel I learned alot about the women of Vietnam and their culture on history. Some great information on marriage and birth rituals/beliefs. I was particularly impressed by the section on women in the Vietnamese war. Would definitely recommend. Cheap entry for 30000/ticket.

Very nice.. Very nice museum to visit. I was fortunate enough to have Vietnamese lady as tour guide I could tell this place was important to her. How many cultures would dedicate an entire museum to the contributions of their women.

Most amazing artifacts, clothing and documentary. This rounded out my trip to Vietnam showing me artifacts and clothing I had seen and was now able to get a better sense of up close. The documentary on the street venders gave me such an appreciation for what life is truly like for them.
Worthwhile . Although definitely the communist view this museum is definitely worth spending a few hours to understand how the life of a vietnamese woman was / is

We loved it. We spent around 1 hour in the museum and we really enjoyed it. We went there with a very informative guide so he provided us a lot of informations about women's role during Vietnam war and nowadays. If we went there by ourshelves, I don’t think we can learn that much! I would recommend going there and much better if you can go with a guide! Overall, a very nice museum!

If you only have time for 1 museum-this is it!. The Vietnamese Women's Museum is a vast collection of important times and women of Vietnam. Each floor is themed and represents events important to women and to Vietnam.

Well worth a visit . Good little museum focused on the role of women. It is slightly strange to have floors on family life and marriage (including all the not so feminist elements of traditional customs) interspersed with floors on women fighters in the resistance (take what it says about the liberation of the South with a large pinch of salt) and a special exhibition on gender equality. That said, I suppose the museum is probably an accurate reflection of a developing nation, and encourages visitors to consider women's evolving role going forward

a MUST SEE whilst in Hanoi. The displays were fabulous, with amazing costumes and details about all the different provinces and how they differ for the women. The fabulous photos and stories about the brave and ingenious women during the war will leave a lasting impression on me. Really enjoyable visit. Allow time as there's plenty to see.

amazing. love vietnamese women, they are always hard-working, patient.
especially vietnamese women in the wars

Not what you think!. Greeted with a load of cartoons, amusing and sexist in the foyer but inside the museum showed the importance that the Vietnamese women have contributed to the success of their country, from farming culture to the contribution given during the war. Not to be missed

A good way to spend a couple of hours. Very interesting learning about the Vietnamese women in the war, in their lives, their families, cultures, tradition clothing etc. They were very much involved in the war and had a huge impact. Worth going! Plenty to see and read all beautifully exhibited.

must visit- more than you expect... Great museum, it takes 2 hours to visit. There are 4 floors to visit. Each floor has a different theme, fashion, working, war, marriage, birth, etc. I found lacquering teeth was very interesting... You can see Vietnamese women' s life until our days. Entry fee is 30000 VND and there is free audio guides in English, french, Vietnamese..

Very Interesting Place!. Really, this is a very interesting place to visit specially like us guys. Enjoyed a lot there and it is very helpful to give some ideas about culture of Vietnam people specially about women.

Quite an eye opener. This interesting and informative museum gives great insight into the lives, culture and tradition of women in Vietnam. Entry fee cheap, and headphones available for a small additional fee. The video and information on female street vendors was particularly interesting and makes you realise the hardship many families in Vietnam must endure in order to earn a living. Recommended.

Excellent Museum. Just go! It covers a lot of ground regarding women in Vietnam and their role in society and in history. You admire the women of Vietnam after going through. Every country should have something like this!

NIce place. when i have a free time , i like go around HaNoi
old quarter
museum
cinema in Trang Thi st.
ice cream Trang Tien very delicious

A Fantastic Museum. Great displays with lots of information offered in English and presented beautifully. Well curated and offers a variety of women-focused themes in the exhibits. Photography is permitted and the small gift shop is quite pleasant.

Unexpected find. Enjoyable visit in understanding the great achievements of vietnams women. You see working women everywhere in vietnam, from street cleaners to road maintance,to maintaining the gardens and public greens to building sites there doesn't seem to be anything they dont do.

Very interesting and informative museum. Very happy we took the time to visit the Vietnamese Women's Museum. Greatly appreciated the free audio tour, which aided in explanation of exhibits. Great visiting photography exhibit, on the top floor, exploring autism in children and teens around the world. Well worth the 30,000 vnd entrance fee.

What an Amazing Museum. There are 4 floors of photographs, stories, and descriptions of what Vietnamese women did, from getting married to giving birth to the roles women played during the war, as well as the costumes worn. A very interesting place to visit. There is also a shop to purchase souvenirs.

Well worth a visit. My husband and I lost track of time as the museum has so many fantastic exhibits, videos and photographs to enjoy.
We paid the extra 30,000 VND to have the audio commentary which I highly recommend.
I have a new perspective of the women of Vietnam and a knowledge of their family life and traditions.

Different Kind of Museum - Worth a Trip. For the country you are experiencing it is definitely worth a visit if you have time in Hanoi.If you see the women on the street selling fruit and wonder what their background story is, this museum will have some answers for you.Focusing on women from rural backgrounds and their reasons for moving to work in larger cities, to the wedding traditions which are still visible in society.A must see museum!

Interesting visit. Hadn't planned to visit this Museum, more stumbled across it really, but actually turned out to be well worth a visit. Very interesting aspects of Vietnamese women roles in Society, right across all aspects of life

Interesting. Way more than we thought they would have. textiles,fashion,art and other things all done by women. You just don't think women have much power in Vietnam. It was well worth the time we spent there and it was a big suprise.

Must see!. I reallllly enjoyed this place ( I have an interest in culture, history and Vietnam so i may be a little biased). The museum is extensive and so well done. I walked out feeling like I really got to know the Vietnamese traditions. A must see! You even get a free audio guide, which is extremely helpful and user friendly! I

Amazing Place. This is a Must Do on your trip to Hanoi. The museum is well laid out and the FREE audio tour could keep you there all day! I felt like I learned a lot about the cultures in Vietnam at this museum.

Tough at times, but very informative. This museum has exhibitions on Women and Family (marriage and birth), Women's costumes, Worshipping goddesses, the place of women in Vietnam today and Women at War.The displays are very informative and pleasant to look at, and a lot of information is given on ethnic minorities in Vietnam as well as the hard lives women still often have to endure today. I was extremely touched when reading the tragic stories of war heroines on the second floor - very little propaganda there, just the stories, and they are heartbreaking. There were also video interviews of contemporary women having to do backbreaking jobs to support their family even today - an eye-opener that teaches us how lucky we are! There was a great display on traditional worship of female deities, along with music and videos. The displays are a mix of reconstitutions and encased objects, with a few replicas you can handle/wear.Overall very quiet, interesting museum that everyone should go and see!

Definitely visit this museum!. I must confess that I am a museum fan- I always like to visit museums when I am visiting cities, but this museum really impressed me. Each floor had different theme- although the museum is about 'women' - it tells the story of all the people of Vietnam- it took us through marriage rituals across the country, farming, women's role in the wars amongst others. I personally was really taken by the textiles and fabrics. I learnt a lot about reliefs rituals and there was a really interesting video about the street sellers. It was calm and a real escape from the busy streets. The displays were all well translated into English and French- the museum really top class.

Loved this museum!. Great history of Vietnamese women including cultural and social obligations, cultural maternal traditions and rituals and revolutionary strength in challenging colonialism and war. Strong and inspiring woman who did what you do to protect your family, culture and country. Just loved it and worth visiting!

One of my favorite small museums in the world . This wonderful new museum tells an inspiring and compelling story of women's role in Vietnam history - from traditional clothing and customs of various tribes to the role of women in the both the north and south during the French and American wars. Get the free headset program - very well done and adds a lot to the visit. Ticket was 30,000 d, a real bargain.

A must in Hanoi. Exspecially ifyou are going to travel up north is worthed to makeyou understand all the different woman from different tribe..its just impressive the part about the war..It took me 3,5h..so make sure u had food before going!

A very informative museum well worth a visit. This museum is spread over five floors and gives a very good detailed information about womens lives in vietnam over history. It is worth visiting - one of the best museums I have been too for a very long time. There was an painting/cartoon exhibition when we were there showing how women are portrayed as second class citizens some of the paintings were very clever in the way they expressed this.The cafe just outside serves very good iced coffeeThe entrance fee was about 2 euros
A Great Surprise. This museum is so much more interesting and powerful than I imagined. The floor dedicated to the women who supported the independence movement is especially moving.
Pretty naff. Pretty naff museum, not worth the effort. God job it's free otherwise I would have asked for my money back.

Nice museum . My friend has recommended me to see the museum when I wad in Hanoi. It was nice, well presented and organised. I very much liked the drawing exhibition re: equal opportunities. The museum is in a lovely area in Hanoi
Interesting . This place gives you an insight into just how equal men and women have been treated in Vietnam. Interesting museum and a great cafe outside

The Heart and Soul of Vietnam-the Women.. Strongly recommend, that the Vietnamese Women's Museum be your first destination as you begin to explore Hanoi, an amazing city of culture, history, people, food and so much more. Women are the foundation of this culture. So many of the women leave their small farming, fishing communities to come to work and to live , 30 in a room, in the city In order to support their children-providing funds for education. In seeing, a video and photo exhibit, showing the women street vendors of Hanoi, I stood humbly in awe. I suddenly had a more sensitive understanding of the women selling flowers, fruit, stuff out of their balanced baskets asking for a few dollars to support their families. The idea is to buy and not to donate. So please do so when you meet them. Also at the entrance of the museum was a poster contest encouraging students to focus on gender equity. The sensitivity, maturity, reality, and impact was powerful. A must visit.

Well worth while. An interesting and informative place to visit. The women of Vietnam are certainly strong and resilient and this museum highlights this. There is also a lovely reasonable priced little gift shop there that is worth a look in.
Very good museum. Very interesting museum (and i don't normally do museums) on the history of women in Vietnam and some general history too. Worth a trip in Hanoi.

Informative. The Vietnamese Women's Museum was informative, comprehensive, modern and a valuable addition to Hanoi. The museum allows the voices of Vietnamese women to be heard in a setting that I would otherwise not have had the opportunity to do so. It was insightful to see this gendered perspective and while there is room for improvement, I would highly recommend a visit to this museum.

Powerful . It is important to go, to see and understand the lives of the hard working woman of Vietnam, if you take the time to sit and watch the movies and other exhibits of the museum you will have a powerful experience

Really good quality. I was really pleasantly surprised by the Women's Museum - the exhibitions have recently been redone and there are three floors covering such topics as women's role in family life, childbirth rituals, and women in military history in Vietnam. In most museums the entire experience of women only gets a token nod in one small room so I found it refreshing that this museum exists and is so well done. The interpretation materials are detailed and thoughtfully researched in the information provided, I wish more museums would provide this level of quality. You can borrow a free audio tour in Vietnamese, English or French which gives good information about the exhibits. The exhibits are really fascinating and I learnt a lot about Vietnamese culture, I especially appreciated the video presentations which were humbling at times and stuck in my mind a long time after I left. There was a wonderful floor of beautiful clothing from the various ethnic groups of Vietnam which I really enjoyed. There is also a stone mill in the museum which the visitor has the opportunity to try and use the wooden lever to grind the grains - very hard and makes you appreciate how tiring this task is.Would highly recommend this as an example of how museums should be.

A wonderful insight into the role of Vietnamese women. A very well laid out museum. Each floor has a different theme: top floor - tribal clothes and traditional fashions, excellent. Next floor down, the role of women in wars - very good, but clearly written from the 'winners' perspective - not overly so though. Then down one floor again, the traditional roles of women in the home and childbirth. All very well presented and displayed in VN, FR and English.The atrium mobile of painted coolie hats is worth the small admission price by itself. Have the ginger tea at the attached Cafe - wonderfully refreshing.
interesting museum. Showcases the variety of regional customs and clothing as related to the various different areas of Vietnam with the focus on understanding women's role and life.
Fascinating. A very very interesting and enlightening museum covering many aspects of women's life in Vietnam including their role in wartime

A nice attraction in Hanoi. A well laid out and informative museum. Free audio guide available. Small souvenir shop on sight and a nice little café outside. If you're in Hanoi, pay a visit and learn something new about Vietnamese women.

Definitely visit. Especially for men. Very interesting and informative. Shocking that 1 in 3 women suffer violence from a close male at least once in their life. The inequality of women's lives is also made very clear. Raises the question what is one as a man going to do about it!Also displays of clothes, farming and cooking equipment etcDefinitely worth a visit
Interesting. Basically it shows the life of a Vietnamese woman. It is interesting but nothing much. The ticket is only 30.000 VND, so it is not expensive at all.

Highly recommended. We attended 6 museums whilst in Vietnam and this was the best behind the war museum in ho chi minh. Absolutely recommend it and allow yourself at least and hour or two to visit all 6 floors and read the fascinating history held within!
Somewhat interesting.. It's worth a look but little is explained and it certainly doesn't rank up there with other museums I've visited.

If you like Museums i'm sure you'll enjoy this.. Despite it not being my thing i cannot by any means take away from the well laid out information that was on offer. it was really nice to see the history of Vietnam even from a one sided part of the story and that being said that's what also made this place as special as it intended to be. Themes were sectioned off on levels and there was the typical offering of a video room and artifacts, although i did feel there could have been more. At the very top of the building was an gallery with some of the most bizarre art i've seen, which i probably enjoyed the most. It seemed a little difficult to get to, even for a local as that's who took me. Sadly i cannot remember the price of admission, but if you enjoy museum's or supporting business's like this i encourage you to check it out. Only took about 20 mins all in all.
not so interesting. its not so interesting what they placed in there. maybe because i am more into the usual museum contents

One of Hanoi Museum. Women’s Museum in Hanoi gives you a good view of the women’s importance in Vietnamese society. The art displays are nicely presented. Depending of the program they offer, I saw a retrospective about the women’s involvement during the French war (end in Feb.1954) and the American’s one, with beautiful black and white photos. This museum is nicely situated downtown of Hanoi.

Fascinating glimpse into the lives of Vietnam's women, and the impact they had in the War. A major museum giving a good over view, both of the history and lives of Vietnamese women (and the different ethnic groups) through the ages. It also goes a long way to ensuring the American war is not seen as purely fought by men!

Must-do but just to check the box. If you've travelled around Vietnam for some time you will find that most of the clothes, objects and everything is very familiar to you, but the place itself is very nice, there are audio-guides for free, another small exhibition upstairs and a pleasant cafe outside, so in general it is worth seeing.

Interesting and well thought out. We heard about this museum from fellow travellers and decided to take a look. We are so glad we did. The museum would be interesting to everyone. It is colourful, interesting and educational. Great exhibits, great photos with explanations and you could easily spend a couple of hours looking through each level of the museum. I have never been to a museum that focuses solely on women's roles in a society. This museum is remarkable and shows you the extent of their contribution to Vietnam life. A must see.

A fascinating museum showing the importance of women historically and now, in war and in peace. If you are staying in the Old Quarter of Hanoi, this museum is a short distance away, walking partly around the Hoan Kiem lake. It is an outstanding collection, showing cultural life and traditions such as weddings and the production of the textiles so important in Vietnamese life. The glorious traditional costumes alone make the visit worthwhile. The role of women is highlighted in Vietnam's struggles against the French and then in the American (Vietnam) War. We loved the enormous gold figure in the foyer,honouring mothers. All cities should have a Women's Museum! We were family, but adults.
enjoyable. spent four hour looking around on international ladies day...enjoyed and came away with some meaning thoughts

Interesting look at Vietnamese culture, and women's role in history!. This museum was 30 000 VND and was well worth it. There are several floors inside, focusing on different aspects of women's lives in Vietnam.
If you like history and culture, then this museum is for you. Most displays written in english as well as french and vietnamese.
Well worth a visit.. This museum is just amazing. It gives a clear insight into the history of Vietnamese women and the roles they portrayed during the war. Extremely informative, a must to see !!!

informative and interesting. Recommended to us prior to our trip. Did not disappoint! Well layed out and informative on the woman role in Vietnam and vietnamese culture. Dispalys were all layed out with information written on board next to each piece to learn about how used. Cafe outside looked lovely however did not have time to try it.

Hanoi's Most Beautifully Done Museum. The Vietnamese Women's Museum is a world-class museum featuring at least four floors of top notch exhibits on women during the Vietnam War, Tribal women, women's day-to-day life in Vietnam, notable women of the past, and topics of special interest to women such as absolutely gorgeous displays of tribal women's costumes, family life, child-bearing, the Mother Goddess religion, and various professions that women hold including women who deliver produce to markets, craftsmen, etc.The museum has a splendid gift shop, where we spent a lot of money on very reasonably priced prints, textiles, sculptures, and watercolors. This is one of the two best places to buy inexpensive art we found in Hanoi.The museum also has a fine coffee shop/restaurant with good food and even better desserts and coffee. This is a good place to stop over if you are tired, as it is very lovely, restful, and has locals stopping off for the coffee and pastries. We strongly recommend this museum, this gift shop, and this café.The museum is beautifully put together and very enjoyable to view, as the

More than expected. We had this museum in the same day as the Ho Chi Minh museum. For only 33000d ($1,50) you get a fairly good insight about women and how people treated/looked at them througout the years in Vietnamese culture. It'll take you about half an hour to 45 mins to see it all (3 floors).

Not to be missed!. We were advised by fellow travelers not to miss this museum and agree fully. Thoughtful exhibits focusing on experience of women in Vietnam. Interesting videos on textile production which we really enjoyed. Visited on our second day in Hanoi. Wish we had had time to re-visit at end of our visit after we visited Laos and Sapa, where we spent time in Hmong village and took batik class.

Very interesting museums about how times are changing for women in Vietnam. On different floors but has lift available. Well spaced out and interesting topics. Various eating areas outside in complex for a cool drink or snack.
Something for common knowledge. I don't usually like museums, but this was exception. It was good to see how state of women has develop during Vietnam history.
Very interesting museum!. One of the best museums we've seen. Learned about women of Vietnam, the many minority groups in Vietnam, their roles in history, their culture and dress.

Wonderful place to visit on International Women's Day. It is very impressive in content and detail but being there on International Women's Day from Canada was very special. The exhibit of winning cartoon depictions of life in Vietnam for women was profound.

Great museum. Wish every country had a museum dedicated to women. If you are interested in learning more about women and their role in Vietnamese society than this is a great place to start.
Marriage, children,fashion,working in fields as well as the culture of worship of mother goddess is extensively covered. The contribution and leadership in wars provided by Vietnamese women is quite astounding
Don't miss. Very good museum. We learned so much how women contributed into country’s history. Hard to believe how much those tiny shoulders carried through all these years. Must visit!

Equality!. The first observation you notice when arriving to Vietnam is the Women dominance! They do everything here. All the hard work, sales! They were a huge part in the Vietnam war! All of that, you see in a very informative way in the museum

Wooo man!!! It's a good Museum. . A simple journey through an incredibly complex and inspiring lifestyle. The women of Vietnam seem to do so much, and have done so much, to provide for their families and give so much to their country. Take a journey through marriage, food, employment, sacrifice, military service, motherhood and the amazing fashion of Vietnams better half. Read everything and take it all in. It's worth it! 30,000vnd

Very good museum . Me and my friends really enjoyed this museum. The layout was clear and informative with a floor dedicated to women as mothers, women in war and the women who make textiles. All beautifully presented and detailed so we felt we learnt a lot about the history and culture of Vietnam through the eyes of women. All information is written in Vietnamese, English and French but also offers headsets for other languages. We also bought lots of postcards from the small gift shop.

The sister's struggle. Visit this museum for a beautiful, powerful, comprehensive look at the contribution made by women to the life of Vietnam. Showcasing talents of heroes and communities, there are some very poignant stories highlighted by displays and multi-media programs. Give yourself 2 hours to have a leisurely tour- you'll need it to get around everything. The experience of visiting this museum gave me a better understanding and some insight into local cultural practices. Stuff started to make sense.
Interesting museum. Worth the admission price. Certainly helps with sorting out the minority groups. Spread over several stories of a building but there is a lift.

Fascinating museum . I managed to get my husband to visit with me, and he doesn't normally like museums, but we both found this particularly interesting. We only had an hour to spend there, but could easily have wandered around the three floors for a few hours. We learnt about the amazing spirit of the women of Vietnam and what an important part they played in the war, but also about marriage customs and family life. Well worth a visit.

Well invested time. Huge collection of women's history in Vietnam. Did not know 40% of soldiers in Vietnam war were women. Loads more documented history of their strength and tenacity. Not sure other countries have documented as much. Husband also found it enjoyable historically

The Lives of Women in the Revolution. In this small, beautiful modern museum, the exhibits were lovely and moving. I especially appreciated some of the videos shown, like the artist painting portraits of the honored women of the Revolution, and the modern village women who come to sell in Hanoi every morning.

OUR SUNDAY. Thought I'm gonna bring my husband to the museum. It's our first time to visit the place and i must say its great way to retire our day. T'was worth it. I thought it was fun. From the ground floor up to the 4th floor. Each floor has a history to tell from religion, culture and beliefs. Don't worry too when it comes to reading or knowing because all is translated in English.The museum is really informative and educational. I enjoyed visiting all the floors but the display on the 3rd floor interest me more, their women fashion. The presentation of their different clothing from before and now is somewhat very interesting. The generation change, but they keep their traditional style of woman's clothing 'alive' up to now. Overall, its really wonderful!

One of the best museums in Vietnam. We decided to go this museun during our stay in Hanoi thanks to TripAdvisor, and it was great decision!You can learn there a lot about Vietnamese culture By their women's stories. About different and special weddings in different tribes, about the active women in Vietnam War, about their hand made work and cooking and more.Everything written very easily in English and we learned a lot about Vietnam thanks to this Museum.Very recommended!
Not so much of interest. Have been there several times for business,But there are other placed which are a must, but not thisSo if you have time and stay in any nearby hotel and its raining, ok

Amazing museum with great displays. This museum tells the story of Vietnam from the women's perspective and it does it very well over 4 floors. We learnt about the different ethnic groups of Vietnam and saw clothing and learnt about the rictual practices around key life events.There was a fascinating display of the women's contribution to the various conflicts that have shaped Vietnam.

Very nice! . If you are interested in vietnamese history of women and theire storys, duties and crafts, this Museum opens a different perspektive. I personally enjoyed seeing different arts and crafts of traditional clothings, and styles of the villages as well as how women served in times of war, how much they were part of it and how strong they were. You can read or listen to storys of vietnamese Women, which shows a beautiful and strong storyline of the past.

An Excellent Idea Inadequately Executed. I was looking forward to this museum immensely, but left disappointed and somewhat irritated. Things start brilliantly with a 10 minute video about the lives of contemporary female street vendors, which gives an insight into the everyday experience of poor women in Vietnam, mostly working to support their husbands, as well as their children. Perhaps it's a misconception on the part of a casual visitor, but it struck me that I saw huge numbers of women diligently working away, and lots of men drinking in cafes and bars, so this part of the exhibition seemed as though it was setting the tone for something not only appraising Vietnamese women's role in shaping their society, but also some level of criticism of gender roles. This hope was short lived, however, as despite what followed having some interesting moments (explanation of marriage arrangements, the immense war contribution), there was very little in the way of challenging what appears to be an extraordinary burden that women fulfil in Vietnam, and a complete absence of the role of men in relation to the ascribed female roles. There was also a puritanical theme, a kind of straight jacketing, that Vietnamese women can only function as support figures for men and the nation, symbolically pure and divine motherly figures, reified through mystical/religious belief. Only towards the very end, is there a brief mention of women in professional roles, and nothing about female involvement in art, literature and music; this small section is somewhat ironically juxtaposed with a much larger exhibition on female fashion and appearance. The seemingly separate art gallery on the top floor makes no sense whatsoever. It could be argued that I've misunderstood the museum and Vietnamese culture, or it's simply not the museum I wanted, but all good museums have some kind of unifying critical theme; the theme of this museum seemed to me be close to celebrating how much Vietnamese women have had to put up with historically, how things aren't really changing despite all their hard work, and - hey - there's no point in complaining because that's just how it is.

Ok if you have an hour or two free. This museum is on multi floors so be prepared for lots of steps. It's 30,000 dong entry & although an audio guide is free at reception, you have to have & leave ID like a passport as security.It's interesting but not sure it's on my 'must see' list. The audio guide is very helpful to explain some of the exhibits but I selectively listened rather than followed every entry. So worth a visit if you are in the area but I would not go out of my way

Best museum In hanoi. Great museum which tells you all about Vietnamese history - get the audio guides (free if you give in id) as they make the museum more interesting by explaining why the objects are important in the museum.
Insightful and well designed. If you are going to the north or coming back from the north, this is a must stop. It will give you a brief but well informed insight on the tribe cultures and more.
The backbone of Vietnam. It is a eye opener when you see how some of these brave women coped during times of great importance and hardship, it is well worth taking the time out to visit this place.

An absolute gem. Easy to walk to and find from the lake, this museum is a great mixture of displays, multimedia films and written materials to give a sense of the huge contribution that women (and girls) have made to this society. It is quite sobering to read their sacrifices, from the war to modern day economic poverty, and life as a modern street vendor in Hanoi. There should be a museum of women in every country.
Interesting. Lovely airy building. Good range of old artefacts, including some that are probably difficult to authenticate, e.g. "the spoon a war hero ate her lunch with". Cute.
Eye opener. Great insight into the roles that women played during the war, and the many tribes and differences in vietnam.Building is just next to the school, and has a cafe before the entrance.

Detailed and modern. This was one of the best museums I visited in Hanoi. It's not always included on the the standard list of touristy locations which may have helped account for how quiet and calm it is. I especially liked the exhibit on the destiny of today's women and the video of women who come from rural villages to sell things in Hanoi. The front desk staff was very helpful but we didn't end up taking them up on the offer of the free audio guides. They asked to hold an ID in exchange which was reasonable in theory but my husband and I weren't going to leave our passports.
Very interesting. Large museum that is well done concerning everything about women 5 or 6 floors dealing with the way Veitnams young people court, marry, have children and live.

The women's museum . A little disappointing but interesting. When I say disappointing its because I was hoping for more. The time period was more modern but after visiting other museums that appears ro be the norm. I would still recommend a stop if you have time. The signs are in English, French, and Vietnamese. It was easy to get to from our hotel in the old quarter. Each floor was a different theme, fashion, war, marriage and children, etc. I found the marriage and child birth floor very interesting. The fashion floor was also fun. I would have liked more info and explanation but maybe that's just me.

Spent an eye-opening few hours here, highly recommended!. A top-notch museum of international standard. Great layout and design. I love the focus on the everyday lives and customs of Vietnamese women, particularly the different tribes. Fascinating and informative. Other levels focus on the Mother Goddess spiritual tradition and the role of women in revolution/war. I was particularly moved by a documentary film I saw playing about the lives/experiences of female street vendors in Hanoi.

Interesting Museum shocasing the role of women in the revolution and life of Vietnam. Visually interesting museum highlighting the role of women in Vietnamese history, Also features an interesting exhibit on the marital rituals of the various minority gtoups and a very special clothing exhibit. Well worth a visit.

Not sure what it's purpose is. Wow! Five floors of.... I'm not sure what. Displays are poorly presented with zero appeal. I think there is a story here, but it's impossible to discern. A total waste of time.
Western standard museum. Intelligently designed museum with good explanations. Especially good for those interested in crafts, costumes, and customs of all the different groups on Vietnam.

Very interesting. Definitely worth a visit. Husband and I found it very informative and interesting. A great FREE audio guide. You hear about customs and tribes, fashions and the role of women in the war. Highly recommend.
A magnificent museum. I visited this museum on my second day in Vietnam. It was a fantastic introduction to the culture, history and social systems. The content was fascinating and very well curated.

Know more about women’s power! Impressive!. Wandering around the lake area and found the museum. very nicely-decorated. well-organized and informative. Got to know more about Vietnamese woman in different ethnic regions. their roles during Vietnam war. I was surprised on how important women is in Vietnam. Very good museum. worth a visit if you’re in Hanoi!

Interesting points of view about Vietnamese women's lives. The entrance fee is 30,000 VND (about $1.50) and is well worth a visit of about an hour. There are 4 floors of exhibits - each with a different theme. You can learn quite a bit about the culture of the country. There is, of, course, some propaganda in the section on the "American War" but it is tolerable and actually interesting.

Great history of wonderful women!. Well worth a visit to the women's museum. Easy to find and full of history of the way women have lived and evolved in Vietnam over hundreds of years, from their daily lives to traditional clothing to their participation in the wars and the strength they bring to their families. Really explains the traditions that women face within the Vietnamese culture. I spent at least an hour there.

Interesting perspective. Interesting perspective over several floors, starting with different ethnic tribes and customs for women starting with marriage, family life, children etc.The floor concerning American/Vietnam war was interesting with personal stories featuring particular women along with the articles featured on display. For myself whilst the view was different the view of war being tough on all was definitely felt. Some of the stories of what the women endured during their fights, espionage etc were not known to me beforehand. I did however feel very unsettled with a little of the glorification (not sure if this is the right word, but I had a bad taste in my mouth)The fashion floor was also interesting, but did seem a bit of an afterthought given the many different topics that would be more relevant to women in Vietnam and elsewhere.

Insights into Vietnamese culture. In my opinion, this museum is an absolute must do when staying in Hanoi. It gives interesting insights into Vietnamese culture and society. Although it focuses onto Vietnam's women, it particularly expresses how much this country strived for independence over the past century. Information is well presented and in good balance to the nicely chosen exhibits. Go for the free audio guide!

Now with audio guide!. This is the most interested I have ever been in a museum. I was kind of hoping for a feminist view and for the content to show me if Vietnamese women are more empowered than women in the rest of the world, which is not really the point of this museum. But it was fascinating anyway. It was kind of like an awesome documentary. I was there on the first day of the audio tour being introduced. It was excellent and really enriched the experience. I doubt a guide would know a quarter of what the audio tour gave me. Last point = critical. It will take you >1 hour for each of the 3 floors. Level 1- Family and culture. Level 2- Women in War. Level 3- Women's fashion. With 2.5 hours I made it exactly halfway. I'm dying to come back to Hanoi now, so I can see more of the War bit. There were ideas presented here that I had no idea about, that hadn't even occurred to me. TOTALLY FANTASTIC MUSEUM. WILL BE INTERESTING TO MANY PEOPLE. GO TO THIS. ALLOW MORE THAN 2.5 HOURS!

A worth while visit. The women's museum has a lot to offer those with a hankering for a view into Vietnam's cultural diversity and woman's part in it.Filled with information in English and French to augment the local Vietnamese, its well presented and insightful.The detail descriptions are for the most part very well thought out and cover enough to give the casual observer concise information and the more studious a taste for continued research. There are even a few hand on exhibits to help get an understanding of how it is to grind grain or carry baskets balanced on shoulders. A must for visitors wanting to get an insight into Vietnamese culture. Its also a quiet haven from the noise of the city.At the time we visited there was a photography display which was also an added bonus.If you have children who are riveted to technology and first world consumables the museum provides a gimps into the world of country Vietnamese kids as well. Some hard work. Little technology, few consumables but beaming happy smiles enjoying the simple things and the joy of family.
