Worth going.. Has great historical information. Nice to look around. There's a floor that is the most interesting, about women war heroes and their stories. Makes you wonder how much is propaganda and how much is real. :)

If you are a women - a must see. If you are a women you will find this museum interesting. The museum has exhibits from Vietnamese women over the ages. In this museum is talks about birth, marriage, clothing and feeding their families. It is a good place to learn about Vietnamese women
Visit To Women's Museum. Very interesting and thought provoking. Four floors of history about women from marriage, clothing, feeding their famillies and the wars. A must

Even my husband loved it. What an incredible insight into the culture of Vietnamese women through the ages. The beautiful women have had tough times and are so resilient and proud. I would go back again.

Informative and interesting insight.. This museum is a wonderful legacy of the history of Vietnamese women and the role they have played in refining the tradition of Vietnam. So well worth a visit and especially the floor dedicated to the history of all women in the Vietnamese War. Very humbling and thought provoking.
Spacious and rich. Each floor is spacious and tells about the rich past of the vietnamese women. The displays about the women who were martyred for their patriotism moved me.

Interesting and well presented!. The museum of women is a rather ‘pleasant situation’ to visit. It gives a diversified oversight of female status in Vietnam throughout the years (marriage, ethnicity, religion & rituals, war contribution, fashion, etc.). It is completely harmless as it is most certainly neither an advocate nor the eyes of waning female rights in VN. One wonders how it could come this far after the strong position women occupied during and shortly after the war. You won’t find the answer here. Moreover, this museum gives well-documented proof and elaborate testimony of woman’s past strong position in society. The ‘art floor’ is rather poor : one would expect happenings to take place. It consists of around 10 paintings by most certainly 1 artist (a lesser Bacon; end September 2015).Overall I would recommend a visit because of the museums interesting and active appearance. After all it’s a museum and not a branch of the feminist movement, but this aspect could be better documented.

Vivid portrayal of the lives and cultutes of Vietnamese women. This recently renovated museum displays unique illustrations of various cultures in Vietnam. The displays show rituals, marriage customs, childbirth and family life, traditional women's clothing. All text is available in Vietnamese, English and French. Very educational and interesting.

Inspiring. Welcomed the air conditioned comfort as we moved through well presented displays and many personal stories of courage, family life, marriage and dress. A real insight into the strength of the Vietnamese women.

Excellent museum!! Beautiful collections and very informative. I spent a little bit more than 2 hours wandering in this very well made museum, the collections are logically displayed and I learnt a lot about the role of women and their contribution to the really interesting Vietnamese culture. Loved the "women in wartime" part - very moving. I would highly recommend!

Excellent museum. Very well designed and curated museum. Exhibits were properly labelled, and there is a nice flow to the exhibits. Good place to learn about the role of Vietnamese women in their society.
Textiles. Excellent exhibits about textiles and traditional clothing of Vietnam's indigenous groups. Overall, a really interesting museum. I would say it's a must-see!

Some well done exhibits. There were some very well done exhibits in this museum, especially the political role of woman. The many photographs of women were particularly compelling and well done. The video documentaries of women who come to Hanoi to make money for their families outside of the City were probably the best exhibits-- the stories of these women were fascinating.
Excellent Museum. Excellent museum. We really enjoyed it and found it very interesting and informative. It took us a few hours to go round. Worth visiting.

Well done . Very interesting and gave me a much better perspective of Vietnamese women and Vietnamese culture as a whole.
There is a nice little cafe outside in the courtyard and a gift shop.
The section on the women's roll in the Vietnam War was the most interesting in my opinion.

Good for a relaxing day . We had a chill out day today on our last day in Hanoi as we were pretty tired from all the sight seeing and we decided to see this museum. I really enjoyed it as an insight into Vietnamese culture - the only downside is it is quite hot inside as the fans/air con doesn't work in all the museum. I would recommend this if you enjoy learning about different cultures.

Great insight into the lives of the hard working women of Vietnam. Great museum that we really enjoyed. Finding our more about the lives of women in Vietnam was truly insightful - especially those poor street vendors. Lovely gift shop too - gotta love a gift shop.

Hidden treasure of Vietnam. Upon visit, you will be amazed of how much Vietnamese women contribute to its nation. The museum has different section at every level. My favourite was the war where it tells brave stories about brave Vietnamese women (from hijacking planes to being a leader of guerilla)This museum is a must visit! Doesn't matter if you are a guy or lady, a visit to this place will definitely leave a mark or two in your heart.

Interesting, worth a visit, lots of information in good written English.. Worth a visit - only takes 1.5 hours - an interesting look at women in local societies (past and present). Included a piece about the female street traders in Hanoi which I found interesting. The visuals weren't stunning, but there's lots of written text in good English and well curated/organised. Worth a visit!

Great museum, lots to see. Modern museum, especially compared to some of the others around Hanoi. Wonderfully air conditioned. Great exhibits, particularly the one on the women street vendors of Hanoi. Must see for Hanoi museum goers!

Excellent museum in central Hanoi. One of the best museums I've seen so far in Hanoi - in terms of the interior design and upkeep, and in terms of content. The museum is centrally located in Hanoi, not far from Hoan Kiem lake, and contains tastefully presented artifacts and explanations of the role of women in Vietnamese culture, past and present. Well worth a visit.

Good ineighbour into Vietnamese lives. Great place to get an insight into the real lives of Vietnamese people. The interview clips with street vendors show you just how hard so many lives are make for sobering viewing. It's surprisingly clear eyed and free from propaganda in this respect.

A wonderful insight to the wonderful women of Vietnam.. Any amount of time in Vietnam leaves you reflecting on the amount of tireless work that women seem to contribute to the countries tourism and economy. If this is something that you have noticed I urge you to take some time to visit this pleasant museum and absorb the history, culture and struggles of the Vietnamese women

Well worth a visit. I'm not a fan of museums but this place is well worth visiting. We didn't have a lot of time so had to rush through the 4 floors of exhibits and stories which was a real shame. I would have love to explore it more leisurely. A nice thing to take home is the DVD of the stories of woman selling fruits/veggies/flowers. It's a very well done short documentary (about 15 mins). You can see it on a rolling video on Level 2 (I think) and available for purchase on the gift shop. I'm sharing this video with family and friends ... it's will serve as a good reminder that we should not complain about how hard our lives are. The following review has everything else I wanted to say about this place. http://www.tripadvisor.co.nz/ShowUserReviews-g293924-d447354-r312063297-Vietnamese_Women_s_Museum-Hanoi.html#REVIEWS
Women's museum . Excellent museum. Great to see how women's roles progressed and how they are progressing. Especially loved the exhibit on women in war, so inspiring.

Fantastic place to get a sense of vietnamese culture. A must-visit museum in Hanoi, much better than others. Really great museum that gives you a real sense of history and culture. Each exhibition is beautifully presented including interactive aspects, wonderful photography and personal pieces. You get a great sense for the varying cultures and the importance of women in vietnam along with what feels like real insight. We only had an hour, two hours would have been better.

Not to be missed. If you have time for one museum only, I would suggest this one (closely followed by Hoa Lo Prison). If you have already noticed how hard women in Vietnam work, this will give you more of an insight into the contribution women have given to the country. It also gives you an insight into various traditions with regards marriage and family, struggles of the women selling fruit and vegetables on their bicycles, not forgetting their enormous contribution toward the war and the role of the Mother Goddess in worship. It's good to see women and their lives being recognised and celebrated. You can whizz round in an hour, or take longer reading more. Museums are not generally as you might find in the Western world with hands on activities for children, all in all considering others, it is worth a visit as the information you will glean, you won't be able to find on one site on the internet. The shop generally has interesting items for sale.
Local culture!. The staff were immensely helpful in explaining the works to us! Very delightful in understanding the local culture.

An interesting way to spend an hour or so. Some friends and I kind of stumbled on this place whilst exploring the City. It looks visually appealing from outside and is just as cool and modern on the inside. My friends were two women, who whilst I champion equality as much as the next person, I'd say probably got a lot more out of it than I did. I always like to be fair in reviews, so I think for me, I felt tired and just wanted to find some nice air conditioning from the consistent punishing Vietnamese humidity, so I didn't maybe get as much from it as I possibly could have done. That said, they have some really interesting exhibitions in there and I'd certainly go back to fully take in and appreciate what the museum was conveying.

Interesting stop . This place gives good insight into women in Vietnam, and let me just say that Vietnamese women are some of the most amazing I have ever met! This place really helps capture how hard working, determined and selfless the women of Vietnam are through the ages, a really interesting place to stop

Wonderful Women's Museum. My sister and I loved this Museum. It's really well organised and the fashion and textiles are presented really well. Great to learn about the women's integral role in the war. Loved all of the propaganda posters

Highlights the important roles women play in Vietnam. Before coming to this museum I had no idea how important of a role women played in Vietnamese society, especially during the war! It was amazing to learn about the women of Vietnam and their culture. Personally I think it's brilliant that they celebrate women like this and show appreciation for their hard work during the war. The museum offers displays of traditional clothes and artifacts, as well as a small art gallery on the top floor. The Vietnamese Women's Museum should be on everyone's must-see list when visiting Hanoi.

Finding the our Origin. The Museum divide into 3 level which allow us to view different history of women's in Vietnam and displaying their costume and their tradition. Sending a message the Important role of a women's in a family and portrait strong character holding the family and country together. With the help of the Audio visual showing how they performs the wedding ceremonies and I was surprise that we share the same tradition. Their costume and how things were conducted.

A must see in Hanoi. Initially, I was not too excited to go to the women's museum in Hanoi, but my wife and daughters insisted. Also the hotel staff strongly recommended going there. Once arrived we got in for a very small fee. It is a very nice museum, 4 floors high. Each floor shows the impact women have had in the history of Vietnam, and also today, with a focus on a different area. From fashion, to war heroes, to family life. I was impressed by it all.

Well done museum. Not too much information so it was not overwhelming but very interesting. Of course it is to take with some cynicism because of the context but all the videos of current women working in Hanoi were great and seemed very genuine. Well done museum and I would recommend it (takes about 1h).

Strong women celebrated. So good to see the very strong women of the lovely country celebrated in this way. Very informative on many aspects of life both past and present and the culture and rituals they observe. I was very moved by the stories of the roles women played during the many struggles for independence. Well worth a visit.

Interesting and well set up. This museum is anyhow interesting. The set up, the short videos, the foto's all of it is set up in a nice way and very informative. It puts a lot of the culture in its perspective and makes you very aware of the history around the positioning of women in the society of Vietnam.

Essential Resource for Learning about Women in Vietnam. This museum provides very good background for anyone interested in the current situation and history of women in Vietnam. Highlights include very colorful traditional dress of ethnic groups and artifacts from home and work associated with women. Although there are photos and displays documenting the role of women in the war with the U.S., it was disappointing to see very little representation of current efforts of Vietnamese women working for peace. A special current exhibition is "Worshipping Mother Goddess" which includes an actual altar used in Mother Goddess Worship and oral accounts of the meaning of worship for common people. An inexpensive catalog for the exhibition is available in English.

Okay for a visit. Perhaps I have a automatic feeling of boredom when I see the word museum. I followed many peoples advice and took the visit to this museum. Luckily, it was one of the places I got to visit with my Vietnam volunteer and therefore I learnt more than I would have if alone. Perhaps that's the secret to this museum, go with someone who is highly knowledgeable.

thought provoking. I found the museum very thought provoking .. as the role of women always is when viewed in isolation. Their role in war is all too often understated or unrecognized … so it is refreshing, at this museum, to see a record of their sacrifice during the French and American wars on display .. albeit, without a doubt, still being but a minute sample of their boundless commitment.
excellent. So interesting and inspiringA must visit attraction to visit in HanoiGreat gift shop tooInteractive displays

Worth the Walk. We walked down from the old quarter (about 20 minutes), found the museum without too much difficulty. The museum provides a good historical background to the role of women in Vietnam; I found their role during the Vietnam war very interesting as well as a better understanding for all the women hawkers in Hanoi. Sure the museum could do with a makeover but the entry fee is only $1 and it has some really good information and audio-visual displays.

Could have been better. The museum facility is capable of housing a much bigger display featuring the contributions of the woman of Vietnam. What I did take away from this is the fact that the woman of Vietnam have contributed greatly from the very beginning. A few of the political prisoners under the French rule went on to help found the Vietnam of today. The gift shop and Art Gallery offer some additional insights into the woman of this wonderful country!
Women's Museum worth a visit. You could easily spend 2 hours in here - lovely costumes - beautiful embroidery, good cultural information

Not Interesting women musuem. It was very empty when we went there and we were there for maybe an hour touring all the floors looking at the musuem. Not much to look at or learn as why point out the obvious that the pesky women peddlers on the street selling their wares and foods on bicycle or caring it on their basket are doing it because their family is very poor. However what they forget to mention the Vietnamese are also constantly harassing tourists walking past and this is very annoying.Overall I did find the musuem boring and having to pay 60,000 dong for two if us is not worth my visit

Empowering. Having it been overly exacerbated over TripAdvisor and such a unique critea for a museum we decided to go. Its also empowering that they do understand woman play a equal part in society or even more soGranted that its not the greatest museum I have been in, with the museum starting on the top floor and working down. I still felt as if it has its own beauty. It was a bit pricy to enter and it was also very stuffy inside in some places. The displays were very modern however theres a lot of information to take it, its very interesting to see the things they present in this museum. I learnt a lot (this may be niave because I went in not knowing a thing about Vietnamese cutlure and people) especially about the hawker ladies and the marriage and child birth culture. I liked the interactive basket holding, a very good touristic photo to snap up. I liked the videos they showed on each floor as well, although the headphones could do with updating. I overall really liked my visit.

Nothing spectacular . This museum is all about Vietnamese women, of course: their marriage and birthing traditions, their fashion, their various ethnicities, and their contributions to society, mostly during the Vietnam war. The size of the building is medium, so a thorough visit should take about 1 hour.

Fabulous. What a great museum. 5 levels of family, community, artistry, religion and heros! There are descriptions in english and the historic relevance is excellent. A great little shop, the only thing that would make it better is a guidebook to take away.

Story of Vietnamese Women. Vietnamese women seem to be lot more hard working than men (in our exp on the trip) and this museum was nice little exp for us. This and the Ethnology museum are a must see if you are in Ha noi.

Remarkable insights into family life. Of the many museums and monuments I visited in Hanoi, this felt the least like propaganda. There was so much to see -- I spent more than 2 hours wandering through the exhibits but could easily have spent more time.The museum is divided into several thematic areas: family/reproduction; work (primarily domestic/agricultural); religion; contributions to war/liberation; fashion. Most displays had vivid descriptions in three languages, though the fashion exhibit was just an assortment of costumes/clothing. (On the top floor there was an "art" exhibit set up but there really wasn't much to see and this can easily be skipped.)I hope that the museum continues to be updated -- if I make it back to Hanoi I plan to visit again!

Worth a look. Having visited the museum this gave me a different out look on the women who sell on the streets, I now ask a few questions about them and there family life before I buy any thing or bargin with them.And this is from a mans veiw

Don't miss!. I thought that this was an excellent museum. Great display in English and French which tells not only the traditional way of living from a womam's perspective but also shows the great role that women played in both the war for independence from France and the Vietnam-American war. Where are all the women's museums in other countries?! Well done Vietnam!

A great museum, the best in Hanoi. We went as a family and loved this museum, it was really informative and moving. Don't miss the video about the street sellers, it'll make your visit to Vietnam more rewarding.

Very interesting!. This museum is quite extensive, and covers everything from marriage to fashion to women in war. We spent a couple of hours in there and found it very interesting - worth the money! We were recommended this by a friend who lives there as one of the museums really worth the money to visit if only spending a short time in Hanoi.
Well worth the visit. very sad to read and see history of what these women endured but interesting, not a big museum so only need 1 hour to visit ,

The strength of Vietnamese women is amazing.. What a hard time so many Vietnamese women still have today. Made me look at the street seller women rather differently on the way back to my hotel. Lots of interesting displays, well presented and yes, it all made me feel quite humble.

A place that made me feel humble and so lucky with where I was born. A great snapshot of the unsung heroes of Vietnams growth, if this place doesnt bring a tear to your eye you are probably dead. Just go

Excellent Overview of Experiences of Vietnamese Women. I came here on a recommendation of a friend and because I was seeking a air conditioned place to hide one hot afternoon in Hanoi.This museum is small and spartan but does have a voice. There are exhibits on basic aspects of life for women: birth, marriage, family. They do a good job and highlighting different ethnic groups experiences throughout Vietnam. There was a short video section highlighting women street vendors and there lives that made look at every fruit and flower station differently. A while section was dedicated to women who were of service to the communist cause during the recent wars, which was fascinating read about particularly because it is presented from a very specific viewpoint. The roving exhibit was focused on Mother Earth worship and that ritual and tradition. I especially appreciated this not just because it was interesting but also because it's something I would have known nothing about if I hadn't visited there. I will say that the information provided could have been fleshed out more.Overall I am really supportive of what they are trying to do through this facility and are on their way. It's definitely worth a short trip if you think you are at all interested. There is some content that is unavailable in English, but the French translations were more comprehensive.

Women's Museum shows Vietnamese women courage and strong will. Women museum highlights the women contributions to Vietnam's struggle for independence and reunification. Women are part of the country's economic backbone.

Many irrelevant exhibitions. I dont know why women need a museum? Why there isnt any museum for man? The facilities are really good, modern and clean and well taken care of. They have lots of events but many of them quite irrelevent to "women", more like contemporary exhibition.

One of the best museums in Vietnam. This is easily the best if not one of the best museums in Vietnam. It talks a lot about the culture and traditions of the different ethnic groups and highlights the accomplishments of women. The commentary is stellar and does not usually have grammar errors. It is incredibly educational and eye-opening.

Rural women heroines. Phew after going here I am looking at the ladies selling their wares in the city. I will never again complain about my lot in life without being pulled up by my conscience in thinking about what the Vietnamese have been through. Now these are what I call WOMEN.

A must see for all women. A great museum with a lot of history a must see even if it is to get out of the gear for a short while. This museum displays all the strengths that the Vietnamese woman have shown from the 40's to present
Basic but good and worth a visit. The museum is very basic but still good. Worth visiting. Found particularly interesting the part about women-street vendors, they are amazing hard working women.

Just something to pass the time with . The museum is great in a sense that it shows how the country appreciates their women. They really celebrate women in general as well as the women in their history. You learn a lot about the family culture as well as their customs and traditions. You also get to learn a little about the women of war (there's quite a few that will impress you) and you can see some of those familiar faces you saw in Hoa La Prison (if you pay attention to the pictures of the women prisoners). Then I got bored after the "women in history" level.
hill tribe costumes + traditions. Great ethnic and cultural info on history, customs and crafts of women, families in Vietnam. Good cafe in the courtyard to rest the tired feet.

small but effective. At an first view you think; "What do I do here? " Patience and some interest will give a an unique view of women in the history of Vietnam. Do ask to open the musuem shop. They sell magnific hand woven shawls.
Excellent museum. Really good museum, well laid out and very interesting perspective on life in Vietnam. Brilliant! All signs and explanations were written in Vietnamese, English and French.

Uneventful . Visited this museum as it was recommended on trip advisor but to be honest it was pretty boring and we much preferred the other attractions around! This is of course just a personal opinion!

Put it on your list. This is a very interesting museum featuring insights into the cultural aspects of the various tribal women as well as a floor dedicated to the significant role women played in the Vietnam War, which was quite fascinating. The video on the street sellers is a must. All in all, the museum paints a picture of how strong the women of Vietnam are and have been, in supporting their families and the nation.

Good value and interesting displays!. This museum is very well thought through and spacious. I wasn't sure what to expect but the displays include women in history, Vietnamese wedding traditions and fashion (and many more).All of the displays have lots to look at with very good English information.
Vietnamese Women. A thought provoking display of great achievements by Vietnamese women , mostly during the wars. Quite humbling and very interesting.
My favorite Museum in Vietnam!. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum and the variety of information and displays. It took us over an hour to get round and it was great value.

Great museum!. We enjoyed visiting the women Museum in Hanoi. The museum is recently updated and has some very interesting exhibitions. We especially enjoyed the one about women role during war-time. You get a lot of respect for the vietnamese women, and their pride and power. A great visit when you arrive in Hanoi, as it will give you some insight to the lives of the women you see in the city. Very interesting experience.
Worth a visit. Spent a nice morning here exploring the many well put together exhibits on marriage, pregnancy, fashion, and women heroes.

Highly informative. Highly informative and educational museum. The 4 storey museum shows the history, daily life of women in Vietnamese society. It also gives a good overview of life style of the minorities. One of the 4 floors is mainly propaganda about the role of women in the Vietnam war, bein overly glorifying and political.

Very interesting museum. Very interesting museum. all about ethnic culture and vietnamese tradition connected to women. Many Costumes, photos, good explanations, religion and cults and many many other interesting info and objects.
Amasing woman. A very interesting museum, four levels of culture , costumes , food . Marriage and how women engaged the the Vietnam war.

Very interesting and informative!. I found this place very interesting!! I have learned a lot here about the culture, the war and the life in general in Vietnam. Of course like most museums, you gotta take your time and read the information, not just look at pictures. If you are after an interactive sort of museum, not for you. If you enjoy reading and learning about a new culture, totally for you. :)

Great museum with some cool pictures and artifacts. I spent at least 4 hours in that museum. I enjoyed all the pictures and artifacts and explanation in English. A few of the pictures I can still picture i my head, they made such an impression on me. Really worth a visit.

Better than average and worth a visit. Unlike quite a few "museums" in Vietnam, this one is well worth a visit. During our visit it covered three floors with three exhibits: women's costumes covering the dress of many minority communities, women at war (the most interesting exhibit) and women in the family. Items on display have reasonable descriptions and certainly better than those of some other Vietnamese museums. If you can find a reliable guide to take you around it would probably be worth it.

Women's Museum. This newly renovated museum boasts lots of nice artifacts and information that is well documented and arranged. Information was very clear and precise, and the layout of the items was open and uncluttered. The lighting in the building was also great and gave me a very good impression as I walked through all the exhibits,
Insight into the women of Han oi. Excellent displays and good gift shop. Beautiful costumes and particularly enjoyed the video about the street vendors.

Well presented and informative museum.. Impressive collection of stuff about women's contribution to the Vietnamese society. It seems that they have been quite busy and have worked hard - Well that's what it shows here (with a little help from the fellas)?

Insights into Vietnam's Women's Lives in the last 60 years.. I visited with my mom, so two very different generations. We enjoyed learning about modern women's lives in Vietnam, women during the war of resistance, and women's fashion. The information on various wedding traditions was very interesting, too. Great museum to escape the heat and crowds for a while!

Okay museum. I really like museums and I was super excited to see one all about women and everything we have done to contribute to society.This was a great museum that showed how Vietnamese women helped not only their families but also their country to survive. I gave it an average rating becuase some of the descriptions about he culture lacked detailed. They would say something existed and then not explain the history. E.g blacking their teeth. The museum showed pictures of it and gave about 1 paragraph on it. Seeing how this goes vastly against other and presented cultures I thought they would have touched on the health of it, the fashion, how it started and how long it takes. Other than things like that it was a decent museum.
Much more interesting than it may sound. Well worth the visit , gives an amazing insight into the lives of Vietnams women , they certainly are the back bone of the country .

Unique museum about vietnamese women in Hanoi. This museum give a large window about vietnamese women. I'm young and happy to know how my mother ' s life in past. I like the art gallery of female artist in the top floor of this museum. Must to visit in Ha noi.

Excellent. I found this museum to be very interesting and could have easily spent longer than the two and a half hours we had there before closing time.Much to my surprise my husband loved it too, there is something for everyone here and we both came out with a renewed admiration for the women of Vietnam.
It's highly recommended to visit. The museum displays with variety of images of Vietnamese women in their daily life. I like most the modern order of the photos and its art.

Well worth a visit. Well put together museum. One of the more interesting things to do in Hanoi. It helps to explain the minority groups' cultures and appeals to all senses. There are some great videos to watch also.

Real dedication to women in Vietnam !. I really enjoyed it ! Each floor is dedicated to Women in Vietnam : Ethnic Group, Women in Everyday Life and Women during the Vietnam War. The explanations in each floors are perfect, I really enjoyed this museum and how it was dedicated to women !

Good but not the best museum I've seen. I expected a whole lot of this museum but it wasn't one of the best museums I've seen. There's a big variety of exhibitions and it's an educational and nice place to visit though..

Impressive. One of the floor is dedicated to the women in wars. It was really impressive to see how young some of them were and what they did. You can see artefacts they were using. Another floor is dedicated to fashion, all of the technics they use to weave, dye and knit the fabric they use to make traditional clothes. Very beautiful!

Interesting place to spend a few hours. Well signed museum with exhibits on family life, marriage, textiles and female folk beliefs. Surprising find in Vietnam. Wouldn't say it's a must see especially if you have limited time and it's your first visit to Hanoi but for returning travellers it's a place worthy of your time.
Beautiful exhibition. We've spent almost two hours in this museum. It's a great way to learn about the traditional lives of women in Vietnam. A colourful exhibition!

A bit boring.... We decided to go here one afternoon since it had gotten pretty good reviews in our tour book. There were a lot of exhibits of women's costumes throughout different periods of time. I found it a bit boring. If going, you would definitely not want to make it your main attraction of the day.

Women warriors and weavers. This museum gives a window into the history of Vietnamese women, their courage and strength through war, marriage, and traditional values. Upstairs - at the top - is a contemporary art exhibit. The gallery shop downstairs sells great handmade items and postcards.

Best Exhibits in Hanoi. This Museum has excellent exhibits and provides fascinating stories about Vietnamese women. The role of women during conflict is well explored and female heroes over the past 100 years is well documented.
Great museum and very informative. Also cover the Muong women.. Spent haft day here and really enjoyed it. Lots of details about daily activities of Vietnamese woman from all aspects.

Empowering as a women, Surprising as a man, Respectful as a country.. You will never truly know Vietnam or its people until you visit this Museum. Honouring the contribution of the women of Vietnam and providing insight into the backbone they our in Vietnamese culture, a must visit for any traveller to Hanoi or the north of Vietnam.

Informative and very interesting look at the traditional and historic life and input of women in ?Vietnam.. Several floors of fascinating information and artefacts about the lives of women. Located close to the lake in the old quarter of Hanoi and only a small entrance fee to pay.

Impressive musuem honouring women's contribution in Vietnam. Quite an impressive museum detailing the status of women in Vietnamese society, particularly their roles as home-makers & their contribution during the war. Go there as part of your walk through the Old Quarter; it is easily located.

Excellent museum. This shows how formidable Vietnamese women have been and still are in how they work, provide for their families and have fought for their country. The displays are well put together showing cultural differences between the ethnic tribes in marriage, clothing, spirituality, handicrafts, raising families and more. The art on the top floor was not my personal taste but the space is excellent as a gallery. The gift shop has beautiful handicrafts at reasonable prices. Worth a visit.

Surpirsingly different experience. This is definitely one of the better museums in Hanoi, and a good spot even for non-museum goers. The exhibits are well-thought out and offer interesting insights. Very modern look & feel too. Be sure to visit the Printopia shop next door for some sweet swags.

Unexpected. What an unexpected surprise,the exhibits were well presented and english translations very good and the detail of the lives of the women of many minority groups were covered in great detail. We were particularly impressed by the many sacrifices as well as the roles undertaken by the women in Vietnams long struggle for the right to control its own destiny.This museum should be one all visitors to Hanoi should visit.

Great place to learn. This museum is housed in a more modern complex than many Vietnamese museums. Although this might be not as characterful as many, this does mean the AC is very good. Even more importantly, this museum is very well laid out and interesting, and provides a valuable perspective on Vietnamese history and society. Well worth a look.

Surprisingly interesting. Though we're not huge museum goers, the Women's Museum ended up being one of our favorite spots in Hanoi. The exposes on the culture (dress, wedding customs, etc.) of the various minorities of Vietnam was extremely well done and documented--English speakers will have a very easy time in the museum without a guide. The one downside is that this is one of the pricer museums in Hanoi (though by no stretch expensive).This spot is a nice break from the sun after Hoa Lo--the AC is extremely powerful here!

Interesting Portrayal. The women's museum is interesting and shows the development of Vietnamese women over the years as well as the stages in their lives. The war heroes section is good. However this museum can be skipped if you are in a hurry.

Insightful and comprehensive look at role of women in Vietnamese history. We decided to stop in this Museum on the way back from La Maison Centrale and lunch at Quan An Ngon. As in most places, the entry fee was minimal and the stop well-worth it. The museum is small (less than an hour.. depending on your speed) but very visual and informative. We were especially impressed by a video on the 2nd floor about female street vendors. It was eye-opening. Several of these women were interviewed, their hardships brought to light. I truly think it's something that visitors to Vietnam should see, particularly because there are female street vendors all over the country. It definitely made me respect them and their hard work even more.

Realy worth a visit. Women's museum will bring home to the struggle that women in Vietnam have had. The American War displays and stories were incredible. Quite hard to find as it is not obvious even though it is a huge building.

Interesting - definitely worth a visit. My mum and I visited the museum in the morning on a Monday. The ticket price of 30k was well worth it, and we spent over 2 hours exploring the place. There's lots of information, clearly divided up by categories with videos, text and items on display. The only con about the museum was that there were videos translated only into french, or only into English. My basic french got me through the french only videos, but if you had no knowledge of it you might struggle to access all of the displays. Having said that, the fact that almost everything is tri-lingual is amazing.

Great celebration of Vietnamese women and ethnic designs. Fantastic museum which explains the role of women in Vietnamese social-history and also gives excellent explanations about the social practices and craft skills/designs of some of the 54 ethnic groups. Great museum shop too - selling very reasonably priced examples of some of their hand-crafted design work. Loved it and spent 3 happy hours there!

A bit of history to enjoy. On a lark, my wife and I stopped by on a whim and discovered a very well planned and interesting look at the fascinating involvement women have had in the life of Viet Nam. Well worth an hour or so to investigate the levels from bottom to top. When finish stop by the cafe on the campus and enjoy an ice cream dish.

Amazing museum, must to see when you come to Hanoi, Vietnam. The Vietnamese Women's Museum is a beautiful and interested museum. You can get more information and acknowledgment of women's role in our life. I feel my life more meaningful and love my mother and grandmother more, appreciate them... in short, I will come back here to learn more about culture and Vietnamese religion.

The best museum I've ever been to. Such a fantastic museum, a fascinating insight into Vietnamese culture and history. The floors talking about women's role in the war was so interesting, as well as all the information about matrilineal societies. Also some incredibly moving pieces about women's lives in Hanoi today, so worth a visit.

Well worth a visit, and highlights the important role of women in Vietnam. Particularly looks at the involvement of women n the Vietnam war, and the struggles and sacrifices hey made, some of the women's stories were really nteresting

A Must to See. We weren't sure what was involved but by the time we left we were left in awe of the woman of Vietnam. This museum covers the lives of the women. The woman featured heavily in the war and the stories will leave you very surprised. A Must see when you are in Hanoi

A salute to women!. The Hanoi women's museum is a beautiful acknowledgment of women's contribution to Vietnams history. It highlights women's roles as mothers, farmers, wives, soldiers, political activists etc. There are beautiful displays of traditional costumes, work implements, head gear and photos. Highly recommended.

Learn about culture, religion and listen to personal stories. This is the only major museum I've been able to visit in Vietnam so far, but I found it really interesting to learn more about the various cultures around the country. There are over 50 ethnic groups in the country, and the marriage and pregnancy exhibit explained a lot of the different customs (with clothing and artifact displays) which I really enjoyed. They also show video interviews with female street sellers who have left their homes and families to sell in Hanoi, and have a nice exhibit about Vietnamese religious beliefs. The war exhibit was fairly propagandistic, but that's to be expected.

Loads of information!. The museum is in the city of Hanoi. Boasting loads of information about the roles of vietnamese women throughout the times from their roles to diet to attire and most importantly their contribution. A great place to learn.

Honoring of all women. I can't believe that we almost missed this place! It was on a whim that we decided to go after seeing a blurb about the museum. We were SO happy to have not missed it! The museum is well appointed and the information in English is really exceptional. From honoring women as mothers, to soldiers, to artisans and the multiple ethnic groups in the country, there is so much to learn about the culture and history. You have to like history, not get miffed about the obvious communist propaganda that gets thrown in (what do you expect?) and be open to taking your time to learn about the people of this country. I've never been to a museum that was so honoring to women. I especially loved getting to see the many traditional costumes that have been collected from all over the country. The clothing is beautifully displayed and you can see the details of each piece. A real score if you enjoy looking at clothing design. The museum is old, it doesn't have any bells and whistles, the rooms are HOT and there is no air conditioning, so come with water and a fan! Vietnam is a poor country but it has done a great job giving its women the attention and dignity that they deserve.

Lots to Learn. There is a lot in this museum. I learned a lot of history and I think it reveals a lot of culture, especially from rural areas of Vietnam that tourists may not get to see as easily. Children may not enjoy it as much though.

History of women. This is a history of Vietnamese women through early childhood, engagement, marriage, children and the heroines of the battles and wars of their country.
Good array of artefacts and costumes and lots of photos.
We enjoyed the museum and recommend it to visit.

Worth a look but not mind-blowing. Some points of interest but got a bit repetitive. Could do with more multimedia presentations. A bit too much propaganda in the war part. Most interesting part was watching the videos of the street vendors and their struggle to support their families. Interesting clothes section from minority cultures too.
Good Historical and Cultural info. Visited the museum with some Vietnamese friends. Great information on Vietnamese culture. Spare 2-3 hours.

Not to miss. This is a good museum, but I was surprised that it wasn't more. Can't really pin down why, but I was a bit disappointed in the exhibits. It is the only place we visited that seemed to be directed more at western visitors than Vietnamese. I guess I expected more on strong, political, women and was surprised by the focus on dress and marriage. Just a personal reaction - but definitely go!

Very interesting, modern museum - not just for women!. Over 4 floors of well laid out exhibits, this modern feeling museum shows women's roles, societal contributions (including the war), customs and familial relationships. Not just for women - husband and 10 year old son thought it was very good also!

Enjoyable time. Very spacious, clean, and large museum to explore. Lots of photos and articles to see. Signs also in English so it was an easy self guided tour. Very inexpensive...around $2 US. Well worth it.

So interesting.....and the clothes..... OK- let's talk about the whole floor devoted to fashion. It was amazing and interesting.Each floor is divided up into a different category like fashion, marriage, women in history, etc....Then there are special exhibits. The top floor is suppose to be modern art but it feels a little bare. However, that is my biggest complaint. Of course there can always be more. That is probably why the building next to the museum is under construction for an expansion.But even without the expansion, the museum is interesting and educational. Definitely check it out!!!

A don't miss while in Hanoi.... I have always admired Vietnamese women, but this museum will give you an in depth view of the role they play in Vietnam. Out of all the museums in Hanoi...this is at the top.

I learned a lot. This museum showed a very real and interesting side of the women living in Vietnam. What I found most interesting was the stories that the women that go around with their stalls told. How they have travel to one of the bigger city to earn money.It was also very interesting to see all the faces of the different groups of people living in Vietnam.

Interesting museum. Beautiful clothing displays and interesting insights into the role of women in various tribes. The video documentaries of street sellers are well worth watching. You might find yourself buying fruit from them more often after your visit.

Intresting view on the History of Vietnam. While a number of the displays did look at the Vietnam war there was a huge variety of attractions including how women have helped develop the current Vietnam. It was great to get a more encompassing view of women in Vietnam society.

Must visit for museum lovers. My favourite museum in Hanoi. Well laid out, with plenty of interesting information in English, and a great combination of content (videos, displays, artifacts, artwork etc).
Interesting!. Very interesting to learn a lot about the position of women through time. Takes about two hours to walk around, going through different stages of human history.
The Women's museum is fab. Brilliant introduction to the female experience in Vietnam, the information about the women's involvement during the wars was particularly eye opening.
Most interesting. Was not sure what to expect but found it very interesting. Most thing are written in Vietnamese but, guide spoke pretty good english.
Women history. Women museum where you can see a lot of traditional vietnamese dress. Very memorable place and a lot of emotions.

Very Interesting. I didn't know what to expect but I was very surprised. This was very interesting as the womens role in Vietnam is not like others. I was really interested to see that they played a huge part in the Vietnam war and that a lot of women played in a combat oriented role. A lot became leaders of guerrilla groups and just as renowned as some of the great male fighters. Such an eye-opener. I was also interested to read the more traditional role of women in Vietnam, I guessed I just loved the fact they were compelled to go from family caretaker to warrior.

Gave us a great understanding. Wow, this is the place to visit to get a better understanding of what life is like for a Vietnamese woman. Myself and my boyfriend are in awe of how hard working and dignified these women are. If in Hanoi I would recommend a visit to this museum as it is a great learning experience and makes you appreciate how wonderful the women from here are.

Interesting..... We walked around the museum for about an hour and found it interesting but it was more a collection of items which in some cases did not really tell a story you can identify yourself with. It is somehow missing "soul". I am sure there must be an set designer who can make this into an interesting exhibition with a proper flow. I would still recommend a visit, the place is cool and interesting enough for what you pay. The top floor "art expo".........?! Where my husband could not even stand up straight.........was a bit of a joke.Which is a pity.....The last should give you an impressive feeling.
Underwhelming. My wife and I went to this museum with high expectations, but weren't really blown away by anything there. Everything seemed sort of standard.

Dull. Firstly, this museum allegedly underwent an extensive renovation recently. But you wouldn't know it. Fittings are old and broken, some parts don't have air conditioning. There are many exhibits relating to women in Vietnam, mostly about hill tribe ceremonies and the various minor deeds and artifacts of women who fought for the Viet Cong in the war. If you like seeing milk powder sachets or the shoes of some female martyr, then this is the museum for you! All others, this place is boring, stiflingly hot, and indecipherable.

Don't miss this. We could have spent half a day here and still not taken it all in. I would highly recommend it this museum. It gives you a fascinating history of Vietnamese women from warfare to modern fashion. What extraordinary people they are! The street vendor display and video is a must see - if ever you've been a little annoyed at being approached so constantly, this will give you pause to reflect on the hardships these women endure to make ends meet. We may not buy but we can always be polite to them. The marriage and family exhibits are extensive and something really enjoyable to linger over. Do visit this place if you are ever in Hanoi.

Very modern set-up and very interesting!. It is highly recommended to visit. The museum is in the center of the city. It takes 5-10 minutes by taxi from the First Hotel. It is well set-up and provide sound information about the history and development of the Vietnmaese women. It is hopefully one of the most frequently location which is visited by tourists and reseachers.

Expected more..... Vietnamese women are what keep this country going. They are strong, beautiful, and the real backbone of Vietnam. They do so much for their country. To me, this museum didn't convey that message. For $1 USD you can spend a couple of hours viewing Vietnamese fashion through the ages, reading stories of wedding and birthing traditions, as well as see some informative videos on life in the city. Worth it, yes. But I think the museum owes more credit to the women of Vietnam.

Highlight. I spent hours here and very much enjoyed it. Everything is organised and offers interesting insights to the vietnamese women, from vendors to women during the war. Mixed feeling and I cried while watching a documentary. Definitely worth a visit.

A great museum in Hanoi. This was recommended to us by the Sofitel concierge staff and we very much enjoyed it. It is on 4 floors all of which are a/c and covers the story and nature of woman and family in Vietnam. The costumes and artifacts are beautiful.

An Enjoyable Museum with Some Standout Exhibits. We squeezed in a visit to the Vietnamese Women's Museum about 45 minutes before closing. Therefore we were not able to spend as much time as we would have liked in all of the exhibits. We particularly liked the exhibit on marriage and family life. Our favorite part of the museum was the video of street vendors talking about their experiences. We were a little disappointed in the limited information about contemporary women's lives. The historical exhibit was also primarily focused on women during the war. Despite our mixed impressions of the various exhibits the museum was very enjoyable and well worth visiting.

Fantastic Insights to Vietnamese Women. This museum stands out in what it promises to show. The museum is modern and nicely done, the air-conditioners do help in the summer of Hanoi and the place offers interesting insights to the vietnamese women. The different floors have various themes and all are very well done with nice bit of details mentioned. We really liked the section on family and costumes of various ethnic tribes.

Definitely worthwhile . Spent about an hour here and could have definitely spent longer if I had more time. The museum is clean, professional and well thought out unlike a lot of other museums I have been to in Vietnam. Women within a family and the fashion levels were my two favourites. I didn't come out as inspired as I thought I would but did come out wanting to learn more and being more fascinated in Vietnamese textiles.
Gun on back while farming. Although the air condition is bad and make your sweating. The exhibited works are worth seeing. You will learn how women in Vietnam are fighting for their city in war time.

Great history. Great history section in this museum covering women heroines in both the French and American wars. Great overview of women's contribution to all aspects of Vietnamese life, including the minority groups.

Great way to learn a little more about Vietnamese culture. I spent a few hours here, if you don't have that much time to spare I'd suggest picking just one or two levels to do rather than rush them all.Great displays, won't need an English speaking guide as you will learn plenty just reading from the exhibits. Not very interactive but colourful and plenty of display materials donated by women.

Great museum in Hanoi. Definitely one of the best museums I've visited in Vietnam. Very well out together and interesting to understand the role of women in Vietnam's history. A great way to spend a couple of hours and bonus: t has air con!Be sure to watch the video playing on the second floor. It has heartbreaking stories of the women vendors in Hanoi. Its a must see.

Choose this museum. We visited the women's museum with the Hanoi Kids English club on a very hot day. I was happy to visit this museum rather than some of the other attractions in Hanoi due to the heat and a couple of members of the family were feeling a little worse for wear so a slightly easier day was order. Again, like most Vietnamese museums, the entry price was negligible. There were free lockers provided which was fantastic - most venues in Sydney charge for lockers so that was a welcome change. The museum itself provided us with a decent insight into vietnamese life, not just for women but for people in general. My favourite exhibit was the wedding exhibit which showed rituals around traditional marriage processes and ceremonies for the various ethnic groups within the country. This revealed a lot that I hadn't already understood. I also liked the exhibit describing the work of women and the lives that they lead around earning money for the family. We all marvelled that so many women leave their families for weeks at a time to come to the big cities to sell wares for a few weeks at a time before returning to their homes to see their children. What a different life they lead! And how good for my own kids to see this! Finally, I was moved by impact of war exhibit that showed mothers who had lost multiple sons and/or their husbands in the war. One woman had lost 10 members of the family! How could you not be affected by that??

Didn't work.... I went in to this museum with an open mind only to be hugely disappointed. The three levels of the museum are split into marriage, giving birth and fashion. Hardly a fair representation of a whole gender and made worse by the limited exhibits and sometimes non existent explanations. There is an interesting ten minute video on the street vendors of Hanoi and the war exhibit is interesting but falls short on actual related exhibits and artefacts. In comparison to the other museums in Hanoi this one falls very very far short.

Really worth it. It can take half a day or a full day. You'l notice that woomen in Vietnam have been associated with the course of the history and that they have played major rôles in all the conflicts. Also, woomen play a major rôle in everydays'life
Informative and air-conditioned. Enjoyed wandering through looking at the artifacts and stories of Vietnamese women. Much needed temperature as outside 39 degrees.

Interesting but long. Museum was great to do during the middle of the day when it was too hot to be outside. Was a great insight into the women of Vietnam. We found it too factual with a lot of information to read on everything. Could improve with more interactive videos or things to do

"Wow". I loved this museum! It wasn't a museum about the achievements of individual women but showed the daily life of the Vietnamese woman in different parts of Vietnam. It opened my eyes and gave me a great appreciation for Vietnamese Women!
Informative & colourful. Loved the exhibition on women revolutionaries and the video of women street vendors stories. Well worth a visit

Insightful. Found this museum to be very interesting and great to see they have catered for English speaking tourists, with all information including a translation. The day we were there the place was pretty much deserted and unfortunately, the air-conditioning was not working in some areas making it very warm and stuffy. Overall, worth a visit if only to learn more about the Vietnamese women and their daily lives.

Interesting Way to Spend an Hour or Two. The museum overall has a good layout, good displays and some of the stories about women during the war time are very interesting, overall a good way to spend a couple of hours in Hanoi, but I found exploring the city to be more fun.

Intriguing view of a different. Culture. Very interesting to understand a culture completely different form my own. The beliefs and traditions associated with betrothal, marriage and new families were intriguing. I would highly recommend the visit.
Well taken care and a lot of information. Great way to learn more about women in Vietnam and a bit of history! It gets too detailed in ceremonies and how it works, but if you like this part enjoy!

Incredible Experience. We spend a whole afternoon in the museum and it was amazing. It was the first museum dedicated to Women that we had been to and it was excellent. We learnt a lot about rituals, tribes and women in politics. Is a good way to see how the Vietnamese give women a recognized role in the society. I recommend to invest five minutes to watch the video Street Workers, that show the reality of the women that walk to the streets selling fruits and handcrafts. I bought a book and a dvd about this matter for both ten us dollars. The entrance fee is more than fair (U$1.50 per person) and after the visit you can have lunch in one of the restaurants nearby. Definitely the museum is a marvelous experience in Hanoi.
Modern museum. The museum is modern and well set. For someone interested in culture, the museum is a must. For someone quickly bored watching cultural items, the museum is not the first choice.

Not many places with a strong emphasis on women, this is a gem!. This is about the one and only museum that I ever visited that is solely dedicated to women's contributions to society. Very informative and interesting, especially the exhibits on the second and third levels. They also have many video clips, however, there are a few in Vietnamese without English subtitles. Nevertheless, one of the best museums I visited in Southeast Asia!

Very well done museum. I like art museums, other museums I tend not to like very much. But people suggested this museum and I am glad I went. It is very well done. It has just the right amount of details for me. Many museums have far to little information on what you are seeing, and occasionally they have far too little for most stuff and then tons one a couple things. This place had short writeups on many things and a couple paragraphs on different sections.They also did a very good job with video - another area that is not often done well. For most people (including me) many short videos at different places are better. If we wanted 20 minutes we could just get a DVD or watch YouTube... They did a good job and included subtitles in English, French and some others I think (I wasn't too clear if there was some rotation or selection mechanism (I saw enough with English that I was fine and skipped the ones with French...).There is AC also.If you like museums or at least sometimes do I think this is a very wise item to add to your agenda in Hanoi.

Great museum. Covered many different aspects of Vietnamese women's lives in different time periods. You can go for a shorter time or a half day and get a lot out of it. Watch the short video upstairs on Vietnamese women trying to make a living in Hanoi now.

Everyone needs to go here. What a humbling experience. The museum is well laid out & spacious. All very interesting. Then you come to women's involvement in war. This moved me. This is testament to the strength of a whole nation of amazing women. Their stories touched me. Every woman needs to bring her daughter here ( and her husband)

Fascinating insights. On the recommendation of Lonely Planet, we visited with high expectations and they were met. There was so much interesting information, and I liked how the museum was laid out into different sections (birth, marriage, etc). A great way to spend an hour or so.
Well presented museum. Well worth a visit. The displays are very interesting showing the lives of Vietnamese women. Not open on a Monday

Well worth the visit. This museum is an absolute gem in Hanoi. It receives my full recommendation. There were so many parts of the museum that I really enjoyed. For me, the street vendor documentary was the most touching and memorable. It really was eye opening and it made me see the street vendors of Hanoi in a completely different light afterward. Also, there’s some amazing photography there that I really liked as well. The cherry on top afterward was picking up my favorite Vietnamese souvenir here at the gift shop—a handmade doll of a traditional Vietnamese woman for a young cousin of mine. She’s going to love it. This museum is well worth the time and the visit.

A moving tribute to Women. A somewhat eclectic collection of artifacts on display. So unusual to pay homage to women. I found the part where women who had lost sons and husbands commemorated for their bravery and endurance particularly moving.

Informative, kids play area available if required. We didn't actually plan to go here initially, but was suggested by our tour guide as we had completed our Old Quarter tour much earlier than we thought. Went in and managed to spend a good hour, before our young children had started to become restless. I guess it's much more info than they're willing to take in :-) On our way out, we stopped by their gift shop and realised that the museum actually had a dedicated play area for kids, very useful if we had known about this before we started going into the museum. The kids could have spend more time, and my husband could have spend more time in the museum. But all in all, good visit,

Atribute to women - the Vietnamese. Heading to Hanoi, Vietnam's frenetic capital, to choose one museum, choose this! Obviously influenced by his opposition this country has good experience, but no less interesting - on the contrary.

Nice to see a different side. This is the first museum solely dedicated to women and it was great. Really informative, and there were a lot of visual exhibits which definitely helped to keep my interest. Great insight into how the Vietnamese people respect and value women in their society, which is great! Would recommend, especially when there are many museum dedicated to war and suffering, this one has a positive feel and outlook.
NIce experience. Very nice place to get to know about vietnamese women, how they manage their lives and their importance. You should see it

Fascinating Museum. This is like several museums in one. The top floor displays stories and mementoes of women who served heroically in the war and other floors have displays on women of the various tribes in Vietnam and on the mother goddess beliefs. It left me wishing I had time to visit some of the tribal areas to see more of their lifestyle.

Interesting museum. A nice museum which tells you the story of the Vietnamese women. The way they dress, marriage, daily life, jobs, tribes, how they experienced and fought in the wars...Explained in a nice and easy way with examples, clothes, pictures,.. It shows how hard life was and is for women but also how they deal with it, in a great way... Never got bored here...
Women"s Museum. A quite modern and nicely set up Museum. We passed it will walking round Hanoi and fortunately decided to pop in.
Very interesting! One of the best museum i visited in Vietnam. Higly recommended to understand women's condition and their importance in the past, present and future society!

Another Great History Museum. Full of history and bursting with information and artifacts, it's a nice casual stroll from the Old Quarter and has a cafe attached that does great coffee, like many of the attractions in Hanoi the enrty price is very cheap.

An underrated museum in Hanoi. This museum offers a peak into marriage, ritual, fashion and other aspects of daily lives surrounding women in Vietnam. Life is hard, but the Viet women deal with it beautifully.

Interesting and Educating. Quite a lot to see in this museum, arranged over several floors. Covers various aspects of the lives of women in Vietnam, compares some different ethnic groups. Worth a visit

A surprise. Fascinating, with interesting insights into tradition social structures. In some 'tribes' it's the guy who takes on the woman's family name on marriage! Cool... Lots of other very interesting snippets of information too that help understand and appreciate other cultures.

Must See in Hanoi. Wow - what a museum. I've been to museums in Europe, Africa, North America, Central and South America, and this one was really top. Of course, I'm a Vietnam War scholar so I'm biased, but the ferocity and bravery of women in Vietnamese history is very nicely articulated here. There's several different sections about women in Vietnam - marriage & family, revolutionaries, cultural events, and even some insight into the women street vendors you'll likely encounter in Hanoi. I'm very pleased to have visited this museum; it's pretty fantastic.
museum. This was interesting and a very good price indeed. However it was extremely hot and the air conditioning could have been on a bit higher!
Excellent museum, very interesting. I loved the part about the political and military engagement of women during the revolution against fremch colonialism and during war against USA

Excellent and diverse museum. 4 floors of fantastic historical scope - from marriage customs in Matrilineal societies, to intimate stories of street vendors, an in depth perspective on mother goddess worship, amazing guerrilla fighters and more. Give yourself a few hours.

Excellent museum. Really well laid out with several floors of exhibitions each with a different theme i.e. Women in history, maternity and childbirth, women in society. Even a mother goddess section.Fascinating to discover the patriarchal and matriarchal societies and the different roles of women in each. Interesting to see the stark contrast of women's roles in the military when compared to the West including the numbers of female leaders and the recognition of women as national heroes.You can easily spend a few hours in the museum, information is well presented and available in English, French and Vietnamese.
Holiday. A must see museum in hanoi.Amazing diaspora of women accross vietnamese society from ethnic communities to women contribution to the freedom wars & struggleTruly wonderful experience

Excellent. Thoroughly enjoyed our afternoon here. Learned a great deal of interesting history about the women in the many ethnic groups within Vietnam. I found the written elements short yet informative. The information on wedding rituals and the guerrilla fighters was particularly interesting. The artefacts were often very beautiful (ornate jewelry and clothing) and the photos engaging. The rooms were mostly very air conditioned which was a relief from the humid day. Definitely worth a look.

Amazing - must do whilst in Hanoi. The Women's Museum touches your heart. It gives you an insight into the life of a Vietnamese Woman from working long hard hours to marriage/childbirth, traditions/culture.Throughout there are videos to watch (make sure you watch the one showing the street vendors - my heart went out to these women long hours for little money).Entry price 30,000 dong and definitely worth it. Glad I went and a great learning experience.

It was wonderful.. The Vietnamese Women's Museum was wonderful. It was the third museum I visited...and at it I learned something I wish I'd known when I'd been at the Museum of Ethnology and the Museum of Fine Arts: That the exhibits are laid out left to right, not right to left. At this museum on the second floor they had a clear arrow pointing one to the LEFT to begin the tour. That was very helpful, cuz I like to see history from older to more recent. GREAT (and beautifully laid our) museum.

A great tribute to some amazing women. Take the time to visit this Museum it gives you a great insight into Vietnamese women and the roles they have played in the development of this country and what strong women this country has produced.
Go here!. Really good content. Best activity in Hanoi. Watch the videos, especially the one about street vendors.

Respite from the hustle and bustle. Interesting and informative. It was well laid out. Unfortunately it was very hot, some of the rooms weren't cooled with fans. However there was plenty to see and read.
Disappointing . Read really good reviews of this place so was excited to go. Was disappointed, none of the exhibits were interesting at all im not sure what the fuss is about.

Touching museum, great experience. This is great place to know more about Vietnam history, especially about Woman- who contributed all life for the independence in Vietnam and affected much in over the world. All pictures, video, information were touching and great. Highly recommend here.

Large Museum with many exhibits. Well laid out presentations of various aspects of the life of women in Vietnam. The floor portraying the enormous part they played in the wars was of particular interest. Well worth a visit...allow some time!!!

Very interesting and different . This was a really great, if slightly boring (what museum isn't let's be honest), museum experience. The notable women from times of conflict were a highlight to read about. Very glad I went.

Lovely Museum with Fascinating Exhibits. This is a really lovely Museum to visit and gives you a real insight into the women of Vietnam - culture, traditions, history, work and life. Everything is very well laid out and signposted. The Museum feels very modern and smart. A particular highlight was watching the videos about the women who work as street sellers in the city and hearing their stories.

Great place to visit. This is a well organised museum with interesting and unique exhibitions. This museum is ideal for everyone interested in the vietnamese culture and learning about the important role of women in Vietnam.

Great museum!. This unique, well put together museum is worth the visit. I learned a lot about the history and life of Vietnamese women. I found myself referring to things I saw/learned at the museum throughout my stay.
Also nice. We went to this museum and the History museum in Hanoi both of that were nice and provided lots of information about the Vietnamese history and the locals

Great little museum. This is a great little museum. It is clearly run on a small budget, but displays are informative and engaging. It is also fully air conditioned - which is a nice relief in the current heat!

A fascinating surprise. The name of this museum did not really inspire me but once inside the excellent displays in multi-floored galleries gave me a fascinating insight into the lives of Vietnamese women including those from ethnic minority groups. Displays include domestic life, marriage ceremonies, fashion, farming and famous revolutionaries. A contemporary art gallery is on the top floor where exhibits can be purchased. By combining a visit to this museum in the morning with the Museum of Ethnology in the afternoon a relaxed and interesting day can be had - especially if it is very hot and humid outside. Lunch can be purchased in the restaurant at the Museum of Ethnology so no need to go hunting around for a meal. I visited both museums on a motorcycle driven by a University student. During long vacations they supplement their income as Hanoi guides and are very knowledgeable taking you to where you want to go and not what a tour company wants you to visit. This can be adventurous.

a learning experience. this place will reach into your mind ,i was unsure why it was on my tour but once there i realized ,and learn t ...a lot ,some things i will never forget ,great reality check for the western person

Insightful. Spent 1.5 hours here learning about the Vietnamese women and the part they play in society. Found it interesting and the Mr said it was good too which is a bonus. It is humbling to see how hard they work. There is a bit where you can try picking up the baskets of fruit which you place on their shoulder and it was so heavy and difficult balancing it whilst walking - my hat goes off to these ladies. Worth a trip to see

An extraordinary history. A trip to Hanoi will not be complete unless you visit this amazing museum celebrating the strength of Vietnamese women. The underlying statement is subtle but the fact is that women run Vn and do it very well. Humbling....

Expected more. Not going to lie expected more . A large building with 5 floors of average information, poor AC and un engaging videos and pictures . This had the potential to be superb but it isn't .... I would not recommend .

Worth the time. Wow - Vietnamese women are powerful. This museum did a great job of highlighting everyday life and special individuals. Very affordable - the Goddess Altar and costumes were interesting
Quite interesting. Spread over several floors this museum is worth visiting if you have a spare hour. It celebrates women in Vietnamese culture. It was good but not captivating
Cultural insight. Vietnamese women have contributed immensely to the development of their country. This museum provides very interesting insight.

Wonderful Museum!. I was very impressed with this little gem in Hanoi! It is a fantastic place to learn about the history of women in Vietnamese society, in the past and in modern day life. Completely worth the 30,000 entree cost. Make a trip, you won't regret it.
fascinating insight into womens life. really interesting museum , doesn't take long to go round but very good especially the info on women in the war

Well worth the visit. This is a superb museum, spread out over 4 levels. It gives a great perspective into the lives and history of vietnamese women and covers all facets of their lives. I particularly enjoyed the focus on women and work, and reading about the lives of the women who sell produce on the street, as well as the stunning photography. The cafe in the courtyard is a lovely place to relax and enjoy a drink and an icecream coffee.

Impressive acknowledgement. Interesting and insightful- an impressive acknowledgement of the role of women in Vietnamese culture, life and history. Refreshing to see the achievements and importance of women acknowledged beyond that of fashion, motherhood and the home. While these themes are included as significant parts of culture, the role of women in industry, conflict and peace building is also prominently featured. Well worth a couple of hours.

interesting museum. Lots of interesting things to look at, different roles of women. The short documentary on the life of the street vendors is what I found to be most interesting. Also the role of women in the Vietnam war.

Excellent!. A wonderfully curated museum about the role of women in Vietnam. A great balance of history and modern roles. Fine examples of clothing, housing, pottery, photographs etc etc. Highly recommended and well worth a visit.

A great museum but not an absolute must see. This museum has very well displayed exhibits and I felt like I learned a lot about Vietnam in general, but thru the lens of its impacts on women. Some of the video exhibits were particularly interesting; I was amazed when watching the one about women street vendors in Hanoi - these women work so hard & it is quite humbling. That said, I wouldn't call this a "must see".

Very interesting museum. This is very interesting museum. Good informations bords. I liked the way it was set up with the 'different categories'. It was a good introduction for my trip to Sapa and the tribes. It's close to the city centre so you can walk to it.

Interesting visit to Museum focused on Women. On a very hot day welcome to be inside in air con. History of women in Vietnam and their role in the various uprisings in their country. Presented in straight forward manner. Also exhibits of daily life around marriage. Child birth and fashion spread over 4 floors. Can easily spend 2-3 hours here.
Well worth a visit. Really interesting exhibits on the roll women played in the war. Good museum, decent English and French info. Spend a couple of hours here!
Wonderful. This was certainly an excellent insight into the women of Viet Nam. Many interesting exhibits, a mist-see whilst in Hanoi.

Very well curated museum in the heart of Hanoi . Three floors of informative and well curated exhibits highlighting the achievements of women throughout Vietnam's history. Made for a highly enjoyable afternoon.

Everyday life in vietnam. The regular exhibits explained many aspects of vietnam life and culture. There was a special exhibit about the "Long-hair soldiers" which I found fascinating, making notes on some of the women for further research.

Dry presentation but truly inspiring. I went here with a male friend. Two typical blokes surrounded by women and anthropologists.
