You may expect us to be bored, but actually we're glad we checked it out. You don't have to be a woman to enjoy this museum. You simply have to be interested in history and humanity. If you love photography, you will walk away feeling inspired. Some of the photos are fantastic. They show remarkable joy and devotion to the cause in the women's faces. You can be cynical and wonder if they were coerced - or you can view this as a struggle for nationhood. Even if you visit for just one hour, it's worth it.

Great Place. The story of the Vietnamese woman is inspiring...imagine 1000 years of war with China; them France; then Japan; the France again; then the USA; then Cambodia-yes it was the VIETNAMESE that stopped the Khmer Rouge!; than another border war with China...these woman "have it together"!
They did it hard. Thank god we are from the west women here had it tough, if you were a women you had nothing but work day and night
No woman should miss this. Learn how hard it really was to survive in Vietnam during the 20th Century from a womans perspective. We allowed 1 hour and left after 3. Don't forget the shop.
great. good if you're into textiles, cultural education and reading about some of the heroines of the country, with a healthy dose of propaganda to boot

The strength and struggle of Vietnamese women.. If you only have time to visit one museum in Hanoi then don't go past Vietnamese Women's Museum. The exhibits and large photographs give a glimps of life through the ages,to the present of family life and the huge contribution women have made to Vietnamese society.
Must go museum in Hanoi. Must go museum in Hanoi - very interesting and especially the stories of women and the Vietnam war. one of the best museums in Vietnam, if not the best.
Great, interesting museum. Informative modern museum. Gave a good insight to Vietnamese culture. The film on the street food vendors was very interesting. Great photographs on display.

Very Interesting - worth a visit. My wife and I went here because it was near our hotel and we had a couple of hours free. What a find. This was a very interesting Museum and full of surprising facts and pictures. If your interested in the Vietnam war, it may surprise you to see the role women played and their terrible losses.

Powerful and moving. Reasonably centrally located in Hanoi, if you have time for only 1 or 2 museums in Hanoi make this one of them to visit (the other being the Museum of Ethnology). The Women's Museum was unlike any museum I've been to. Beautifully done, powerful, captivating, emotional, interesting, striking, etc. It revealed much about Vietnamese culture particularly in regards to street food vendors, women's role in the recent war, and general day to day life, religion and rituals. Every country should have one of these museums but sadly only 3 do (The US and Germany being the other 2). My partner and I, and our kids, thought this one of the better museums we've ever been to anywhere. And its all about the exceptional content although the actual displays are good to. Highly recommended.
Fitting tribute to women in general and Vietnamese Women in particular.. Inspirational and informative. Well laid out and expertly curated. A great way to spend an hour in this wonderful city.
A Women's Museum!. Fascinating museum dedicated to the strong hard-working women of Vietnam. Their role in the American war is especially interesting. Highly recommended.

A Lovely Museum - Very Informative. We thought we would be at this museum only an hour or so but it was such a good museum that we continued up every floor. The exhibits were beautifully displayed and life and experiences of the women of Vietnam were truly educational and yet fun to experience. a delight to see

A Wonderful Tribute to Vietnamese Women. It was great to visit this museum, where the women's role in wars, education, fashion, every day farming, home making, religion/medium worshipping etc is highlighted. Four floors of displays with additional changing special exhibits are not to be missed.
Where is such museum in the United States?
Girl power. My friend and I loved this museum, especially the floor detailing women's participation in war and politics. Very well done and interesting- highly recommended.

Certainly worth a visit if you like museums. I rate the Womens Museum about as high as the Ethnic Museum. As others have noted, it is a bit repetitive, but you can go through at whatever pace you feel and dwell on the parts of interest, just moving through others. I think 70-90 minutes would be a typical trip. There are quite a few floors, with the lower floors of the most interest. The large exhibit on the left before you ascend the main museum steps is a woman-in-war exhibit, which was rather unique. Have seen similar topics in other places, but it is mostly the home front, this one very mixed with interesting bios. There is more on the topic in the Main Museum. It wasn't very expensive and they have a little crafts shop on the main floor. The shop isn't as good as the one at the Ethic Museum. The Womans Museum is very convenient to Old Town and the Business areas, but a little hard to see from the street. I walked right buy it once, looking for it. Signs are inside the courtyard. Certainly worth the time and money.

Inspiring. Great insight into the history of Vietnam's 'fairer sex' or not so as it happens. Make sure you go inside the first building to the left, it's easy to miss but probably the best part of the museum

Well worth the visit, it exceeded my expectations. To be honest I was expecting just a " good" experience with a hefty helping of propaganda. However we were very pleasantly surprised. The building is a bit drab and on the inside and out away from exhibits it seems a little run down, but the exhibits were smart, very interesting and well crafted, all with explanations in Vietnamese, English and French. The photographs and stories were amazing. My wife and I thought we would only stay an hour: after 2 and a half we had to stop as we were quite tired. With temperatures outside closer to 40 than to 30 each floor had air conditioned exhibit halls and so made that all the more bearable as well. Do go. Just wish they had more benches to sit down on and contemplate some of the exhibits!

Ok but a little repetitive. This museum sprawls out through 5-6 floors and by floor 3 I'd had about enough. Perhaps just my opinion but my wife shared it too. We are a mid 30's couple (for info only) but it just tends to go on a bit.
Can go visit if you have time. If you go there, prepare yourself that you have lots of reading to do. But overall it's nice.
Womans Thing. My wife again went on a tour with the Hanoi Kids, gone for nearly the whole day. Vietnam's women, she said really worked in the old days.

Pretty good visit. The museum was in walking distance to the old Quarter, wasn't much to see there since I have been to the Ethymology museum the day before. Still they have a pretty nice collection on Vietnamese Ancestors Worship Ceremony.

Really interesting insight into life in Vietnam. Great to read about what life is like in different parts of Vietnam including traditions for weddings, births and religious ceremonies. Entrance fee is only about 30,000VND
Worth your while. Learned a lot about the Vietnamese history and culture from this visit. It covered the roles women have played throughout history as well as the clothes and costumes they wore.

Fabulous insight into the lives of women in Vietnam. Well worth a visit. Actually, well worth a second visit - went last year as well. Went with Hanoi Kids both times, but the exhibits are well-documented if you go by yourself. The exhibits cover the Chinese influences, hill tribes and up to the present day. The clothing is really interesting, as are the customs.There is an entry fee. It will take some hours if you want to do the museum justice.
Vietnam women fighters. It made me aware of the number of women that fought during the war & how many were made generals & won medals for bravery. It was very moving & eye-opening.

Women's history. Made an early start as it is a hot day in Hanoi - 35+. From our place we get a virtual door to door trip on the No. 31 bus - what could better. The airconditioning in the museum is good compared to many others.This is a must. Worldwide the place of women in political and commercial history is either ignored or merely assumed. The collection is of everyday artifacts, stories and photographs covering birth, marriage and death, clothing styles etc. Then you get to the third floor where a principally photographic and film illustration of the stories of the heroes of Vietnam in, particularly, the American war, the women, is told. A very moving collection and rendition. Fantastic communist poster art.On the second floor is a little subsection about the street vendors of Hanoi. As a visitor they can be mildly annoying. I will never have the same view - this is a stand out story of life for the poor, where there is little welfare support for the sick or injured.This alcove makes an effective full stop to the wartime philosophy of 'three responsibilities' for women: to protect and nurture the family, improve agricultural productivity and be in a state of readiness for war. You can buy a DVD at the shop - the proceeds go towards assisting these women.

Very interesting. A must see. Learn about vietnams recent history through the eyes of Women. I particularly enjoyed the photos from the war, showing the heroic women and what they went through and the mother goddess room.

A jewel . Placed right in the heart of Hanoi and certainly some of the best hours you can spend in Vietnam's capitol. The top floor with its art gallery seems superfluous, and the floor about the role of the Vietnamese women in the fight for independence has (of course) a nationalistic tinge. But it's still one of the most interesting museums I have ever seen and it made me wonder why Western nations don't portray the history of their women as prominently.

Probably the best museum in Hanoi. This museum makes for a certain 2-3 hours of your time in Hanoi. A fascinating account of the role of women in the development of the country. Their role at the time of the American War is glossed over a bit because it is covered more than adequately in other history museums in the country. But the Women's Museum is one of the most insightful information sources you could hope to take it while in the city. Displays are very good. Three floors.

Lays the groundwork for the rest of what you see. My visit to this museum laid the groundwork for the rest of my three weeks in Vietnam. Many of the sights you see as you tour the country were built by the women. Their role in the history of the country and their part in the war is fascinating. This museum provides a wonderful overview.

Something special. Very modern and well organised museum with interesting and unique exhibitions. Learning about the important role of women in Vietnam, this museum is ideal for everyone interested in the vietnamese culture. From street vendors on their loaded push bikes to marriages and the mothers of Vietnam every story is told in a beautiful way.The entrance fee is 30,000D per person and this is a great place to visit when you are in Hanoi.

Didn't have high expectations. I really did not know what to expect, and suspected a poor experience. I was wrong! Vietnamese women are upfront, confident and not to be dismissed. The Museum likewise. Learnt a lot, enjoyed every floor but the top one (fashion!), a must see.
Very interesting!. We visited this museum last week and found it very informative. Women in Vietnam are certainly a force to be reckoned with!
A fresh museum. Very well organised exhibition in a fresh museum. Women clothing was great with a large diversity through the country.

SAD and PROUD. Heart wrenching stuff here but definitely worth the visit ! Strong women in Vietnam I'm sure they won the WARS as they've fought in so many !! but now there's PEACE let's hope it lasts as it's been 40 years and this Museum gives the visitor a time line and what they've endured! 10 points.

When you need some rest and deep insight into local culture. Takes some to see the whole exhibition. I would say 1,5h if you wanna take your time and just hang around. The exhibition is very interesting if you are really into the culture and religion. Maybe not the best place for the thrill seekers. Rather take the escalator to the upper floor and walk down. You will save some energy ;) There is a nice cafe outside the museum.
Women's part in the war. Interesting to visit and although there is lots of detail it is only a small museum and is worth a visit

Before you go to Sapa.... ... you should check out this museum. It is well done and gives you some interesting insight on the role of women in vietnamese culture. Also, it displays some of the traditions of the ethnic minorities which is a great preparation for some days in Sapa.

Worth a visit. Not just for women!. My husband also found this interesting and worth a visit. Each floor is devoted to a different are of women's contribution to life in Vietnam. Something for everyone: textiles, silks, cottons, linens, weaving and dyes, each displayed according to geographical region. Mannequins wearing costumes. Beautiful. The floor devoted to women's roles in the American War is inspiring and amazing.There is also a section on the cultural artefacts relating to motherhood ( pregnancy, childbirth, nutrition, etc). I also liked the area devoted to the production of daily food, as well as the explanations about the religion.There is a quiet corner upstairs just outside the exhibition with photos of the mothers who have been honoured because of their contribution to the war effort in 'giving' their sons and daughters, who had lost their lives. It is worth spending a few moments sitting here.

Fantastic!. This was one of the most intriguing and fascinating museums that I have ever been to. It centres around the roles of Vietnamese women in traditional areas as well as their involvement in the war with America. There is so much information here and each floor displays a different theme or period of time or the development of traditions. I spent hours here which I hadn't anticipated, so you should be aware that this museum is not a quick visit but is well worth the length of time that you will spend there.

Definitely a 'must visit' when in Hanoi. An excellent museum with modern displays and video interpretation. Three floors are devoted to women's culture and role in society. The three themes are different, first: marriage and birth, second: the role women played in the war, third: fashion and clothing. I loved it all!!There is a good cafe restaurant in the courtyard and a museum shop which sells very good quality textiles and gifts....at very reasonable prices to a European!I am sure husbands/boyfriends would find it interesting too.
Great. I liked the fact that there even was a women's museum. In a globally patriarchal society it was great to see the vital role that women have played in Vietnamese society.

Fascinating and sobering. This museum celebrates the life and customs of Vietnamese women both historical and contemporary. Their role in the 'American' war (the Vietnam war to me) was particularly moving. I really liked the particular focus on women and found the exhibits very interesting - allow several hours to do it justice.

A piece of work to see every floor. it can get hot inside so go earlier than 2:00 pm it is just a great way to see the life of people and traditions and off to side a museum about Vietnam war and how woke we're apart of it

Some fascinating stuff. This museum is, as the name suggests, entirely devoted to the role of women in Vietnamese society, with each floor of the museum looking at a different aspect of that. The ground floor looks at the different marriage and birth rituals of the 54 different ethnic groups in the country, the first floor looks at working women, with a very good video of interviews with many of the female street traders of Hanoi, who discuss what the job entails, and why they have to do it. There is also a fascinating exhibition with lots of costumes and videos of the Mother Goddess cult in Vietnam, which I found particularly intriguing. The second floor looked at the role of women during the Vietnam War from 1845 onwards, and the top floor at fashion through the ages.

Go there... Of all the sights we saw in Hanoi, the women's museum, detailing the contributions women have made to the history of Vietnam was the most memorable. Particularly so when showing women's involvment in the wars against the French occupation and the American conflict.The photos of the human bridge, where women were chest deep in water holding up bridge supports used to ferry wounded solders, or the sight of a tiny Vietnamise woman capturing an enormous American GI will live with me for a long time.

fascinating collections related to daily routine and tradition. This museum was fascinating in its depiction of the dress and the implements of the day-to-day life of the native people. Videos and signs explain the customs in which the items displayed are used. some air conditioning, but generally hot and humid. More than worth it! Nice cafe on the grounds

A well designed, moving and informative small museum. The Vietnamese Women's Museum has a clear, modern design. Everything is clearly translated into English. The display cases about women involved in the liberation and revolutionary movements are particularly moving, with a short biography and a small selection of objects associated with each woman. The display (which I think may be temporary) about the Mother Goddess religion was also fascinating, revealing a part of Vietnamese culture I didn't know existed. The museum is small enough to visit in a couple of hours. I would definitely recommend it to anyone who's staying for a few days in Hanoi and would like to have a deeper understanding of Vietnam.

Fantastic museum. This was a really well thought out museum, with a range of interesting exhibits. It gives information about the traditions of the different ethnic groups of Vietnam, as well as information about modern life in Vietnam, and one exhibit focuses on the Vietnam war. Very interesting, very much worth a visit.

A very professional, well thought out display regarding the life and roles of Vietnamese women. This Museum is easy walking distance from the Old Quarter. It has 3 levels on display depicting the lifestyles and roles of Vietnamese women including Minority groups. The first floor depicts the culture, Marriage and handcrafts. It gives a very good insight into family traditions.There is recent video worth watching regarding the lives of some of the Street sellers. It is an eye opener really, to understand the sacrifices many women must make, leaving their villages to come to Hanoi, in order to earn a few dollars, to support their children, and give them an education.There is also an interesting temple display on this second floor.The third floor depicts the Vietnamese women's roles in the fight for Independence.There is a gift shop on the ground floor and a cafe with shade outside the Museum.We definitely recommend this Museum. It really gives you a better understanding of the roles Vietnamese women hold and have held in society.

Insight. I made a good choice by visiting this museum. Everything was well laid out in a surprisingly spacious building. There was a video depicting the life of street vendors which I found quite moving. I had no idea just how hard these women have to work to make little money whilst being separated from their families. How fortunate I am. There is a whole section of beautiful costumes. Also photos and stories of women, some very young, who contributed greatly during the war.

Very moving and instructive. this museum really gives a picture of how much women have contributed to Vietnamese society including fighting alongside men in the last conflict - thought of as a war of liberation by the indigenous population of course. Good displays well thought out and some disturbing stories on video about poor street sellers.

Nice venue. It presents the role of women in the vietnmesse society, in family, in economy, in agriculture, and in the war. There is a room that is it is used as an event hall for cocktails, and receptions.
Worth a visit. My husband and I are pleasantly surprised by the amount of information in this small museum. Give yourself a couple hours to be able to read through everything.
Makes ya think. Worth the entrance price for the video on female street vendors alone. The role of women in the American war was also eye-opening.

Surprisingly interesting. Very interesting modern museum, floors on family life and marriage and womens involvement in the american war were the best floors. There is also a very good video on the day in the life of a street seller - once seen you will want to buy from them!

Nice setting and well presented museum. Well worth spending an hour or more to appreciate the importance of the womens' work in Vietnam Strikes me how much this would be needed in more places. Some even deeper insights could do as it sometimes. Walking distance from city centre/old parts.
Interesting place. lots of information about the culture in Vietnam and the history including some surprising stuff about the wars
Fascinating. It was so interesting to learn all about heroic vietnamese women, very well laid out and a good authentic gift shop on the ground floor

Women's role in Vietnam. From the wars to the fields to everyday life--this is an interesting museum. It does cover the role of the Women in the wars and they have had many but most importantly you see what a role women have in running the real work of everyday life. From weddings, customs, traditional dress, textiles,farming, child bearing and carrying the large loads on the street ( you can try and lift it in the museum--good luck ) to todays fashions this museum covers loads. Don't forget the museum shop downstairs--good stuff.

Interesting. Going to Hanoi, Vietnam's frenetic capital, to choose one museum, choose this! Obviously influenced by his opponent this country has good experience, but no less interesting - on the contrary.My girlfriend felt happy at there.

fascinating. I visited this museum after three weeks travelling from the south to the north of Vietnam. It was so interesting to learn about all the women I had seen on my trip. They are so hardworking and inspirational. Their lives are very different to my own and I don't think I'm necessarily the more fortunate.

Fascinating and educational. The museum had a very nice layout, and showed many aspects of the life of women through the recent history of Vietnam. We especially liked the section about women in the Vietnam war, and the section about marriage.
Well done. This museum gives an insight into the role women played in the Vietnam war. Each section flows well and engages the visitor. Highly recommended
woman power. A very well laid out exhibition and very interesting exhibits.covers all the aspects of a woman's daily life.

Interesting Insights. The Vietnamese Women's Museum offered some very interesting insights into the daily lives of Vietnamese women. I particularly enjoyed the videos which revealed the stories of the women who we'd seen walking around on the streets of Hanoi. There were also some interactive exhibits which made it a bit more interesting too.

Quite an interesting museum :)). The Vietnamese Women's Museum is a nicely-curated place to learn about the important roles of women among Viet Nam's different ethnicities :) While some of the information here is repeated at other Ha Noi museums, there are a number of unique topics & displays as well... I found the exhibits regarding women street vendors to be very enlightening -- the video documentary that is offered is well done, and provides important information about this subject (no "spoilers" from me -- best to check this out yourself :). The museum's displays have English & French translations too, and there's a gift shop that carries examples of handicrafts. It's definitely worth taking an hour or so to visit this place... Enjoy :)
Very informative. Really enjoyed having an in depth insight into the role of Vietnamese women - and prepared our children for what to expect in Sapa (traditional dress etc). Highly recommend.

Women's place. Fascinating - especially the first 2 floors of exhibits. Walking around you will notice women work hard - this museum gives you background on women, poverty, work, marriage and family. It explores the relationships for the different ethnic groups. Must see!

A great insight into the Women of Vietnam. A wonderful way to see how the women have had an impact on the Vietnam Culture, including the village women to the mothers of the soldiers. Within an hour or two, you will get a feel for what the life of these women is, and was.

Lots of beautiful artifacts. There are several floors of this museum, organized by topics such as religion, life of a woman, traditional attire of the ethnic minority tribes, etc... My husband and I spent a couple of hours there, and only left because we were hungry and needed to eat. We will probably go back in the future.

Very Informative. We learned a lot from this museum. It give great insight into the role of women in Vietnam throughout the years. It also gives detailed information about marriage, having children, fashion, women in wars. We found it really interesting. Worth it.

Edifying. I spent over 2 hours but had I time would have spent more. It gave
a very full explanation of womens work, marriage rituals, birthing
customs, Army and civil duties. Great displays and meny descriptions on the walls.

A tribute to women, albeit a little confusing!. It is wonderful to see that so much effort has gone into recognising the contributions of, and hardships endured by, women over the years. The museum certainly has all of that and more, including insights to the roles undertaken by women in present day. What was a little confusing was how the women in the south had to fight off the US aggressors but perhaps I just need a refresher on history! Despite this, we did enjoy our visit.

THE LIFE AND CONTRIBUTION OF THE WOMEN OF VIETNAM. Very interesting museum. Each floor of the museum adds to your knowledge and creates more interest in the Life and how the Vietnamese women contribute to the Nation and their family, community.Highly recommended. The life of a Vietnamese Women from birth, to old gate.
Boring. Not much to see here, quite boring. If you have more time to visit the city then best to invest it to another attractions.

Interesting look at women in Vietnam. I'm not really much of a museum person, but the women's museum did provide a very interesting and educational view of the roles of women throughout the history of Vietnam. There were lots of interesting displays on traditional clothing. Of particular interest, though also slightly depressing, was the video and display on the women vendors who wander the streets selling fruit and the like, simply because of the fact that I had seen so many during my time walking through the city. It gave me a greater appreciation of what they are going through to try to make a living.
Well worth a visit. Good and comprehensive view of the role of women in Vietnam, as well as insights into history, religion and culture.

very interesting. There are some good displays and stories in this exhibition. Some of the other places don't have the displays you expect and there is a lot of photocopied documents but little else. This Museum was displayed well.

A unique attraction worth a visit. Stopped by this place while walking around Hanoi.Unique museum that shows the history and powerful women in Vietnam.Considering we were a group of 5 men who thought it would be about women's fashion in Vietnam, we came out with a whole new respect for Vietnamese women and how strong they were during war times. Well worth the time for a visit.

Fantastic. I think it's amazing that Hanoi have dedicated an entire museum to the history and story of women in Vietnam. The museum is large and worth the 30,000 entry fee with very descriptive explanations of what it means to be a women in Vietnam. The museum is split across 4 floors each with its own theme meaning that there's something interesting for everyone. I came here with my boyfriend however I would say it would also suit family travellers and solo travellers. Highly recommend this museum whilst in Hanoi.

A different perspective. Web spent an interview resting couple of hours at the museum learning about the female side of life in Vietnam. From family and home life to fashion and liberation, it covers a variety of past and current aspects of female life.

Best museum in Hanoi. Well told history in modern museology. Excellent for families.
Easy access. Good shop. Covered all aspects of life in Vietnam with wars sensitively covered.

So interesting and informative. I managed to get three people to visit with me that didn't really want to and by the end we were all talking about our favourite sections of the museum.
It was wonderful to see what women have done for Vietnam being celebrated that way.

a unique place and surprising to find it in Hanoi. this museum is dedicated to women and their roles. It is a short walk from many of the tourist sites and well worth the trip. don't miss it. Lunch was good there too.

Interesting portrait of women in Vietnamese society. The museum is not very big. Five floors, and it takes about 10-15 minutes per floor. A nice sampling of costumes, tools and implements, etc. There seems to be a curious emphasis on Vietnam’s ethnic minority women and the role of women in the independence movement against French colonialism and the war against the US/South Vietnam, but not much on life today for Vietnamese women, or during the French colonial period or indeed even before that period. There was also some sort of modern art exhibit on the 5th floor which was really awful.

Loved the museum. If you enjoy history and lifestyle insights, you will really enjoy this museum, it is well laid out, very informative and so worthwhile. It really gave me the appreciation of the Vietnamese women and how their lives have been impacted by the war, social issues, and economic factors.

Woman's role. Definitely worth going to.. So much to see and follow. Women's role spread out on three floors. The film clip about the women street vendors is interesting and gives an insight of what their roles in life is all about

Woman's Museum. Interesting look at the role of women in Vietnam. The film clip with interviews with the street vendors was particularly interesting as was the details of the large number of women military leaders. An easy walk in the old quarter.
Engaging exhibition. And great value. Sections on marriage, women workers, and their contribution to the revolutionary effort. Diverse exhibition with great video sections (subtitled).
Worth a bisit. This is a fascinating museum, I likehighlighting the contribution women have made to Vietnam...I recommend a visit.

Go only if you're interested!. The museum is very well done and if you're interested, you could definitely spend a couple hours there looking at all kinds of different clothes, items, descriptions, videos, etc.That being said, I'm not particularly interested in history and found the museum to be a bit of a bore. My experience was 3/5 but I gave it 4 because it is indeed well done.
unique museum. probably the best museum in hanoi. very interesting and nice introduction in women's significance for family and vietnam's society.
worth the visit. Demonstrated the value that women have contributed to Vietnam's history. We learnt so much by visiting this museum.
A definite visit is recommeded. An amazing collection of clothes and artifacts from the women of Vietnam through the centuries. Wonderful pictures and exhibits. Allow at least 1-1.5 hours here.

Best Museum I visited in Hanoi. I went here not reallt knowing what to expect. Perhaps more communism propoganda? Thankfully it wasn't. One of the most interesting places I visited.I left with a better understanding of Vietnamese people, ceremony, dress, culture and practices.A must see in Hanoi.

Vietnamese women are truly amazing. Very informative, well organized history of Women in Vietnam. When we visited there was a temporary exhibition about women in the war. Amazing what the Vietnamese women did whilst looking after their families.

Good For Visit. Good to learn about Vietnamese women in the mostly patrilineal Vietnamese society. Museum has about 5 floors, each with a different focus, including birth, marriage, fashion, etc. It's worth 1-2 hours visit for the price. Good for visit.

Well Done and Impressive. I arrived at 4pm and they they close at 5 so I only had an hour. I recommend allowing yourself 2 if you want to read all the excerpts and watch the mini videos. I especially enjoyed the amazing photography on display.
Historical place of Vietnamese Women. This museum is truly worth your time to go. There are so many thing you can discover and learn about the Vietnamese Women by the time.

Excellent. I love museums and this was the first museum I've been to/heard of dedicated for only women's history. Very informative and unique point of view from a western perspective. All I can say is that it's an excellent way to spend a rainy day comfortably inside a modern building housing this museum. Recommended!

The best museum by far in Hanoi!. Since we were faced with pretty bad weather during our stay in Hanoi, we visited almost all of the museums and this was by far the best! The different exhibitions about the role and importance of women in the history of Vietnam as well in today's society were all very well arranged and informative.

really interesting. Well worth the effort, and something different to the normal museum. It's easy to get to and well laid out. My wife and I both enjoyed the history of women in Vietnam - oh, and the traditional costumes are great.

A Good Place to Spend Women's Day. Coincidentally, we went to the Women's museum on the same day as the Women's Day. Apparently , Women's Day is celebrated widely in Hanoi. i am not sure about the other cities/provinces though.When we came, the museum had an ad-hoc exhibition, if I am not wrong, it was called the '55th Anniversary of the Long Haired Army'. The ad-hoc exhibition is free but the permanent ones are not. There are 3 main themes and each theme is different for each levels. They are basically Family, History, Fashion and if I am not wrong, there are also themes of weddings and birth. The exhibition showcased the different practices that the different ethnic minorities and the majority Viets follow through their customs and traditions.However, do visit if you have the interests in looking at the different cultures of the minorities. I am especially amazed at how closely a few of the ethnic minorities are similar to the Malays and the Eastern Malaysians. The whole visit took about 1.5hours and that was enough to cover the whole 4 levels.

To be seen, but.... If you want to understand what is the role of women in the present socialist Vietnam, you will not be satisfied: you just see women who are mothers, housewives, workers, fighters in the liberation wars from the French and Americans, all at the same time as in Western countries! What is most impressive is a video about street vendors: not a good propaganda for vietnamese government, indeed!
Interesting visit. An interesting museum to visit. The displays were well thought out and the stories next to each display made it an engaging experience

Great museum to visit.. Only 30,000D entry and I spent 1.5 hrs walking up the 5 levels of displays at this charming museum. Really interesting exhibits on Vietnamese customs relating to marriage, birth, wonderful costume displays, war history and stories of female workers today. A nice break from the outside noise of Hanoi. Recommended.

Novel idea and excellently presented. Very well presented and catalogued. The first few floors had wonderful stuff but we were saturated by the time we reached the top where we got a little bored, to be honest. But all in all, definitely worth a visit, to see how well they've executed the concept.

Worth the modest price of admission!. Women are the backbone of Vietnam and they perform many of the tough jobs that men don't do. What's with that? This museum gives credit where credit is due to the hard-working women of Vietnam. Visit the museum with a local tour guide if you can as you will benefit by their perspective.

Vietnamese Women's Museum- a must-see place to visit in Hanoi. Despite being a patriarchal society, Viet Nam still reserves a special, if not sacred, place to honour Vietnamese women. Not only is October 20th is made Vietnam’s Women day but there also exists a museum dedicated to women.The museum displays rather recent history of women, such as women and ethnicity; women and the national struggle; Vietnam women association and the feminism; women and traditional costumes; and women’s cultural traits expressed through handicrafts.

Worth it but..... This is an interesting museum for me (being male). It certainly raises your awareness of how Vietnamese woman have contributed to the society through the centuries.... some tough birds here (excuse the expression).Again as though out Vietnam, the museums are severely lacking on written information as to what you are looking at...
An Interesting Take. Well done! Lots to see and lots to learn about the very tough Vietnamese women...they had and still have a lot on their plates.

Lovely depiction of roles of women!. This museum is quite new, only seven years old, and very nicely put together. They is an exhibit on women as leaders in war and the struggle for liberation and then attractive displays related to marriage, motherhood, and religion, particularly the mother goddess. The fashions and ethnic costumes on display are beautiful.

Best for the textiles and fashion floor. Definitely worth a visit when in Hanoi. 5 floors of exhibits and nicely presented with adequate signage in english and or french. The floor with the costumes, textiles and fashion had the best displays and information by far. The floor of day to day family life, traditions, marriage, and household tasks interesting to see and could be better developed in future with more research. This is a patrilineal society, except for a few hill tribes as noted in the displays, so not sure why some previous reviewers call it matriarchal culture. The floor with the women war heroes was tragic and too focused on the recent war, with no mention of the Japanese in WW2. It becomes boringly biased with too much focus on blaming Americans. Felt like it was put together by high school students.Enjoyed the small room which had panels depicting modern women in Vietnam today, in various occupations and business. Got a sense of town vs country attitudes and regional divisions as well.
very informative. went here with 2 students from Hanoi Kids, who took time to explain more about the culture & origins of some of the exhibits, which made it so much more "real"

Celebrating women's lives in Vietnam. This was an unusual museum, very well presented and informative. Captions are in both English and French , easily drawing you in. The floor covering the women's role in war was very poignant and enlightening. My 5 year old granddaughter was easily engaged with the stories of work on the land and traditional costumes. Definitely worth a visit.

Worth a visit. This is a very easy museum to find, not very far from the lake in town. It is also very helpful how all the places here have their street numbers clearly displayed.The museum costs 30000VND each, ticket office on the left as you enter the area fronting the museum. It is signed which way to travel around the different floors and the exhibits are all explains in Vietnamese French and English. The main attraction of the museum is the credit it pays to the efforts of the women who have fought off successive invaders and lost sons and husbands. There are a wide range of exhibits covering the cycle of life for women in Vietnam and it is careful to include the many ethnic group that make up Vietnamese life and history. There is a small shop within the museum and a café outside. I enjoyed the visit.

Unusual and Excellent. We ended a full day of sightseeing in Hanoi with a visit to the Women's Museum. It is unlike any other institution my wife and I have visited anywhere in the world in that it focuses on the role of women in the family, economy, politics and even war. It is very well done and eye-opening on many issues. I was particularly taken with the exhibits dealing with the role of women in the war with the USA and the rooms devoted to the Mother Goddess. The latter subject was a total surprise and through it I got a completely new sense of the role of traditional religion in contemporary Vietnamese society. This museum should be a primary destination for tourists and not just an extra.

interesting museum excellent value. The cost to enter the museum is 30,000 dong so approximately£1 so you cannot complain about that! It is set over 4 or 5 floors displaying women's contributions to Vietnam over the years and currently. There are displays on marriage, children and family, agriculture, women's activities during the war, fashion and commerce. To be honest I was not expecting very much but was pleasantly surprised how interesting I found the museum. I spent a good couple of hours in there and would definitely recommend it for a visit

Very interesting and definitely worth a visit. This museum is far more modern and much better displayed than any other we have visited in Vietnam. There is a lot of information about the lives of women in Vietnam, from many different perspectives. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

A place to honor women. This excellent museum showcases women’s role in Vietnamese society and culture.The Vietnamese Women’s Museum is a community repository of cultural and historical knowledge about Vietnamese women’s lives across the nation’s 54 ethnic community groups. The Museum is also a centre for cultural exchange with women from other nations with the goal of fostering ‘equality, development and peace

Best museum. 5 floored so need at least 2 hrs. Very informative about child birth and marriage across diff ethnic tribes in Vietnam, working life, work and efforts during the war and fashion and traditional dress. There's very informative videos giving you real life story's of women's work life's and rituals for marriage and birth, plus displays and many pictures. Great way of getting knowledge of diff tribes before heading to sapa. Only wish we had more time here instead of in the ho chi Minh museum and Vietnamese history museum.

Museum Visit. This museum is well worth a visit when in Hanoi. The visit took us 2 hours to investigate the 3 floors which were open. The staff were all friendly, helpful and efficient .The layout of the museum is perfect with signage in Vietnamese, English and French. Adequate written descriptions of all artefacts explaining the date, purpose and detail. We especially liked the selection of costumes and the explanation and examples of textile techniques. The museum shop is worth a visit with well priced gifts and mementoes. The coffee shop is also an excellent stop with a range of coffees and refreshments. A perfect sightseeing and informative venue.
Incredible Museum. This was one of the highlights for the City. Beautifully designed building and the history of the women in Vietnam is incredibly interesting and valuable.

Gender Equality in Action. This museum was a joy to behold! The history was so interesting as well as impressive; the role that women have taken in Vietnam's history and the social standing they still enjoy surpasses any western country. I really enjoyed finding out about traditional Vietnamese culture as well as more about the wars that have moulded the country into the nation it is now. I would say take your time, I spent around 2 hours there and I would have preferred to have a little more time. It's pretty cold in the museum so take a jacket.
Woman Museum. Opened our eyes to the role women have played in the history of Vietnam which from my point of view was amazing
waste time. very waste time for this museum as it was really boring for me. The service there was not good at all. So, i would not recommend people come to this place.
Part of the history of Vietnam. A must place to visit and give yourself plenty of time. What would Vietnam done without their women. Every floor has different aspects of interest.

A nice way to learn about women in Vietnamese society. The museum is quite diverse, showing the culture and lifestyle of women in Vietnam through different perspectives: fashion, war, day-to-day life, marriage and children, history and so on. It's an interesting museum and you can easily pass a couple of hours here looking at the artefacts and watching some of the videos (most are in Vietnamese with English subtitles). It's located centrally, to the south east of the Hoan Kiem lake and costs 30,000 dong to go in. Some nice cafes right outside too. Really enjoyed it!
Women's Contribution to the country. I'm inclined to think that without the women's perseverance and motherly nature, Vietnam may take even longer to win the war.

Fabulous museum!. Fascinating museum focusing on women's lives in Vietnam. Includes an entire floor on fabric arts and women's fashion, which was my favorite part. But the entire museum was wonderful. Loved it!

Over your expectaation. Women's Museum is located in 36 Ly Thuong Kiet, Hoan Kiem, Ha Noi, Viet Nam. It takes you about 10 minutes from Hoan Kiem lake. Beside Permanent Exhibitions with Womens in Family, Womens in history and women's fashion. Some specialy exhibition such as workshipping mother Goddnes, Mam-art projest and past exhibition are also very interested to see.At least 3-4 hours you need to see everything in here and you will never be disappointed.

Excellent overview of women's history in Vietnam. We loved this museum as it gave us a chance to learn about a diversity of women (numerous ethnic minorities, war heroes) their role, customs and fashions.

Closed for tet . Reopening on the 24th of feb just though some hopeful travellers should know. There are some great coffee shops that surround this area and the Hoa Lo prison is a short walk away and was open on the 20th when we went.

Extensive collection... too extensive for some. The museum feels bit repetitive in its displays, although it is certainly worth a visit, especially if you like textiles. My male parter would not have cared for this museum. However, there is a cafe next door where the uninterested may opt out in favor of a beer or a coffee.

The power of winen. I was astounded to learn about Vietnamese women ... They changed the face of vietnam throughout history. Their courage and strength is extraordinary Don't miss this museum. Watch documentaries shown throughout each floor

Quite interesting. Ok so I'm a male and whilst women interest me I did not think a museum about women would be of much interest. I was wrong. I found it very informative. I learned much more than just things about the multitude of women's issues. I learned about the ethnic groups that exist in Vietnam, their national dress, and the contribution that women made to their battles for independence.The price is cheap and the visit was worthwhile.
Worth a visit. An amazing history of the women that helped create Vietnam today...unlike Western countries, the women of Vietnam are reverred ☺️

Cultural experience with displays of costumes and household items. Well laid out displays of traditional clothing and video footage of interviews with real women who sacrifice their home life selling simple items on the streets of Vietnamese cities, to earn money to support their families/ children who live in the rural villages back home. Very moving stories of the history and culture of Vietnamese women. Worth spending an hour or so viewing something so simple yet interesting.

Good museum for 1-2 hours. Good to learn about Vietnamese women in the mostly patrilineal Vietnamese society. Museum has about 5 floors, each with a different focus, including birth, marriage, fashion, etc. To me, the most interesting was women's role in the war on ?3rd floor. It shows that women have the courage, nationalism, and viciousness that is usually attributed to men. It's worth 1-2 hours visit for the price. But, the ethnology and ho chi minh museums are better for information.

One of the highlights of our trip. For a nominal fee you can visit the Women's Museum which highlights the accomplishments of Vietnamese women not only as leaders in their matriarchal culture but as vital military members in wartime. I liked that women are shown beyond the home as successful individuals in addition to family roles. There are about five levels to the museum, but are easy to access so see all of them. Pictoral history of some women you've probably never heard of but will be inspired by.
A great insight. It made me look at things in a new way, which is always good, and at Vietnamese women with new respect. A very interesting couple of hours and a nice mix of displays, videos etc.

A must. We went there because of a recommendation in our travel-app and really liked it. The museum is divided in different parts of women's life and history in Vietnam and if you are interested in more than just strolling through the streets but also in culture and history, it is a very interesting place to visit. You will learn a lot about women in Vietnam and therefore also about men, children, politics, history, ethnic groups, religion, marriage ceremonies, fashion, women in war times, heroes... I totally agree with a previous review that the movie about the street vendors is most interesting, but there are many more movies which are not to miss. Not only a place for women and a great place to understand and learn lot about a fascinating country.

Definitely worth a visit. This is very informative museum of women and family in Vietnam, from birth, marriage and all aspects of life. It's well set out and so interesting. You can see the position of women, women in fashion, war and history. Great!

Favourite museum in Vietnam. Very well done, a lot of information about women in Vietnam, minority cultures and traditions, clothing, rituals, women's role in the wars. Along with the Museum of Ethnology this was my favourite museum in Vietnam.

Great museum. A very informative museum that is well set out and easy to follow. I especially loved learning about the different tribes and their marriage and birth traditions, as well as the hill tribe fashions. Would definitely recommend doing this when you're in Hanoi.

Worth a visit!. The museum show you the history and role the women have/had in the Vietnamese history and in the society.From hard working farmers, their role as soldier in the wars, as factory workers, how mothers brought up family as sole provider. How clothes were made & what kind of jewellery they worn.But also interesting stories told by women of today in all sorts of occupations and their thoughts about life today. (short movies with audio translator)It's a short walk from the old quarter and cost 3 US$. And takes about 2 hours to go through.

Good museum that you can see in about 1 hour. This was one of the more enjoyable museums in Hanoi. It's organised by theme so you can pick and choose what subjects you are interested in. There is a bit of reading required to get the most out of the displays, but it's manageable. It's a shame that there's few displays about women in Vietnam in more moderm times, I was hoping to learn about the experiences and challenges of Vietnamese women today. It was also really lovely to see many women working at the museum.

Strong spirit of strong womens. Really enjoyed the visit to Women´s Museum. The Museum is huge, on 5 floors and each and every floor is so amazing and impressing. Really can feel the spirit of the strong women of this nation.
Great. Myself and fiancee both thought this was the best museum in hanoi. If you can see only one, this is it
Great museum. Great history of women and family in Vietnam, birth, marriage and all aspects of lve. A must see in Hanoi.

Interesting alternative to the Ethnology museum. Some museums are closed on Monday such as the ethnology museum so ended up going to the Womens museum. There is a lot of information on ethnic minorities here too and has background information if you are planning to visit Sapa

one of the better museums in Vietnam. I think this was definitely one of the better museums in Vietnam.As the name implies, it's a museum dedicated to the contributions of women.. It presents different aspects of women in the country,
histry of strong women in VN culture. well worth the visit especially if you have an interest in the wars between the French and Vietnamese and American's and Vietnamese.

Definitely worth a visit. This museum is very interesting, and certainly not just for women. Honestly, there is enough material here to keep you there all day, depending on how much you're able to absorb! We sputtered out after nearly 2 hours, and we could have taken it more slowly. Many different aspects of culture are presented in this museum and I'd highly recommend taking as much time as possible for this museum. It's several floors/stories, and the layout of this museum is very nice. There's a cafe right outside the steps, and the Hoa Lo Prison is pretty close.

Interesting place. After years, Hanoians find this place a intersting place to visit, not only for a simple museum but moreover, a comtemporary designed museum in town. Lost of events hold here and toursist should not miss it out.

Starts with Marriage traditions but higight is women's participation in wars. Pick your floors wisely:1) wedding and birth traditions. The contrast of matrilineal and patrilineal tribes. was fascinating. Lots of clothing and jewelry information Entry video: street vendor life is compelling2) women in wars. Some hard reading - names of dozens of girls and women who had tough roles in upholding the fights for vietnam's independence. Entry display: Heroic Mothers. Beautiful candid photos, see this after the rest of the floor. 3) fashion. We had gone through tok much, skipped it. Bonus: independent ME art gallery on the top floor, showcasing works from children workshops also nice modern work of a few artists.

Located near/in the old quarter.. The musuem is a great way to spend an hour while in the old quarter. Entry is cheap and it is great to get to learn about the history behind Vietnamese weddings and see all the dresses that the women would wear!
So much to see. Five floors covering different aspects of women's life. Well set out and labelled. Interesting exhibits and great value for money. We spent ages here

Interestimg!. Visit the place if you have spare time on your hands. Otherwise not a must see. I went there without too much expectation and the visit was pleasant. Cater around 2 hours for a thorough see through of the place. The place does offer some interesting history worthy of going into your historical knowledge of vietnam.
Fine collection. Well arranged collections. I like English caption. The sleeping bed is very good. Amazing stuff on the items related to pregnancy and delivery. The dress collection is very colorful.

Really interesting, a must see. The Women's Museum was one of the highlights of my time in Hanoi, exploring the roles and activities of women in Vietnam's various diverse ethnic groups. Make sure you set aside a couple of hours in order to fully explore the exhibits. Of particular interest for me was the level on women in combat, as well as the special exhibit on Mother Goddess worship in Vietnam.I'd very highly recommend making a trip here.

Well worth a visit. It gives a real insight into the lives of women who work in Hanoi to subsidise and support their families. There is also a section on the role of women in the War with USA, some of the wording is biased, but somewhere between this version and what we grew up with from the USA lies the actual story
Fascinating exploration of women and their place. very well laid out with fascinating exhibits and good commentary. Particularly liked the section on women in history; so much to ponder and take in.
a great place. The Women’s Museum is one of Hanoi’s best. It features simple, compelling exhibits and has plenty of English captioning.

Highly worthwhile. Thanks to the good reviews on Tripadvisor, we decided to check out this museum. We weren't sold on it initially, but when we found one of the other museums was closed for lunch, we kept on walking and made our way here - and I'm glad we did! We really enjoyed learning more about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam - especially the different costumes, gifts, and customs for weddings. It was also very interesting to learn the part that women played in the wars. It is only with more well designed, clear, and informative museums like this that we can take more steps towards gender equality. Also, the fee for entry is very reasonable!

Fantastic. Loved this museum- there are 4 levels open at the moment and we found everything thoroughly interesting! Gave great insight into customs for Vietnamese women and how they live and have lived- definitely worth a visit.

One of the best museums in Hanoi. Worth visiting and getting an insight into the life of women in vietnam and some of the personal stories of women in the war both American and French. Interesting videos about marriage rituals and some displays of traditional clothing as well.Most of the museum's I've seen in Vietnam haven't differentiated between sexes, especially during the American war, in fact most highlight stories of women's struggle. Some of these stories are covered elsewhere in more detail, however the displays are well thought out and in multiple languages including English. Although some detail is lacking, especially as some of the clothing displays fail to suggest what they would typically worn for.
A place to understand Vietnamese women. Come here, I found they was heroic. they're small but they're so brave. you can't imagine how did they sacrifice their life for this country and their Families

Best museum in Vietnam - must see!. I absolutely loved this museum and highly recommend it to anyone who wants to learn more about the history of Vietnam as well as some personal stories.As anyone travelling through Vietnam will realise, women here work exceptionally hard and the museum offers great insights.Not only does it cover current times, or tribes, but also what food they cook, how they make a living and support their families, war time and traditions.On the top floor is an art exhibition which I also liked.Make sure you have enough time to visit the museum, I spent 4 hours here and think 2 should definitely be needed.Also - they have all information in Vietnamese, English and French!
Very informative; nicely curated. Easy to access, well set out - very interesting. The display about the role of women in conflicts is especially good.

Best museum in Hanoi (even Vietnam). This was overall by far the best museum we have visited during our 3 month Asia travel. It was interesting, diverse, well set up, nicely presented and they provided enough and interesting accompanied information.

Deserves all the praise it gets. I went to the Vietnam Women’s Museum to remind myself how extraordinary women are, and these incredible Vietnamese women did not disappoint. From the traditions and folk customs of married life and childbirth to the lady goddess of earth, water, air, and fire; from the women street vendors who are forced to live in Hanoi away from their families in the villages in order to support them, while earning only pittance, to their village home life where they spend days in the fields, cook for their families, and are employed for clothing making and basket weaving. Work never ends. And the women of war who fought alongside their men and helped rebuild the country, literally and figuratively, thereafter. This was my favorite section - dozens of brief bios showcase the mind-blowing feats of women during the Vietnam War. This museum is a testament to the truth: that women are brilliant, strong as steel, and insanely heroic. Enough said.

Insight into life of others. A wonderful museum. Gave really great insight into the history, culture and critical roles women play in Vietnam. Best exhibit was the street vendor interviews. Don't miss this museum!

Huh?. We saw great reviews of this spot but didn't agree. Several floors of displays; focusing mainly on dress. In a country where women do a LOT of the work, seemed to underemphasize womens' major role in the Vietnamese economy!

Should be mandatory. go. History, culture, art and more. Not to be missed by men or women. From both, marriage to revolution it helps understand all of the Vietnam culture. Lots of info on ethnic minorities, too
Interesting museum, the best organised in Hanoi!. Interesting, covering many different topics, from rituals and clothes to the role of women during the wars.

Hmmm. Seems a bit as if the procures had a lack of material. The only good part is a quick video on the street peddlers - we gave tons of money away after watching this quick video on their situation. Visit if you can. Vive la femme.

my favorite museum in Hanoi. This museum, dedicated to the Vietnamese women, is well organized, fairly modern, and quite interesting. Start on the top floor, and work your way down in a circular fashion. My favorite exhibit was a short film containing interviews with female street vendors.The entrance fee is negligible ($1.50), the exhibits are self-explanatory and in English, and there's a nice cafe (with free wifi) in the museum's front courtyard. Plan to spend an hour or two here.

Great visit!. We liked how they divided up the museum as it was easy to follow and easy to understand all the exhibits. ITs clear to see the role that women play in vietnam and how important it is b/c of all the war the country has had to endure over the years. Must see when you are in Hanoi.
Interesting. Interesting to see woman's involvement in war time. To be honest not really interested in museums in Asia

Clear, interesting and informative . Really interesting museum. It is clearly split into different sections with colourful information boards which are easy to read and follow. I've found many of the museums hard to appreciate because they are filled with artefacts with no relevance or information and sometimes no English translation, but everything is clearly explained here. Particularly enjoyed the women revolutionaries, street vendors and ethnic minority sections. One of the best museums in my travels so far, highly recommend.

Informative museum with poor layout. This museum is cheap to see and gives an adequate insight into the lives of Vietnamese women and their roles within society. However I was left a little disappointed with the scattered information with no real structure. I felt as if I was jumping from exhibit to exhibit without fully understanding what was happening at that point in time. A time line and redesign of the information is really necessary!

Interesting, but way overpraised. The museum has a decent amount of culture, and is manageable for an hour or two. But I find the raves about it way over the top. Unfortunately, like much else in this part of the world, it reeks of propaganda. There are however some feel-good beautiful photos and sayings scattered about. And it will speak to some feminists.
Not to be missed. A superb museum detailing the women of Vietnam. Not in many guide books which it should be. easily spend 2-3 hours enjoying the very well laid out displays.

A Well-presented Museum. This museum covers a good range of women's lives in Vietnamese culture, including women's role in family life, marriage, religion, business and war, as well as exhibits about clothing. Particularly interesting is the exhibition about the street traders in Hanoi, and the details about different traditions amongst ethnic minorities across Vietnam. Compared to some of the other museums in Hanoi, it is well presented; there is lots of signage giving a story, rather than just piles of artefacts without context. Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit.. Good English signage at each exhibit. For me the best bit was the film about the female street vendors - gave me a whole new perspective. I knew the worked hard - but they have very hard lives .... Give them your time.

Vietnamese women are heroes. After spending more than 2 hours in Vietnamese women's museum, we really admired vietnamese women, they are shining examples for all women throughout the world.They are really hard-working, considerate as well as intelligent. We really want to express our thanks to the museum where we could know everything relating to vietnamese women: birth, marriage, religion, traditional crafts and costumes, etc.

Wonderful!. I was very impressed with this well presented Museum dedicated to Woman. Note seen this in any there country before. History, dedications to woman and their part in the culture of Vietnam and hardships they faced and face. The Vietnamese woman are amazing. My husband really enjoyed this too.
Quite Beautiful. It's a really nice set up in here and very colourful. There is a really nice textiles display that accompanies the stories of the people.

Proud of Vietnamese women. we now know that Vietnamese women is very strong and special. no matter how difficult their life is, they always try to overcome. especially, during the past, they are not only a mother, a father to take care of their family but also a strong rear.

Brilliantly presented museum of family life. Excellent curation of all issues central to women - birth, marriage, religion, traditional crafts and costumes, plus the role of women throughout Vietnamese social and political history from the Truong sisters to resistance against the French and Americans. Totally engrossing. Needs a good 2 hours to begin to do it justice. Excellent!

Very interesting!. The museum provided a unique insight into the lives of women throughout Vietnam's long and coloured history. It covered marriage and birth rituals to traditional outfits and a provided a close examination of women in Vietnam today. There is a lot to see and experience, so give it ample time!

Educational. I know educational sound a little dry, but this museum was really interesting and we all came out and all agreed it was a very worthwhile visit. It showed the many aspects of life for women in Vietnam - culture, customs, skills and their contribution to the war. A short visit also put into context the life of the street sellers and street food ladies.. No regrets.
Worth seeing. Just watching the video of the street vendors, the bowls hanging in the atrium and some of the outfits was worth it.

Great museum. This museum has wonderful exhibits on the role of women in Vietnamese culture and history. It is well-organized and rich with so much information--I only wish we had visited earlier in our trip, because it provided useful context for so much of what we saw.

Enjoyed this - worth the visit. This is one of the better museum experiences I have had in SE Asia since I moved here 18 months ago. The museum is well organized with interesting and well explained exhibits (in Vietnamese, French and English). The women in history exhibit and the "women fashion" exhibit are really interesting. The museum also has a lovely courtyard and coffee shop in front to enjoy post or pre visit

Interesting, different, informative. The museum is divided in different parts of women's life and history in Vietnam and if you are interested in more than just strolling through the streets, but also in culture and history, it is a very interesting place to visit. You will learn a lot about women in Vietnam and therefore also about men, children, politics, history, ethnic groups, religion, marriage ceremonies, fashion, women in war times, heroes... I totally agree with a previous review that the movie about the street vendors is most interesting, but there are many more movies which are not to miss. Not only a place for women and a great place to understand and learn lot about a fascinating country.

Very Interesting. I found this museum very interesting, particularly the short film about the female street sellers with interviews and also the history on the contribution of vietnamese women during the war. The bravery and heroism of these women is quite unbelievable.I think it is definitely worth a visit if you are spending some time in Hanoi.

Very well thought museum. Dont miss!!!A serious museum and excellent experience. The building outside may be ordinary but the interior, layout and setting is very much the 1 or 2 hours spent.Check the link for a quick tour:http://m.youtube.com/watch?v=zblSTp_U70w&feature=youtu.be
worth a visit. I liked the video of interviews with women who sell fruit and veg in the streets. You dont think about why they do this and what it entails. Its worth a visit just for that.

The women of Vietnam. This museum focuses solely on the women of Vietnam, as the name implies. It's educational and has some good exhibitions to show both clothing and tools used in daily life. Some multimedia exhibits are also part of the museum where you can learn more about the struggles of the Vietnamese women. There are also showings of the wedding rituals and preparations that should not be missed.Absolutely worth a visit for both men and women,
Well worth a visit. Great museum to learn about the contributions the women of Vietnam gave given to their families, religion and country.

Educational and a must see in Hanoi. Reasonably priced at only 30,000VND per person the Women's museum in Hanoi is a great place to learn more about Vietnam and its women. You could spend an hour or two here or even more if you wanted to read and learn everything. The bathrooms aren't crash hot so don't expect much but the displays are nicely presented and organised in a logical way.

Don't miss it.. As far as anyone concerned, woman's role differed a lot between cultures; and Vietnamese Women's Museum really helped us Westerner's to get a quick glimpse about these cultural differences. Now I'm jealous with the Vietnamese men already(j/k) !

Vietnamese women are superior to any men!. They are caring and hardworking. They are fierce and brave in defending their nation. They are personable in everyday life. They are wonderful and talented in this modern society. I know that many Vietnamese women now still suffer from hardship and poverty, but with such characteristic traits, they will eventually be happy. At least that is my wish.

an amazing museum in Vietnam. The museum shows many artifacts helped me understand more about the Vietnamese Woman, gives me a good insight into the experiences and contributions of Vietnamese women to political and social life. It covers everything from babies to revolution. Every country should have one of these! I love it so much.
Lots to learn and see!. What a fascinating way to spend a few hours! Lots of costumes, artifacts and history all packed together make this a site for men and women alike. Loved this discovery!!

No info on the French eara or Religion. Fine to walk around for an hour, but I could not get over the sheer oversight of excluding the impact of Catholicism or European colonization of the country! A Disney inspired Museum for Women, with the inevitable part of on the American War. Chance lost to make this a real museum of information, rather than of propaganda! The traditional birthing area was the part I found most interesting!

One hour for learning quickly about women in Vietnam. Clean, educational, convenient, well worth seeing.. Quiet, educational, enjoyable, well worth seeing. Convenient to most tourist locations. Easy to walk to and spend one hour.

Major props to the ladies. After visiting other sites around Vietnam, I was aware of the plight of Vietnamese women. However, this museum provides deeper insight into their specific roles throughout history. I particularly liked the documentaries about street vendors. I wouldn't say this museum is particularly exceptional but it's certainly worth checking out.

Thought provoking and beautiful. this is a must for anyone interested in the story of women in Vietnam, it is beautifully set out, is accessible for those with only English as a language. the textiles on the top floor must not be missed.

Well worth a visit. Great overall of the role of women in Vietnamese society
Highlighted the diversity in culture and beliefs amongst women in different Vietnamese groups

Set aside half a day to explore this museum. The museum has convenient lockers where you can store your bags while you explore the multi-level museum. Each level is dedicated to a different part of the role of Vietnamese women in the past and present of the country. The narratives of female revolutionaries capture the imagination; while the highly informative displays of traditional life give tourists insight into the different societies that make up the Vietnamese population. Well worth a visit!

The important role of women. Given the still sexist nature of Vietnamese society, it was a pleasant surprise to see the role of women recognized in at least one way: war and resistance to enemy occupation. The video interviews of street vendors was particularly poignant.
Definitely not a museum to miss. The information displayed is thorough and organized and very interesting! I loved the layout of the museum and found it very easy to navigate.

A great insight into Vietnamese history and culture. I loved this museum; it gives a good insight into the experiences and contributions of Vietnamese women to political and social life. It covers everything from babies to revolution. Every country should have one of these!

Quite an interesting museum. The Women's Museum was not even on our list, but a friendly elderly couple recommended it one day at breakfast. It turned out to be quite an interesting museum. There's a lot to read and learn about women's role in Vietnamese traditional and modern society. Quite a lot of information while the exhibits are simple to non-existent. Opens early and is a 10 minute walk from Hoa Lo Prison, so the two can be combined.

Women Rule. My wife was very keen to visit this museum and really liked most of the exhibits, in particular the part related to women birthing. She is a midwife after all.I really enjoyed the historical aspect of exibits and stories of bravery from women during the war in Vietnam (or American War as it is called there).The different costumes and apparel from different regions was also very interesting.All in all worth visiting

Museum is almost too big. My girlfriend and I went there in the afternoon and the museum is not a must see...The museum is very nice and well done, but there is a lot to read, almost too much! If you are very interested in Vietnamese weddings and traditions it's worth a visit.

Well done! . We spent nearly 3 hours in this museum and learned a lot about the women of Vietnam. The museum's setup is done nicely and the different video films are most informing. The written explanations on the wall are also interesting. All together we recommend this museum for those who are interested in the cultural and societal aspects of Vietnamese women.
So much cool history. This is a great place. Full of pictures and information makes this an amazing experience. Really neat to see what a big impact these women make. Fantasstic

Very central and will fill in an hour. We liked that this was easy to walk to and saw an insight to the history which was interesting. It did not take very long though to look around.
I believe in seeing for yourself though to make your own judgement and at least say you have seen it.

Average yet important. As far as museums go, this is a fairly average attempt at presentation. The displays are mostly static, a very large number of displays of clothing have little or no explanation. However, there is much more of value here. The area displaying worship of the Mother Goddess was interesting. The two sections that most attracted us were the short movie of women street vendors describing their lives and why they needed to work so incredibly hard. Westerners just don't know. The section recording the sacrifices of individual women in the struggles against invaders since and including the Japanese has, by far, the most impact. What I found most striking of all is that the state, in a third world country, has recognised and institutionalised the role and equality of women. An average attempt at presentation but an outstanding social comment and well worth visiting.

Well Done Museum. This museum is full of great information of the Vietnamese Women's roles throughout time. The information is presented in Vietnamese, English and French, making it very easy for foreigners to follow. The floor plan of the museum is well planned and flows nicely. The information on the various artifacts/ textiles is lacking, it would be nice to know more detail on how the items were used. Other than that, this museum is well worth the visit.

One of the best museums in entire Vietnam. This museum gives you a very good overview about the different tribes, family life and women during the wars in Vietnam. Excellent exhibition, one of the best I have seen in entire Vietnam.
A gem. Well worth a 1.5 hour visit, lots to see and read about, especially of pioneering women during the American War.
Ok. Ok to visit. U get first hand information about women of Vietnam . Should have been more Elobrate about sacrifices of Vietnamese women and hardship they faced instead more focus on clothes.
OK for a short visit. A few interesting displays. Some of the film footage seemed interesting but the subtitles were mainly French so we could not understand! No more than 1 hour required to visit.

Well worth a visit. The museum is a calm and peaceful place, well set out and informative. The women in history section stirred my emotions. Inspirational, but sad to read of women's lives lost during times of conflict, particularly those who were imprisoned and tortured and/or executed. I came out feeling humbled.

An unexpected and outstanding find. It's hard to pinpoint how the design and focus of this museum made both my wife and I want to read and ask questions about literally every display in the place, but somehow they did it. We visit unique collections and museums on every trip where we are not too far in the back country. This is among the best we have visited in the world.

Fantastic. Very interesting and well worth the effort to visit, the token entrance fee doesn't do justice to the story told at the museum.
Not very well advertised so that is a little disappointing and think the local people would do well to send the message out to visit.
