Boring. It was just not interesting. I felt we wasted our time and can't quite get the excitement on tripadvisor. But that is obviously my personal opinion...

Excellent history of women's strong roles in Vietnam life.. 30,000 vd per person (€1.15) admission with child free. A cultural history of Vietnamese women's role in society over five floors of this museum. Excellent videos and signage with French and English subtitles . Lovely friendly staff all with English. Storage for hand luggage so you can relax when u learn. Harrowing videos of hard life during wars and also of street vendors struggles .....sad ......but such determined women working hard to give their children better lives.
Insightful. Brilliant! We got an insightful view on the hard working women in Vietnam. Sad but definitely worth the visit
A quick visit. We only had 30 minutes for a quick look around the museum and could have spent more time here. Lots of interesting artefacts and information.
very nice museum to visit. A great deal of history and it was well done. The price was not high but the meuseum was quite large

Must See. This excellent museum showcases women's role in Vietnamese society. There is a good collection of costumes, tribal ware. It has a lot of historical information on women's lives. Its overlooked among museums in Hanoi and deserves a higher listing.

Really worth a visit. A well done museum with lots to see and many interesting things. Really worth a visit. From heroines of the American/Viet War to stalwarts of the Viet history. Interesting. The textile exhibit may interest many too and the photographs of the ladies of different ages and times was fascinating.

Great summary of Vietnam's history and traditions. The museum will show you the substance of the Vietnamese society taking you through everyday aspects like marriage, birth, work, fashion, religion and the role of women in politics. The organization is great, you will not be disappointed.

Best Museum in Hanoi. One of my main complaints about many of the museums we went to in Hanoi was that they were very poorly curated. There were artifacts or photos, but no context (even if there were English translations). This museum was the exception, and I would highly recommend it.
great short visit. Easy to find, easy to tour on your own. Really enjoyed the ethnographic info. Loved the war heroes floor - that was the highlight. And it has a café right there.
understand vietnam well. Very nice museum.Payed only 3 Dollars if i caN remember.It is very informative.4 Storeys to learn about thier culture.Dont miss it!worth visiting
interested. There are a lot of good thing to see and its make you know more about hows the vietnamese women's life.

Tough women!. The Vietnamese are not misogynists. Women are equal (and often do more) than the men. Some good insight into the lives of women at peace and at war. During the long French occupation, the Japanese occupation during the war and the “American” war, women were as active as the men. Worth the visit.

You'll never see Viatnamese women the same way. Really good museum about Viatnamese women. Don't miss the film about women selling whatever they can along the road. I also had no idea of the importance of the work women did during the war before we visited this museum.

Lots of History. This was a very nice museum to visit. There was a great deal of history and it was well done. The price was not high and yet the meuseum was quite large. Would not need more than 2 hours to go through it unless you read absoultly everything.

Well worth a visit. This museum is FAR better than the National History Museum in relation to it's interpretation. You are actually given interesting information about the exhibits and each of the floors has narrative. There are four floors in total. The attic held a temporary art exhibit, which was not worth the space. The lower three floors have exhibits on women's clothing (a good introduction to the costumes of the minority ethnic tribes if you are going to visit Sapa), family life (including a fascinating glimpse into patriarchal and matriarchal societies of the North and South), and the role of the goddess in religion.I particularly found moving the exhibits on the contribution of women in the war of independence and one on the life of street vendors. The former included real life stories of the brave contribution made by so many. The latter will make you look differently at the hawker who approaches you in the hope that you may spend a few cents on some food. The money will probably mean nothing to most tourists but it could help a child to finish high school...Well done to all those connected to this museum. It is history and education at its best. It cost just 30000 dong - less than £1 - to enter. The museum is about a 10 minute walk from the bottom of )Hoan Kiem Lake.

An insight. I would not have considered this museum if it hadn't been for TripAdvisor but thought as it's reviews were so good I would go.As a group of mid twenties guys, we were not sure what to expect and were a little sceptical as to what we would experience. However, the visit was very interesting and gave a great insight into the lives of women over the years and of the Vietnamese culture as a whole. Each floor presented a different aspect of a woman's life in Vietnam and I felt like I left with a huge amount of knowledge from just a very short visit. I would recommend this to you if you have time for it!

Women at war and much more.. Themed on marriage, ritual and ceremony, and war there is much to offer for the cost of a few pence. Subtitled video show what a tough time it is for many trying to make ends meet. The floor on women's involvement in the Vietnam war was particularly fascinating. They may look like delicate little flowers but they are as hard as nails. Well worth a visit and there are plenty of coffee shops nearby and a decent ice cream bar down the road.

If you are free.... If you have an additional day in Hanoi, you may want to visit this museum but I recommend the Huo Lo Prison or Ho Chi Minh museum over this any day. Exhibits are interesting but nothing to gape about.,

Informative and thought provoking. The museum has very interesting exhibits with thorough english and french translations. It was fascinating to learn about Vietnamese women's experience, beliefs and crafts through history and there were some great videos about the modern experience from several class perspectives. The section on female revolutionary leaders was particularly interesting.

Great insight to history and modern times. This was my favorite site in Hanoi. I was disappointed that the 5th floor was closed for renovation. When you walk in there is a daycare center for the women who work there it appeared. Glad they were practicing women's rights where they were educating others on them, seems like there is a lot of opportunity for female empowerment in Vietnam. Really enjoyed a movie I watched on street vendors, and readings on pregnant women, childbirth and nursing, all very insightful.
Vietnamese women rule!. Loved the North VN propaganda posters from the American war. The women worked and fought so hard. So many war heroines!

Really interesting. Really interesting to learn about the history of the woman's role in Vietnam but also about the lives of women there today. Really puts it into perspective and makes you respect/understand the women you see selling things along the streets of the city

Most interesting to learn about contributions of women to daily life. It was part of our three days tour organised by EXO Tours. Our guide was very knowledgeable. He explained the daily life of a woman in Vietnam, the contribution a woman makes in society, the crafts in textiles, metals, wood, paper, pottery, leather, horn, soil, glass etc…Very educative and a learning experience worth the visit. It reflects and presents the rich cultural heritage of the society.
Interesting. My wife wanted to go in here and I'm glad we did as it shows you a lot of info on the history of the Vietnamese woman's history...

Great museum. This museum is much bigger than I anticipated. It covers marriage and family, political activists, fashion, and more. The shop has numerous items made by women and there is a great restaurant in front of the museum.
good tiem here. i went this museum by moto bike mr Thang in my hotel take me to there it's good to see and take photo

A lesson gain. Worth the time.. Worth the time to visit the museum. Best museum I visited in Hanoi! I totally love this museum, how they arrange and layout the different content. Informative and interesting facts! Feels like I have just went for a class and learned about the life of a women in Vietnam. Spend some time there, you won't regret.

Interesting!. Good exhibits informs of the context around women in Vietnam. A whole floor is dedicated to their role in the war, another to wedding customs in the various ethnic minorities. Most interesting to me was the small section on the stories of the women street sellers. I would have valued more about viet women's role today and through time. Good exhibits!

Definitely worth a visit. This museum might not be seem very impressing and does not display art or many interesting artefacts, yet it is a very interesting place to help understand history of Vietnam and especially how women contributed to it.Through different angles, family, countryside, cities, war... life of women is explained and it is very clear that it is a hard one. I enjoyed this museum a lot and I learned many things.
A must see. Very interesting, after a visit to the museum I looked differently at female street vendors. Well worth a visit

An eye opener on women in Vietnam. I found this a fascinating insight into the women in Vietnam, both in the past and now. The museum is well layed out with great labeling. I felt that I understood the street vendors after this visit and had an insight into their struggles to support their families

Honestly, Magnificent. Vietnam is the only country I've ever been in (including my own) that has a beautiful museum dedicated exclusively to women. And that speaks volumes. I was overwhelmed by this museum, its exhibits, the stories it told. And the fact that it chose to tell the story of women struggling the most, coming from their villages to work to provide for their families. No woman should miss this museum.

A pleasant surprise. This museum was surprisingly good. We went here to fill time while in Hanoi and really loved it. It really made us appreciate certain aspects of Vietnamese culture in a different light. None of us are the kind of people that read all of the information at museums but there was still plenty for us to look at. You couldn't spend all day there but it was a great thing to do with our spare time.

So unique. I don't think I have ever visited a museum before whose focus was totally on women. The exhibits were clear and easy to understand with audio an visual displays also. Very interesting I would totally recommend.

Learn about women in Vietnam. I liked this museum for it's celebration of the role of women in Vietnam (especially in the war and in society). It was particularly heart-breaking (and useful) to learn about the women with the poles and baskets you see everywhere and how they eek out an existence and earn money for the family who live elsewhere.

Very well presented. Overall the best museum I visited in Vietnam, all exhibits well presented and all information in English too.I was approached by a film crew from Vietnam state television for an interview about the experience!
OK. Okay museum, but don't expect any feminist revolutions or revelations. Although very nicely arranged.

A great insight into the women of Vietnam. I would say this is one of the must dos in Hanoi. A great range of exhibits and photographs detailing the part women have played in the development of the country.Make sure to spend five minutes watching the film shot by an American university about the lives of the women street vendors in Hanoi. VERY thought provoking! Made me want to buy every pineapple and doughnut on the street!
Good visit. I enjoyed seeing the different clothes and reading about the customs of the people. It's not expensive and takes about an hour to go through.

Worth a Visit. Just a few metres from the Melia Hotel. This museum does not feature on most organised tours of Vietnam - and it should. There are three floors detailing the role of women in Vietnamese society over several centuries. There is a great exhibit on marriage customs which varied tremendously throughout the country.

Worth to see!. I love the displays & video presentation which they provide. The staff are also friendly too & able to give me a direction for traveling in HANOI ( where to go & where to visit). The location was good, not to far from the other museum & opera house.

Interesting. We went to the museum today as part of our Hanoi Kids tour. It was informative, interesting and sparked some great conversations with our guides. It is worth a quick visit. It helped to develop our understanding of the broad range of woman's roles, histories and cultures in Vietnam. Our 10 year old daughter especially enjoyed this museum. Ps. Doesn't take long to visit, maybe set aside one hour.

Most Surprising Museum in Town. First, check out the video about street vendors. It's very enlightening, and you won't look at those women the same after viewing the film. Then take a good look at the Mother Goddess exhibit. This is a Vietnam original conception, with her four persons. Thirdly, I recommend the war exhibit. Find the woman who personally killed 150 American soldiers. Note too that women have been warriors in wars going back at least 2,000 years. I got very lucky and was invited to a concert at the museum where the Mother Goddess appeared, sang, danced, metamorphosed from one personality to another, and gave out gifts--all to the accompaniment of traditional Vietnamese instruments. You may like the costumes or other exhibits. Go go go!

A special place valuing women. I visited the museum with my wife and my parents, and must say it has been set up very well. This shows how much respect is given to women in this country. There are 5 floors with various themes, the videos are especially very touching...

Very informative!. This was a good museum to visit, I learnt a lot about the different tribes and the cultures with regards to weddings and child birth. My favourite part was the displays showing the contribution and impact the women made on the war.
Lucky day. Great museum with food videosWe visited on a day with Japanese student day and got in free and had lots of extras like Japanese tea ceremony

Nice place to learn about Vietnamese traditional.. Love their decoration and all the story behind the exhibit. It was take us 2 hours to go around this small museum without skipping any interesting memo their. Each was stick like a small story about our real life.Helpful!!!
Modern and informative . We liked this museum a lot. It is professional and modern. I just ask myself if that is the whole story, cause I missed the (not small) business and political active women.

A gem. Not as popular as some of the major museums but this is very interesting and focuses on womens position within society in Vietnam. Definately worth a trip if you have time as the exhibits are very well done and informative
Noshers view. Good information nice place to go, shows how women have progressed, takes a couple of hours to walk around

Enlightening and worth the visit. I loved the video telling you about the lives of the women who are food vendors in the city.
The clothing was beautiful and the wedding customs of the various tribes were interesting.
A great display of Female visionaries. This explains the roles that Vietnamese woman have and do play in everyday life. It ranges from famous soldiers to inventors. Well presented.

Great Museum with Great Presentation,. I love the displays & video presentation which they provide. The staff are also friendly too & able to give me a direction for traveling in HANOI ( where to go & where to visit). The location was good, not to far from the other museum & opera house. What I don't like from the museum was the smelt of the exhibitions good or display, the room may need an air freshener. Perhaps the management have an attention on it.Regards,Carindra UNTORO

Informative and well-designed. Hadn't planned on visiting this museum but passed by it and decided to stop in. Very informative and well-designed, with excellent displays containing the right amount of history/explanations to inform. Extensive section discussing different marriage traditions of the ethnic minorities (Hmong, etc.). Some videos with subtitles allow women's voices to directly communicate with the viewers, discussing working in the city, life in the villages, etc. A great experience.

Excellent, very interesting museum. Detailing many facets of Vietnamese women, starting with differing courtship/marriage customs among the many tribes. Vital roles women played individually and collectively in several wars. In the American war, they comprised 40 percent of the total forces! Taped interviews with a number of street vendors describing the grueling life they endure to bring money back to their families. Beautiful fashions on the 4th floor. There is a large open courtyard in front of the museum with a cafe. Free storage lockers.

Well thought out, interesting.. If you think about a museum as a learning experience, this one certainly hits the mark. There are interesting displays and some thought provoking videos which make you appreciate things you will see on the streets in Hanoi. Recommended.

Excellent museum with relevant interesting exhibits. I think this museum is overlooked by tour companies and I don't know why.It was far more interesting than the fine arts museum and any visitor to Hanoi would enjoy seeing this well laid out museum and it's exhibits.It is a modern museum but has much information especially for first time visitors to Vietnam.Well worth seeing.

Very Informational. I enjoyed the visit to the Vietnamese Women's Museum. The displays are very well presented and the costumes' evolution was very good. The various women's roles in Vietnam are well represented. Quite educational. (We did not explore food facilities and lockers & storage, so not sure if these amenities are available).
Must visit. Recommended to me by a friend who had lived in Hanoi, its a gem of a museum giving insight into the lives of a range of Vietnamese women
Really interesting and surprising. I learnt a lot about how Vietnamese women live and how important they are in the country. This is a must-visit for anyone who visits Hanoi for the first time.

Fascinating. I had no idea that women played such a vital and strong role in the development of Vietnam. This museum pays tribute to past and present individuals as well as women in general.
Well worth a visit.

Not to be missed. A good overview of Vietnam's ethnic diversity, matrilineal and patrilineal societies. As a cultural anthropologist, I found the information on the ethnic groups to be more comprehensive than what was presented at the museum of ethnology. The clothing displays were of secondary interest to me. But there were some excellent videos and photographs depicting women's varied roles in subsistence activities and also, during their struggle for independence. I knew little of the minority women's roles as fighters during the American/Vietnam war. Overall, an enjoyable visit. Be sure to check out the gift shop on the first floor. And the cafe outside near the entrance services delicious fruit smoothies.

Understand more about Vietnamese women!. The museum provided an overview of Vietnamese women. It is scientificly divided into themes: marriage, wartime, daily life, traditional costumes! I am most impressed with the sentence: "When there is enemy, even women would stand up against them."

Good museum celebrating life for the Vietnamese women. This was a four floor museum with a different theme on each floor. It was an excellent tribute to the contribution made by women in Vietnamese society.

Good insight into Vietnam and Women. A unique museum. Focus is on women's role in Vietnam over the past many years. Insight into how women supported the country during the American war along with how Vietnamese women struggle from day to day. It is an emotional experience that expands ones view point on women in Vietnam and on women in general.

Fascinating insight... Brilliant museum honouring the women of Vietnam. Ethnic fashions, Viet cong women soldiers, films of women street vendors, traditional wedding clothing displays and so much more.

A little surprising: more about the womans' role than her struggle. I do not recall a woman's museum in any other country so I'm not sure what I am comparing this to. This museum covered women's fashions to women's role in the liberation wars to several matriarchal societies. It certainly isn't a chronology of the struggle.

A nice celebration of womens' contribution to Vietnam. After seeing how hard Vietnamese women work in all areas of life there it was nice to see a museum dedicated to them. Although it starts of with wedding traditions, there is a lot more to see especially the contributions of Vietnamese women during the American war. The umbrella display in the staircase is stunning and we were visiting when a kindergarten class was being taken around the museum... so sweet to see the exuberant kids being explained things by their teachers.

Vietnamese Women's Museum. Vietnamese woman lives easy and very good that they organize such a museum. I liked it. The museum 3-4 floors, not so many tourists, pay a small ticket. You can sit, relax even the monitor screen, where women talk about their lives, work and worries. It is interesting to consider the suits, high-quality photos of women from minority ethnic groups of the north of Vietnam. I recommend to visit and men, too

Good choice. This is one of the best museum in Hanoi. If the Museum of Ethnology is the best one but it is far from the Old quarter, you have to take a taxi there. Incase you have couple hours free at your hotel and you want to see something interesting, you can take a walk to Women museum frm your hotel.
a must. It is small manageably in an hour and affords a great insight into women's lives. GoLiked a lot.It should be on everyone's itinerary.

Worth the visit - very interesting and nice museum.. Very interesting if you want to know more about the status of women in vietnam! Went there together with locals (from HanoiKids) which made this visit even more interesting and special.

Impressive. This is only a small museum and is quite understated, however it really gives an insight into the role of women in a wide variety of aspects of Vietnamese life. The combat images are striking. A suggestion would be to have better contrast information cards and to have them higher up in the cases. However a must visit when in Hanoi.
So interesting. This is such a good place to spend an hour or so. Extremely interesting and informative exhibits outlining the role Vietnamese women have had in key aspects of the country's history.

Women honoured in Vietnam. A very interesting museum in the French quarter. An easy walk from Hoan Kiem Lake and the old quarter. 4 floors dedicated to Vietnamese women as mothers, brides, entrepeneurs and heroines. The top floor all about clothing with examples of bridal, tribal, and religious clothing ! Video clips with english subtitles made this a worthwhile stop and afterwards enjoy one of the coffee shops nearby.
EPIC!!!!!!!!!!. Not to be missed. Shows how important women's role is in this country as far as family life, achieving independence and more. If you dont go anywhere else...come here.

Informative and well-kept. The museum is housed in a modern building, with air conditioning and great upkeep. The museum is interesting, although not really entertaining. Art exhibit on the top floor is really nice.
Worth a visit. Very interesting museum. The exhibition is of excellent quality. If you have the time in Hanoi and also need some time away from the traffic, then go here and learn more about Vietnam.

Interesting. Ticket cost vnd30000 despite what was said in the guide book or on their website. Is was quite a small museum and there weren't many people. Nevertheless is gave me a good idea of the lives of Vietnamese women - what they do for a living, wedding ceremonies and who they worship. It was all quite interesting but quite a small museum too - you can do it in an hour or so.

Interesting and inexpensive. This is a very interesting museum if you want to learn more about Vietnam and the women of Vietnam. Each floor has a different emphasis and all of the floors were interesting.
Really interesting. This is a really interesting place to visit. Parts were shocking when you realise what the conditions were like and the lives the prisoners led.
Well worth it. So much information and very well presented. It gave you a good historical idea about women in Vietnam and the roles they have played in its history.

Worth a visit. We spent 2-3 hours in this museum but it deserves more time. The video interviews of many of the women you see in the street gives great insight in Vietnamese culture. We were very surprised at the involvement of women in the military dating back thousands of years. The marriage traditions were also interesting. Take the time and see this.
Must see. Brilliant museum about woman in Vietnam. Stories are amazing and quite moving and the museum is well set out

Wonderful Museum Ever. Visiting This museum And Getting Know More About Vietnamese Women In The Past. Inside You Would See More What They Have Done For Their Country. Their Lifestyles, Their Traditions And What Have Made Them Become The Most Powerful Women In The history. I Have Visited Only Less Than An Hour, Therefore, Would definitely Be back When I Have More Time. Such AN Interesting Place, Especially For Those Who Are Feminist.

Excellent museum focused on role of women. It is a very good museum definitely worth a visit. Very well organised and good presentation. Interesting way of highlighting role of women in Vietnamese society. Commendable effort, generates admiration n respect for women.
A really good experience. We really liked this place. A good insight into the role of women in Vietnamese tribal societies. Well presented.

Informative view on culture. You'll never view the street vendors in the same way after watching a short film on the lives of these women and the work they do to support their families. A small, easy to follow and informative museum showcasing the lives and tradition of Vietnamese women across the country - from the more traditional lifestyle to a mural honoring women of the rebellion. You can tour the museum in 1-2 hours.
Informative. Good informative museum, well presented and well thought out. Probably one of the better museums in all of Vietnam.

Great to lean about the locals. We liked the level of information provided about the local Vietnamese women and ethnic tribes, well laid out and easy to walk around in a few hours - well worth a visit

Parts were interesting. I'd only recommend this place if you have more than a couple days in Vietnam. Was satisfied after going through for 1.5-2 hours. Some of the pictures inside were really interesting shots

Fine Museum. I was very interested, based on conversations I had had with Vietnamese friends, on the status of women in the country. This museum is well worth the $1.50 admission. It consists of 4 floors-an elevator is present- each encompassing a theme: role of women and traditions, famous women (including warriors), and fashion. (I skipped the fashion floor). The museum's exhibits, photographs, and artwork provide a lasting picture on the importance of women in Vietnam in cultural, historical, and artistic perspectives. The experience left me with the perception, perhaps inaccurate but probably the intent of the museum's curators, that women in Vietnamese society experience less discrimination than in many Western cultures.

Fascinating look at Women in Vietnam. The museum is quite large and talks about the role of Women in Vietnam. Particularly interesting was the fact that one part of Vietnam female children are preferred, and males preferred in the other part. There were also quite a few exhibits showing the role of women in the Vietnam War and the revolution against the French.
a bit disappointing . because of all the great reviews and the great stories of this museum I really expected a lot. I liked the information that was shown, but I expected it to be more in depth.

So well done. We unfortunately didn't have the time to see this museum properly. We underestimated how detailed, well presented and fascinating it would be. Vietnamese women have an amazing history, we were both disappointed we had to cut it short. Make the time, I would prioritise this over other sites.

By women - for all!. Very high museum standard and a balanced view on all the ethnic minorities in Viet Nam. Taking a fresh look at contemporary issues as well as the traditonal historical themes - and not avoiding the proud look upon women at war.

Great Insite. This was a very interesting visit into the lives of vietnamese women...very enlightened! The displays were informative and the photos really captured life for minority groups, hardships of women surviving on their own.

really interesting. Worth a visit. This museum was so interesting, loads of information about the costumes of women in the various ethnic groups of Vietnam (of which there are 54), their marriage traditions, family life, etc. etc. Also an interesting section about worship of the mother goddess.

don't rush..i did and will go back. I visited before an arranged trip elsewhere and wish I could've stayed longer. Near a school so even if you know the way the children will enjoy giving you directions. Very interesting and colourful exhibits..not too much text..the costumes and the heroines of the wars floors were the best for me but everything is worth your time. Every smile and photo more attractive and photogenic than the last. Very good coffee and friendly staff in the cafe/restaurant attached. Wish I had more time.

Very interesting, well designed museum. The museum shows exactly what the name suggests; the lives of the women of Vietnam and their massive importance to the culture, stability and even survival of the country during war. Lots to learn about in this spacious museum that is well structured and reasonably priced.

Very interesting. If you have a few hours free, make time to see this museum while you're in Hanoi. The womens' stories are well worth reading.The displays are clearly set out in French and English.The costumes on display are beautiful.You will leave enlightened about the lives of the women through Vietnam's history and for those who today walk the streets of Hanoi selling their wares in baskets.It is a wonderful tribute to the women of Vietnam.

Very informative place. The museum highlights the work and achivements of some amazing Vietnamese woman throughout the countries history.There are many different sections over 4 floors ( I think ). There are some really good dispays with a lot of information posted next to them.I'd say it's another 'must see' if you're in Hanoi.
We visited on Women's Day. From all the museums this was one of the most memorable. They captured the life and challenges of the Vietnamese women through generations. Absolutely heartwarming.
Good place. That's wonderful and excellent museum. You can see all the decoration same as the some of temple and show us about lady cultures. That's good.

great rainy day activity. Though we didn't know about this museum ahead of time, we stumbled across it in the French quarter while looking for a spot out of the rain. Happy accident! Wonderful tribute to the women of this beautiful country

Must see in Hanoi . This is a must see museum in Hanoi. Really well set out displays with just the right amount of information. We particularly enjoyed learning about the different marriage ceremonies in different Vietnamese cultural groups, and also about the work of women during the war.

Excellent!. Visited with two young Vietnamese friends who were as impressed as myself. Entry cost 30,000 Dong (less than £1) The display information was also in English. Most poignant was the floor devoted to the bravery of women during the wars not just with the US but also the many years of French colonial brutality.
A good insight . A great way to learn a bit about the private lives of Vietnamese, something that is quite hard to discover. Very interesting and insightful

Make this museum one of the first things you do in Hanoi. Excellent museum. Great layout. Seats everywhere to sit down whilst reading. Very good displays. Make this one of the first places you see in Hanoi as it makes the temple symbology make sense. Great little cafe. I enjoyed a Vienna coffee & my friend enjoyed a lovely drink too. Even gate crashed an art opening. Child friendly family friendly with beautiful souvenirs to boot. Highly recommended.

Vietnemese womens museum. a worthwhile visit to learn more about Vietnemese womens history and courage. Good to visit before setting out to the mountains or other areas to better understand traditions and the role of women
Great place. Visited here as part of a tour with Trang from Hanoikids. Great museum showing the life of the Vietnamese women through the ages, well worth a visit.

Lots to see & interesting. This was a very interesting and very well laid out, lots to see and easy to follow descriptions, 4 floors with different topics in nicely air conditioned room, there were Video to watch which helped explain things, well worth a visit.

Worth seeking out. Unfortunately this is not listed in most of the guide books. I can't imagine why it is not. I found it on Trip Advisor and was directed there by my Hanoikids guide. She (my guide) said it is not in the books, and when I checked I found she was correct. The exhibits are top-notch and the size is substantive while not being overwhelming. Coming from another culture, I found the information to be eye-opening both historically and culturally. I was surprised with Hoa Lo Prison had half dedicated to the women prisoners. After visiting the Women's Museum I was able to have a full understanding of how significant a role women have played in all parts of life in Vietnam for a very long time. It was one of my favorite experiences in Hanoi.

Feminism as well as communism. Two good 'isms' to learn about! (depending on your point of view). Great to see the praise and recognition of women in society! Each floor was different in content and very insightful. It was not all we expected as we were expecting more of a an emphasis on historic figures. However it was more of a timeline of womens roles in everything ranging from the war, to child rearing and marriage. It was a great cultural insight into the way in which world traditions are carried out. There was also a heroic tribute to female revolutionaries!

Great Insight Into The Opposite Sex. This museum is a lot larger than you might expect and you could spend an entire day here if you wanted to read every display in detail. The museum provides a great insight into the lives of Vietnamese women throughout their lives and throughout history. The highlight of the museum for me were the video displays into the lives of the women selling fruit/flowers etc on the side of the street. You see a lot of propaganda in Vietnam but the stories from these women seems quite genuine leaving a very poignant feeling lingering. The video of the wedding celebrations was another highlight. I was both suprised and delighted to see a video in a museum showing people drinking beers, taking shots, and stumbling around in front of the camera.

Informative and well laid out. Informative and well laid out. This museum is easy to navigate and has lots of information for you to read in a number of languages. I really enjoyed the wedding dress section and the part which helped to explain the role women played in the Vietnamese-American war. Definitely worth a visit.
Comfortable, well laid out, informative. The museum was very well laid out, and gave a wonderful insight into Vietnamese life for women. Lots of information about ethnic minorities.
More than you may think. This is really a history of domestic life in Veit Nam well worth a visit on a raining afternoon in Hanoi!

Heroines in War and Daily life. Visiting this museum make me proud of being a vietnamese women. They was so strong and powerful in war times. They're even more powerful to take care their family nowaday as a woman, a wife and a mother. That's why we have the special day for Vietnamese women "20-10" each year. Come and see what did they suffer from the past and how they are struggling the half- morden- and - half-traditional life!
Nice adventure . You get to know a bit more about the culture!!! Very nice place! A bit spooky but it's worth the visit! You shouldn't miss this attraction
About time. It's important that how other cultures learn about Vietnamese women have handled their lives, supporting their families.
Great museum. From which you can lean and know about Vietnamese women. They had to work hard, and more and more. Should consider to spend an hour here and visit this great meseum

the role of Vietnam's women from the past to the present. A good museum to get insight of how influential the woman is in Vietnam's culture. From displays, videos, music, you will feel how hard the women of Vietnam work and intergral they are in their society....much more hard working than western women. It evokes how teamwork between a man and a woman will lead to success and contentment.

Women's Museum Hanoi. For me this museum was a highlight of my stay in Hanoi. I walked to the museum, took me about 30 minutes but was well worth it. The museum is so well thought out with each floor focussing on a particular aspect of Vietnamese Women's lives through the decades. Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit! . The museum tells the history of women in Vietnam through out the decades detailing different phases of their lives. The building has a few levels where each floor is categorised to tell about a different story. I thoroughly enjoyed the museum and for VND 30k, it's a steal.

A little stiff and starchy / 'orthodox' but colourful and overall interesting. One of the pleasant museums in Hanoi. A little stiff and starchy in post-1975 'orthodoxy': plenty of recollections of heroic, selfless fighters etc. But overall the museum is colourful, with attention to detail. The collections are not badly arranged and overall interesting. Less interesting than the Museum of Ethnology, though
Insightful. Displays felt a bit dated but it is definitely worth a visit and we loved the social-aspect, especially with traditional life being well detailed.

Worth a visit !. The most modern and well organised museum in Hanoi. I learnt a lot of the lives of the women and how they have progressed and contributed to Vietnam before the war, during the war and today. I salute them.
Interesting insights into the history of Vietnam. This museum is close to the Old Quarter and a good start for understanding the history of Vietnam, particularly in relation to the role of women.

Stop here first and watch the street hawker video. Great museum. Beautifully laid out. Heaps of interesting stuff to look at covering many different aspect of women in Vietnam. If the fruit sellers annoy you then watch the video about them and hear their stories and you will see things very differently. Heaps of great traditional textiles to admire and really interesting photos and videos and good english translations on most objects and displays so you know what is going on. So worth the visit..

Interesting but not mind blowing. So I think I had higher expectations due to the Tripadvisor reviews, but nothing really stood out to me. Not to say it was a bad experience. Actually it was quite educational to learn about the different ethnicities and how women contributed to the war effort. It was well catalogued so it was easy to follow from floor to floor, but just as advertised, museum about Vietnamese women. There are plenty of english signage and panels to describe what you're looking at as well.

Perfectly Laid Out. Hanoi has a lot of museums. Most of them aren't particularly good. The Vietnamese Women's Museum is the exception. It takes a while to get through its four floors, but the museum systematically takes you through a history of vietnam and the significant contributions made by Vietnamese women to the resistance. It blends objects of significance and personal anecdotes to create an experience worthy of every minute you spend there! Definitely worth a visit.

The wonderful spirit of Vietnamese Woman is clearly evident.. We spent a relaxed Sunday morning moving easily through the four levels of this small, comprehensive museum where clear English signage was much appreciated. Displays were asthetically pleasing and thoughtfully placed and presented. We visited prior to travelling to the miniority hiil tribes of Sapa and this enriched our time there. A light brunch shared outside in the cafe at the front of the museum was disappointing.
A MUST see. a very strong experience. The stories about Vietnamese women is well shown and you should take time to visit this place.

Unique and Interesting. Visited the Vietnam woman's museum today and was very impressed by the subject matter and the quality of the museum and it's displays.Cost to enter was 30,000 VND and it took about an hour to get through the displays. I highly recommend watching some of the multi-media displays particularly the video on the street merchants and the artist who travelled around Vietnam drawing pictures of mothers.

lots of interest. Tells the important story of women in Vietnam. Well organised and described museum with good facilities. Coffee shop at the entrance excellent. Most descriptions are clear and they are happy for you to take photographs. Low-cost

Womens Museum - fantastic. We were not sure what to expect but this was one of the best museums that we have seen in our three trips to Vietnam. Very well set out, well signed and extremely professional - start at the top and work your way down. Well worth a visit

Intriguing . The atmosphere as soon as you approach the museum is energising. I am glad I took time to visit the museum on the only day free in this trip. The history of women floor was my favourite. Powerful stories and curation (the english translation at times a bit sloppy). The floor on family and marriage, again, interesting. The last few cabinets have interesting objects (dont wanna spoil the visit)Recommend visit
focused and thoughtful. This is a low-hype, thoughtful and intelligent museum. Spend an hour or so away from the bustle of the cityscape: worth a detour. Good descriptions in English and Vietnamese.

good insight into women in Vietnam. Women have played an important part in the life of this wonderful country - from leading the battle againt the Chinese invaders in ancient times to fighting the French and then the Americans. This excellent museum looks at marraige equality, and the roles of women in cultural and social life of the diverse communities of Vietnam. The saddest part was the women who leave their families in rural villages to come to the city to earn a few dollars selling fruit or flowers and other wares.
best Museum. Now I know how women live today and Old days in Vietnam . Very well done Museum, modern Museum .I can not say Anu not so good things there.
Fascinating. Great history lesson about the woman's role over the ages. Very informative and at times sad. Easy to get to and well priced.

Lots to read at the Women's Museum. The museum was very interesting but way too much reading and I like reading! Would have been good if there were headsets for a talking commentary, hearing the voices of the women would have made this place outstanding.

Interesting but.... Interesting museum, but not sure what all the fuss was about. Great insight into female life in Vietnam. Maybe it was too hot or we were "museumed out" but for us it didn't live up to the great reviews on this site and in Lonely Planet.

Well worth a visit. Lots of info and very interesting to get an insight into life as a woman in Vietnam. There is lots to read so depending on your level of interest you might want to allow at least a couple of hours

Great museum about women and Vietnamese culture in general. I didn't expect much from a museum in Vietnam and was blown away. It's a great museum and there is a lot to see. They have a different topic on every floor. E.g. marriage or work. I learned a lot about the Viatnamese culture and the people.Everything is in English.

Fantistic Tour with Great Food. I liked the way he behaved with us.he explained all the things and answered all of my questions.The food was great.The grilled chicken and the sticky rice were delicious and he even surprised us with a coconut filled with rice wine.My husband and i enjoyed very much.
Well worth a visit.. Only city in the world I have been to where there is a museum dedicated to the women of a country. From village life to participation in the 21st century economy.
Worthwhile visit. Good museum which highlights the contribution of women to Vietnamese history and society. Thoroughly enjoyed the visit. Thee's also a cafe and gift shop on site.

Worth a visit. Brilliant, well-rounded introductory to the women of vietnam, its culture, costume, history, etc etc. You do not need to be a man or woman, nor a history buff, in particular to enjoy this place of art.

Highly Worthwhile. We made a point of visiting this museum, due to the excellent reviews and ranking on Trip Adviser. We agree that is is a fascinating museum focusing on the role of women in Vietnam through history and today, particularly their role during the American War as guerillas, spies, generals and organisers. We spent 1.5 hours and perhaps that was a little short. I liked the film clips though lack of time makes it impossible to watch all of them. The series of conversations with street traders was most interesting and gave a true perspective on the reality of life today for many Vietnamese. Unfortunately for all exhibits, the use of white writing on a red or blue perspex backing made all the writing extremely hard to read. There is reflection from lights and shadows, and the print is small! The translation is the best English we saw throughout Vietnam, however it is extremely tiring on the eyes trying to make out the words. Nothing beats, black print on a white background in a size 14+ font! Please consider adding this to the exhibits.Other than this practical drawback, it is a well organised museum and gives visitors a thorough understanding of the economic and political and cultural aspects of Vietnam from a women's perspective. Absolutely recommend to women and men keen to understand life in Vietnam - past and present. Women are the driving force behind the family and culture and economy, if not it's decision-makers!
wonderful. i had heard for years how amazing the vietnamese women are,but was quite blown away reading their stories

Very good. We went there as a family and found it very good ,takes about 1 1/2 to 2 hours to go around. A very different view from the American view in some sections of the museum ,eye opening.Would recommend.

Vietnam Women Rock. Loved this museum. Top floor is all about marriage ceremonies of the 54 ethnic peoples in Vietnam, some matriarchal, some patriarchal. There's a floor devoted to women in the wars, plus exhibits on current entrepreneurial stars. Loved this place!
Women recognized for their great work.. Very interesting, though not totally AC'd. Really enjoyed the video of workers that had to leave rural life and work in the city. Tough women!

A 'must do' for your Hanoi list!. A very special experience. I loved that there were such emotional experiences in this museum. I left in awe of the women represented in this place, and incredibly touched by the role that women have played in the life of their country over centuries.

Endearing Insight in to the Women in Vietnam. This was one of our most interesting and moving attractions in Hanoi. Of particular interest to me were the biographies of the women engaged in the independence struggles of Vietnam. The biographies provide insight in to the courage and commitment of these woman and young girls in their independence struggle. These women were truly courageous often at very young age with a number executed after torture by their French captures as a result of the actions they took. A humbling experience.

An important take on history. The Museum was very well laid out and gave a really good insight into how this matriarchal and matrilineal society has developed. It is also right across from the Temple of Literature so very easy to visit both at the same time.

Very Good Museum. The topic of woman in Vietnam was explained from every angle and in an interesting way. It is a quite special museum because its focus solely on history from a woman perspective which I liked very much. Good & professional exhibition.
We think we had it tough. Worth a visit to get some perspective on this country and its growth. All the signs are in English as well. A little sparsely exhibited but worth the time out.

Facinating and well curated for English speakers. This extensive museum was packed full of interesting and informative exhibits about Vietnam. We got a better understanding of the history and culture of Vietnam and the role and challenges Vietnamese women faced in the past and face today. There was an interesting temporary exhibit with photographs and stories of street sellers. The museum uses individual stories at lot which I found to be very interesting.
Pleasant surprise.... Plenty of interesting exhibits that covered a lot of culture and ethnology. Don't miss the the modern art gallery in the attic of the building - you never know what they have.

Excellent Museum, MUST SEE. I highly recommend to visit this museum as it highlights the importance if women in Vietnamese society and culture, both traditionally and currently. I hope there were more women museums worldwide so we could appreciate the important role in the world.
Do visit. A great place to discover and learn about how Vietnamese women live and lived. Make sure you visit all areas as the signage is not that clear.
Interesting place for learning history. the museum itself is quite interesting. good exhibition, well organised and lots of inforation about women in Vietnam from all tribes.
Nice place. Well designed. To learn about Vietnamese street women. Videos have English captions not expensive but I was shocked they made us pay full price for out two hanoi kid tour guides!

Impressive Recognition of Women and Their Contributions.. I enjoyed my visit to the museum and the insight it gave me into Vietnamese culture and History and the value they give to the female. Lovely colourful displays of costumes and religious/ spiritual customs.

Covers it all. Very well laid out with excellent videos and labeling in English and French. Within walking distance of Hao Lo. Gave us such an insight into the family life of several of the ethnic groups, marriage, children, etc as well as the women's roles in the war. Didn't really need to go any other museums after this.

Well worth a visit. The museum is definitely worth a visit (and it's only in the French Quarter - a 15 minute walk from the centre of the Old Quarter) as it shows you the important and under appreciated role of women across Vietnam throughout the ages. There is a little shop at the end and there is a nice cafe outside the steps at the entrance of the museum. The entry fee is only 20,000 Vietnamese Dong (about $1USD, £0.60GBP) and is definitely well worth it. There are secure lockers at the entrance of the museum to leave your bag (as you're not allowed to take your bag inside).

Interesting !!. Entry fee is just $1- This is a great look at woman thought the years in Vietnam! It covers all aspects of life, and really gives you a good look at these amazing woman! Who are the heart and soul of the country! A wander around the well set out displays, clearly marked and documented will take under 2 1/3 hrs and there are steps.It's very interesting!
best museum for me. written in English as well. Gave the roles of women throughout history. War history particularly good showing the women's role. Close to Old Quarter

Well worth the visit. we spent several hours here it was so interesting it starts with the lives and traditions of the village women on the first floor. There are about 4 levels which have the best air-conditioning too which is wonderful at this time of the year. Each level is dedicated to a different theme and the one on women's contributions to Vietnams Independence was a real eye opener. Definitely take the time to come here. It is amongst the best exhibitions that I have seen.
Very worthwhile. The museum was spacious, attractions well labelled and interesting. A very worthwhile stop. Allow at least an hour or two. Lots to see.
Most inspiring and educational - impressive. Most enjoyable and educational. the history of women in Vietnam is described well and highlights the importance they have contributed

Loads of interesting information. There is a lot of very interesting information about Vietnamese culture and there is an obvious appreciation for womens role in this. Lovely set out displays with lots of colour and information while not being overwhelming!

Fascinating insight into the lives of everyday Vietnamese women. This is a place where you can get an insight into the woman of Vietnam hearing the story of those who sell things on the street and the families that they support. This is a musuem with panels to read and videos to watch. It will not suit all but for those who would like to know a little more about the lives of the woman and enjoy museum this is quite unique and recommended to visit.

Worth Seeing!. Very calm environment interesting exhibition. Very informative and really appreciated the poor women selling in the streets. Films were good and loved trying out holding the balancing bowls that the women hold every day. Wording could have been bigger near some of the exhibits.

Very very interesting. If one has limited time for viewing museums, this is probably one of the best ones. Interesting history of matriarchal and patriarchal influences, of strong-willed young women fighters, of lacquered teeth and of daily life.
Must do in Hanoi. This museum left a deep impression on me! I really like the video about the street vendors there! You will learn alot about Vietnamese woman, it is so impressive

Awesome Museum. I have walked for more than 2km to find the museum and very glad that it worth the walking. Amazed by the details given and it is a very well decorated and arranged museum. Definitely worth a visit if you are interested in women contribution to Vietnam as a whole.
Fascinating. We loved the fact that we learned a lot about Vietnamese culture here. Very interesting and morning spent here.

Terence Yorkshire, my visit to the Womans Museum. This exibition gives an insite to the struggles of country women who have to leave their homes and families and stay in the city for extended periods to make enough money to feed their families and send their children to school.
Interesting and unusual Museum. Well worth a visit. The historical sections on woman heroes and roles in the times of conflict were very interesting.

Perfect. This is a beautiful tribute to every woman in Vietnam past and present. The history and heritage here is lovely, enlightening and sometimes very upsetting but always remarkable. Worth a visit, wonderful way to spend a day.
Excellent. Great Museum to visit , women are very hard worker in Vietnam ...A nice coffee shop at the museum.I had the best Mango Juice ...:-)
Impressive. A cab will cost about $1 if you don't fancy walking. Quite an enlightening experience. Worth more than one visit.

A really good intro to the women of Vietnam. A really thorough and interesting museum, and much bigger that we'd expected. The stuff about the street sellers was incredibly good, full of insight and empathy - really made you look at them when you got back out into the city. The exhibits about marriage traditions in Vietnam's various tribes and ethnicities were really interesting, while the bits about women's roles in wartime were absolutely fascinating. Highly recommended.
Fantastic. Do not miss this. A real gem that shows women's roles through the ages. Very informative and nicely displayed.

fascinating insights. Particularly liked the section on the role of women in the independence movement and also during the American War. Powerful personalised stories brought the struggles they faced to life.

Inspiring. We went here and spend all afternoon, we eventually got kicked out and did not have time to visit the shop. This museum is rather inspirational, this history Vietnamese Women is remarkable. Worth the visit.

More than expected. Much bigger than expected, five floors of interesting stories. Staff were incredibly nice as well. Much of it was on strong women from a supporting your family perspective which was initially disappointing, until you made the connection that this was still the situation today with many of the street sellers. Many stories of women who would leave their families to come to Hanoi to make money, taking $20 home every two weeks or so to see their husband and kids.

Great museum. A wonderful way to learn about the culture and history of Vietnam from the perspective of women. The museum is beautifully designed. There are signs and explanations in English. Highly recommended.
Well worth a visit. Great museum and well worth a visit. The design and exhibits were very interesting and my perspectives were changed here.

Just the right amount of information. Excellent museum, gives you a very good insight with regards to women's roles during the war and in modern society. Just the right amount of information so you leave feeling like you have learned something rather than being overloaded which can happen in some museums. Highly recommended.
One of the better museums. Was a nice musueum with 5 floors - really liked the women in war display. Not going to blow your socks off - but definitely worth a visit if you have time.

A great way to get an overview of Vietnamese life. We were pleasantly surprised by this museum. We were not sure what to expect of a "womans museum" but it is really the story of everday life in Vietnam. Just looking around on the street it is easy to see that there are many people struggling to earn a living and through the information presented here we had a better idea of how and why this came about. It was a fascinating exploration of Vietnamese culture and well worth a visit. Even my husband (who was a little reluctant to go to a womens museum) loved it.

Not to be missed. For a first time visit and to give pause to all the shopping that you will do, the Women's Museum is worth spending part of the day at.If you find local and traditional costumes and clothing interesting, the ethnic diversity within the country and the accomplishments of the local people, then you will enjoy your visit.

Very average, but it is cheap.. I found the majority of the museum displays to be pretty boring, although the floor on women's roles in the Vietnam war was interesting and worth a look at. It is also well-displayed with well-written and informative signs, and the staff were friendly.

At last a story. By far one of the better museums in Hanoi. This one tells a story as well as presents a display. There are also a number of short films covering various aspects such as dyeing of textiles and army mobilisation. Usually with subtitles.
Well worth a visit. Really interesting museum. It has a good mixture of audio and visual components. It really opened my eyes on how the women in Vietnam live.

So much to see and learn. I'd like to go back, as I was on a time limit. It was fascinating reading and seeing all the information and displays. The women thru history and in all aspects are very interesting.

Good amount of info and well laid out. This museum was rather interesting for me as a Canadian born vietnamese as well as for my non-vietnamese travel partner. Each floor is organized by topic. English (and French, I think?) translations available for everything. The building is air conditioned which is also a treat in Hanoi. It showcases a wide variety of information, tradition, and history of women in Vietnam. Entrance fee was about 1.50 usd/30,000 vnd.

Great insights into the role of women in Vietnam!. The Museum is divided into three major sections - the role of women in the family, women during the war and how Vietnamese fashion has evolved over the ages. It is a great insight into how women have contributed to the building the nation through their varied roles as the primary wage-earner, the family caretaker, the soldier etc. The displays are static and have descriptions attached all along in 3-4 languages. The museum wasn't crowded and you won't be jostling for space here, unlike other attractions in Hanoi. Very peaceful. Go only if you want to appreciate and learn something about the history of the country. Impressive!

One of the far better museums in Hanoi. Gives a better insight into Vietnamese women and their societal roles throughout the history of Vietnam. It has some heavier subjects, like the female soldiers of the indochina wars and then lighter subjects such as fashion. This is definitely more foreigner friendly than some of the other museums.
Culture and History. Interesting and very informative. There are 4 floors of exhibits. Enjoyed watching the documentaries. KUDOS to the Vietnamese women... past and present!

Really lives up to its expectation. This Museum really lives up to its expectation and deserves the Tripadvisor Excellence award. Being very modern and up to date, if you have the time do visit this Museum. Consisting of 4 levels, explaining the life transformation of the woman in Vietnam and their roles in society and history from time to time. Very nicely organized and the entrance fee is cheap too.

I learned something new about Vietnam - nice!. Did you know that during the Vietnamese war, 40 % of the millitary in the south were female soldiers?! The museum has 3 main sections. One about fashion, one about women during the war and one about women in the family, The have an elevator inside, however you have to climb a big staircase to get into the musuem. I went with my 5 month old baby a had to ask for help to get into the museum. Another lady in a wheelchair who wanted to visit couln't get in :(
Culture and History in one stop. This was a well-organized and peaceful museum, which gave a lot of information about the various ethnic groups that live in the country.
Average. Give it an hour perhaps, ethnic costumes worth a look. I'd skip the revolutionary women's floor, but that is up to you.
Interesting. Worth a visit. Very interesting gives a much better understanding of the street sellers so makes you more tolerant. It's a bit sparse on some floors.

Static displays but a fascinating insight. I would suggest you go a soon as you arrive in Hanoi because it will then give you a much better understanding and appreciation of Vietnamise women and their struggle. The Musium is on three or four floors and there are many pictures, artefacts and text to view and study. The displays are well laid out in chronological order.

Good, but i wasn't blown away. . Five stars seems a bit much but the museum is defiantly above average for Hanoi, four stars it is. The exhibits are well laid out, there is plenty to look at and the air conditioning is a nice touch. If you make it to the museum, the lake is just three blocks away so take the opportunity to stroll about.

Very well laid out museum. We liked this museum because it was very well laid out and had clearly explained exhibits. The museum focuses on the role of women in Vietnam. You learn a lot about rituals of marriage, childbirth and the daily life of Vietnamese women. There are lots of interesting artefacts and some cool videos. Was nice to find a museum that wasn't just about war and killing, though the section on women's role in the war was also interesting. Definitely worth a visit, if you have time.
A Must See. You will get a better understanding of what life is like for a Vietnamese woman during the war and currently. What an eye opener!

Not too busy and nicely organised.. It's quite well organised and has a nice and quiet atmosphere. We especially like the section dedicated to the war revolutionary women and the parts that showed the ethnic minorities traditional clothes and costumes.

Very nice museum. I came in Hanoi for vacation in July 2014 from JapanI like this Museum a lot , its very interesting to understand asian culture and many things related women in VietnamI really enjoyed here

Interesting and moving museum. This museum makes you think about the role women play in daily life and also the several conflicts Vietnam has seen. Women play an important part in life in Vietnam and this museum is dedicated to the many roles they fulfill.

Nice Place. The Vietnamese Women’s Museum is one of Hanoi’s most overlooked museums and is also one of its best. The museum was reopened in 2010 after a period of 4 years of renovations.The museum has three main galleries and these present three main themes: Women in Family, Women in History and Women’s Fashion. Visitors have the opportunity to learn and understand traditional culture, marriage customs, childbirth and family life, traditional women’s clothing and the role of women in the defense of the nation. All the texts are available in Vietnamese, English and French for easy understanding of the exhibits.

Low cost museum with great culture and open on Mondays!. Unfortunately, in Hanoi, on Monday’s most museums are closed. But there is one open and it is the history of the women in Vietnam…The Vietnamese Women’s Museum. It is composed of many ethnicities and culture throughout the country. Lots of stories and artifacts. Did you know there is >54 ethnicities and dialects in Vietnam? A definite out of the way low cost museum that you get to learn a lot about the people.The top floor was composed of all the famous women in Vietnam from the war…some very interesting stories and exhibits.Very low cost and worth a visit if you want to learn more about the culture across Vietnam.

Well worth a visit. A most interesting museum, particularly helpful in giving perspective to the plight of many poor women in Vietnam... my opinion of the many street vendors changed completely after visiting here. There is also a lovely gift shop with proceeds going back into the community so a perfect place to purchase souvenirs.
Worth going. I went with my teenager son, maybe not the best attraction for him, but we enjoyed the visit and I recommend it, if you have time

A must see. A must see. A great tribute to women in Vietnam, and it can change your perspective on Vietnam altogether (the women revolutionaries, the struggle some woman sellers on the street face to barely earn enough money to survive, etc.)

Very interesting museum. Interesting to understand the way of living in Vietnam! The vendors in the street reveal their life story, the role of the women in war time... The museum has a very modern design.

Quite a small museum but cultural all the same. After visiting so many museums, it was enjoyable to have one on the history of Vietnamese woman. I visited mid-July so the museum was very quiet and not that expensive either. It does exactly what it says on the tin.....explores and explains the history of women in Vietnam. Worth a look and very cool inside if you're wanting to escape the Hanoi heat!

A rarely seen view. This was a good place to see the cultural history and current view of women in all aspects of Vietnamese life. The experience would have been better if maps were present with the clothing, stories and artifacts to show the different minorities. Also, more information on certain floors would have been nice, but it seems like the Museum was still being somewhat developed.
Inspirational. The Museum was great, it was a journey from birth, marriage, way of life, politics. Liked everything.
Well worth a visit. One of the best museums we visited in Vietnam. It covers all aspects of life from birth to death. You must listen to all the stories told on the videos by the women themselves.

Really accessible cultural tour. Set on 3 floors the museum offers an insight into Vietnamese culture from a female perspective. I met a couple here who thought that they wouldn't go as the man might nbot be into it, but I persuaded them as the museum looks at so many of the important milestones and cultural aspects of Vietnam which come from women and give great insight into the traditions of the country.The permanent floors include exhibitions on marriage and birth (no gruesome pictures though), women in history, family life and women heroes. These were really interesting and include explanations in Vietnamese, English and French, making it all really clear. Some good, honest and frank videos too about women in the culture, spoken in Vietnamese and subtitled in English and French. I went with my Mum and we both really enjoyed it and could have spent more time there. Wish there were such a good tribute to women in London Museums!

One of the most interesting museum in Hanoï. A very interesting point of view on the place of women in Hanoi and in Vietnam. A good way to understand the people. After the visit, you don't see as before women in town.

Really interesting. A really interesting place, divided on many floors, i learnt a lot about Vietnamese people here.
Amazing the religion and war areas!

Surprising gem. I came away with an entirely new sense of the (complicated) status of women throughout Vietnam's history. The floor devoted mainly to Vietnamese women in the military was especially powerful. Go!
EXCELLENT. Very good information on Vietnamese Women's Museum. Museum should upgrade their aircon system as it is very hot and stuffy in the Museum

Well presented, interesting. Warning - ceiling on 5th floor stairs is only 6 feet high. Watch your head, ouch!!
That said the museum is very well presented and shows displays on family, fashion, women at war etc.
Set over 5 floors well worth a visit.

Well worth a visit. Modern, air-conditioned, clean and well-presented. Different aspects of the role of women in Vietnam are depicted in different rooms. There are beautiful photographs, artefacts and film clips explaining everything. I particularly liked the comments made by ordinary Vietnamese people about their relationship with the Mother Goddesses. Incredibly good value for money.

Interesting, worth the money. Great insight into the hill tribes of Vietnam and their way of life. If you are not travelling to Sapa you should definitely check out this museum as it fills in that gap of the minority tribes in Vietnam.
Also covers a lot of women's roles during the 'American war'. Well worth the $1.50!

Tribute to the Women of Vietnam. The museum was clean and air conditioned and provided an insight into the lives of Vietnamese Women, sad mostly, there are a few displays, mostly photos and captions, the displays get a bit repetitive, probably worth a visit but not as a priority.

Insightful. We didn't really have expectations for this museum, as we were looking to kill time in Hanoi, but it turned out to be one of the better museum visits. I found it interesting to see the diversity of Vietnamese life for women through war, the difficulties of street pedlars, traditional marriage practices, religion, fashion, household responsibilities - such as harvesting, cooking and traditional crafting. Overall, really insightful.

worth a visit. Vietnam is extremely cheap to visit and this museum was one of my highlight visits. It's a very well organised museum and makes you realise how important are the women in this beautiful country.

So so. The museum is rather large in size but offers very little in terms of what a museum is meant to offer. There are a number of posters that were not translated into English as well.The building itself may be a little difficult to find as there are no signs on the road leading towards the museum.Given the benefit of hindsight, I wouldn't have given this museum a miss but it does seem lacking in effort.

Worth a quick visit. This place is well laid out. Lots of different information on Vietnamese women, from the traditional ethnic groups and how each of them handle weddings/births to the iconic women who fought in the war, or explaining the mother Goddess Cult. Even if you're not interested in everything, you will find some place you'll like in there, since so many different subjects are addressed.
Fascinating. Well worth a visit. Even had my 13-year old daughter interested. Very well set out and gives a great insight into the lives of Vietnamese women. Cheap as chips as well!

Fascinating Museum!. This museum was incredible! It's set up so well and I learned so many things that I would never have known had I not gone. It's super cheap to get in, and the knowledge and respect for Vietnamese women that you take away from the exhibits far surpasses the price. It appeals to all kinds of people. So wonderful, absolutely a must-go if you're in Hanoi. Don't skip it.
Gives a new understand to Vietnam. Brillianr displays, easy to follow, and opens up a whole side of the Vietnam woman that is not necessarily depicted in other places.
Worth to visit. Interesting and good place to visit in Hanoi. Is it great to remember women this kind of place. Every man should go there.

What a great museum.... Thanks to TA reviews, and Lonely Planet, we chose to spend a couple of hours in this museum.This turned out to be the most interesting and enjoyable museums during all our Vietnam holidays. A real eye-opener too. It made us all reflect on the background and circumstances behind many of the women we kept encountering in Hanoi's streets, street vendors, etc. Let alone women who have been part of the recent eventful past in Vietnam. Very poignant stories.Very well set up with great video footage on display, and interesting architectonically too ( small version. Of NY Guggenheim).Do not miss it if you want to understand a bit better the peoples in Vietnam.

Took our daughters. Brilliant. Took our daughters aged 9 and 11 and when we left I'm sure they had grown 2 years in knowledge and maturity. To see what Vietnamese ladies had been through was amazing. Beautifully presented displays and a few opportunities to participate. Also, lovely little stalls selling local crafts etc outside the door. Also a great little school just up the road that you can peak in thought fence right on the footpath,

Vietnamese women and their lives.. Thought this would be interesting for my teenage daughters - good effort but just fell a little short- although for a dollar or two entry, really amazing value. There is a lift between stairs which was useful for the 7 storey museum. Good variety of info from family life to history to marriage ceremony etc. Not a long excursion - half an hour to 45 minutes should get you through.

A must for feminists. This is a museum dedicated to women. Displays show many women who fought the French and during the Vietnam war. However, it was not only about patriotic women but mothers, artists and rural women of Vietnam.

I was really impressed. I spent 2 hours in the museum, wandering through the Vietnamese culture. The museum was really nicely organized offering great info about the pieces. I also recommend the documentaries about the street vendors and also the hero mothers of Vietnam. Check the famous women of Vietnam history is also really interesting, even if you know close to nothing about war and stuff like me. On the top of all, the museum has AC, which helps the happiness of the visit.
Info on the women of Vietnam. Place where to see all the journey of life of women in Vietnam. Cooling place. Clean and neat. Toilet is clean as well. Great place

Very nicely laid out. Arriving just as a downpour hit, this was the perfect place to spend a few hours. Exhibits were different on each floor from ethnic costume to customs and labeled clearly. Air conditioned! Good gift shop with great retro postcards and a nice cafe. Friendly and educational. (wonderful bathrooms) Lockers for your bag.

Inspiring!. This museum far surpassed my expectations - it's wonderful. We spent a good 4 hours walking around all the different floors, learning about the strength, lives and customs of Vietnamese women.We learned about marriage, birth, clothing, war, careers, street vendors and beliefs, and more.Everything is translated beautifully into French and English, and the building is air-conditioned (hoorah!) so makes for a nice afternoon away from the heat of the city.There is also a shop, but we didn't have time to visit. The café next door was lovely for lunch!I have a fuller understanding now of the women of this beautiful country, and a healthy respect for those women who work so very hard to support their families and better their environment. What more could a museum aim to do?
Worth a visit if your bored!. It was very informative in the first 2 floors but the top floor was a bit boring! There's a lovely cafe downstairs with nice drinks and food!
Top Notch!. Go see this very well done museum and see the strength of the women of Vietnam through thick and thin!!! Great cultural and historical information too! Try very hard not to miss this!

Facinating. As a group of girls travelling together we felt this was a must and were not disapointed.Facinating insight into the lives of Vietnamese wemon .The museum itself is beautiful and we thouroughly enjoyed our visit.

worth the time if you have already seen the main sites. really interesting and well-laid out. Great walk around there to cafes and the lake. Don't miss the videos and exhibit of the cooking practices and customs.

Amazing museum. This museum is wonderful and well-worth your time. We really enjoyed the short documentary on the street vendors as well as the exhibit on female soldiers and revolutionaries. We learned so much.
You need to see the contribution women have made to this country. The fashion is crazy. I guarantee you will be amazed by the information that you can gather at this place.

Worthwhile stop in Hanoi. This is a well-curated museum that definitely provides a window into the lives of women in the city. I especially enjoyed a documentary on the lives of women who come to work in the city to support their families. The museum offers free lockers and is air-conditioned, so this is a great place to spend an a couple of hours away from the heat.
