Definitely worth a visit!. The Museum has minimal fee and is spread out on different levels. Its such an interesting resource to gain insight into the lives of Vietnamese women. Easily walkable from the Hoa Lo Prison and a great respite from the city heat as well.

informative exhibits and super heat!. It was very, very humid in the museum.Apart from that, the items / photos / videos on display were really interesting and demonstrated a very different side of women at war (and also during the 60s). As I was writing a thesis along the lines of Vietnamese women and war, this museum offered very informative first - hand information, as well as lesser-known books. There isn't much information on the web regarding this issue.Not too saturated, well curated. Not sure if the exhibits change often, but definitely one of the better museums in Hanoi! :)

Wonderfully presented, rich in history. This museum was beautifully curated and taught us a LOT about Vietnam through the women's stories presented. The most striking were those of women who served in the resistance during the American war, and those of some of the women we had passed every day on the street, selling fruit and flowers from dawn to well after dusk. Their stories will break your heart. The exhibits dedicated to traditional clothing and women's roles in traditional religious practices were also fascinating. A wonderful insight into the culture and history of Vietnam, worth far more than the tiny entrance fee.

Interesting Place!. I went to quite a number of museums in Hanoi, and arguably, this was the best museum in terms of experience. The museum has many interesting exhibits about the lives of women in Vietnam. There are three exhibits - "Women and Family", "Women and Fashion", and "Women and War" (if I remember correctly). All the exhibits have good English translations, and the exhibits are very well done. The souvenir store has pretty good books about Vietnamese women too.It's not expensive to get in, and students have a discount. I reckon that it'll take about 2-3 hours if you were to read the exhibits carefully.

Very interesting, but hot!. Seeking respite from the out door heat and humidity, and after reading good reviews, we took our two daughters to check out this museum. It was fascinating, BUT because it was even hotter inside than out we felt we couldn't spend as much time as we would have liked browsing and reading all the information. It was worthwhile, but could be tremendously improved with working air conditioning so you can really slow down and thoroughly take in the exhibits.

Well-curated. This museum tells an important story - that of women in the history and of present-day of Vietnam. Many of the exhibits can only show simple things that remain from what was an incredibly complex history. This is where good curation can help fill in the gaps, and it does. Overall - worth a visit.

Vietnamese Women's Museum. This museum was recently renovated and expanded during the millennium of Hanoi. It is composed of many rooms not always easy to access and poorly signposted but do not hesitate to open doors to discover what is behind it. My favorite part is that with ethnic costumes. A wonder.

Great Museum. Great Museum to learn about women's lives I'm Vietnam.Likes:- Only about $1.50 to get in- Air conditioned (nice break away from city heat)- Everything translated in English (was very pleased about this) and great layout of exhibit- You learn about women in Vietnam from birthing, marriage, contribution to military, fashion: it's quite a comprehensive exhibitTip:- Go when you need a break from heat or rain- You will need about 2 hours to get through everything - I saw Vietnamese, English and French translation Enjoy!

Favourite Hanoi museum. A really well laid out and informative museum with great English translations (many of the other museums had minimal English translations so it was hard to follow the content). We spent a long rainy afternoon in here at the bargain price of 15, 000 dong for student. Highly recommend for a bit of girl power and a fascinating insight into the lives of Vietnamese women. Particularly interesting was the section on female guerrilla fighters.

One of the best museums I've been to. A really excellent museum, very educational about women's role in families, different marriage customs, women street vendors in Hanoi, a section on traditional costumes with really interesting videos about different dying and embroidery processes, and a whole floor about various women's involvement in the Vietnam war. It had a great selection of photographs, artefacts, jewellery, translations of letters and diaries, tools, costumes and personal items. We went after the disappointing Military museum which has nothing in English and just a lot of old planes dumped in the gardens and blurry photographs and bits of shrapnel, so it was great to follow that with this fabulous, inspiring museum. I highly recommend it! And it's super air conditioned!

Excellent. Excellent museum, really well done. I loved this museum. I found the section on the role of women during the war in Vietnam especially interesting, and also really enjoyed the video pieces on migrant workers, which were both heartbreaking and engaging. I also loved the textiles and traditional clothing.Everything was explained really well, and I found it a fascinating insight into the role and lives of women in Vietnam.

Vietnamese Womens Museum. Extremely well set out museum which covers the life of women. It does not just focus on war. The displays are well set out and mostly labelled in English. it covers women of all walks of life. A great display of the costumes worn by the various ethic groups as well as documenting their specific customs.

What women they are!. This museum is very well laid out and for the most part the exhibits are well explained. I certainly learned an enormous amount about the variety of different ways women in different parts of Vietnam are seen. I also came out with an enormous respect for the strength of Vietnamese women. There is a brief video in one section that tells the background of many of the street sellers, with baskets on poles across their soldiers. It is quite an eye opener.If you want to learn a huge amount about Vietnamese society and its women, go.

Women's Museum. For the small entrance fee, we found this museum to be very interesting. Lives of both urban and rural women are illustrated and the variety of clothing styles and marriage customs were fascinating The role of women in war was also an eye-opener, but be prepared to translate from French, as some of the exhibits did not have English signage.

Great place to learn the strength of Vietnamese women. In terms of presentation, this museum was excellent and very well-maintained and surprisingly so as entry fee was only VND 30,000 (AU$ 1.50 give or take). The lobby had a locker area and a nice, souvenir shop, different to what I've seen in other shops about town.We went there on a particularly hot day, the main exhibition was airconditioned although it wasn't cold enough it was decent. The stair area weren't airconditioned.The content of the museum was amazing, it broke down patrilineal, matrilineal and ambilineal societies as normally one tribe to another practice different lineage, Vietnamese women's different traditional wear from north to south, pregnancy and birth traditions. It was all a rush of information that I missed to look into prior to my trip to Vietnam. I wasn't aware the level of acknowledgment of women's role in Vietnamese culture, there are more aspects than I anticipated where Vietnam is more forward thinking in gender equality than most South-East Asian countries. That's not to say inequality doesn't exist but they have less work to do to reach the gender equality goal.Definitely worth a couple hour out of your time in Hanoi to visit.

Not as good as others. I love museums, and this one was okay, but there are much better ones in Hanoi to go to. The entrance fee here is very cheap, and it is a four or five story building with each floor dedicated to one aspect of Vietnamese women's lives (family/fashion/war/marriage etc). The exhibits were interesting but I found there was less to see, and more to learn. I could have probably learnt just as much researching from home on the internet. The museum was also very hot so lots of water was a must.

Vietnamese women play a huge part in their society.. After visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum we proceed to the Woman's Museum once again by Rickshaw.There is a small entrance fee, but it was well worth it. The Museum was well set out and you moved from one aspect of Vietnamese society to the next without repeats, once again a humbling experience and something that will for-ever stay with us. Certainly I recommend this as part of the Vietnam experience .

Well worth it. Fantastic exhibitions of the lives of the women of Vietnam! lots of information, exhibits, videos. Really interesting. Must see. But the building is really hot though, take heaps of water...

Very intriguing. I loved watching the video on the first floor about the women who carry the baskets around Hanoi. Some earned about $20 every two months. The museum definitely gave me a new perspective of Vietnamese women.

Well worth a visit. I find some museums quite boring but really enjoyed the Vietnamese Women's Museum. I think the name probably put a few people off visiting but it gives a great overview of life in Vietnam.

so wonderful place u must visit!!. so wonderful place u must visit!! with very kind and nice curator, u can understand well about vietnam women culture and history! near Hoan Kiem Lake, so convinient!!
Great place. like all of everytthing stay here, the view is beautiful and so much picture about vietnamese the war from 1945 to 1975

A Great Way to Gain Perspective. As Americans in Vietnam, we were fascinated with the Vietnamese outlook on the war. This wonderfully curated museum opened our eyes to the other side and left us with a sense of respect for the Vietnamese people.

improve knowledge!. takes no more than 1 hour to get a good and informative view of the women in vietnam. worth the visit
aircon and lighting wasn't good though. feels hot and stuffy. the lights were too dim.

Charming. I find the museum quite charming because of its modern design and airy feeling, like everything's well-illuminated. Each exhibit and floor has a different mode of presentation, such as interactive video, sets of replica, posters, etc. The staff are always ready to assist and the receptionist is friendly. The highlight of my visit was learning about the various women which helped shaped the history of Vietnam, and I would recommend other people to pay a visit to the Women's Museum.
Interesting. It gave an interesting view of the role of Vietnamese women in their society. Worth seeing.Especially interesting to see about the role of women in their wars.
Informative. Gives a good insight to past and present generations of Vietnamese woman. good to spend an hour there if you have the chance.

A must see. Museum is very well set out. It is very informative with displays, videos & written information. I believe it is the best museum in Vietnam - tells a wonderful story of the lives of Vietnamese women for years - their resourcefulness, hardiness & dedication to family.I was really moved by some videos of todays women & their struggles. Please go & I am sure you will experience the same emotions.
Attraction. awesome piece of sight i enjoyed visit to that museum. i will promote this and i will also tell o=to my friends about it

Well worth a visit. Great museum very well presented and very impressive, great acknowledgement of the very significant part Vietnamese women played in the war and in the community - do not miss the opportunity to explore this museum!
An honour to women. I thought it a thoughtful and meaningful honour to women thru the ages and their achievements , successes and lives of famous and ordinary women in vietnam
Best part of Vietnam. Very informative museum. I would definitely recommend a visit. It's the best museum I visited in Vietnam.

Good Place to Visit. This is one of the good place to visit, and for me and wife to understand about the women in Vietnam from the History point of view.
There is a nice cafe near by if you need to chill after the Museum session.
After all, I'm glad I had a visit here.

History of Vietnam Women. I have a trip to Vietnam's Women Museum last week. The displays are so professional. The most impression remained in my mind so far is the museum's exhibitions. They are so wonderful and marvellous. I love them.

Interesting and informative museum. The museum and modern and well laid out and covers several floors. It explores and shows the role of women in Vietnamese society and the part they paid in the Vietnam War. Well worth the visit.

Hurray for Vietnamese Women. We enjoyed the filmed biographies of contemporary women making a difference in Vietnam. I liked looking at the many costumes and handicrafts of women. My husband liked it less than I.

Loved the displays. This little museum was larger than I expected, and covered 4 floors or so. I especially enjoyed the more fold artsy area and also the propaganda posters. I would go again to spend more time.

Vietnamese Women's Museum. Herein lies the real city. You can experience the daily life of the inhabitants of Hanoi, as many house doors are open and the street is the continuation of this house. Each block has its own identity and function. It is also worth staying in hotels that are here to observe better the more interesting Viêt Nam, the people.

Vietnamese woman before and today. This museum illustrates the role of Vietnamese woman from revolutionary time to daily life today. This is a comprehensive overview on woman who work hard and brilliant in different situations in Vietnam. Some of our travelers said that Cosmos Travel Vietnam Co., Ltd must recommend Woman museum to woman travelers while they are in Vietnam for a holiday.

Informative and moving. The museum is very well laid out and takes you through women's lives past and present. The most moving aspect was their role during the American war when they made up 40% of Vietnamese soldiers. It was quite difficult to find as the cab driver didn't know where it was and dropped us in the right street but quite a long way off!
I loved It. Let come there to get more understand of Vietnamese' women. I would recommend my friends who have plan come to see this Museum.I will come back soom with my wife!

Interesting and well presented museum. We found the women's museum really well presented and incredibly interesting. It gives you a great overview of the sort of everyday artefacts of women in Vietnam and there's an especially interesting section on the historical/political position of women. It would have been good to get a bit more of a picture of modern life and issues for Vietnamese women but well worth the visit!

A real education and insight into Vietnam. A 'women's museum' doesn't necessarily give the right marketing message as I know this would cause some people to pass this by - more fool them. The museum is three floors dedicated to: women's contribution to the war, their role in family life and women's fashions; but it really gives an overall review of Vietnamese society.The exhibits are interesting and there are good explanatory texts (as far as I can remember in a variety of languages - at least Vietnamese, French and English). The key exhibits for me were the short films that play in the side-rooms off the main hall on each floor describing the lives of contemporary Vietnamese women; you will learn a new found sense of admiration for the street vendors when you understand their lives, you'll maybe even then be tempted to buy a few doughnuts as a result .....The Museum is easy to navigate, well air-conditioned, the displays are well attended to, has helpful staff, clean facilities etc. and will certainly provide 1-2 hours of interesting history and social documentary. there is a shop, a cafe and the location is pretty central and near other exhibits.

Very interesting. My husband and I visited based on the high recommendations on trip advisor and were very happy with our visit.. The air con alone was worth escaping the heat! We would recommend adding it to your trip list..

very nice museums. the first woman museums i ever visit and i learn a lot. so many things to visit. the history it self it describe how woman can do like man do. place is very clean, its very quite and downstairs they sell souvenirs items with very affordable price. im glad i did this visit.

One of the most well-executed museums I've ever seen. I stopped by because it happened to be on the route back to my hotel and I am SO glad I did! Innovative displays, extremely comprehensive explanations (in English, French & Vietnamese), gorgeous pieces, interesting history... I was really taken aback. Women are amazing, but... maybe Vietnamese women especially so! If you're not a total douche, you'll enjoy it.

Arrived at 8.15am and told to come back at Noon. My guide book stated that this museum was open from 0800 so I decided to walk there early to avoid the heat. I arrived at 8.15am and the ticket booth was empty but clearly said open at 8am. I went inside as it was open and an attendant said to come back later around noon. As I was flying out in the afternoon this didn't suit me so I was disappointed. I couldn't work out why they weren't admitting people as they were staffed but the language barrier made it difficult to ascertain what the problem was.
Good for an hour. I found it a little sparse to be honest but was there was well maintained and the entrance fee was nominal. I just couldn't see myself there for any longer than an hour.

Unique and well done . This is probably the first museum I've seen dedicated entirely to women and it did not disappoint, it was well organised and the exhibits informative of women's role in both Vietnamese society and history, it was interesting to learn about Vietnamese ethnic minorities as well, the museum shop was also great as well as the attached cafe

Well worth a visit. Really enjoyed walking round this museum - lots of good information and great pictures and videos showing what a hard time many Vietnamese woman have had through the years. Well worth a visit.
Wow!. So informative, really well-layed out and comprehensible. Gave me a completely new outlook on Vietnamese women and precipitated great conversation among friends.

It was ok. Had some free time my wife and I wanted to see this museum. Would not make a special trip unless you are interested in the history of clothes and lifestyles. There is an area of the heroines of Vietnam, but there was not much of a description to what they had achieved.

Great Museum. I found this museum really interesting. It was sad to hear women telling their stories of how they had to leave their families to go to the city to find work so they could afford to send their children to school. The display of ethnic costumes was so good especially if you like fabric and embroidery. If you are in Ha Noi you should take the time to visit this museum.

Interesting museum. The best section was the second floor which was all about women during the war. Interesting to learn about different tribal traditions around marriage and birth. Women's fashion section is quite small, only needed 10 minutes to see everything. A good break from the heat too!

Modern and easy to navigate. The museum is very modern though exposing old traditional appliances and dresses Vietnamese women. It is very easy to track the history route, as every object has an explanatory table next to it. I found it attractive, simple, and a bit too simple and slight. A kind of new museum created by European funding: new, modern, accessible but without spirit.

Inspiring museum. Wow what an inspiration the Vietnamese women are to all women around the world. This was one of the best museums I have visited in Vietnam. So interesting, it is a must visit for anyone coming to Hanoi.
Very Interesting. A little hard to find as most maps cut off at this place. Worth the search as I never knew that women played such a big part in the military there.

Powerful. I particularly liked the exhibition regarding Vietnamese contribution to the war. Very powerful and inspiring. The others were OK and interesting enough.... they had lockers to keep your belongings safe and no need to take them around the museum!
Amazing!. This was one of he best things I've done in Hanoi! I would definitely recommend taking the time to visit!

The strength of Vietnamese women on show.. After advice from a TA destination expert we made time to visit here. The contribution of women in Vn is proven in this beautifully exhibited museum and we really enjoyed it. We were four 50ish males and I think that anyone who wants to get to the heart of Vietnam should take a look.
Great history. If you are interested in the history of Vietnam and the role of women this is a great place to visit
Not to be missed!. I very insightful and in depth display of women's role in past and present Vietnam. The explanations were good too! Amazing work done during the war !
Surprise surprise!. It was very interesting place to visit. Surprise, surprise, there was no man to visit the place when we were there, no local or tourists.

Gives you a good idea of daily life. It's a really nice way of getting an idea of certain aspects of the countries history and the daily life of some of the street merchants. It's location also pushed me towards an area of Hanoi I had not visited yet.

Don't miss it!. A one of a kind gender museum with clear modern displays, interesting and moving exhibits that gave me a complete new understanding of the role of Vietnamese women during the war. Without their support, it seems that winning this war would have been much more difficult. What they went through is beyond imagination. I loved the minorities' costumes on the 3rd floor and also the ones dedicated to the cult of the mother goddess of the temporary exhibition.

Vietnamese tradition, society and diversity. This museum is centrally located. It has great information (included English) about various aspects of the life at the women perspective: wedding, religion, family life, pregnancy, giving birth, education, costums, arts, crafts. embroidery and fasion. It is interesting to notice how the culture changes across region and time. It is inspirint the display about the brave and resilient women at the French and American wars.Don't miss the vietnamese women's museum!

First class presentation. Visiting this museum was one of the highlights of my trip to Hanoi. A great concept which has been executed in an excellent manner.The layout is easy to follow, with different topics on each floor. The plaques of information next to each exhibit had the right amount of detail to hold my interest. There are a number of very moving displays, such as the wall with the Heroic mothers of Vietnam.One particular plaque reminds that "they are only at the beginning of their history".Everything is beautifully presented, and visiting here is a must-do in Hanoi.Completed my visit with a Vietnamese coffee at a coffee shop in the grounds of the museum.

Interesting & informative. Glad I went to this museum. Didn't realised there were women involved in the war and seeing their picture and the heroic stance in their life during the war.Would recommend it to all travellers.

not a word about womens' rights. go to the ethnology museum for good information about culture, clothing, etc. they don't have anything about prostitution which is a huge market in vietnam. Not a word about sexual freedom. Not a word about salary differences. Briefly, they don't go into any "hot topic", which is kind of sad.I hope they will in the future!

very interesting exhibition. Nice and interesting exhibition.
Several floors, each dedicated to different aspects of Vietnamese women's lifes.
Starting from education, growing up, marriage, house life, pregnancy and giving birth, work and of course fashion.
Loads of colors and items from real life of a woman with loads of interesting descriptions and facts.
Was helpful in some aspects.

Pleasantly surprised!. My family and I went along not really knowing what we would see here - we were pleasantly surprised. We found it very educational, learning about the important role so many Vietnamese women played in the many early wars, fighting for independence, proving they are very strong and resilient. We also enjoyed the clothing exhibits and the information about birthing and mothering issues. Found this worthwhile.

If you like costumes and jewelry, you must go here. A superb collection of tribal costumes in a beautiful setting. There is also jewelry and interesting everyday traditional objects. We loved this museum.

Awesome place to visit!. I went here with my mum on a recent trip to Hanoi. This museum was definitely a highlight with so many fantastic exhibits, the huge amount of English (a rarity in Hanoi museums), and lots of videos! Personal favourites were the floor about the roles women played in the French and Reunification Wars, and the floor about fashion and weaving and dying. Definitely worth a visit.

Interesting stories. We visited this museum because of the excelent rating in tripadvisor.It is nice how they display the things. You have to read a lot of stories, otherwise it will get boring. Enough for an hour-1.5h visit.

To be honest not as good as expected. I was really keen to see this after reading some really good reveiws and dragged my 2 friends Im travelling with along to. Unfortunately I didnt find it as informative as expected. I did learn about the woman of Vietnam dont get me wrong. The museum was laid out well with small paragraphs of text of a lot of case studies which made it easy to take in though.

Very enjoyable morning. This is a well laid out display of life through the ages for women in Vietnam. We spent around 1.5 hrs hers, but you could easily spend 2-3 hrs enjoying the stories and displays.

Very interesting and inspiring museum. I thought this museum was really great, not only is it modern and spacious in design with English translation it is very thought provoking and insightful. The pictures and displays are beautiful and some of the stories about the women's role during the wars are really eye opening. It is definitely worth a visit only 30,000 Dong and you can spend an hour to two wandering round.
Not what I was expecting.. A little disappointed, thought it not not really tell the story of Vietnamese women in daily life apart from a couple of the displays.

Beautiful. This museum is really worth visiting as it has wonderful examples of Vietnamese women's crafts which I found to be simply gorgeous. What surprised me though was the pictorial history of how women contributed to the war effort. This was particularly moving and inspiring.
Interesting Museum, great info. This was a great choice for our only museum of the visit. Really interesting information about wedding customs, lots of info about the women during the wars.
Interesting and attractive. Well-designed, well-curated and very interesting museum. Cute cafe in courtyard. Would highly recommend.

Handy lockers to stow away your bags. This is an excellent museum dedicated to the different ethnic women who make up Vietnam. The costumes are great and there are a small number of interactive exercises you can try. the shop here was very reasonable in it's pricing.

Why can't all countries have a place like this?. The best way to understand any culture is through the lives of its women - why don't western cultures get this?
Excellent interpretations through all stages of the lives of Vietnamese women.
very informative. very interesting and all brand new building, well done exhibition, especially the history of the war women

Best museum in Hanoi. Spent a very pleasant couple of hours here. The museum is bright and modern, and offers a fascinating insight on the lives of Vietnamese women. In particular, I was genuinely stunned and moved by some of the tales of bravery and resourcefulness shown by women during the Vietnam War. If you only have time for 1 museum in Hanoi, go here. IMO, much better than the vastly over-rated Museum of Ethnology, which is dreary in comparison...There is also a nice looking cafe and bar on the site.
Great photos. Very informative, particularly about women's role in the American War. Lovely and evocative photos, some very moving.

Very different... in a great way. It was great to see the contributions women have made in the history of this great country. It's even greater to see women being recognized in this way, with an entire museum dedicated to such. It was a very pleasant time, and definitely worth it.

Markets exhibit was my favorite part. Our favorite part was the "markets" exhibit outside the front doors -- the rest was interesting but I'm not really a museum lover so it's hard for me to rate. What I did appreciate was learning about the culture and the back story behind the markets and the women who spend their days selling fruit and other things on the street. This was worth the visit alone, and helped me to understand a lot more about the experience.

Eye opener.. This opened both mine and my 11 year old daughters eyes to how amazing Vietnamese Women are.The evidence of their role in vietnamese society is all around you, but until we went here, we hadn't given it much thought. It certainly made us more forgiving with regard to the constant requests from street hawkers to buy their wares.A must, especially if you have young daughters. My own daughter is a wiser, kinder, more grateful kid than she was before going to this museum.

Very interesting museum. This is a such a cool concept for a museum. It was fascinating learning about women in Vietnam - their history and culture and in particular their contribution during the various wars and battles. Lots of information and exhibits. I wish we had something like this back home!

We are women.... Hear us roar!!. I can see why the women's museum has one countless awards from Trip Advisor. The exhibitions were educational and colourful. The information regarding Vietnamese family life was informative and assisted us in understanding how difficult it can be for mothers to leave their families in rural Vietnam and move to the city to sell street items for money in order for their children to be able to attend school. The costumes were beautiful.I would most definitely recommend taking the time to visit this little gem.

A must see. A fascinating insight into the lives of women in Vietnam- allow at least 1 -2 hours to have a look at this informative and extensive museum which goes over four floors. I now have a better understanding of what it is like for women in this country.
Very interesting!. Woman life there differs from ours. Beautiful clothes, brave young ladies who started revolutionary activity in age 9 or 11, and were executed in age of 18th

Worth a stop if you have time. It's not the best museum I've ever been to but at $1.20 and an hour of your time it's worth a look to understand and appreciate how tough Vietnamese women's lives were and still are. Lots of pictures and costumes of the tribes as well as a section on women in the war. Worth a visit if you have time and like that sort of thing.

Boring. I had high hopes for this museum due to it's high ratings on TA. I'm a reader and I love learning new things but I found this to be boring and lacking any exciting information. The women in war display was probably the most interesting but the rest I could take or leave. The museum is well set out though and there is a lot of general information and displays so I'm sure others may enjoy it, it just wasn't for me.

Interesting insights, particularly the family life section.. This museum is well worth a visit and a really good complement to the Museum of Ethnology. There is interesting AV material and a wide range of displays.

Innovative Designs among Women's History. The most amazing collection of traditional and modern women's clothing to rival the New York Met in beauty. The tradition ethnic and aodai are represented but then there are innovative designs I would wear and treasure! I found great design both in fashion and fabrics in Vietnam and that should be an exhibit. It has two floors illustrating women's lives historically. Difficult, hard working, family focused lives. Many were warriors through the last 200 years as men disappeared. It's an in and out but worth the time

Amazing exhibit. The exhibits are well curated and focus well on the Vietnamese women: how they work and get married. My favorite is the top most exhibit with a collection of the amazing traditional dresses. Because of this, I bought myself a hand made skirt with a batik print!
It was okay. The museum was okay. It told about the lifestyle of traditional Vietnamese women, and their roles in everyday life and during wartime. It is worth a look if you are in the area.
recommended!. Hanoi is the capital of vietnam. they are becoming more and more modern, but still remember the ươmen's scarify to family.

Beautiful museum!. We went to a number of museums in Hanoi and this museum was one of the best. The design of the displays were simple yet beautiful and the organization of the information (fashion, history, family life, etc.) made it easy to walk through and get a glimpse of the Vietnamese women's roles in society, both past and present.

A great idea poorly executed. We were interested to see what this museum had to offer as so many positive reviews were on TripAdvisor, but we were both quite disappointed. We weren't pulled in by any of the exhibits and would have skipped it had we known what we know now. We really hope that it can evolve into something wonderful in the future, but for now, it's just a dud in our book.

Very interesting. Worth a visit if your about. Made me reflect on women's roles etc . Spent around two hours walking around. Not that interactive so maybe with kids not the best but if you read with them should be fine.

Very well done which you shouldn't miss visiting. Excellent displays throughout this museum dedicated to the Vietnamese women. One area is dedicated to all the heroic women during the war. Another area is their fashions throughout the years. Also gives you an insight into their many diverse cultures and traditions.
Inspiring. A showcase of the critical role women played and continue to play in Vietnam. Not sure why this is so high on TA list however well worth visiting .
Do not miss this. Moments in history that we all should know. If this place doesn't bring a tear to your eye, nothing will.

A must see. This and the Museum of Ethnology are unique and not to be missed on a trip to Hanoi. I look forward to taking my daughter again. The restaurant is a nice place to relax on the way out. My daughter loved the ice cream.

Great museum!. I'm a nerd and love museums, and this one was exceptionally interesting and well-done. Good mix of pictures, clothes and other items, and helpful text. Learned a lot and had fun- Highly recommended!

Well worth it!. We had only a short time before our flight so we decided to take a taxi to the Women's Museum and were very glad we did. We learned much about the role of women in the Vietnamese culture. Also viewed many to the ethnic minority costumes and rituals. We were able to rush through in about an hour and could have used another half hour. But on a drizzly February morning, this was a great stop on our Vietnamese vacation.
Memorable visit. Interesting museum, particularly the section on street vendors. They have a video with interviews and English subtitles. English translation to some degree on most exhibits

beautiful..Interesting...Must Do. was here in 2013 August, was pleasantly surprised at the information this place packs up about viet ways of life, very well presented and is Air conditioned (Hanoi After Noon's can be unforgiving) so plan your visit here when Sun is right up there.
Will come again... just to soak up some more culture.!

Great Museum. I enjoyed wondering around this museum. Interesting facts about what women do in Vietnam and did in the past also. Its a lot bigger than you think with lots to see. An enjoyable couple of hours was spent wondering around here.

Vietnam women's museum. Really enjoyed my morning here. Lots of interesting exhibits giving me a greater insight into women in Vietnam. As a mother myself I particularly enjoyed the section on family. Well worth the time spent here. Recommended, especially for women and teen girls.
Historical. The museum was very informative, I like the way they display different kinds of clothing from different places and age. Interesting to see how the culture change.
Yes, do go!. Well set out and colorful. Will take you 1-2 hours depending on how interesting you find it! Lots of information and photos, even some videos.

Impressive new museum. If you take time to read the stories which are in English beside the photos I don't think you can fail to be impressed by the stoicism and tenacity of these women. The videos also shed light on the background to the Vietnamese social attitudes towards the family and marriage. A newly built museum nicely laid out and with a café in the courtyard.
Fascinating stories. Best bit was the personal stories of women during the recent war. Marriage ceremonies good too.v clean loos!
About women for women.. Easy viewing, with interesting ethnic clothing. But with a socialist bent of heroic down trodden women who have risen above to help the nation!

I found myself moved by the stories. There's something about seeing a country from a completely different focus than that usually shown. I found myself moved by the stories and displays of a woman's history in Vietnam.

Chauvinist and boring. There are few women museums in the world due the complex issues and this one is definitely the worst. For this museum women's life sum up in given birth, marriage and of course fashion. The narrative is chauvinist and shouldn't Be accepted. The only part that was interesting was women in war but it was badly done. This women's museum is ridiculous and if you really want to learn about women in Vietnam just open your eyes in the streets of Vietnam.

Nice stop in the city!. The women's museum is a great little find in Hanoi. They have a cute cafe located in their quiet courtyard, a nice stop before going in to the museum. The museum itself has four floors and interesting exhibits, including a very interesting collection of historical posters.

Fantastic - it gave us a real insight of life in Vietnam. We visited here on our last day in Vietnam and wondered what to do as it was a very damp day. However, we thoroughly enjoyed it as it gave us a real insight into the life of some of the street traders such as the women selling flowers from bicycles, and also gave us a real insight into the part that some very brave women played in the war. It helped us realise the difficulties women and families have been through and also some of the difficulties they face today.

Interesting and well organized- worth a visit. The exhibits are spacious and well organized- there is a mixture of videos, objects, information boards etc, which keep it interesting.Each floor focuses on a different area of women's lives or spheres women have impacted- Family, in History and Fashion, with smaller exhibits relating to work and art.Although I skipped over some exhibits as some of it got a bit samey, overall I enjoyed the museum and particularly found the exhibits about women in the Vietnam War and current women working on the streets inspiring and eye-opening.Worth a visit (and open on Mondays unlike most the other museums)

Really nice!. It's really interesting to see how women in other cultures live. I'm not sure if they were doing a special exhibit or something but the focus when I was there was about marriage and family. I thought it was really interesting to see how Vietnamese women go through the marriage rituals and life with children.

Great Museum. Shows you women in Vietnam through the ages and how hard they work and the various jobs that they do, very interesting especially the bits about childbirth and their different beliefs. Some propaganda but that's to be expected. Well worth a visit for 1-2 hours

Reminds one of the ethnic groups in China. It is a small comprehensive museum depicting Vietnamese women & culture in the past. Rather interesting ethnic type clothes, but there's a kind of "moss" smell all around 3 floors!

Touching - definitely worth an hour or two. Talked my husband into joining me for this visit, and we were both glad we went. It's a well organized exhibit and easy to navigate. We found the video clips to be very interesting and well done; the one about street vendors was particularly touching. These clips give a different perspective on the lives and customs and challenges and courage of the Vietnamese women. Worth spending an hour or two, for sure.

Insightful museum. This was the first museum we visited in Hanoi and the one that made the strongest impression. We had planned to visit another nearby museum the same afternoon but were so enthralled by the Women's Museum we spent several hours there, no time for a second museum. The contribution women have made over the years to Vietnam's struggles is well documented.
excellent place to go. like the museum so much, I went alone but made a new accompany friend during my visit to this place.Thank you for that
Modern and well organised. This is a museum which illuminates the diversity of lifestyles within Vietnam. Its well laid out, with explanations in Vietnamese, French and English.

Worthwhile. For the price, this museum offers great insight into the female history of Vietnam - you certainly gain an interesting perspective and appreciation for the strength and determination of Vietnamese women once you visit.

Giving Woman a Voice. Through the exhibits, I now know more about the great contributions woman have done for Vietnam. I also know how woman have suffered and what help vietnamese woman in suburban areas of vietnam need. Many of them from the suburbs came to large cities like Hanoi to work to help raise their family. They work for long hours and yet earn less than 50USD a month. Life is very difficult for them. Such scenes can still commonly be seen in Hanoi and HCM today. So friends and tourists please buy from small stalls/hawker by the road to help them with their livelihood if you can.
worth your time. a wonderful glimpse of women's role in Vietnam, historically and today. Fashion/textiles section is exquisite.

Best Museum on Ha Noi. This museum tells the story of Women in Vietnam through the ages. I found it very personal and intimate. You can watch videos and read stories of the lives of the incredibly hard working women who you see every day selling produce on the street. I enjoyed the area that focuse on various traditions and dress codes of Ethnic minority groups. And was especially impressed with the section that focuses on the women who fought so bravely during the American/Vietnam war. In this country of hard working, courageous, family orientated people, it is always the women who shine out brightly. I loved to see this being honoured in this museum. I guess I am biased being a woman but my male companion on the day found it equally interesting.

Worth 1 or 2 hours. We have lived in Vietnam and we found this museum to be very interesting. It opens your eyes to all of the women and street vendors that you see around the cities. The displays are well laid out, however could be a bit more detailed. There is a detailed display of marriage and children. There is also a beautiful display of women's fashion on the 4th floor but they do not tell you what minorities wore them. Having just traveled from Sapa it would have been nice to know which clothing came from what minority group. The Women's Museum is worth a visit if you have an extra hour or two in the city.

A museum not to be missed. This is an excellent museum not to be missed. Depending on how long you have stayed in VIetnam you will either know or learn, that women play a massive role in Vietnamese society and this museum is essentially a tribute to this fact. The displays are set in a modern, western fashion and there is English captions with most displays.A both entertaining and illuminating experience.
great museum. good historical info on the lives of women in vietnam and the important roles they ahve played throughout history

A real insight. Excellent museum with four floors each depicting different roles of women in Vietnamese society and the great importance and sacrifice they make, even today. It went from marriage to child birth, family life and women's roles, war and the many courageous women fighting for their cause, traditions and clothing. A real insight into their lives in the pasta and influences today. Spent around 2 hours plus there, easily walkable from the lake.

A tribute to the contribution of the Vietnamese women. This modern museum presents a view of the Vietnamese women in the past and present, their role in daily life, religious ceremonies and war, and shows the different tribal dresses and ornaments. For me, not all the exhibits were interesting. For example I skipped the part of women in war, however many parts of the museum were extremely interesting and helped to understand the characteristics of the Vietnamese woman. Don't skip the videos. They definitely add a deeper perspective to the static exhibits.
Enlightening. Well laid out and very informative. Interesting to see how womens role in Vietnam is so important. Just about the right size and well worth a visit.

The revolution of Women. It display all the history of the women in Vietnam. From birth, to marriage, to fashion. You can see it all here. A great place to know about the country culture and history. Worth a visit, but not a must

Excellent Mueseum. We did not plan to visit the museum but our "guide" brought us here and we really enjoyed it and found it to be very informative. In fact the guide and had been here himself before and he found it to be most interesting and informative. Although it is not one of the better known sites to visit in Hanoi it was one of the more informative places that we visited. We arrrived late in the day and had to leave the building due to the closing time but we could have easily spent a lot longer than we did due to the nature of the museum.Was it worth visiting? YesWould I recommend it to other to visit? Yes

Thoughtful, high quality presentation; important visit, especially for kids. The Women's Museum was an unexpected surprise. A mix of multi-media, strongly curated shows on fashion, marriage and other topics made this a very stimulating and interesting museum experience. I especially enjoyed the video accounts of the women who sell produce and other items in the streets of Hanoi -- incredible personal sacrifices for families. You probably need about one to two hours to make the most of this museum. Don't forget to visit the top floor, which houses a contemporary art gallery featuring female artists -- an interesting space with a mix of different art. There's also a cute cafe adjoining the museum -- we didn't try it, but it looked clean, spacious and offered an good array of refresmhents.

Well done museum. Definitely a unique museum - just focused on women. It makes sense, thought, as the women plan a very important part in society (and they work hard!). The museum did a nice job of explaining the role of women and what they are faced with from childhood, through marriage and having kids, to growing old. It talked about their important roles in the household and the impacts of the markets. Worth a trip.
Glad we went to this museum. Found it very interesting. Displays excellent. An interesting few hours spent here. Worth a visit if you have time.

Very nice musuem. The musuem was very educational and very nice. I thoroughly enjoyed being there and proceeds go to a very good cause. The facilities are a bit old but apart from that it was a good way to spend some of our day in Hanoi

Kind of boring. I'm not sure why this was rated so high but my kids and i attended from Canada and found it very boring. The only part i enjoyed was about the american and french wars. The rest of it we went through very quickly but it was really cheap and something to do

Do as part of the Hanoi tour circuit. I know this is ranked number 1 attraction in Hanoi but I did not thing it was as good the Ethnology museum. It's a popular place with some interesting information, stories and photos spread across 4 floors but it did not wow me. Takes about an hour to walk round.

Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit to better understand the role women play in vietnam. Especially interested in the info about markets and how changes therein influence social interactions. Info about the lives of street vendors was humbling indeed.

A place to understand women history of Vietnam. So recommendable ! it cost 30.000 VND to go inside, it is located just out side the old quarter. This museum helps a lot to understand vietnamis women and behaviour and all the effor they make everyday.

Inspiring. After visiting many places over four days in Hanoi this was the best of all. On four floors it placed the role of women in a historical, political and cultural context which helped to explain the nature of these wonderful people. Tough, resilient, gentle, courageous and fun loving; al these qualities emerged as the exhibits unfolded. This is a peaceful place set back from the road and on leaving offers a quiet place for refreshment and reflection served by friendly staff. A "must not miss" if you visit Hanoi.
A great contemporary museum. Gorgeous space with easy to understand exhibits - make sure you buy the street vendor DVD at the gift shop as it is a heart warming eye opener to these savvy women.
Great tribute to amazing women. Very interesting and well laid out museum with very good English signs and information about the exhibits

Very sad but very informative. I found this museum wonderful but not sure my husband felt the same. Like most men that visited it, they seemed to be a bit bored after a little while. Definitely a must if you can drag your other half along and really cheap entrance fees.

A very different museum. Women have clearly played an enormous role in Vietnam's momentous struggles over the last 60 years or so…this museum helps to give context to that and showcases the lives of many of the heroines of the nation. Especially moved by the grandmothers who have lost their children. Well worth spending a few hours here
Modern museum in Hanoi. A very modern, well-equiped museum, holding interesting literature events. A place to be for people who love culture events.

Large museum with English Translation. Was glad that the exhibits were translated in English. The museum is large over 5 levels, so by the end we were over the reading and just quickly walked through the last few levels. The most interesting part for me was the display of the markets, which is in a room located just to the left of the ticket counter.

Deserve our world choice on tripadvisor. we spend time here in our rest of time in Hanoi.it is exellent museum.here you can see all the activities of the women in Viet nam could do in the past.with full of information in both language French and English. we feel happily when the ladies here have to strike for freedom and now many generation of wemen got it. I am a women so it is for me as well.congratulation for all.

Quite interesting. My friend and I spent a couple of hours here and cant complain for the price paid (20,000 dong) the exhibits are very descriptive and you can easily spend a couple of hours here. Not everything is in English and you definitely don't need a guide to take you around.It was easy enough to find and not a long walk from the lake at all. Worth visiting the old prison not too far from here as well as the two fit together nicely for a nice afternoon or morning out.
Fantastic museum. One of the best museums I have visited in Asia - good display of artefacts, explanations in English and French and a very thoughtfully organized exposition.

informative, visually stimulating and well laid-out. the Women's Museum is a must-see. it is so informative and really well-laid out. so easy to follow! the descriptions are very thorough and really give you a better understanding of not only women's role in Vietnam, but of lifestyle/traditions/culture of Vietnamese people in general. the women in war section, the part about fruit/food/flower vendors in the city and the Vietman fashion sections were highlights!

A Good Place to Spend a Couple Hours. I thought it was quite interesting to learn about all the female fighters in the war as well as the different customs women from different tribes have in regard to marriage and raising children. There was also a video when I was there of some interviews of contemporary street vendors. It gave me a bit of insight into the lives of the women on the street selling fruit, t-shirts, etc.

One of the best museum in Hanoi. During our trip to Hanoi, we got chance to visit this museum and we really enjoy it. Its all about the Vietnamese women, culture, history and family life. From here, we learn about the hardness life of some Vietnamese women to get money for their family. A must visit museum in Hanoi!

A good insight into Vietnamese life. A really interesting museum full of artefacts from Vietnamese life focussing on the role that women play. Staff are on hand to explain about any of the exhibits if required and there are some excellent video clips illustrating the many different ways of life in the country. Certainly worth visiting.

Our favourite museum in Vietnam. This museum is really excellent. The subject matter is much wider than simply Vietnamese women, covering by consequence family life and Vietnamese history from the social and cultural perspective in general. It was really modern in its approach and the way the displays were laid out, and was far more balanced than most other museums we had visited, which had a tendency to lay on the propaganda a bit thick. Oh and there is a nice shop and café too!

Better than the other museums.... After visiting the Ho Chi Minh museum we were hoping for great things visiting this museum. It's ratings were a lot higher and to be honest anything had to be better! It was average. I wouldn't write home about it.

Not usually a museum person. As others have said, well laid out and very informative. After speaking with some other travellers who went to other museums in Hanoi is sounds like I won out. Sit down and watch the interviews with the street vendors, it's quite eye opening. That's the biggest downfall to being a traveller in a place where you don't speak the language, not being able to talk to locals and I really think that this video helped fill that gap for me.

Nice place to spend an afternoon. Lots of information about the impact women have on Vietnamese society. Covers the family, the revolution and while the call it fashion it is about the minority women and their lives. Very interesting place to visit.

Moving and informative. This is a fascinating look at Vietnamese life, through birth, marriage, religion, war, and the roles that women play. Seeing how hard life is for the street sellers moved me to tears.well worth visiting.

A must-see in Hanoi. This museum was the perfect rainy-day activity when we visited Hanoi. Each of the exhibitions on all four floors are set up perfectly to inform visitors of the role of women in history, culture, family life, etc. We found the presentation on street vendors to be particularly eye-opening. Definitely worth a couple of hours of your time.

Worth the visit. This museum is a little gem and well worth the time. Its beautifully set up into four themed floors of womens contributions to Vietnam's history and culture and all of it is moving, informative and very well written (in English). I highly recommend it.

This is a must see. I had no expectations when I was taken to to the womens museum on a day out with the excellent Hanoi Kids tour. I was moved to tears by the exhibition, the contribution and sacrifice made by so many young women during the French and American wars was astounding. The faces of elderly women who lost children during the American war, one lost eight children, will stay with me.The story of the street flower sellers was very moving. This museum tells a story that has never been told in Australia as far as I know, I can't recommend it highly enough.

Absolute gem. One of the best museums I've seen in a long time. Superbly set up, everything in English and the information is actually useful and well written. There are 4 floors split up distinctly in themes all about women in Vietnamese history and culture. An absolute gem of a museum and a must see even if just for the set up. My book had said that it is closed on Mondays but luckily we managed to find out last min that it was not and checked it out. Used to close on Mondays last year but now open daily. I would put this high on the list of places to see in Hanoi.
Loved it . I learned so much, i could have easily spent 3 hours there, but unfortunetly i had only 1 and a half. Feeling motivated and inspired to do more as a woman. Thankyou.

Truly a celebration of Vietnamese women. My wife loved the museum, which charted women's lives through the war, birth death and marriage, family life, ethnic costumes and modern fashion. To read and understand the notes at each exhibit would take all day. so our 2 hours were, by necessity, just about enough to get a good flavour of the museum.There is a lift to the top [4th] floor, so working your way down makes life easier.We had an excellent lunch in the museum café.

Visit highly recommended. The Vietnamese Women's Museum is a great place to learn a lot about Vietnameses history and traditions and especially the role of women in it. It comprises of short biographies of the most important women in Vietnames history, shows the different marital customs of different ethnic groups and has a large exhibition about the mother goddess cult. Last but not least the museum documents everyday's life of Vietnamese women today.

An interesting insight to Vietnamese Women. A very well laid out museum with lots of information & videos in English.Learnt a lot about the fascinating cultures of Vietnamese ethnic women, everyday life of women & the roles women played during the Vietnam War.Definitely worth a visit.
Really worth a visit.. How fabulous to see Vietnam investing in the commitment of its women to the cause. A well organised, informative and special museum. Go!

Refreshing and well-done. I was so happy to see that Hanoi had an entire museum celebrating how women have shaped Vietnam's history. I thought it was very well done - celebrating all types of contributions from women throughout history.

great, must see!. I Think this is the best museum of Hanoi! There is a lot to see there. You will learn about the way of living of local women, but also about family life. There are interesting things to learn aboutthe street vendors you see on the streets everyday! I got the dvd and watched it at home, a lot of good information!
20-30 minutes max!. Not the best, you some very interesting stories. Women are important in Vietnam, because Mothers are important. Explained how different ethnic groups approach family/marriage.

the strength of Vietnamese women. There is something about Vietnamese women. They are strong, confident, and don't stand for any silly stuff. The Vietnamese Women's Museum (Bảo Tàng Phụ Nữ Việt Nam) will help you understand why. As the 2nd floor exhibit illustrates (with photos, propaganda posters and other material artifacts), Vietnam's women played a pivotal role in the country's spectacularly war-ridden history. The museum has three other floors, each of which explores a different aspect of women's lives, from marriage and childbirth to fashion and ethnic costumes. My favorite was obviously the second, for it's chill-inducing stories of women soldiers and their efforts in both in south and north Vietnam from the beginning of the communist revolution until liberation. Other points of interests were the floor dedicated to the Mother Goddess and the video documentary with women street vendors in Hanoi. Overall, an excellent way to spend a morning or afternoon in Hanoi.
Great museum. The women's museum is very interesting and has several very well laid out exhibitions all in a central location. Definitely worth a visit.

Refreshingly modern exhibition. A well arranged presentation on the life of women in historical and modern Vietnam. Very touching and a real tribute to the women of Vietnam. With genuinely interesting displays definitely do not miss this museum.

Honoring all he women of Vietnam. A very informative exhibit which honors the many great women of Vietnam past and present. To understand Vietnam culture better a visit to the women's museum should be on one's list of things to do.

A great museum. My wife and I loved this outstanding museum. I wish that there was space here to show some of the pictures that we took.The textile exhibits were among the best I've ever seen (Including Europe, US and Latin America). We spent about three hours here.Our thanks to the museum staff.

I Could Have Skipped It. I was excited to see what the talk was all about and I have to say that I was disappointed. There are 4 floors to the exhibition which is well laid out and professionally presented. Maybe I was expecting more but I found the first two floors were not very informative nor unique. I was definitely more interested when I got to the part about the women's important role during the Vietnam war. It just didn't do it for me and I felt that there was some disconnect and flow. The are, however, some beautiful examples of clothing and art.
Well worth a visit. So glad we went to this museum. It's well laid out and very informative. We left filled with admiration for these women.
Worth a visit. Insight into the street hawkers of Hanoi. Great displays of hill tribe costumes. Spread over several floors, this museum was worth the visit.

Vietnams Woman's Museum. very good historical review of woman involved in the freedom fighting for a unified VN
Very good cultural displays
Some insightful movies on how many of the street vendors come to be in Hanoi and other cities with families elsewhere.

Excellent overview of many aspects of women's lives. Great videos of traditional weddings, religious ceremonies, and interviews with women street vendors. Super collection of traditional clothing produced by women of the many ethnic minorities in Vietnam. Good translations of the texts in both French and English.

Absolutely fascinating!. Read good reviews on TA and was not dissapointed, it was so interesting to read about the amazing hare Work the Vietnamese women put in to support their families and their efforts during the Amervisn War. Entry was $1.50, and there is so mmuch to see. Definately recommended!!

Great incite to women's life in Vietnam. This spacious museum has much to offer; we especially enjoyed the video displays which gave us better understanding of rural life and the reasons the street sellers need to work so hard. We also enjoyed the costume displays of clothes through the ages.

Worth the walk. I only heard about this wonderful museum from a fellow traveller who stumbled over it, I hadn't seen it mentioned in any guides. Of the three stories of women's business I was most intrigued by their stories during the Vietnam War. The other floors cover marriage and childbirth, art and fashion.

Fascinating Exhibition. We found the museum fascinating and so informative, it is amazing to discover the part many Vietnamese women played during the war, the attire village women still make & wear today and the struggle women have today trying to make money to send their children to school.
Worth a visit. Well worth a visit,informative looking into the history and different customs of women in Vietnam very well set out ,takes about 2 hrs to have a look around

Good museum to dip in and out of. Excellent well displayed exhibits. Info in English, French & Vietnamese. Very informative. Sections on the family - women's place in the home and marriage; women and the fight for independence, costumes, women and religion
Very good . This is a well presented museum with a lot of material. We found it hard work to read everything but there are some great bits to find such as the street traders stories.

Informative visit. I did not know what to expect, most of my museum visits are European Art Galleries...the content seems limited and small but what I learned that day stayed with me for the 2 weeks I spent in Vietnam.
It is clean, open, and air conditioned. Well working elevator, but I think some steps to get inside the building

Great museum. I really enjoyed this museum, after heading back from Sapa it was really interesting to see all the Hill Tribe info. There was a great exhibition on the lives of the street sellers and it really made you think about the lives behind the jobs.
Nice Museum. Lovely museum depicting women's life in Vietnam from different perspectives and for different groups.

Worth visiting. It was my last day in Hanoi and I did not want to leave without going to one of the museums. This museum is located a bit outside of the center but it is possible to walk if you have time. It was a very interesting museum with cool artifacts from everyday life of Vietnamese women and it was easy to explore. It did not take me more than 1h30 minutes to see the entire place.

Modern and attractive, just not particularly interesting. Mostly just photos and examples of traditional dress. Unless you have a particular interest in the topic and want to spend the time reading all the info might give it a miss.

Great Museum!. Had an unexpectedly great trip to the Women's Museum. I think it has been recently renovated, as the exhibits were well organised, well presented, interesting- covering not only women's achievements, but also commerce, birth and marriage customs etc. Definitely worth the trip!

Interesting place. Possibly biased by being female... but I thought this a very interesting museum, well within walking distance from Hoan Kiem lake and only 30,000 dong.There is tons of info in this museum and lots of exhibits, I was impressed by the level of detail included about Vietnam's women and their contributions to the country. Most exhibits have English and French translations as well which I appreciated.Good bathrooms too :-)
Disappointing Visit. Enjoyed the discussions on the marriage traditions. The other exhibitions did not appeal to our group

Very informative and worth a visit. My husband and I spent an afternoon at the Women's museum and I really enjoyed learning all I did about the life of women in Vietnam, especially how they contributed to the American and French wars. Fascinating exhibits and real life stories kept my interest for hours and I really enjoyed the many different types of exhibits. A nice escape from the craziness that is Hanoi. If you have the time and are interested - go!

Really interesting museum. This museum is fantastic, with varied exhibits from fashion through to womens' role in the war. The information is written in french, english and vietnamse and as well as things to look at they have really interesting interviews and videos documenting womens' role in vietnamses society. I particularly found learning about the street vendors life interesting. I managed to persuade my partner to go, and he enjoyed it too!

Well Worth a Visit. Contains quite a lot of interesting exhibits. I particularly liked the short documentary about the street vendors which made me more willing to purchase items from the street vendors Well worth a visit if you have time.

Strong women. The museum showed the way of life for ethnic minorities. It was a collection of beautiful dresses and showed how much work the women had to do. It also showed how the women contributed in the wars with the French and the Americans. A very interesting museum.

Interesting (and quiet)!. A welcome reprieve from the busy museum circuit, the Vietnamese Women's Museum was informative, well designed, and huge, but without the bustling crowds of Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum etc. A good mix of audio/visual, artefact exhibits and always accompanied with well-written English explaining the exhibit (can't speak for the French or Vietnamese). The women's perspective is important to recognise even if you're not a feminist historian, and gender roles in Vietnam's history are incredibly interesting, so it's a must-see. Free Wi-Fi too! I would go in the late afternoon - if you really like museums, maybe plan for two hours, and finish off with a look around Hao Lo Prison (500m away) which closes at 5pm.

Very insightful and interesting. We enjoyed the Women's musuem- it was very insightful and interesting. We learnt lots and there was a good mix of artifacts, multimedia displays and exhibits. There was at least 3 or 4 floors to explore- so you could spend a good 2-3 hours here. The price was also quite reasonable- around $U.S 2-3 from memory. Definitely worth a visit.

Interesting exhibits about women's lives in Vietnam. We learned much about the background to the many street sellers in Hanoi, as well as marriage customs, children, clothing etc. Well worth visiting.

interesting but not fantastic.. I went here as I thought it sounded very interesting. I was the only person there and my driver took me to the wrong museum first. There were three floors and I nearly missed the top two as I just didnt know they were there. No one around to ask. I did find some of the displays interesting and seeing the vietnamese traditional dress was the most interesting. Wouldnt worry if you dont get to this museum.

This museum is a must in Hanoi. Very interesting museum that tells you more about the strong role of women in Vietnam. Streetvendors, familylife and all the rituals around wedding and birth. Beautiful exhibition!

Well worth a visit. The most interesting thing for me was the photos of women who had lost many of their children to the war. All politics aside, a mother is a mother, and the faces told such a story of struggle and hardship and perseverance.

Not just for women!. I am a solo guy traveling and decided to check out this museum since it has such good reviews on here (and it is right nearby my favorite vegetarian restaurant). I knew it wasn't a museum for women, but actually about women in Vietnamese culture. However, I wonder if other people know this because the museum was brimming with westerners, all of which were women (either solo or in groups). Perhaps it was just a coincidence, or perhaps guys avoid this place because of the name? Who knows.I am usually not a fan of museums, but this one held my interest for awhile. There are a bunch of videos to watch throughout the exhibits and they mostly have English subtitles. The one that affected me the most was the one about women selling stuff on the streets of Hanoi. I no longer look at them as annoying pests, but instead have a new respect for them (many come from the countryside out of desperation and would rather be living in their home villages).The museum has a lot of info covering 4 floors and depending on your attention span it could take up anywhere from 1-3+ hours of time to fully explore.As I said, I am not a fan of museums, but this one seems worthy of visiting.

Fantastic insight into women's lives. This is a well laid out museum, featuring a range of different exhibits and short films about different aspects of women's lives. I found the interviews with street vendors particularly powerful and the floor which illustrated women's contribution to the Vietnam (or - as it is known here - American) War was fascinating. Well worth a visit.

What a bunch of women!. They may seem innocently sweet, and no doubt are, but don't be fooled - the Vietnamese women were a tough and awe-inspiring bunch! They did their bit to free their country from the constraintes of imperialism, old and new, and are wonderful role models. I came away feeling uplifted and somewhat ordinary.

Very interesting exhibit on views from teenagers on their bodies and sex. The museum isn't "world class" but I really enjoyed the statistics about the views on sex by teenagers in Vietnam. Really interesting.

Very interesting museum!. You Will learn à lot, not only about women but Also other aspect of Vietnamese life. For example family life, youngsters and sexuality, and stories street vendors.
To me this museum is à must in Hanoi!

Celebrates women. The museum is well presented. The art works, videos and fashion were all remarkable. I was quite impressed with all the vietnamese women who were brave and strong , fighting for what they believe in. It was well worth the visit.

worth visiting!!!. The Vietnamese women's museum in in walking distance from the Hoan Kiem Lake. It's very worth visiting. Over 4 storeys of well represented information about life of women in Vietnam.
Every storey displays a different phase in a woman's life. Most impressive are the displays of tribal costumes and their making.

Well laid out. The history of the women in Vietnam is well portrayed and well laid out. lots of film and also lots of costumes. It looks like without the women Vietnam would not have won all their conflicts. Same the world over.

Surprisingly well done museum. I really liked it. Women in Vietnam played big role in the history of country and museum shows you what role + local habbits, wedding procedures. There is also very good video about women working on streets of Hanoi, selling goods and fruits. You get idea how hard they live and its different feeling when you enter the streets again and see them. At least you can give them more respect.
Only if you are really interested. Lots of photos and old costumes. We didn't really find this exhibition that interesting and wouldn't return. The Ethnology Museum was more appealing to us.

Great exhibits!. Not sure what I was expecting, but very pleasantly surprised at how well done this museum was to depict women of VietNam. I especially was astonished at how many war heroes and young espionage agents there were... Some as young as 9 yrs old that were fearless and strong. Gave insight into what a hard life current women of low income suffer being separated from families and working long hours selling in the street to support their children and save for an education. Good value and very informative!
good place. i'm impressed by vietnamese custome - have many dress, my girl friend said: "diversity - I love it" - I know how many dress they wear - Muong people.???? they are colorful

If you're into museums this is your kind of place. For someone that doesn't get a huge thrill from visiting museums I made it through 3 of the 4 floors. The information is very simply laid out with the artefacts to go with it, for every 10 information panels you read there's a seat and short video (with English and French subtitles) waiting for you. Worth while if you have a few days to kill in Hanoi.

Must visit. The contributions of women in society are seldom given its necessary place in museums and cultural monuments and the Vietnamese Women's Museum tackles exactly that. Anyone who is interested in knowing more about the Vietnamese peoples' courage, struggles and victories must not pass up on being intimate with the contributions of Vietnamese women in society. The museum's collection is rich with videos, photographs, letters, memorabilia, artifacts, textiles, tools and implements of generations upon generations of women who helped build society. Exhibition notes also come with English translation so everything is understandable to non-Vietnamese speakers. It would be good to have museums like this everywhere in the world.

Cultural insights. A modern museum that puts the culture into context. You'll see all those amazing ethnic mountain wedding costumes but also videos of street vendors and their hard lives. You'll reconsider next time you get asked to buy from some small basket of goods. This is what all museums should be like.

Interesting visit. Came here after reading reviews on trip advisor and wasn't disappointed. Entry was only about 30,000 dong and the museum is well laid out with lots of information in English and displays spread across several floors. The photography was really good, it was also interesting to read the other side of opinions on the wars that have taken place over course history.

Loved it. Loved the section on the participation of women in the wars. They even had excerpts from letters written home, and diaries. Very interesting. And everything was translated in English (unlike the Historical museum in Hue). Also, students can get entry for cheaper so take your student card with you.

Girl power!. an insight into the lives of women in Vietnam. It's amazing to see how women played such a major role in the war.There are also videos explaining why the women on the street are there all day and all night. their just trying to make a living!!! now when one approaches me I'll be happy to give them a little extra money. No one should go through that!They have loads of different ethnic dresses too, beautiful!

Really worth a visit. This was a very interesting museum, containing lot's of photos and historical information. It documents the amazing accomplishments of many Vietnamese women and also the terrible brutality of human trade. It's not overly preachy, either. It is really worth a visit.

Came with rave reviews, didn't disappoint.. This modern relaxed museum gives a great insight into how women have shaped modern day Vietnam and what an important part they have played in it's development over the centuries and continue to so now.

Great experience!. So this isn't really about famous people or events but the lives of the ordinary in Vietnam. I loved their exhibits on weddings in different communities in Vietnam - succinct and interesting. Their propaganda posters were also very good. Overall, the best museum in Hanoi!And the gift shop was really cool too! Got my postcards and gifts for friends from here!

Interesting. I normally don't like too much going to museums, but this was great. Interesting seeing the history og Vietnamese women. And nice to see the power they have had, and still have in the country.

A tribute to women. Great insight into the life of women in Vietnam. The museum is a tribute to women, and very different from what would expect from a western museum with the same title. There is little on equal rights, but a lot of respect and admiration.
Well worth a visit. The museum gave an excellent insight into the lives of the women in Vietnam. The highlighting of the part women have taken in the military in Vietnam was impressive.

Well worth a visit. This is easily one of the better museums in Hanoi, with professionally made exhibits showing the history of vietnamese women.
