Don't miss out on the video showing the lives of the street sellers outside, or the floor covering the war time era.

Great recommendation!. We had one more day in Hanoi at the end of our 10 day tour of Vietnam, and we were on our own for the morning. We checked trip advisor for what was recommended while in Hanoi. Number 1 was the Old Quarter which we had done (and after 10 days we were shopped out), and number 2 was the Vietnam Woman’s Museum. So we headed there.It is an excellent very well done museum. And the only thing I would recommend would be to do this early in your Vietnam holiday and not last. The museum gives excellent insight to the many women you see carting their wares on their bicycles, or carrying them in huge loads on the double ended poles they carry on their shoulders, and then selling their wares on the street. The museum covers Vietnamese woman in the family, religion, wars, and fashion. Very memorable. They also have a nice tasteful gift shot.

Interesting, worth avisit. We visited several musea in Hanoi and after the museum for ethnology this one was particularly interesting. On 4 floors a great overview is given in the role women played in Vietnamese history, defending their proud country and progressing society as mothers and those that create families. It humbled me as a oerson from the opposite sex. Very subtle, moving through the museum, one is brought to the role of women in todays Vietnamese society. This part is well done. I very much liked the videos of the women who sell their goods in the streets. These people lead difficult lives for a few dollars per day.The museum is worth a visit, as it also nicely shows the spiritual connection of womanhood to familial leadership (Mother Goddess). The only thing that bemused me was to see an obstetric forceps on exhibition with the label: 'Forceps - Device to purify the newborn'.

Women in the "American War". Well worth a visit - quiet and peaceful compared with the chaos of Hanoi streets outside. Entrance fee 30,000VND (about a £1). There are various exhibits about women and their lives in Vietnam, all with English commentary. The most interesting I thought was a video about the lives of women street sellers and the whole section on the Vietnam War (known as the American War, in Vietnam).It was the first time my wife and I had thought about this war from the Vietnamese point of view (as all previous knowledge was from US films) and this museum certainly shows the war from the opposite point of view and highlights the heroism of the Vietnamese women as well as the futility of war. Having said that, the museum in HCMC was even better regarding this.It is not a far walk from here to the Hoa Lo Prison which we thought was even more interesting than the women's museum.

This museum is well worth a visit. I spent about three hours here and could have easily stayed longer if I had more time. The area dedicated to the women in the war was incredibly. It really highlights the courageousness of the women in the war who are often left out of war stories.

Quiet getaway to learn . First off, don't look at the pin drop from trip advisor, it's not at the right location. It took me a long time to find the museum because of that...The museum was modern and organized. There were a few videos that didn't have any English, but it wasn't a big deal for me. They had a lot of examples of what all different type of vietnamese wore from the north to the south. What I wish they had more of was stories of modern woman. Or a video of women from the past. They had many quick bios of the women from revolutionary war, but didn't emphasize a lot on any certain ones. I think if you're in the area and have time to kill, it's a good place to visit.

Great exhibition. This wonderful museum has 4 floors. It seems quit new.There is a very nice exhibition on the different tribes living in Vietnam and the role of women in society. It is well maintained And very interesting. Suitable for children as well.
Interesting and well worth a visit. Well presented exhibitions with videos and artefacts. Helpful staff in the ticket office arranged a legitimate taxi to our next destination.

One of the more modern museums. If the name doesn't appeal to you, then it will be a boring time. We visited a few museums while in Hanoi but this one was the most well-kept. Explanations were detailed and numerous which made me feel like I actually learned something.Someone mentioned the bathrooms being horrid. The ones in the lobby are very nice. The ones on the upper floors are not very good. Something to keep in mind.

Really interesting. Didn't know what to expect at this museum. Pleasantly surprised to find a no nonsense, factual story in pictures and narrative of the role women play in Vietnam within the family, society in general and of course their contribution to the war effort. Worth a visit.

Finally - A Museum That Gives Women Their Due. This is a one of a kind gathering of stories, photos and tributes to the unimaginable sacrifices, leadership and strength of a wide range of Vietnamese women that have been instrumental in the survival and growth of this amazing country, despite over 1100 years of foreign occupation, wars and influence. Definitely worth taking the time to go through leisurely and attentively.

Interesting info. Lovely museum and well presented. Very clean and easy to navigate. Lifts for pram or disabled access (after negotiating about 20 steps at front of bldg). 4 floors, each presents different info on various aspects of Vietnamese womens' roles. was ok to keep children relatively motivated, lots to look at and could make up stories for different artifacts so they could be involved too. Take your own snacks as museum cafe was full of smokers. We ventured up the rd to small twitters cafe on the way to Hao long jail - cafe was a nice stop. A few various cakes to try and slushies for kids. (7, 4 & 20 months).

There's More to Vietnamese Ladies than Meet the Eye. A very well-thought, well-designed museum. I liked the way that marriage, pregnancy, and child-raising is presented in the context of Vietnam's ethnic variety - some patriarchal, some matriarchal. The video on the life stories of the famous hawkers carrying merchandise on their shoulder poles gave me a compelling picture of how hard those women work to support their families.I think I spent close to an hour in the wartime history section alone. While there are many exhibits related to the Communist Party, I felt that the museum takes great pains to go beyond political preferences and reach out to a global audience with stories that touch us all. The story of the 10 young girls (who were hit by a US bomb while repairing bomb craters on a road) reminded me of similar stories that took place on Okinawa in 1945, and drove me to tears.After those two hours, I think I have come to appreciate the true beauty that lies behind their smiles and ao dais.

Tourist friendly, well thought out museum. I was surprised at how professional and well considered this museum was. A great place to stop by and doesn't kill you with too much detail or content either like some of the museums do.

Surprisingly brilliant museum. The concept of the museum didn't sound particularly interesting but we were pleasantly surprised. Exhibits had plenty of English explanations (unlike some other museums in the area) and displays were fascinating. We spent about 1.5 hours here and rushed some parts. This museum gives you a real appreciation for the history and culture of Vietnamese women.

Beautiful museum. The Women's Museum in Hanoi is a must-go place as it fantastically illustrates the pivotal role that women play in any society and the toll women (and their children) pay as a result of wars and harsh economic conditions.The visit to the museum has certainly been one of the highlights of our visit to Hanoi.

Interesting. It was an interesting and well displayed exhibit. I was surprised as I had no knowledge of the role that women played in Vietnamese history yet came away knowing more. I enjoyed this more than the Prison Museum

Very informative. I actually was a little sceptical I have to say about this but once in there I was both intrigued and enthralled. The museum details the history of women in the struggle of Vietnam for independence but also goes into detail about the many different ethnic customs and traditions of the various different ethnic groups in Vietnam. It was both fascinating and interesting. I spent well ver two hours there and enjoyed the visit immensely. I highly recommend it!

Don't miss this museum. This is a very interesting museum. As is true for many of Vietnam's museums, parts of the museum are not well curated. However, you can learn quite a lot from a visit to this interesting museum that shows the important role that women have and do play in Vietnam.

Worth a look. This was a worthwhile and enlightening museum . It gave so e perspective on the women of Vietnam and their roles. We particularly liked a short film clip about the women street vendors who come up to you and ask you to buy things. Very good value

well worth a visit. I liked everything about it except the propaganda it didnt need any. its amazing how women are treated the same as men over there troubled history very tough women used top hardship

Gives a good insight in the Vietnamese Culture. A culture that is multicultural with different tribes and traditions, a god preparation if You are going trekking in the countryside in Lao Cai / Sa Pa.
There is also a good description on womens roles in the different wars the Vietnamese peoples has been taken through.

So - so!. It's clean and nice with good pictures, directions etc. However, being from India, I didn't find anything extra-ordinary in terms of life and style of Vietnamese women. It will be great for tourists who are not from Asia as an insight to life of most Asian women.

A tribute to women in all their roles.. A friend mentioned this museum and so I decided to visit. It is walking distance from the Old Quarter. The museum is modern and has 4 floors of permanent exhibition space devoted to fashion (from traditional to contemporary), family, rituals, and national heroines. The collection and presentation of textiles and costumes is excellent. There are many informative exhibits, visual, printed and audio visual. The video of statements by women street vendors gave a real insight into their lives and their struggles. Well worth visiting as it is a museum with a rather different perspective than most
Street Vendors. The best part is about street vendors. See it and you will stop feeling hassled and understand why they sometimes seem a little pushy.
Worth a visit. Well laid out and excellent translations into English. Something a bit different from the military and war museums that are prevalent.
amazing!. this was one of the highlights of my hanoi stay. i learned so much and the history was amazing. the displays were beautiful and well cared for.

Good museum, worth a visit. Nice museum, well set up, cheap. Particularly liked the interviews with the street vendors, and about the ethnic minorities. Good to see from a woman's perspective. Not an essential museum to visit if only got limited time but if in Hanoi for a while do go

Absolutely Superb. I went here today with my girlfriend, on our first full day in Hanoi. It's located close to the French Quarter and easy to find, although make sure you get to the museum before 3pm as it closes at 4:30pm.The museum focusses - unsurprisingly - on women's contribution to Vietnamese culture and society, and largely focuses on the past 100 years. There are 6 floors; all but the top floor being dedicated to a different area of life, such as marriage ceremonies and rituals, fashion, and women's contribution to the war efforts. There is a lot to see and read about so I'd recommend allowing 2-3 hours for your visit, especially if you want to read many of the stories of the dozens of remarkable women the gallery pays homage to, or if you are hungry and decide to stop by their cafe.Pros:-Professional displays, with good lighting and excellemt translations of each exhibit into English and French.-Detailed forays into fascinating aspects of life in Vietnam over the past 50 years for women, with lots about nuances between regions, and ethnicities and tribes.-Very well laid out, with no panicking about where to start and finish each exhibition and which way to circulate.-amazingly cheap at only 30,000 VND each ($1.40/90p).Con:-Dirty toilet with no towel or tissue paper.
Worth the visit. We found this place fascinating and informative. It was great seeing it at the beginning of our Vietnam trip. Takes a bit of time to go through but you can go at your own pace.

Goddesses of Vietnam. The Women’s Museum gives an amazing history, visual and written, of the role women have played in the amazing history of Vietnam. I do not see evidence that the role of women today matches the respect afforded the women warriors performances in the war torn history of the country. Still the history women, their arts and crafts, war roles is a must not be missed experienced.

Sisters. Great perspective in Vietnamese society and life through the eyes and experiences of women. The part they play is probably greater than in many other societies and women are highly respected because of that.

Interesting ethnography section. As well as show casing the contribution of women in modern and wartime Vietnam, this also has a wonderful exhibition on the marriage and birth traditions of the many ethnic groups who live in Vietnam. I especially enjoyed learning about the different traditions practiced by matrilineal and patrilineal tribes and their diverse pregnancy and birth superstitions. There is also a hall of women’s traditional clothing and a tribute to the women who contributed to revolutionary efforts during the last century – some of whom were imprisoned, executed or lost their lives during wars. There’s a world of Indochinese Sophie Scholls I never knew about, sadly. There’s also an interesting exhibit on Mother Goddess worship – practiced through theatrical and mediumistic Hang Dau ceremonies by men and women.

Really admire Vietnamese Women. We went to Vietnam Women's Museum on this November and we really amazed. We impressed much by the Vietnamese women in war, they sacrificed their happiness and youth more than ever for Vietnam revolution progress. Really admire these great women!

A bit hit and miss. Spent a good few hours exploring this museum. It's a well presented and very modern museum with good Vietnamese, French and English signage. Several topics are covered: woman at war, traditional marriages, motherhood, work and clothing amongst others. I felt some areas were much better than others. There is clearly a very strong political bias which is hard to ignore. There is also a disturbing lack of concern over the role of children in society (photos of smiling child labourers and comments such as "...joined the party when she was 9 to vanquish the enemy"). All a bit sugar coated.
Women Power. A place one must visit in Hanoi , you shall see and realize how much women have sacrificed over generations to make the world . The Third Dame said it all .

Insight into Vietnam Women. We spent nearly two hours at the museum. There are 3 floors with detailed information about the role of women. I was intrigued by the role of the young women during the Vietnam War and their sacrifices. The top floor is largely fashion of the various sub-cultures. It's worth a visit and may be the best museum in Hanoi. It's a short taxi ride from the Old Quarter or quite easy to walk to from Hoan Kiem Lake.
Great Museum. What a tribute to the women of Vietnam! The gift store was also excellent...Not to be missed when visiting Hanoi!

WOW! This is a must! Learned so much. Although it is called "women's museum" it really is a Vietnamese cultural museum. I wasn't sure what to expect being that it is called a women's museum, but we went because of the excellent TA reviews. It is a very well layed out museum with every exhibit in English. Each section addressed a different aspect of life and went through the different Vietnamese cultures and time periods. Family, marriage, pregnancy, occupations, the war, fashion. I loved seeing the fashion and different dress. One of the highlights for me was a movie they played that was a documentary containing interviews of the female street vendors. It really explained why the women have to sell items and food on the street. It was sad to hear how hard they have to work for such little pay.

Little gem. This was certainly one of the best museums in Vietnam. It described the part women played in the conflicts and what part they play today. Full of information which is really well laid out and easy to follow. Definitely worth a visit.

Beautifully Curated. Don't let the name deceive you, this Museum is the best in Hanoi. Set over 4 floors, it is a boutique museum but worth spending an hour or two. From stunning garments to the detailed role Vietnamese women have played in conflict and protecting their country from invading forces, each exhibit is thoughtfully displayed. As an observer you are invited to travel on a journey through the milestone of Vietnamese women's culture without any cheap sentimentality - a really worthwhile visit.

Modern museum -- best in Hanoi. A great way to spend a few hours is visiting this modern, clean, well-organized museum. I loved seeing the exhibits on marriage, family, and the mother goddess. A very interesting look at history and culture.

Tiny but mighty. The museum is pretty small but worth a look - the second floor in particular that highlights the role of women in the anti-colonial movements and during the American War is of particular interest

Interesting and insightful. The Vietnam Women's Museum is well worth a visit when you find yourself in Hanoi next. One gets to explore the role and context of women in society and in the many different Vietnamese cultures. In one segment the women who sell their flowers and rice cakes and other wares on the street talk about their lives, I found this to be particularly moving. Becoming acquainted with the achievements some of the women that are excelling in business or as social entrepreneurs was also a highlight.The exhibit on the role of women in the military and the many and various wars in the history of this country left me quite thoughtful. Even more more poignant than the feats and achievements of these women - 15 battles fought, 150 killed or wounded, twice captured, 3 Dakota's shot down, met Uncle Ho 5 times - is what is said by omission. How many died? How did they suffer? How did the many wars impact the lives of men and women and children?Vietnam remains a tricky place to become acquainted with in a real way, I do think a visit to this museum brings one a small step closer to a knowing.

Fabulous museum providing a fascinating insight into the lives of Vietnam's women.. Fabulous displays on a range of different themes including the role of women in the war, ethnic minorities, day to day life and some of the many hardships faced by women earning a living as street vendors etc.

interesting history of Vietnam Women. Well displayed and learnt a lot. English translation at each display. Souvenir gift shop had reasonable prices. Quality of items better compared to night market in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh!

A testement to the strength and courage of Vietnamese women.. This is one of the few museums in Hanoi that does not close and is open on Mondays. The museum covers lifestyles, clothing, farming and cooking implements, acts of heroism and political leaders and much more. Take your time as it is on four levels and quite extensive in its coverage of womens affairs. Very modern and weel thought out. The displays are amazing. Once again the entry fee is inexpensive and totally worth any effort you take to get there. We caught a taxi from our hotel and walked back via the shopping streets.

Interesting insight. We had a couple of hours spare and the guide suggested we visit here. It was very interesting, focussed on women in society, women in history and women in fashion. Liked the layout and found the curators and guides very knowledgeable
Well worth a visit!. The most modern museum we came across in Vietnam. It had excellent displays and gave a lot of insight into the lives of everyday Viet women.
Really interesting museum. Wow, the women of Vietnam were so instrumental in many facets of life. This museum is truly worth going to. Doesn't take too long but definitely worth the $1 US to get in.

Worth a visit. We enjoyed our visit to this beautiful museum.It provides a deep insight into the role women have played throughout the history of Vietnam and a wide perspective of various ethnic groups daily life. The information displayed is thorough and and very interesting. There is also a good museum shop with special handmade gifts.

One of the better museums in Hanoi. While I was not blown away by the Women's Museum it did provide some interesting insight into the roles Vietnamese women played in the war and also provides insight into their lives. You don't need much time here about 30 - 45 minutes is enough.
Informative. Well thought out museum with lots of information without being oppressive. Nice combination of video and exhibits.
Great insight in life in Vietnam. It's worth taking the time to see the exhibition. Well done. Especially the stories about living conditions and every day activities.

Worth a visit. A good museum. Discover the life of street sellers, the role of women in the revolutionary struggle, and the life of women from the ethnic tribes.
If you like museums, you might find it better to see it on your own, tours don't quite give you enough time.
Beautiful. A beautiful museum with beautiful scenography. I liked the ethnic minorities & the village roots culture spots, but the war heroins department was very moving too !

An enriching êxperience. This ís an in-depth, moving multimedia collage of women in Vietnam, ranging from fashion and handicraft production to their daily lives and roles that they have played in Vietnamese rural and urban society across the last 70 years, dating back to French colonial rule. Very reasonably priced gift shop with an assortment ò handicrafts. Not to be missed/

exellent museum. recommended by a friend, and now, it is time for me to recommend it! nice display; frequently organize helpful and interesting events; lovely souvenir corner; right at the centre of hanoi (within walking distance from hoankiem lake) surrounded by lovely streets with great sour ice-cream
Fascinating and perfect for rainy day. 30.000 dong entrance. It's really fascinating and worth a visit. Watch the movies and take your time to see the pictures

Great way to spend a rainy and/or hot day. Another one of Ha Noi's really nice museums, with a variety of displays, some interactive. They have many nice items on display, including traditional clothing of different ethnic groups. Overall, this is a nice and modern museum in a very convenient location. The price can't be beat (about $1 USD).

An excellent museum worth a visit. We enjoyed our visit to this museum as it was well presented with captions in English, French and Vietnamese, so easy to understand. It certainly was informative, and showed the extreme bravery of so many Vietnamese women, young and old, who had helped, fought, shielded and protected throughout the struggles and wars that had Vietnam had endured. It was fascinating to see it all, and learn about something that we had so little knowledge of.

Favorite museum in Hanoi. What a unique and informative museum experience! From weddings, motherhood, jobs, and role in the military, this museum gave me an appreciation for the history, struggles and strength of Vietnamese women. It offered a refreshing, new perspective and was one of our favorite stops in Hanoi.
A good insight to vietnamese women's roles.. Well worth a visit if you've got the time and you've got the interest. Otherwise there are more exciting places to visit.

Great to learn about Vietnamese culture. This is an interesting museum with lots of explanations (in English and French) about the roles of women in Vietnamese society. Well worth a look if you have time.
Gives good insight into ethnic groups. well laid out museum enjoyed more than museum of ethnicity as quiet and spacious. built on various levels so sound did not echo. Good av installations

Loved it. Amazing from weddings to war the exhibits explained photos and displays in English. The traditional way of life was highlighted over 5 amazing floors. I especially loved the heroes of Vietnam section covering the war

This is a quite different thing to do in Hanoi!. This museam is quite different than the others in Hanoi. I can say that is a mixed of the ethnology museam, the Vietnam Military History Museum and the history museam. The floor about the women participation in the wars are fantastic. Well organised, the explanations are in vietnamese, english and french. Its not a such big musem so you will spend about 1 hour to walk around and its worth. the café outside is not good. Walk a few meters and you will find a couple of better ones.

Highly Recommended. My wife & I spent nearly 4 hours here. Well presented with Vietnamese, French & English text. It occupies 3 floors & is not particularly big. However, we found the content very engaging.I think it offers foriegn visitors some fascinating perspectives on Vietnamese history, culture and contemporary life.I would also commend this exhibition to the younger generations of Vietnamese people, the young women in particular.

Favorite museum. This was my favorite museum that we visited in southeast asia. The information displayed is thorough and organized and very interesting! I loved the layout of the museum and found it very easy to navigate. My favorite section was the one on the women's contribution to the wars with pictures and bios. Incredible. This is definitely not a museum to miss.
What a superb idea. This is a great concept and well planned and laid out. A celebration of women of Vietnam. A must see.

A Tribute to the Women of Vietnam. This museum was one of the best we visited in Vietnam. Well displayed and incredibly informative, this museum provides a deep insight into the role women have played throughout the history of Vietnam, as well as daily life across various ethnic groups of this country. There are many excellent museums in Hanoi, but if you can only see a few, this is one we would highly recommend.

Totally enjoyable learning experience. I found the museum totally absorbing and informative. I came away with a new respect for the Vietnamese women. It is well worth making time for this museum. It has been remodeled in recent years and includes translation in Vietnamese, English and French.

Learn about Vietnamese women. At first I didn't have the intention of visiting this museum. But one day I just passed by it and decided to come. I didn't regret it though. The museum is very informative. It displays the life of Vietnamese women from different ethnicity. At some points they will show video related to the display. In the section about street vendor they show video of real street vendor. It's very touching hearing their story, how they have to live far from their children, work hard and earn only so little.
Inspiring place. This is an amazing place to spend a few hours in. Its full of heart warming stories of amazing women and there families.
Interesting to see how Vietnamese women live. Good museum in the old quarter, there is a cost but not much. There are some interesting videos and stories about women during the war.

Boring (for me). I mean, visit if interested, or if you need a place to get some AC while you stroll past the panels...As the ticket is 1$ this is easy to do, while the museum did not interest me as it did with my girlfriend.The exhibits are nice, but you need to read the information on the panels to understand them, and after a few minutes this became just plain dull to me.

A revelation of the role of women in Vietnamese culture and life. This museum takes the traveller through every facet of life and history for Vietnamese women. The interviews and documentary evidence is compelling evidence of the strengths and diversity of Vietnamese women. I moved through rooms of extraordinary displays of clothing from different ethnic groups, photographs and stories of individual women in armed struggle for their country and women with deep commitment to family - to 'make a difference'. I came away humbled at the dedication and strength of women in Vietnam.

Unique Experience. Although limited in time I was able to explore and experience the historical and contemporary roles of Vietnamese women via the 3 thematic displays of women in family, history and fashion.Perhaps the most interesting was their role in the French and American wars.

One of the Best Attractions in Hanoi. Very well presented, excellent captions in Vietnamese, French and English. Interesting description of the life and culture of the 54 Vietnamese ethnic groups from the women's point of view. Great section on women's role in the long wars of liberation. Cool, modern museum with great facilities.

History of women in Vietnam. We found this in our Lonely Planet guide and I'm pleased we visited it. It's a beautiful modern building and the exhibitions covered many floors. They were well laid out and filled with lots of information in English and lots of artifacts. Not only did they have sections on the women who had fought for their country either in a military sense or political but also areas dedicated to revealing a woman’s place in the current culture. It showed the different styles of Vietnamese weddings and how they would bring up their children. It was fantastic to see a museum dedicated to the gender that’s generally looked over in Vietnamese history.It took us a few hours to see everything and we were impressed with the quality of the museum.
Very interesting. Was interesting to read about the women's involvement in the war. They had a few videos and photos and lots of English and French translations.
Lots to learn. A good little museum with lots of information about Vietnam and its women. Beautiful photos and artefacts.

Unique and moving experience. I highly recommend a visit to the Vietnam Women's Museum. It gave a wonderful insight into the lives of women in Vietnam and the extraordinary ways in which they have shaped the country. The images and the stories were very moving. It really celebrates strong women and would be a wonderful place to take young women especially! Prepare to feel inspired!

Good opportunities to know the history of Vietnam through Women!. This place showcase the history of Vietnam through the lives of women. It is very interesting with the different era and their way of life. there are videos as well which makes everything better.
Interesting exhibits. Definitely worth a visit. Some of the life stories of the revolutionary women of Vietnam are captivating.
Thoughtful focus on Vietnamese women. Excellent, centrally located museum focused on women's contributions in Vietnam. Most captions are in English and focus on historical and political developments.
Worth a visit. Well set out and very interesting. Gives a great view of the women of Vietnam across the ages and ethnicity groups. Great documentaries.

Well Worth The Visit. This was recommended by a few people and initially had my doubts but pleased I was talked into the visit! It goes to show how much women have contributed to society for centuries ! The culture is truly amazing in this countries.

Definitely worth a visit. It was a rainy day and a friend suggested that we visit. There were four floors covering different areas of women's lives. The floor showcasing the role of women during the war was particularly interesting.

No mysogyny here!. A women's museum is a rare find. This one is well done and essentially pays tribute to Vietnamese women and the significant role they have played in the country's history. Very interesting - for any gender!

Well worth a visit. A museum dedicated to women. How good is that? An excellent museum - interesting, well organised and well curated. It provided many insights into the lives of women in Vietnam. They truly hold up half the sky ( borrowing from a phrase they use to describe women in China). Exhibits that are etched in my mind was the video about the women street vendors and the role women played in the war. They reflect the central role I believe women in Vietnam must have.

Excellent. This museum was amazing!!! It was well setout, informative, and even the children loved it!!! We walked there from the Old Quarter and spent a few hours looking around. Also, it was very cheap entrance fee. Highly recommended.

Number 4 of top things to see in Ha Noi. Very interesting and well done museum although not large and not much in terms of pieces of work. Important to promote in Vietnam and near most sights for travelers. Themed exhibits on usual rotation always makes a visit different than the last time one came here.

Fantastic display of the life of Vietnamese women. Spent a very interesting afternoon browsing the history, customs and daily life of Vietnamese women. Particularly interesting section on the role of women during the American war.

A museum about daily life and Life's cycles- don't miss it!. This is a great museum- it really focuses on daily life in Vietnam by looking at it through the lenses of marriage, pregnancy and childbirth, the role of women in the shaping of the country during the American war, and the possibilities for the future. On the first floor, don't miss the video interviews with women street vendors- their stories are quite revealing and often touching. They spend all of their waking moments working to help their families and yet they are so strong and so hopeful. The section on marriage ceremonies is interesting in part because it is divided into matrilinear and patrilinear based cultures/ethnic groups. I was really impressed with clear respect and emphasis given to the women who fought during the- it is a level of recognition of women's efforts I have not see in any other museum. This was a great museum and I highly recommend a visit. (There is a school right next door- peering into the windows as the students studied or recited was fun. It was even better to witness the 'let out of school' scene with tons of scooters and parents waiting for their kids to come out and all the chatter amongst the kids.)

Fascinating and touching. We loved the beautiful walk through Hanoi streets to this amazing museum. We were both spellbound by the floor relating to contribution by Vietnamese women to the various conflicts throughout the day decades. A wonderful experience which will stay with us both for a long time.

Very interesting!. I was somewhat very sceptical about "yet another museum" - i was pleasantly surprised though! It is interesting to learn and see it all & you will leave with a new found respect for Vietnamese women - they are amazing!

A museum not to be missed!. The Vietnam Women's Museum is a well put together place where you can spend a bit of time learning about the different roles woman have played in the history of Vietnam right from the early days, throught the numerous wars and right up until the present day.

A Unique Museum Dedicated to Women. It's interesting to see how Vietnamese women worked like men especially during the war period. The top floor exhibits costumes of various tribes and the lower floors have culture, religion and marriages.
Interesting and worth the time.. Take your time to take it all in, a very well put together exhibit explaining just how much these women have gone through in the past.
Nice surprise!. Interesting and surprising. Strongly suggested! It gives you an idea of the social aspect of Vietnam, in any form and from the 50s to today's life.
Vietnam women's museum. A well set out, airconditioned 3 floors of interesting facts, displays and information. Well worth the visit

A moving experience - one that brings tears to the eyes a year late, I kid you not!. I am of the American war era, though I escaped the draft by virtue of the luck of my birthday, 20 in 1965, but not drafted. I stood before these walls of paintings of women who had wept time and again through the war years.How can I tell you how it moved me to see these women, and the honour with which they are viewed? Nine hundred women whose many children all died or disappeared during those dreadful years.What a wonderful and lovely and appalling experience, I'd go to Vietnam just to stand here again.

Me and my male friend enjoyed it. It was very interesting to get some insight to women's roles in Vietnam. The floor about the war captivated me and my friend the most and was so impressed with what we learnt. Worth a visit!
history of vietnam woman. i like here, i can see many things about Vietnamese woman. there are many photos, clothes and things.High recomment.

Honouring women in Vietnam. How astounding that there is a museum dedicated to women. They are honoured and valued through the portrayal of their roles in Vietnamese culture and history. The exhibits and information about the role of women in the war were particularly interesting and moving

Well worth the visit. This was one of the better museums we have visited recently. It gave us a good insight into what it would have been like for women in Vietnam in the 1970's through to current times. Many really good videos that were well worth watching. Allow at least 2 hours if you plan to visit this museum.

even sceptical men enjoyed it. The idea of a museum dedicated to women seemed not to fill all the men in our party with joy, but in fact, we all found it fascinating - ok, so the display of gorgeous traditional costumes was more to some tastes than others, but the ethnological stuff about marriage and birth rituals amongst the country's different tribes was fascinating, and the film talking to the rural street vendors struggling to earn a living selling fruit to city workers was eye-opening. Really worth a visit - the only criticism I'd have was that it would be good to have a bit more background information in the war section to put the women's actions in context.

Interesting. I enjoyed this - my husband less so!! - The museum is dedicated to all aspects of women and it is done very well3rd floor - fashions2nd floor - religion and street vendors1st floor - the warThe video re the street vendors was my personal favourite and it really does make you take a breath and smile when you have been asked for the 100th time weather you want something - these women are working so hard for their families....

Womens Museum. Not as big as I thought it was going to be, been in quite a few museums across asia now and the exhibits in this wern't that intresting in comparison. If your looking for somewhere to kill some time to get out of the heat its not bad.

Great museum which really captures life of a women in Vietnam. This museum was a gret experience, telling the life of what it is/was like for women living in Vietnam. They really capture the essence and all exhibits are inviting and informative. A must visit when next in Hanoi.
Fantastic. A real insight to what the women of Vietnam have done for their country, and what they still go through today on the streets of Hanoi

Excellent. A very interesting museum that is definitely worth a look for both men and women. Set out well, with each floor displaying exhibitions on marriage, birth, working life, contribution to the war, fashion, and other things like ceremonies etc. Lots of very interesting displays and photos with English translation. I left with a whole new perception of Vietnamese women, especially street vendors. Good value for money.
Great place to visit. Really informative museum. Strong women highlighted. Worth a visit and even my teenage son seemed to like it .
Found it very interesting. Im not a huge fan of museums but the Woman's Museum was very interesting, informative and in english

Has It All. The museum, located conveniently around the center of Hanoi and the Lake, was the complete package. I particularly loved the section of women in the war, possibly because I fought in it on the losing side. It is in a well appointed building with a great gift shop. The museum depicted all aspects of Vietnamese culture, including dress, work, family life, and the incredible involvement of women in the struggle for independence against the French and the Americans. It is thoughtful, well curated, and very informative and engaging.

Great place ...check the address they have moved. This was a great place to visit even for the guys. It was amazing to see the life of the women from street vendors to fighting in the war. You will need a few hours.

Great to See A Female Perspective. Glad we went to this museum. Found it very interesting. Displays excellent. An interesting few hours spent here. Worth a visit if you have time.Not as commercial as other venues.
Interesting. Museum gave an interesting account of the role of women through varying times in Vietnam. An interesting and cool haven in a busy city.

Must do while in Hanoi. Great museum, very interesting (even if you are not a female) because it talks about Vietnam's history and culture. You will be surprise by the interesting fact there, Vietnam women are incredible...

good surprise, the "war" floor is outstanding. very good surprise on the way the vietnamese women helped shaping the history of this country.the museum shows the differences for the minority groups and the different clothes / way of leaving.however, to me, the best it is at the end, where the museum raises the importance on the women during the wars against French and Americans, with many women taking leading roles in the fight for an independent nation.it costs around USD 2, and you can spend around 2hours for a good view.
Must see. I wish I had longer to explore the museum, I stumbled across it just an hour before it closed and you definitely need longer to absorb and take in the fascinating displays.

Very interesting, lots to see. Covers lots of different aspects of women in Vietnamese society, from traditional beliefs, marriage and childbirth, through their roles in the war to their current day lives. Plenty to look at whatever your area of interest and great to have English (and French) descriptions. We spent a couple of hours here (maybe more) and I came away with a much better understanding of Vietnamese life both past and present, as well as a deep respect for the strength of Vietnamese women.

A surprise highlight!. Having wondered about the complex position of women in Vietnamese society (from their role in the American War to their role in agriculture) I was keen to find out more at the VWM. We were also lucky to visit during an extravagant flower exhibition which was a lovely bonus. That aside this is a well planned and detailed museum with English information provided throughout. Overall this museum offered a fascinating insight to Vietnamese culture from a female perspective.

Not What I Expected. It Was More!. I'm generally not a huge museum person, but this one is definitely worth a visit. The cost is 30,000 VND and you could spend as little as an hour (but you won't appreciate what's there in that time) or 3 or more.There are four levels all displaying something different, whether it be marriage, customs and childbirth, through to the history of Vietnam women and costumes. It is written in three languages: Vietnamese, French and English. There are videos in support of the floor display and they are worth watching.Overall, it is an excellent overview of Women in Vietnam and gave me a better understanding of why the women of today are still hard working people and I am not so annoyed by the street vendors. Go visit!

Great!. I spent about three hours here and could have easily stayed longer if I had more time. The area dedicated to the women in the war was incredibly. It really highlights the courageousness of the women in the war who are often left out of war stories. This museum is well worth a visit.

A highlight of Hanoi. Spent almost 2 hours here. The documentary videos that accompany the wonderful displays are an essential part of the museum and add tremendously to the exhibits. The one on women street vendors is very moving. Don't miss them.

Wow! A truly great museum!. I live only 5 blocks from this museum. I also live and have lived in Viet Nam for 18 months. The cost is 30.000 VND (a little less than $1.50 US), 20.000 VND for students. I entered, expecting to spend only 2-3 hours and spent the entire day there (6 hours) with two breaks: having lunch as well as a soda in The Museum Cafe. Good prices and very tasty. Eat there, you won't be disappointed if you don't order fries and order rice instead. The oil is not hot enough, making the fries full of oil. Yuck.I only spent time on the second and third floors of the main museum, fascinated by their information, graphics and exhibits. Don't miss the film about the street vendors selling trinkets, fresh fruit or doughnut-like things made with heavy rice flour. The taste is not that of a "usual" donut that one would order in the US: heavier, tougher, GREASIER and sweeter than any apple fritter! Their lives are very hard and they have no other way to try to support themselves. When you learn how much they take home to their families each month, you must know that many earn less than $50 US per month in Viet nam outside of the three or four major cities. The first floor relates how women marry, marriage customs and childbirth (with notations describing rituals and local beliefs). This is a "slow" room, expansive and not overwhelming. If you read everything (all titles and notations are in Vietnamese, English and French), it can easily take an hour or two, more if you really look at the wedding ritualistic gowns and the implements used for birthing and taking care of one's baby.The second floor, referred to by some as the "propaganda" room here on this site, documents women through history. There is an area before entering where a film on women through the history of Viet Nam begins with the year 40 BCE with a woman who lead a successful war against the Chinese and continues to the contribution of women in the 21st century. It plays in two languages: French and English. I sat through the French and wanted to see it again as it is fascinating. Well, the second time through, it is in English. So, be patient. Learning the role of women in the various conflicts, something for the West only shown in glorified war films, is very real and touching. In the area before entering, there is a set of three walls with pictures of Vietnamese medal recipients (many posthumously) for their service. Sit there, look around. Look at the faces of these old women, many now deceased, and wonder what they did, their sacrifices for their homeland: Imagine their suffering and of those who knew them. When you go into the main room, it creates perspective as well as a greater appreciation for what you will see. Inside of the main gallery, it is much less spacious than on the second floor. It begins with the work of those supporting the government of the north beginning in 1945. Yes, it is VIETNAMESE history, NOT propaganda. Remember that the North won the war despite the massive power used against them by the French and then the Americans. Women of all ages, spied, supported the troops and even fought and died for and in their activities. The war posters are wonderful to see as well and all are translated into English and French.Yes, many will remember the deaths of the French, Americans and others who were young; however, this is an accounting of the role of Vietnamese "women," not men! Personal possessions, usually very minute, are shown, making one wonder about her use of that item, leading each of us, if open and able, to reach into each one's heart and feelings.It becomes severely personal and, for some, that may be hard: from the tough life of street vendors, through childbirth and marriage and, then, into the tragedy of many wars.Yes, if you get ANY sense of this, the "humanity" of these people will strike you deeply and you will take home a profound sense of the role of women in Viet Nam, warts and all!

Magnificent portrayal of Vietnamese women!. This museum is well worth a visit. Parts of it are a bit boring, but when you get to the floor with all the women who had an impact on the history of Vietnam & the role they played in the Vietnam War you really stand back & take notice. They also have some interesting movies running about women in Vietnam today. Not all of them were working which was disappointing, but enjoyed those that we did see. Gave me a whole new understanding of the women selling there wares on the street.

Vietnames women (a power of strength).. A bit of a shock, so good to see wome get a mention somewhere in the world. In many ways the women are the backbone of Vietnam. This attraction is worth a look and won't take to long to do.

A fascinating insight into women's life in Vietnam. A brilliantly displayed history of women within Vietnam. Each floor is dedicated to a different aspect of life ie. Women in Family Life, Women's Fashion, displaying traditional dress inculding those of the ethnic minorities. This is a must see/do if coming to Hanoi. It is a great introduction to womens role in family and society. I highly recommend a visit here prior to heading to Sapa as you learn even more about the ethnic minorities.

Extremely interesting. We walked to this museum from the French quarter...just took a few minutes. We found the juxtaposition of the floors very thought provoking. On one floor we learnt about the different peoples and their culture and where women fitted into traditions etc. On the next floor there was an excellent study of the role of Vietnamese women in the various wars. How they led battalions into battle, how they were honoured as heroes, how they were spies and how they were executed. Highly recommended to those who are interested in the role of women in history.

Good Museum and worth a visit. I found this museum quite interesting and informative. We spent around 3 hours going through the exhibits and information. Woman play an important role in every society so it's good to see how different cultures portray womankind. Interesting to note the direct war efforts portrayed so they are obviously a tough bunch.

Really worth a visit. This is THE museum to visit in Hanoi, if you only have time for one. It is laid out thematically, has an excellent range and quality of exhibits and provides a wonderful insight into life for the diverse cultural and ethnic groups in Vietnam. A good example of how a 21st century museum should be designed - not always the case in Hanoi, in our experience. highly recommended.
Educational. Great history lesson and life lesson to appreciate how good most of us have it in the western world.

Take the time to visit this attraction. This was a very interesting museum and very well presented. You need to make time to take in all of the information on hand. It has lots of very interesting information and we had just been to Sa Pa we were very well acquainted with the some of the tribes that were well represented

Decent Place to Visit if you Have Time. If you have been to different museums in Asia, the Vietnam Women’s Museum isn’t too different. They have the pictures of women who contributed to the Vietnam war, the different suits and uniforms that they wore. What stroke me is the color and the indigenous materials that they have like gems and crystals on their headdresses. The intricate design and patterns of the clothing and the details in the decoration gives a great vibe to the place. It is not exactly a place you would like to go to if it’s your first time in Vietnam especially if you’re not too interested in History.

Fab!. First thing- if you're a student make sure you ask for discount! Brin your student card though. Great museum- we found it really interesting and were there for a good hour/&half. Loads to see- clothes, tools etc. and so much to learn! Especially their roles in the war- I was pleasantly surprised by the whole exhibition! A must do- would recommend it!

its a must. The topics that make up this museum are displayed well in properly written English and helps explain being a woman in Viet Nam. The building is easy to reach and within walking distance of the Old Quarter and contains fascinating pictures, stories and history.
Informative displays if a bit large. Very informative museum but we found it too big. Didn't keep our interest for the whole museum as there seemed to be a lot of repetition. Worth going to though
100% worth visiting!. We were really impressed by this,never seen anything like it, certainly worth a visit to learn about inspiring women and history Vietnamese women etc.

Not much to look at. This is a nice building but exhibits were sparse - the best thing was the photos and testimonials of the women who took part in the revolution. But not worth the detour, frankly, for me.

Lots of photos and good stories. I really liked the Women's museum. It's got lots of history of women in Vietnam, some great videos, photos, relics and clothing. All the signs are in perfect English. There's airconditioning. Probably the best attraction in Hanoi.
Very emotional--You may cry. This new museum gives a picture of women's roles and lives in Vietnam. The exhibit of vendor women made my wife cry--it was such a hard picture of an unfair life.

Bronwyn E. Very informative. Enjoyable to learn about the customs of Vietnamese people and their experienced in the American War.
There was a lot to learn that I never realised, the women certainly were very active.

Stunning costumes of many ethnic varieties. I would not have gone there but for a recommendation by another tourist. I found it to be the best museum in Hanoi. There were pictures of many aspects of daily life for women . The costumes displayed on mannequins were outstanding.I found myself taking pictures of everyone of them. I could not resist.

Best attraction in Hanoi. This museum was really interesting covering everything about Vietnamese women and culture from birth to marriage to their role in the war to fashion to work life. It's big, modern, air conditioned, and fascinating. Well worth a visit.

Fascinating. It was a very well set out museum that really told the story of women in Vietnam in the past and today. It was probably one of the besat museums I have visited and was enjoyed by mt husband and adult son too.

Must visit: one of a kind museum. We where not sure to go but after visiting it we recommend it 100%.
You will get to see a lot of textiles worn by ethnic minorities, hand made everyday objects and you will be taken into the rural lifestyle of Vietnamese society.
Very nice.

one of the better museums in Hanoi. As an english speaker there is something for you in most of the museums in Hanoi. But if you've been to a few you may have found that you felt you were missing some of the story.The Women's Museum is the best museum in Hanoi. Displays are colourful, interesting and informative with plenty in English to read and watch. It provides the answers to many questions that you may have from staying in Vietnam about the way of life. Take half a day to g8 there. There is also a cafe if 6ou get hungry :)

Interesting. A great museum depicting the role of women in Vietnamese society. Worth the visit. Well set out and the little videos scattered around the museum are well worth taking the time to sit and watch. There are English translations on the exhibits which is not always the case in Vietnam.

Impressive Documentary. Learn a lot on how Vietnamese women involved in building up Vietnam nation as an individual, as a wife and a mother in the family, as a member in guerrilla forces and as a leader to lead a lot of patriotic movements. Impressive when see the media describes how a lot of Vietnamese street sellers face on their day to day activities to earn their living and survive in a big city like Hanoi.

This museum rates.. Well curated glimpse into the various aspects of life for women in Vietnam in the past and in the present. Fascinating video of various street vendors who tell their story and outline a typical day. You will look at those women differently afterwards, I did. Well worth a couple of hours of your time. My husband enjoyed this too.

Very Comprehensive Museum. Our visit to the Vietnam Women's Museum was very interesting. The museum gives an in-depth look at women through Vietnam's history. The information shows women in villages and how they live and work in society. It also has an entire section on garments worn by Vietnamese women. One section was dedicated to women who assisted during the Vietnam Conflict. There was an entire wall of women heroes who were considered heros, but it did not include the names of the individuals which seemed rather sad because they didn't get recognized for their accomplishments. We really liked the information on the women visionaries.
Worth the visit. Interesting insight into the lives of Vietnamese women (including ethnic minorities) and their role in historical events.A/C better here than at Ethnology museum.

Must-visit attraction. We had a whistle-stop visit of an hour in this museum, and it was fascinating. Learn about the difficulties faced by the street sellers you will see shouldering baskets around hanoi, read about the women who lead resistance movements during the war, and discover unusual things like wedding traditions in remote matriarchal tribal groups.
Very interesting. Well designed modern museum tells the stories of individuals and the country through the eyes of women

Good overview about the female's role in Vietnam's culture. We visited the museum while some heavy renovation work took place in the upper floors. therefore the noise was quite disturbing while reading the explanations of the different topics.Still we got an complete overview about the role of the women in ancient and present days.Perfect spot to go while the rain floods the streets which happens quite often during the rainy season.

Women's Museum Hanoi. Within almost a year that I live in Hanoi now, I've been to the Women's museum three times. A girl in my Hotel recommended it to me, she especially pointed out the videos of the street vendors. On my first visit I was on my own, enjoying the 4 floors full of information, every floor has its own subject like "family", "tradition", "north and south", "clothes". The museum is made with an eye for details and is packed with objects from history (like a painting a young girl made in war time) and every day life. A lot of colored and black and white photographs demonstrate different stations in vietnamese women's lifes like harvesting, family life, history. The interviews with the streetvendors give a precious insight in their everyday life and their individual stories, there are further interviews with a doctor, a translator and a fashiondesigner. Only the fith floor that is refering to a museum in Singapore is less interesting. My second and third visit was with friends, who loved the museum as well. Next door is the women's museum cafe, a nice place with a cheap and tasty lunch offer and a big choice of beverages, I often meet up in there with friends.

Brilliant and illumunating. One of the best museums in Hanoi - don't miss it. Wide-ranging exhibitions with an excellent video interview with Hanoi street sellers, guaranteed to make you want to support them, and providing a great perspective on the transformation of Vietnamese society, its post-conflict challenges and effects of rapid economic development. Cold water sold at a fair price at the ticket office.

A revelation. What amazing women. These women did everything for their families and we learnt that the women who carry large amount in their baskets are doing it for their families, while they live in dire circumstances.

Do not miss this. I wasn't to keen to visit based o the name, but this is the first museum I have visited in Vietnam that has English on all displays, and explains what you are looking at! It was raining and cold the day we went, so a much better option than shopping.

Definitely a must-see!!. This was definitely my favourite attraction in Hanoi. The diversity of displays - from war to fashion and everything in between was amazing. I loved it!! The different styles/colours etc of the different tribal groups. History right through to contemporary photos - the lives of Vietnamese women through history are beautifully displayed in this spot. The free lockers were definitely something I appreciated as I travelled on a rainy day and was thankful that I could store my umbrella and bag while I browsed the museum. All the staff were happy and friendly, spoke good English and were always keen to help.

Great Museum. Includes a very moving and informative floor on the role of women in the American war - and in the struggle against colonialism. This is a great museum. Also has on sale some beautiful photographs.
what a history.. Do not miss this. Moments in history that we all should know. If this place dosen't bring a tear to your eye, nothing will.

no 1 attraction for a reason. so well done very stimulating excellent museum its for males and well use google maps to find everything or use triposo app has all tourist attractions already listed and a map to find
Great small museum.. Loved the insight we received in to the lives of women in Vietnam. Great display on the traditions of marriage.
Well worth a visit. Lots of different sections (so you can skip those that you have little interest in - eg fashion through the ages)Well labelled and presented. Well worth it

Worth a visit... even for men!. Open daily 8am-5pm, 7 days a week. My family were not keen to go, so I went alone. As I am a Mum/woman, I thoroughly enjoyed it. The museum is quite small, but very informative. Yes, it could be more interactive, but who will invest the money to make it so?. The first floor "Women in Family" was good, particularly for new baby rituals and marriage arrangements. The second floor "Women in History" was absolutely fantastic. Please take your time to read all of the women's war heroics/contributions to their war effort and do watch the movies. Also the 'propaganda' posters were very interesting! . Third floor: "Women's Fashion". Super fine silk embroidery detail and how Vietnamese female designers are influencing today's fashion. On the ground floor, the '"Discovery Room" was interesting and quite fun; although the shop was just OK. The toilets INSIDE the museum were clean. For 30,000 Viet Dong entry, it was well worthwhile. There is also a nice cafe outside.
really fascinating modern museum. Very interesting exhibits, probably the best presented museum we visited in Hanoi. Gives you a great sense into contemporary Vietnamese culture.
Modern museum, not that interesting. It's certainly a well-designed museum, but I didn't find the exhibits particularly interesting. Best section was probably birth and family life.

Well worth visiting.. This is a beautiful tribute to the women & families of Vietnam.. Brutally honest and confronting at times the museum is a celebration of the important role women play and a clear insight into the past and present lives of these special beings..
Eye opening. Must visit this museum. It gives a different light to the wonderful women of Vietnam. The Vietnamese regard mothers very highly.
Boring place. Take my advice do not waste your time here. What you see in one section is the same in the whole building. Wood carvings and such. Better yet make plans for Halong Bay.

Insightful. Quite an interesting place to visit and gives you good insight into how women in Vietnam have a major role in society. If you're big into into museums this is definitely worth checking out.

Enjoyable and educational. My family and I spent an enjoyable and educational morning at this museum. Firstly, the place is air-conditioned. It provides instant relief to hot and weary travelers who may have walked all the way from their accommodation in the Old Quarters. Secondly, the place has ample information in English for every item exhibited. In this regard, I reckon this museum is better than many I have been to in Asia, Europe and USA. And lastly, the toilets are clean. My only complaint is that there is not enough seats to rest our weary bodies. Overall it was an excellent experience. Well worth the visit.
interesting museum. There are sections about tribal groups, the role of women in wartime. Videos are included. A few sections have hands-on aspects.

Very interesting view. There's something about seeing a country from a completely different focus than that usually shown. I found myself moved by the stories and displays of a woman's history in Vietnam.

Best Museum in Hanoi. Compared to other museums in Hanoi, this one gives you the most information. Its a unique focus that provides real insight into Vietnamese culture. Its dynamic, lots of photos videos, photos, artifacts and clothing. Also really enjoyed the section about indigenous women. If you go to the women's museum you cover a lot that is also at the Ethnology museum.

Worth a visit. Really really good museum, one of the best ones I have seen in vietnam. It os very informative and the english translations are perfect, eerything is also explained in French. The exhibits are amazing and it was great to read about women of the war. For 30k it is definitely worth a visit. The gift shop is great too.

its like being in a womens studies course. comprehensive, informative, interesting. 4 floors of displays. depicts different aspects of life. Information about hill tribes. Costume, art and jewelry displays.

#1 in Hanoi, fun tiime!. It was a great trip, everyone loved it, even me; a football watching, normal guy liked it. The movies shown were a good way to learn a lot fast. Things were laid out well and covered far more than woman's history. Great cafe and the staff were really nice, one lady: with a doctorate in Vietnamese Folk Lore strolled up and explained the significance of the "Mother Goddess" to us all and it was really neat!

a worthwhile museum. It is great that there is a museum dedicated to the impact women have had on Vietnamese society. The documentaries about the street vendors and the women who have been successful in different fields and industries or through charity work were the most interesting exhibits.

Up culture. we visited at this museum for 2 hours. It was amazing. We can find out alot of information about 56 minorities of Vietnam and alot of photos for their life and private culture of one by one minority. We was very excited. Lovely

Worth a visit. The museum is very well set out and has lots of explanations as to the history of women in Viet Nam. We particularly found the videos and photos at each level very informative and helped us better understand how these women live/have lived.An excellent morning spent here.

A definite place to vist.. This museum is well presented and modern with numerous English explanations, unlike a number of Museums in Hanoi. It is a great way not only to begin to understand the culture(s) in Vietnam, but also an excellent tribute to the role that Vietnamese women have and continue to play in the Vietnamese society. Often however is Museum is not included in regular tour itineraries. Located on Ly Thuong Kiet Street, you can also link this visit to a visit to Hoa Lo Prison Museum, and if you want to see the centre of Buddhism in Vietnam, take a quick look into the Quan Su Pagoda. This differs from the many other Pagodas that can normally be found in Vietnam.A visit to these three attractions will take you around half a day. The Women's Museum is air conditioned so perhaps do this one last to chill down from the Hanoi heat.
Good museum. This is a great museum to learn about how Vietnamese women is such a big influence in shaping the country. It was very educational!

very beautiful,special........... Hanoi has a lot of museums and this one may not sound that interesting but it is definitely worth visiting. A lot of information,from family life, to different aspects of the different ethnic groups in Vietnam......

Was amazed by the contributions that women did in Vietnam. Was amazed by the contributions that women did in Vietnam, and cool to understand a lot of the customs in the ethnic groups of the country. Definitely worth the visit.

Reasonable time-filler. Worth visiting when spending a few days in Hanoi, but not enough to make a roundtrip for. If you're fairly familiar with Communist history, you won't see much new.
Relatively interesting collection of ethnic minority costumes, though irrelevant if you've include Sa Pa in your trip.

Average but interesting!. I thought it had good information on offer but it does not live up to the hype I found in recent posts!
Still worth a visit!

a recognition of importance of women in Vietnam's history. a great place to think about women and history in Vietnam, the role of the women in the minorities, their place in the fight against colonialism and during the war as well, and some perspectives about today. These days there is also a good photo exhibition at the entrance of the museum

Informative & interesting. For the price, this museum offers great insight into the female history of Vietnam - you certainly gain an interesting perspective and appreciation for the strength and determination of Vietnamese women once you visit. Worthwhile.

Educational!. We were really looking forward to seeing this museum based on what we had heard and read on TA - it did not disappoint - a highlight was the small exhibit about street vendors - and the video (don't miss watching this one!). The exhibit on the Mother Goddess rituals and practices was very interesting and informative. It is well laid out and the air con works really well in most areas! We spent over 2 hours here...the war info was a bit repetitious - it would be a great overview if you have not been south and visited the other war museums along the way - the profiles on specific women were most educational and interesting. Glad we went!

Wonderful museum. A very thoughtful and well-designed museum. The area on women and war is very intriguing. As with almost all of the excellent museums in Hanoi, it takes more time than you might expect to see it all.

Fascinating. A must do the stories of the Vietnamese woman and what they have contributed over the years was fascinating. Some of the stories of the women who faught for independence were incredible and totally heroic.

Worth a Visit. I'm not usually a museum visiting type of traveller. But the name and description of this one sparked my interest. The museum is well curated and organised. Some floors are better than others depending on your personal interests (I.e the wedding and baby bits I skipped). The military floor was fascinating. The representation of minority groups was also impressive. The little video presentations dotted around we're great. Well worth a visit. I fell a little bit more in love with Vietnam as a result!
Nice museum, good collection. This is a really nice museum that gives a good overview of the historic importance of the women in Vietnam.
Very educational. This museum is a modern building in a very central location in the French Quarter. They not only display subjects about Vietnamese women but also Vietnam history.

Very interesting. This museum has a number of floors, each focussing on a different aspect of the importance of women in Vietnamese history. The second floor which detailed the role of women in the fight against the French and then the Americans was extremely interesting and moving.
Insight into the amazing women of Hanoi. Educated me on culture and the strengths of these amazing women, information on family traditions of many ethnic groups of Vietnam
worth a visit. lovely pictures and a nice tribute to the strong women of Vietnam; four levels with photos; educational things about how women have children and their lives etc.

Interesting. This museum is very well done and very interesting. It is worth spending some time there to better understand the culture and history of Vietnam. I particularly enjoyed the section on the role of women in the war
Definitely Worth a Visit. Enjoyable museum. I particularly liked the film which consisted of interviews with women who sell flowers and fruit on the streets.

Worth to learn more about ethnic women's craft work and vietnamese women's life during VN war time. You pay just a small money to have very interesting chance to know more about vietnamese women's life and work in a country that normally women are considered as a "back support" for men and their families. This short tour is quite informative and visual.It is quite Ok if you are going to use less a day to explore this museum.

Information of women's role in Vietnam culture. It is located on Ly Thuong Kiet street, near Hoan Kiem lake - one of Hanoi’s most overlooked museums. It is informative with stories and explanations (in Vietnamese, English and French) regarding 3 themes: Women in Family, Women in History and Women’s Fashion. Recommended to spend 60 to 90 minutes here as part of city tour

Best museum in Hanoi!. The museum is very informative. There are stories and explanations for all of the exhibits. This is not the norm in all museums in Hanoi. There are even videos to provide explanations. If you are interested in marriage/family life, fashion, street vendors, this is a great place to learn more. It is worth the visit and should only take 1 -2 hours. They are open at lunch unlike some of the other museums. We suggest skipping the cafe beside the museum. Overpriced and not very good food. They brought me the wrong drink and wouldn't take it back. Not very good service.
Excellent museum. Excellent museum, focusing on the life of women throughout the country and their role in the struggle towards independence.

Worth a visit. Easy to get to in a taxi, should cost between 40,000 and 70,000vnd, it is cheap to get in and give a good insight into vietnamese life and gave me some sympathy with the street hawkers. It is informative and a nice way to spend a few hours. You can go on from here and visit Hanoi prison and then the temple of literature if that is your desire. All in the same area
Boring...waste of a trip.. Cannot understand why this is #1 on TA. Really pretty dull...not very informative. We wouldn't advise wasting an afternoon here.
Very interesting. Im not a huge fan of museums but the Woman's Museum was very interesting, informative and in english!

Likely the BEST museum in Viet Nam.. I have lived here for a number of years, but this was my first visit to the Women's Museum. I realized that I know nothing about how such a series of crucial accomplishments by the Women of Viet Nam shaped what Viet Nam is today - a Nation on its way to becoming a formidable ally and trading partner. If you have to decide on one museum visit while in Hanoi, this one gets my vote. This is a must see.
Worthy!. A museum devoted to the lives of women in Vietnam was fascinating! I learned alot about traditional roles, as well as women's role in their country's history.

Do not miss. We actually had a Free Hanoi guide insist we go and he was right on. Glad I didn't miss. Learned a lot more than I expected about the women's roles in Vietnam as well as their involvement in the American war.

Very informative and interesting museum. This one took a while to find for us. Great museum about the lives of Vietnamese women and it really gave us a better perspective on the struggles that people go through to make a living in Vietnam. It costs 20,000VND pp to get it, very cheap!

Very Interesting. It was a little hard to find without a map, but the displays were well laid out and excellently detailed. A very informative museum that does not take much longer than an hour and a half.
Worth it. Visit this museum before heeding to prison museum. It give a great deal of perspective on the prison.

Worth a look.. Some really interesting displays with explanations in English, French and Vietnamese. There are short films playing throughout the museum which were probably my favourite, but I think these are temporary and change with time. We spent a couple of hours there and gained valuable knowledge on women in Vietnam, and some of the traditional rituals involved with their lives.

Provides very good insight into women's role in Vietnamese culture. The museum is located in city centre, so it's not difficult to access. It does provide very good insight into Vietnamese culture and their history,and the roles played by their women. Recommended to spare an hour to 90 minutes here as part of city tour

Interesting, easy to fit in. This small museum in a large building describes the life of women in Vietnam, the many ethnicities, the traditions and the worship of the Mother Goddess. It will only take between 1 and 2 hours so it can easily be fitted in even a tight schedule.

worth visiting, touching stories. Women in Vietnam are very great, they do everything what a man shall do, farm working, construction, take part in war. The most touching part is the stories about "Hero Mother", I couldn't help crying when I read one mother lost 10 of her sons and 2 grandsons, that's too cruel to her. Of course, the war are cruel to many women too. That's a must visit place when you are in Hanoi.

Great!. I really enjoyed my visit to the Women's Museum, wandering through the exhibits feeling a lot of empathy and admiration for the Vietnamese women. It is exciting that there is a museum dedicated to women and I was really happy to have had the opportunity to go there. I certainly would recommend it to anyone going to Hanoi.

Interesting museum with informative displays. This was a very interesting museum with photos and artefacts which gave a good illustration of Vietnamese life. The displays all had informative English captions. The museum is air conditioned so it makes a welcome break if you have been trekking around the city.
Interesting. This was a great museum with interest exhibits and information on display. The staff were friendly and helpful and we really enjoyed the cafe!

Good, but not great. This was a decent museum to learn about Vietnam culture and history. A very interesting display was devoted to the working women who sell items on the streets of Hanoi to support their families. In video interviews, the women reveal the hardships and (small) rewards they experience.
Not a big museum fan but loved this!. Very good museum - lots to see and learn about with a variety of different displays and interactive tools. Staff were friendly and the cafe was something else!
Worth a visit. Really interesting musueum, esp the section on the role of Women during the War. Everyhting is well laid out and very informative. Althoguh we did wlak past it twice, I blame the map!

Interesting but expecting more. It is located in Old Quarter area, about 10 minutes walk from Hoan Kiam Lake.
