The contemporary designed building is really catchy along the street dominated by the buildings from French Colonial Era. We were guided by HanoiKids, so we had no problem to reach the museum.The museum is open from 8 am - 5 pm, seven days a week, with entrance fee of 30,000 Dong per person. Be noted that some of the museum in Hanoi are closed on Friday and Monday. Locker are available on the ground floor of the museum, but visitors are allowed to bring their belongings into the exhibition hall.The museum was built to honour the women's contribution to Vietnam. From costume of wedding, the tools for farming and fishing, to the fire arms that the women of Vietnam used in the fight against the intruders.By naming it a museum, we had in fact a higher expectation on it. However, it was more to an exhibition hall than a museum. However, with about 20,000 objects exhibited, it took us one hour to just take a quick round trip in the museum. Is it worth a visit? For us, it is a big "Yes". It is a good place for us to learn more about Vietnam.

I've been here!!. To Funnydude: You're right. Although the local guide just takes a glance of about 30 minutes, but it takes 1 hour or more to learn about lively rituals, marriage customs, childbirth and family life, traditional women's clothing and the role of women in defending the nation in the war. It's so interesting!!!Otherwise, I love the color and decoration of this Museum. It's very young and creative. Therefore, i call this visit "A colorful cultural trip via pictures and artifacts".

Great information, more than just female related material. I was a little hesitant about going as it sounded a little girly I guess you could say but I was pleasantly surprised. The museum had great props and in depth explanations about traditional Vietnamese marriage, birth, death, religion etc...all of which helps us gain a better of understanding of the country we would be in for the next 7 days. Be prepared to read and take your time however. If you aren't big on slow moving exhibits you need to read then it's probably not your kind of place. Was about $1 USD to get in. Walking distance to Old Quarter. Go to the room detailing the Mother Goddess and Birth, interesting stuff

Very informative with good exhibits. I enjoyed my visit to the Women's Museum on my walking tour of Hanoi. I spent at least an hour looking at the exhibits on 3 different levels with varying themes of women's culture in Vietnam. The description of what the exhibits are about are written in many languages other than Vietnamese, which was great. The women heroes of the war i found to be extremely interesting as well as the various tribes clothes of women in Vietnam.On the higher levels there was no air-con but you will survive in the heat.There are stairs to climb but you can take the elevator if you can't walk up.If you love history and are interested in culture this place is a must-very interesting stuff.
Informative experience. Was amazed by the contributions that women did in Vietnam, and cool to understand a lot of the customs in the ethnic groups of the country. Definitely worth the visit.

Women of Vietnam. I saw the Vietnam War first hand from 1965 to 1969; and in 2005 I was in Hanoi on a government mission. I visited the women's museum then and it moved me so much that I promised to take my family there and I did in 2013. It is worth the entire trip alone.

good place to visit. We visited this museum based on a recommendation and we had a nice visit. It was well designed and presented on several levels grouped by different themes and era. Although, as others have commented earlier, the AC was sorely inadequate for the 40C heat, it provided an interesting insight to lives of women of Vietnam throughout history. If you have an hour or so, it's a good place to visit.

Sad Happy Great Learning for me. The four levels took me through learning from life as a baby, to child to woman. Level 3 which is about heroines touched me by reading and looking at photographs in relation to the wars. Young girls putting their lives on the line and some losing them for their beliefs. Totally recommend a visit to this museaum for everyone. The price 40,000vd (about $2)

Good showcase of Viet women's life. This museum has been renovated with interesting displays of the typical life of a Viet woman and how they contributed to society at large, especially in the participation of war during the French colonisation and U.S invasion.
Nothing special. It's about what you would expect it to be. Maybe we were just a bit tired from walking around Hanoi, but we felt slightly disappointed with this museum.
Very Interesting. This museum was great, the A/C wasn't strong enough for the day that we were there but it was still worth it. Ask for the student discount if you are a student.

A wonderful museum. I prefer the French name, Musee des Femmes du Vietnam. The displays are well thought out, the heroines of the struggle against the French and America is the best part for me, and the tribal stuff is very good too, the marriage section was interesting but the ante-natal section left me cold.

Interesting Place in city center. The museum has been renovated and reopened while ago. I got chance to visit the exhibition of Women closet of all time in all over the country and it was fantastic. An interesting spot to learn more about the people of this country.

Fantastic interesting museum. Not majorly into visiting museums but was so glad i visited this one! It was fascinating to see all the vietnamise women have done for their country!! Inspirational!!
Also very well laid out!!

Cultural understanding of a different kind. Parts of this museum were extremely informative and emotive, and really solidified a semi-understanding of the resilience of the Vietnamese spirit. These women are role models for everyone.Admittedly though, some sections of the museum were superficially boring (parts that did not relate to history or culture) and not worth the effort. All in all though, if you have time to spare in Hanoi I would recommend the Women's Museum, for the traveller in search of more than what they can see on the street.

well worth a visit. Well worth a visit. Close to the old quater an easy walk or a short taxi ride. This museum takes you on a journey of the important role the vietnames woman has, and what influance they have had in history.

Gotta respect the Vietnamese women. Well laid out, airy, and fairly cool rooms. Factual information also in English. Found the video labour the women having to leave family to work in Hanoi for a pittance moving.
Great small museum. We really enjoyed our visit to the Womens Museum. Amazing amount of information on the role of women on Vietnam. Well worth a visit
Nice !. it is nice to see However i did not like to see on the top of this Building because i traveled many Places so i think i came to vietnam to see vietnamese culture not Singapore
Not bad. A lovely museum that is definetly worth a visit. But lack a little substance to occupy you more than 1 hour or so
Interesting. Great to get a sense of how women played a role as revolutionaries and in the War. Also really interesting exhibits on Motherhood and marriage.

More information here than we expected. this Museum held more than we expected and it was very informative about the over all life and struggles of the Vietnamese women who work very hard to support their children. the costumes were also displayed well. I found the videos set all throughout the four floors held the most information for me. Worth a visit for an hour or two.

Informative, interesting, worth your time!. I really enjoyed this musuem. The displays are informative and interesting, with plenty of pictures, video, and displays. There are even some interactive exhibits. I learned things here that I wouldn't learn from other museums or experiences in Hanoi. It's only 30,000 dong, and this place is well worth your money and an hour or two of your time.
Very insightful. Really worth a visit while in Hanoi. Great insight into the role women have played in Vietnam's rich history.

Great museum!. The women's museum was definitely worth going. very interesting history about Vietnamese women, movies, pictures etc on more than four floors. Entrance was cheap and we definitely recommend to go there!
Amazing women of Vietnam. A very well presented cross section of the lives of Vienamese women at peace and at war, especially the challenges facing single mothers, street vendors etc

Great museum. I love you museums and this is one of my favourite that I have been to. Very well organized and very interesting. There are videos to watch and lots of personal storoes to read, which is informative and very touching. There price is well worth it!

Superb gem of a museum. Modern, well presented museum showing the role and participation of women in three main areas of Vietnamese life; fashion including the tribal clothes and customs, the war, and family life including marriage / children. Fascinating and insightful, but with a light touch.

Not only for women. Nicely laid out museum that gives a feel for life for women in Vietnam. This is not only for women though but enables you to have some understanding of cultures and traditions amongst different ethnic groups in Vietnam, in relation to marriage practices for example. I found the section on women's role in the war very interesting.

Worth a look. Allow two hours to see through this museum. Worth a trip to see how the locals respect their women. Good display of marriage customs, family, birth, women's service in the war and different national dresses through the 54 different provinces.

One of the best visits in Hanoi. We heard a lot of good comments but having visited other museums in Vietnam I was a bit tired of the propaganda. I am glad I overcame the resistance. As per another review, this is not just about women but about Vietnam, with a strong focus in the minorities. Interesting displays on the traditions and customs, well curated and, for once, relevant and interesting information boards.

Good way to learn about the culture not just women. While some aspects of this museum deal with women issues such as marriage & family, a great deal of it covers the culture in general and is very instructive. You will see a lot of traditional costumes. While it is interesting to see these costumes I found it much better to travel to more remote places, including the Yunnan province in China, to actually see these minority groups who still dress this way. Better see the real thing than see it in a museum.
Women being valued. Very well set out, well labelled etc. Great to see women's role in history being valued this way as they clearly played a significant role in the country's history.

Must Do. A fantastic museum which provides great insight into the culture. The displays were great and all information is provided in English. I particularly loved the women and war display and street vendor information. It was very informative, not too crowded and a great way to spend a couple of hours. I'd recommend it to anyone, not just women as my husband enjoyed it also.
Best yet in Hanoi. Really enjoyed this one. A lot more information and quite well presented. Gave a good insight into women's role within Vietnam.

Emotional. I must admit that when my wife first suggested a visit to the museum, I wasn't to keen. Thinking it would be about fashion and cooking, how wrong could I be. What it is, is an emotional tour de ’force from the sufferings of women during the various conflicts to the women of the 30+ ethnic cultures that make up Vietnam. The museum is laid out over 4 floors and includes videos, artifacts’ and full costumes all for 30.000 dong (1.5 dollars)
Humbling experience. Not a lot here but what there is is worth seeing and reading. Very moving to hear local working women's strife to survive and support their families.
Good Insight. Good museum, but it does drag the subject matter out a bit too much. We were historied out well before the end!
Very interesting. Its easy to find, lots of information and very interesting. Good value for money and Well worth a visit!

Provides great insight. The whole museum is very nicely done, but I particularly enjoyed the sections on the women's contributions to the war effort as well as the modern plight of the street vendors. The museum really celebrates the Vietnamese women and honors their contributions to society. You learn about much more than just the "women's history" and get a very well painted picture of the history of the nation itself.

Fluent, interesting, truly inspiring. My friend is working for a Cambodian NGO focusing on maternal and child health, so this was high on our list, but I am so glad to see that it's high on everyone else's too! I am passionate about history and fascinated by the Vietnamese resistance movements throughout the 20th century, so the floor about "Women in History" was truly awe inspiring. The captions are well done in English, French, and Vietnamese.
Good palce to go. I'm a guide in Hanoi and I definitely recommend this. Very well organized and full of interesting information.

Interesting and Worth a Visit. The video explaining the situation of the women street sellers was the most memorable feature of this museum. I wanted to leave the museum and buy as much as I could from them to help them support their families!

Worth a visit (closed on Mondays). Entrance fee is 30,000VND. From the moment you step into Vietnam, you will see plenty of woman vendors on the streets or markets trying to make a living. The most I’ve seen in any other countries. This museum is all about the Vietnamese women…. their role in the past (including their involvement in war) and present. Time spent about 2 hours here. Recommended.

One of the best museums I visited in a long time. When I arrived some 400 primary school kids were waiting in the courtyard for their buses – the noise was really quite deafening but overall teachers seem to be able to control their groups without too much fuss. The museum (entry is D40,000) is very interesting, for example it explains which tribes follow a patriarchal line and which are matriarchal and how this has affected everyday life. Other parts show the role of women as brides, mothers, goddesses, workers as well as freedom fighters. It's all very well laid out with good explanations (all in Vietnamese, French and English).
Very interesting. A well laid out Museum. Follows history of woman through the years. Different sections ie marriage, Birth, education, part woman took in the wars etc.Spent 2 hours here.

Best museum in Hanoi. A little overlooked this museum is a must it gives a great and vibrant idea of the history of the Vietnamese women, the 51 hill tribes and their culture, dress, lifestyle, childbirth traditions, and a great history of many revolutionary woman in the war with their roles and sacrifices for their country.

A unique & not to be missed musuem. If you are in Hanoi, this is one museum I'd recommend. It honours the contribution of their womenfolk in the journey towards preserving nationhood, culture and family ties through the ages. It is a very informative and very well presented.

More Interesting than I Expected!. I am not a male chauvinist, but a 'women's museum' is not at the top of my list of attractions. In fact, I would have given this place a miss if it wasn't one of the few Hanoi museums not closed on Mondays.However, I was pleasantly surprised. The three floors are dedicated to: women's contribution to the war of liberation, family life, and fashions. I found the story of women's role in what Vietnamese call 'the American war' fascinating. The exhibits are well chosen and there are good explanatory texts (in Vietnamese, French, and English).Also of interest are the videos that play in the side-rooms off the main hall on each floor. These videos are about the lives of contemporary VietNamese women - everything from successful fashion designers to poor street vendors. One story - a woman who founded a home for orphans - was particularly moving.I went with low expectations, but came away feeling I had spent a very interesting morning.

Surprise!. A wonderful surprise in Hanoi, close to the Hanoi Hilton prison museum. Beautifully architecture shows of fascinating exhibits. The. Section on clothing reminds us that fashion is not a European invention. The stories of women at war show how far ahead of us they are in understanding women's abilities.

Great insight. This museum has recently been renovated and it shows as a fresh, interesting, clear, well signed museum with displays on everything from clothes to war with religion and families as well.
Nice visited. Come here, you can get more acknowledge about Vietnam women and culture of Vietnam. And come here you can see some kind of style "Ao Dai Vietnam".

Japanese Dolls. The museum was interesting, esp the areas covering the war. defo a good place to visit if in Hanoi. when we went they also had a Japanese doll exihibition where you could dress up and take photos all for free on your own camera, i thought this was fab and had great fun!!!

Something for everyone. Probably one of the best museums ive been to in a long time - the curator/s have put a lot of thought into how to present the displays and ensure they are interesting for all types of visitors - not just women! Very modern building and reasonable entry fee (30000 dong) I would definately recommend coming here as an interesting way to spend an hour or two!

Worth a visit. Really enjoyed my visit to this museum. The English language information is a 'breath of fresh air' - they have obviously consulted with English speakers because the narration is much better than other museums I visited. I also liked the way the museum presents the many different aspects of women's lives, and the diversity among women -from street sellers to entrepeneurs to freedom fighters - You get a rounded, fuller view of the lives of women in Vietnam.

Nice for an hour to wander through. Video of street vendors was excellent.. I got a bit bored with the clothing side, but I'm a guy so what can you epect. Gave me a further insight in to some of the culture of Vietnam.

A Mixed Experience. The museum is a mixture of the usual traditional dress and ceremonies that can be found in other museums with a facinating look into the roles that Vietnamese women have played and are playing in political, military and commercial society.The exhibition of womens roles in the French and American conflicts is worth the visit alone.The point of other exhibits is sometimes not so clear.

Disappointed. Other reviewers must have visited more than the women in history floor as there were no interactive displays and the displays were not as informative on the 20th century wars as I was hoping for. Hardly fair to pan it after such a limited visit, but we just had very little time.

Excellent Museum. I had been looking forward to visiting this museum for a few days after reading quite a lot about it in guidebooks. It did not disappoint. It was well laid out over three floors, each covering a different aspects of women's lives in Vietnam. There was a lot of information delivered through the use of pamphlets, artefacts, videos and placards.I thoroughly enjoyed the visit to this museum.

Well worth a visit. A really fascinating museum which gives lots of information about the role of women and the many different ethnic groups in Vietnam. It was especially good on women and their role in combat with many fascinating pictures and artefacts.

Interesting insight into women in Vietnamese culture. The museum is very factual - not lots of gimmicks, but if you want to know about others' lives, it tells interesting stories. I was especially moved by the video interviews of rural women who are so poor, they move to Hanoi for work, going to the market at 2 or 3am and then working for about 14 hours for a pittance to send back to support their children. And they can't afford to go home to see the children they're supporting. So sad. Also stories of bravery -18 year old girls who chose to fight to free their country from colonisers. Also the marriage customs of the different ethnic groups are described and displayed. A very educating insight.

Made me look at the street vendors differently. I had a morning to kill in Hanoi before flying home and my hotel suggested I went here and I'm so glad I did. Each floor looks at different aspects of women's life in vietnam: work, their roles in war through to marriage, children and fashion. The interviews with street vendors gave an insight into how difficult life is for many women and made me look at them differently as I made my way back to my hotel. Well worth a visit and near the Hanoi 'Hilton' prison so you can combine your visit.

Interesting oversight of women in Vietnam .... We found the museum very interesting in positioning how much Vietnam depends and is influenced by women in the population.
Definitely worth a visit.

Fascinating insight into Vietnamese woman's way of life. Do visit this museum if you have time it will open your eyes to the important part women have played in history of this nation as well as the family.
You won't be disappointed
Surprisingly interesting. Wasn't expecting much but this place was good. Well laid out, info also in English, lots of costume displays. Worth a visit

very interesting and gives some perspective to being hassled by vendors on the streets. we spent an hour and a half here with our two children and we all enjoyed the experience and learning of the more than substantial role women have played in shaping Vietnam society and history
More like museum of Culture. Interesting display of culture, but more a museum of the family rather than women. Museum was noisy when we visited due to large parties of school children being present

Interesting stories, displays and videos. The womens museum was much more impressive than I was imagining. It goes through 3 main stages - family, history and fashion. The section on the womens involvement throughout war time was particularly interesting.
Well worth the 30,000D entrance fee.
a good place to be. The museum tells you the significance of Vietnamese women in their history. They have played a great part in helping Vietnam win the war over Americans.
Over rated. NOT tops.. Very little has been spent to develop good exhibits. Mobbed by school children. Does not hold a candle to the Museum of History which is really first class.
Brilliantly interesting even if your a bloke.. Was really interesting, street sellers, families, marriage, fashion, wars, religion...Vietnamese women are hardcore.

An interesting way to spend an hour or two. You can get fairly museumed out when travelling but this place was pretty interesting. I particularly liked the second last floor where they displayed their female war heroes - these were some very tough chicks. Even taking account of the somewhat one-sided historical views (everyone does this) it is no wonder the Vietnamese people were victorious against all their occupies over the centuries, they're a very determined and resourceful bunch. It's also intriguing and refreshing to see the emphasis placed on the value of women's role in society. The museum is also opened on Mondays which is unusual.

Moving displays, calm and colourful. We really enjoyed our morning here. It's the sort of museum that keeps your attention because it's been well designed, it utilizes various displays(some interactive!), videos, antiques and keeps you wanting more. Over 4 levels, you come to understand the multitudinal ways in which Vietnamese woman have forged their identities in urban, regional and wartime conditions. The video presentations of street vendors who've been forced to leave their families in order to raise money really struck a sentimental note. As did the inerviews with inspirational Vietnamese women. For a mere dollar fifity, I urge you to take time out to visit this museum.

Excellent fairly new museum. I was glad to know that when I came to Hanoi 7 years ago with a women's rights tour I had organized that I hadn't missed this museum. The museum is a couple of years old and explains quite a bit about different ethnic groups with all the traditional clothing and the like. It is very well organized and even a little interactive. The descriptions of the different groups lineage was informative. There is also wonderful video about woman selling their products on the street and having to stay away from their families. I was suprised by how candid it was.
Very interesting. Fascinating insight to the history of women in Vietnam, very informative displays and well thought out
An informative visit. This museum is very well organized and the content is quite informative. I was suprised and impressed that such a museum has been created.

brilliant museum, do not overlook. Hugely informative on womens' role in Vietnam's wars. Full English/French translations. not among the first division of attractions but really deserves to be. Very impressive museum and educational to those of us in the west fed on Hollywood views.

Vietnamese Women with Substance with Valor. Deep insight into the role and history of Vietnamese women & thoroughly enjoyed our time here. Real eye opening is Women in History floor... You can also find some education about ethnic minority unique fashion and textiles on Women's Fashion floor.There is a Japanese Dolls exhibition on-going during our visit in a separate annexe at the Museum compound with photography opportunities (with kimono wear) for children / teens, and my what a frenzy the atmosphere was. A fine example on how we can encourage young ones to visit Museum by combining relevant activity(s) of interest of this generation.Highly recommended. Allocate at least 2 hours or more to enjoy this cultural experience!

Fascinating. 30,000 VND entrance fee, 6 floors of exhibits - brilliantly laid out. Fully explores the different roles of women, from childhood through to marriage, motherhood and the women's guerilla movement.
Emotional and Life Changing. I liked the pictures depicting women in vietnam. I really respect and admire them for their inner strength. I enjoyed the museum

Hanoi Woman's Museum with Indochina Pioneer.. This was a really enjoyable visit (after the Hanoi Hilton!!). So many courageous woman that you have probably never heard of. I would highly recommend any woman to see these exhibits. A real eye opener, if like me, you thought Vietnam was a male dominated society in the past!

Interesting insights. I visited the museum together with my boyfriend - we both liked it very much and it gave us some new perspectives of the role of woman in the Vietnamese society and vietnamese culture in general. We recommend to take some time to watch the videos within the exhibition. Entrance fee is 30.000dong/person. Exhibition provides all the information in English, French and Vietnamese.

A good visit, worth spending a few hours here. I particularly enjoyed the video diary interviewing the woman who peddle goods on the streets of Hanoi - very informative and moving. The displays are of good quality and there are English translations - this is a real bonus as having visited a great museum in Salta, Argentina but finding only displays in Spanish it means you get the whole experience. The entry fee is low - a good rainy day destination, or if you have 1-2 hours free at a loose end.

Good informative, tourist friendly visit. This is a well managed museum, there is a lot to see and read and worth spending a couple of hours. Gets a bit dry at the clothing exhibition but all in all there is a lot to discover and understand on the women of Vietnam. Would definitely recommend this place for a visit

Very informative. This was far more interesting than Hao Lo Prison....spent about 2 hours there. Very informative boards in Vietnam and English explaining culture, families, marriage, street vendors etc along with colour videos to sit and watch. Displays were very colourful. Very well laid out and clean. Good clean toilets too. 30,000 VND entry fee.

Splendid. We spent several hours in this magnificent museum. It is on 5 levels --Top floor has temporary exhibition about Singapore. Near the entrance is also a special exhibition of many Japanese dolls.The whole layout is well done, great displays and information in Viet,English & French.A really good insight into the history of Vietnamese women, including ethnic cultures.Highly recommend a visit.Fee 30000VND10/10

Fascinating insight into the role of women in Vietnam. A really enjoyable visit and insight into the role women play in Vietnam, both in the past, through the war years and now in modern day Vietnam. What comes through is how tough and determined the women have been and still are. Not just during the Vietnam war, but through out the uprising against French rule women played a pivotal part in helping defeat both regimes, obtaining equality that many nations still struggle to achieve now.The heritage and culture through the ages also comes through, and what you soon realise when you get into the countyside is that although the women have an equal footing the old customs are still alive and well. Particularly poignant are the stories about the women you see carrying huge loads of fruit etc. on their shoulders around the streets if Hanoi on a daily basis to help support their families back home on the farms. The long hours and weeks away from home life are very touching. Helps put into perspective that holiday snap you've just taken and the 50 cents saving you have just archived from five minutes hard bargaining.Spent nearly 2 hours in the here, a welcome relief from the heat of the day and a fascinating insight into real life. Well worth the entrance fee and more than enough of interest to suit any blokes. So take your time and take some I interest. Surprising what you might learn.

Excellent Museum. While some of the information can readily be construed as party propaganda, this museum is outstanding in its displays and information on various subjects of Vietnamese life. Would heartily recommend a visit for all ages and genders.

Do not miss!. After 16 days south to north in Vietnam, this was one of the top attractions. Smart, interesting, worthy stories of Vietnamese women! Everywhere else on the trip, all we heard about women was as nameless concubines. Give me a break. How about the warrioress who freed women from the harem? This story and many others told in this colorful, interactive museum. Check it out!
Thoroughly enjoyable. A very enjoyable museum about Vietnamese women, their lifestyles, their customs, and their role in society.
Educational. Gives a good picture of the contribution of Vietnamese women in nation-building. It shows the sacrifices of women in Vietnam's modern history.

A bit average at best to a fella. Mildly interesting museum but quite well laid out and worth a visit. Nice pictures and interesting videos and plenty of costumes through the ages, just a bit surprised it rated so highly. Cheap entry and will keep you intersted for an hour , me 10 minutes but she said an hour.

A cute museum/ done in 30-45 min. A very cute museum, highlighting Vietnam's heritage and history! Particularly well done for children / overall an interesting place honouring women's tough life on the country side.

Interesting museum!. Very good museum, especially the floor about marriage and daily life. The one about women in history is mainly about the war period, focusing a bit too much about how many enemies each woman killed during the war, which felt patriotic in a uncomfortable way.
Nice. A really interesting museum about women in Vietnam, you'll learn a lot. This museum is really nice !

Average a bit same same. It may be because we have seen similar in Laos and on our travels but found this pretty average. It is great to see how much Vietnamese women have contributed and how brave and strong they are but found it a bit boring at times. Other is too much info seems as if they have displayed anything and everything.Some of the visual displays are interesting.

Interested traveler. It gives an interesting view of women in Vietnam, including a fascinating video about the women street sellers and their circumstances. I'm sorry I know how difficult their lives are but in knowing, I know more about Vietnam. Make sure you read Robert Templer's Shadows and Wind found in pirated copies on the streets.

A great museam. We didn't expect much because we have seen a lot of lousy museums in Asia. But we really liked this museum. You get a lot of information, but not just by text but also throught all the fotographs and videos. It is really spacious. The only thing missing was a restaurant in the museum.

well done museum. We visited this museum solely based on its reviews. Very pleased that we did. The exhibits were very well presented and the subject matter provided insights to Vietnamese numerous ethnic groups and rich history. Outstanding!
excellent. Well laid out exhibits. Good range of information and material. I first visited 11 years ago and it was a bit shabby then, now much improved. A pleasure to visit.

Very Informative & Interesting! Great!. Museum was pretty in itself. Beautifully decorated rice field straw hats hung from ceiling. Great for a 2ish hour visit. To me, most interesting parts were about marriage customs, childbirth & fashion (they had a ton of mannequins w samples of cultural costumes). Worth a trip!

Interesting way to spend an hour or so. I decided to visit this museum as it was International Women's Day and it reviews so well. The highlight for me was the 'fashion' floor - not quite what I expected, a good collection of traditional costumes of various different Vietnamese ethnic groups, many with detailed embroidery, weaving or appliqué. The short film about the women street vendors was eye-opening as well.

Interesting. Interesting story well worth a visit you could spend quite a few hours there and it is good to finally read things for your self were we have been feed information through media or paperwork and you can form your own opinion.

Suprisingly interesting. Had a full day to kill in Hanoi and decided to spend it checking out some of the slightly less visited of the many museums in the city. It is a little away from the rest of the attractions but we still walked from the old city without any problems - it was easy to find and where it was meant to be!The museum is very modern and the layout well designed. It is certainly the most easy museum in Hanoi to navigate with displays clearly separate from each other and all explanations in English to provide you with a worthwhile experience.I feel that visiting these sort of attractions are what makes travelling to a different culture so enriching. It is a facinating hour or so, cheap and definitely recommended if you have a few days in this great city

Ver good if you are into understanding the life and role of the different Ethic groups. Maybe we were museumed out. I think I realised from the visit that I am not into the roles of women. A great visit if you are. Not sure how it gets the number one rating.

Good. Could find out some great exhibits at the museum. History of women in Vietnam was definitely proud. The location located on a large street, easy to find it. You could have some great coffee at coffee shops next door

A great insight into the realities of life for women in Vietnam. Fascinating and sometimes sad view of the lives of Vietnamese women. The stories of the street hawkers brought home how easy life is for people in the west compared with what these ladies have to do to provide better lives for their children.
A Great Museum. Wonderful museum that explores the role women play in society. Very interesting to discover how significant women were during wars. Exhibits well displayed with great commentary.
Worth a visit. Fascinating insight into woman and culture throughout Vietnam. There are a number of floors that deal to issues such as marriage, work, birth and child raising.
Worth it. Please take note that there are a day that this museum was closed. Been twice but one of the day was closed. Worth a visit.

The best museum we visited in Hanoi. Great displays w/ explanations in English. Interesting videos. Lots to see. Interesting video on street vendors. 4 floors of displays. Lots of information on minorities customs and displays of their clothing.

If you have time to waste or want to get out of the heat, this museum has some interesting Exhibits.. The entrance is a large rotunda with a great golden statue of the oversize and over-muscled Soviet school of propaganda depicting a triumphant woman facing a great wind with a small child balanced on her shoulder.Each floor concentrates on a different element of the women of Vietnam with the top floor concentrating on the war. In Northern Vietnam they call it the American War and in the south they call it the Vietnam war. History is written differently every where you go.

Very interesting!. Definitely worth a visit. They have a floor conveying different marriage and birthing practices of the different ethnologies, as well as revealing what everyday life is like for the women on the street in Hanoi. If you go, do it properly and spend time reading every exhibit and watching each video. Very informative!

Great Museum also for children!. Well designed and good infomation!
it even has a children section with LEGO and educational workshops!
Wonderful experience. Wonderful insight into the lives of women in Vietnam outlining birth marriage and their role during the American War - hugely moving and informative

A very unique and touching museum. Rarely have I seen a museum dedicated to the role of women in society and in different times in history. It is a transversal museum touching all aspects of a woman s life, from birth to family life, to role in society and education, and of course, the role of women during the past wars and centuries. I learnt a tremendous amount in this extremely well exhibited museum. Everything is well translated, well lit, easy to grasp, and fit for adults and children alike. Truly enjoyed the visit, the themes are extremely well chosen and celebrate women who really have an instrumental role in Vietnamese society. Bravo.

Great spot to spend a few hours. Lots to see so give yourself time. Five floors of displays, nicely done. Beautiful display of matrimonial traditions, including traditional clothing. Touching wall of portraits of the Heroic Mothers of Vietnam.

Good insight on the life of a Vietnamese woman. I'm not a big fan of museums but this one was quite interesting to learn more about the culture of Vietnamese women through different stages in their lives. I also liked the section where they featured the brave young vietnamese women who fought for their country
Very informative. It was unusual having a museum dedicated to women. It showed the life of real people in Vietnam. It was apolitical with no hidden agenda.
Nice experience. Not being a 'museum fan' I enjoyed my time here. It was not cluttered nor over stimulating but pleasant, informative and interesting.

Very good museum. Good museum that shows the role of the Vietnamese women during past and present.I really liked how the ethnic fashion was displayed and the background of the clothes was being presented. (Good English translation)I heard that the museum café should be good but when we visited it was closed since it was during Tet.I can really recommend a visit to this museum. Entrance fee is not expensive. 20000 or 30000 Vnd I think.
Great museum, worth a look. Well laid out exhibits with good English translations. I particularly enjoyed learning more about womens' roles in the Vietnamese wars.

fabulous. well worth the visit.. So informative and colourful and worth the walk from our hotel. Very reasonably priced too. Leave at least a couple of hours to wak around as there is so much to absorb.

Very good museum. By far the best museum I have visited in Viet Nam. I thought there was a good diversity of exhibits, ranging from objects to photographs, short films, costumes, mock ups of temples and a couple of hands on activities (threshing and grinding rice). The highlights for me were the marriage section and some of the short films, especially the interviews with the street vendors.

Well worth the visit. A nice display of the roles of women in the country: marriage among different tribes, childbirth rituals among different ethnic groups, the work of women, how women played a role during wars, women heroes in history, information about women who sell in the streets every day, fashion, etc.Plan at least about an hour and a half.
Interesting in parts. A bit repetitive as you go round, but does have some interesting information on the street vendors, not expensive to get in, so worth a walk around
Nice pictures. I am not a huge fan of museums, but I liked the Vietnam Women's Museum. It is not too big. I love the pictures that are on display - they are beautiful.
boring. Not very exciting at all, don't know why it has such good reviews. It was pretty interesting in that it gave me insight into women's lives in Vietnam.
Fascinating Museum. Check out the display of the Street vendors in Hanoi. You will want to buy something from every one you see.

value to visit. While I was staying in Hanoi, this is first museum I visited... the way they display culture are very good, they display movies, photos to explain of the traditional costumes, weddings, cultures etc...If you travel and care about culture, It is worth to visit. On the first floor they have one place for kids can play and drawing.

Excellent. To be honest I became a little bored with the top floor which displays all the different costumes worn by the 54 ethnic minorities of Vietnam. That's not to say it wasn't interesting but it was just too much. We went down to the next floor not expecting too much and were absolutely blown away by the exhibition of the Vietnamese women's contributions during what they (rightly) call The American War. Amazing personal histories of wonderfully brave, stalwart women. Just DO NOT miss it.
Worth it. Great place to see some real history, especially if you like textiles. Spend some quality time there.

Very professionally done and worth a look. Unlike many other museums seen so far on the trip, this one has been very well planned and set out, and has many interesting exhibits. Once again, for some spare change, and time-permitting (we spent an hour or so here), it would be foolish to not get along here.
Wasn't blown away but interesting enough. Hardly anybody there as well.

A must see. What a fascinating museum about the lives of Vietnamese women! Especially the part about the role they played during the war. Fun exhibit on the Mother Goddess Worship. Fun and informative.

good cafe too!. Good on ethnic clothing and the minority tribes.Bit ott on bereaved mothers and the role they played in war v usa. Great gift shop which had good cheap gifts. Cafe is a bit dearer than usual food but was excellent

Fascinating. I really liked the stories of the individual women who fought in the wars. I also liked the traditional clothing and the items on marriage/weddings. I still remember the quote 'A man builds his house and a woman her family'Generally a relaxed,quiet, interesting place to visit. But don't go there if you are trying to escape the cold, it was freezing.
One of my favourite things in Hanoi. Life in Hanoi from a women's perspective. Very informative and gave good insight into the behind the scene stories.

A must for women interested in Vietnamese history. We stopped here as an after thought, but will recommend it to all of our women's groups in the future - the trek through history is thoughtfully presented, and the costumes on the top floor are a must.

Modern museum covering the role and history of Vietnamese women. This museum consists of 4 different exhibitions:- Clothes and fashion of women of Vietnam's different tribes in different times- Women's actions during war agains US (expect a lot of Vietnamese war posters and listing of war heroes)- Women in Vietnamese agriculture- Women in families and marriageFor myself as a man, the war section was the most interesting, but you can manage other parts as well.
Best museum in Hanoi. Great, expansive and informational museum. Exhibits on ethnic minority women, the wars, street vendors, and on and on.

Inspiring and worthwhile!. As a women's studies major I absolutely feel in love with this museum. The entrance fee was cheap and we spent a couple of hours wandering around. The museum was well layed out but the top floors were of more interest so I recommend figuring out which floors feature what (eg. fashion, history, marriage, etc) and then start with those floors. Well worth a trip!
Interesting. If you are a history buff, you will enjoy the tracing of the history of the women who have fashioned Vietnam.

Definitely worth it. This is a well laid out museum (not the norm for Vientnam!) and very interesting. I was expecting some more in the propaganda line (a la how women helped the revolution and are the backbone of a socialist society) but it is much more thoughtful and complete than that.

Womens Museum. Gives a view of the struggle of the war
Also marriage and family life for various ethnic groups
Matriarchal as wel as patriarchal societies

Great museum. well done! Thanks very much for this admirable museum. Very interesting, with french and english comments, beautiful pictures, small movies explaining the women's life. On three floors, takes 1-2 hours, not boring at all. We also received free tickets for a musical show for the following day.

Interesting and Well presented. Being a history geek, we greatly enjoyed the presentations on fashion, family life and women's contribution to the anticolonial/imperialist wars with the French and the Americans. While it was a bit propagandaish in places, it was very informative on the Vietnamese perspective and was very well presented with good english didactic panels.

Worth the visit. Would highly recommend coming here when you visit Hanoi. There are about 5 floors of impressive displays which covers so much culture. I was very impressed with the stories of the women street vendors and the historic women figures of war. Vietnamese women are so strong and courageous. 30 000 dong well spent!

Very nice visit, amazing role of women during the war!. The museaum is cheap (1,5euros), quite big, clean and not noisy.
You can learn a lot about Vietnamese women and their role during the war! The pictures are wonderful

Great museum, even if you don't like museums!. This was a really interesting museum and there was some beautiful photographs displayed throughout. I have been in lots of museums throughout my travels so am starting to get weary of long descriptions and quietly walking through dusty halls but this was colourful and interesting. Also not too much information and objects to be an overload!Great museum, well worth a visit.

Add this museum to your itinerary. A beautiful museum with great a great deal of information. The video presentations were excellent and the weaving displays which I was especially interested in were beautiful and well-explained. The interviews with women who explained what brought them to the city and how they were trying to survive helped me to better understand the lives of the women I saw in Hanoi.

If you have to choose what to see in Hanoi... Women Museum must be in your top 3!. Super interresting! A must see. You will learn about the real life of women in Vietnam. About the Clothes, the like, the work, the jewelr and how the women influenced Vietnam. MUST SEE!

AMAZING! Best trip I took.. This was marvellous. The exhibits were clear, insightful and beautiful. I visited after they spent the 4 years rennovating the museum and their hard work certainly paid off, this is definitly worth visiting.
A Must-see Museum. Really enjoyed the history of the Women's Contributions to the Vietnamese War Effort during the 1960's & 1970's.
Fantastic. Great information on women's role in Vietnamese life, from past to present. Fashion floor more about dress in the tribes, rather than fashion today
Professional and interesting displays. Loved the hill tribe wedding and clothing displays and the women heroes from the various wars foisted on the Vietnam people over the years.

Well worth a visit. Highlight was watching the videos of the women who were filmed who come to Hanoi to earn money for their family out in the country. The historical clothing was another highlight. Can easily see nearly all within 1 hour.
Excellent Museum. We visited this museum on a cold afternoon in January. It is an amazing museum, very interesting and well worth a visit

A delightful but moving experience. This is an unusual but significant institution focusing as it does on the experience of women, both historically and currently, in Vietnam. There is a very revealing short documentary film, prepared by an American university team, which portrays the lives of women who ply their wares, fruit, vegetables, street-food or small objects, around the streets of Hanoi, most of whom are rural women having to work extremely long hours in order to make a little extra money for their beleaguered families, often spending many weeks away from home. To hear that such families earn little more than a couple of hundred dollars a year and still have to pay for education and health-care, is a chastening experience. Much of the museum is taken up with the role of women in the Vietnamese struggle for independence, first against the French and then the US. There is no triumphalism just a very factual account of what they all went through. And finally, there are exhibitions of weddings, births, family occasions and, of course, the history of women's work. Altogether an unmissable experience.

Worth a visit. Fascinating details about customs, especially marriages, among various ethnic groups in Vietnam are written in English. Clothing exhibits include types of needlework used by various groups. Videos captioned in English are interesting.
Great and worth for visit. Great to learn more about history of Vietnam Women, the Museum was easy to find, just some minutes from Hoan Kiem lake.

got to take yer hats off to the girls. against my better judgement my wife and i took in the museum but have to say it was very very interesting ..the female gender of vietnam have got my upmost regards

Fantastic. Excellent museum, several short documentaries to see, all exhibits had Vietnamese, French and English information panels - informative, but not lengthy.Definitely worth a visit. Very easy to get to from Old Quarter

Vietnam Women’s Museum – Representing the Face of Woman in a Patriarchal Society. What could impress a visitor most is that despite being a patriarchal society, there is still a Vietnam Women’s Museum in the country. Located in Hanoi, the capital city of the country, it exhibits over 25,000 documents and artifacts for the visitors. Spread over an area of 2000 square meters the museum is a virtual storehouse of information about the history and contemporary culture of Vietnamese women. Documents and artifacts displayed indicate the contribution of women to the history and development of the country.Highlight of the museum are the regular display systems that include historical, social, religious, and fashions of Vietnamese women. The museum also conducts various exhibitions and programs from time to time.

Pretty interesting stuff. The museum is a decent size over several floors with each floor dealing with a different aspect of life. The displays are well laid out and enough space around most of them for several people to view them at the same time. The captions for each display are short enough to read without getting bored but include a decent amount of detail. Captions are in Vietnamese, English and French.The museum is well worth a visit to learn more about birth, marriage, family organisation and the role Vietnamese have played in various conflicts in the country.One thing I would recommend before going is to learn the basics of the various conflicts in Vietnam as some of the captions talk about the enemy etc. but don't mention which country is the enemy. Simply knowing who was involved in each conflict, who was considered the enemy and rough dates will help the conflict floor make more sense.Out of the museums I visitied in Hanoi I think this was probably the best.

A museum worth seeing. Well worth visiting . Great exhibits and interesting documentary about many brave women who fought for their country. Gift Shop had good handmade artifacts for sale and friendly staff

Well curated and exellent displays. Not being a woman, I was not initially interested in visiting this museum until it was recommended by fellow travelers. The museum has recently completed an upgrade, and it has brought it up to international standards. The displays are well designed and well lit. Descriptions are detailed and consistently multilingual (Vietnamese, French and English). The museum deals with various aspects of Vietnamese womanhood: marriage, child birth and family; work and crafts; religion; costumes and fashion; and the role of women during uprisings and wars. It also addresses the differences in customs and dress between minority tribes.The most touching for me were the videos about the women you see selling goods carried on bamboo poles (such hard lives) and about the contribution of several contemporary women.At the moment entrance fee is 30,000 VND.

Absorbing experience. One place we visited without a guide so had loads of time to look around. Loved all of it and the two women in our group spent about 4 hours there. The men looked for 2 hours before heading off to a war museum. Wished I had read a bit more about Vietnam's history before I went. i did buy a book but it was so full of propoganda tha it was not worth having.
The best museum in the city. We nearly missed it, but it was worth the effort. The role of women in the country is well illustrated and interesting

Great place. It was amazing to get an insight into just how hard the Vietnamese women work and what they have done for there country. A very well done museum with lots of interesting things to read if you are looking for something to do for a few hours in Hanoi.
Interesting place. Worth a visit. There is no waste of time. What I did not like the self-promotion of the scheme in any room. I like it, recommend!
Great exhibits. Excellent museum, focusing on the life of women throughout the country and their role in the struggle towards independence.
Do visit. We really liked this museum - not just of interest to women either - it was very well laid out and a pleasure to discover

A great museum that acknowledged the struggles and success of Vietnamese women. The exhibit well documented the struggles, motivation and success of Vietnamese women through different times.
An interesting culture best captured in a unique angle by the Vietnam Women's Museum

Inspirational. The respect for women in Vietnamese society is something to aspire to, and this museum paints a picture of the reason that women are so highly regarded. It is hard to fathom the sacrifice made by any country under occupation or in war - and Vietnam is no different. However, the museum focuses on a much broader picture of women and the result is a fascinating insight into the country, its traditions and its history. Well worth an afternoon.
Quite good, but could do so much more. Would have loved to see more on the contribution of women to society beyond the idolised role as mothers.

Interesting, well organized exhibit that shows a snapshot of life for women in Vietnam over the years.. This museum cost about $1.50 US. It is well set out, with sections on female life, marriage, family, heroes and fashion. Was a good insight into life in Vietnam for women over the centuries. The English translations are great (everything is in Vietnamese, English and French). There are a number of videos, lots of pictures, displays and lots of information. It tells you about the life of some of the female street vendors in Hanoi (who are there to make money to support their families in villages) which was very interesting. There is also some interesting stuff about the Vietnam war and the women who participated.
awesome!. a five story brick building dedicated to the contributions women have made to the Vietnamese society. why don't more countries have such museums?

Interesting!. Great museum with a good overview of how women have contributed to life in Vietnam (it is hard to find that kind of information anywhere). Well laid out with good English explanations on all the displays. Make sure to watch the videos which have english translations also, they are on a cycle so you may need to wait. Best museum I visited in Hanoi.

Best Hidden Gem in the city. This is small but very expansive. It is one of the best maintained and updated museum in the city. It really demonstrates how the women have made the greatest impact on this country. The staff are friendly and helpful but only a few speak good English.This is easily my favorite museum in Hanoi - two thumbs up for the hard work they have done to make this a great place to learn and have a relaxing stroll thtu Vietnamese women's history.
Women's museum. Wonderful museum full of past glory for the women of vietnam. It showed the life, struggle women endured throughout Vietnam history. Good 3-4 floors of displays

Great museum. Easy to like this museum. It was very quiet and they let you see things from the female perspective in Vietnam. I especially liked how they showed parts of regular traditions. I found the american war to take a large part of the museum, but it's also a large part of the Vietnam female history.

better than shopping with your wife. I wasn't to keen to visit based o the name, but this is the first museum I have visited in Vietnam that has English on all displays, and explains what you are looking at! It was raining and cold the day we went, so a much better option than shopping.
Interesting. Nice exhibition, nice building, lovely welcome at the kiosk selling entry tickets, and 4 year old loved the play room.

stunning ...lots to see. my husband even thought it was wonderful...it had lovely clothing and traditional costumes, jewels and inspirational women everywhere you realise what strong and honourably people Vietnamese are ...

don't miss it. very interesting museum - you can learn a lot about vietnamese life style - the first floor is maybe the more interesting: it's about the life of women in different aspect of life - take time to reed the explanation
Well worth a visit. Probably the best laid out and most interesting museum we visited in Hanoi with great exhibits and very informative video clips.

Funny but a lot of the same. We went to the women's museum on a cold day in december. The museum is spacious and not very busy.
There are a few floors with different categories. Most of it is very much alike so after reading every sign in the beginning we stopped doing that and just walked around. It was fun, but not very special.

Not that exciting. I am a man so maybe it affects my opinion but I didn't find much here that was all that exciting. Plenty of war stories and heoric efforts from women but I didn't learn much. We had already been to many villages in Sapa and other places so most of the traditional clothing, customes etc we were already familiar with. My gf enjoyed it and glad we went.
wow!. loved all the displays especially the video interviewing women street vendors. It really gave us an insight into life for women in Vietnam.

Worthy place to visit on foot in Hanoi center. The museum is just 15 minutes walking from the Hoan Kiem Lake. And I think it's very moving. They have an interesting way of introducing some aspects in the past and in the recent. I like it,
Touching Stories. Worth a visit if you are sick of outdoors. Very good display for the notable women in VIetnam. It is definately worth a visit, especially the section on war stories

This place was excellent, I spent 2 hours there.. Gives an excellent history of the hill tribe traditions and the display about the war is unmissable. They give very personal stories about some of the women involved.

Good choice among museums in Hanoi. My first impression is the friendliness of the staffQuite a new museum. Everything is well-organized and carefully-categorized. Excellent way to know more about Vietnamese women. The contents are not the best but enough.The museum is open on Monday, which saves your itinerary if you unexpectedly arrive in Hanoi on Monday when almost all museums in Hanoi close for restoration
One of my favourite museum in Hanoi. Loved this museum! Educational history of past and current lives of Vietnam woman. Make sure you take the time to watch the videos. Well don!

Great Museum. The exhibits were great, and very well explained. The place is huge and the price to get in was hardly anything. I would strongly recommend this museum. It is very interesting to get a perspective on the lives of women in Asia, from making food and clothes to working in the cities to be able to support their families.

Surprising. We were so impressed with this new, beautiful museum with installations on Vietnamese women's history, culture, tribal diversity, customs, costumes, foods, you name it pertaining to women, it's here. Lots of different kinds of educational materials, videos, installations, etc, very modern presentation. Our guide was going to take us to Ethnology Museum and last minute we switched and I'm so glad we did.
great museum. the video of women street sellers and their lives is worth the trip. Also an amazing museum store. I did most of my gift-buying here

Fascinating museum & great play area downstairs. Videos of street sellers telling their story. Well laid out & informative info boards (in good English). Fab children's play room downstairs, things to suit all ages & free. We spent an afternoon there with our 1 & 4 year olds - after visiting the museum of course!

Great museum in Hanoi. A modern museum with fascinating information about Vietnamese women's contribution to Vietnam's independence, family & fashion. Lovely and w/o most of the propaganda you find in Vietnamese government-run museums.

great show. Visited Vietnam Women Museum in a day tour organized for us by Visit Wonders. The place makes a great hideaway from the street bustle. It was also a highlight of our time in Hanoi. Very informative and well-displayed with fantastic street vendor show which actually changes theme weekly. A must visit in Hanoi, my kids loved it too.

The best museum we visited in vietnam..... We visited this museum after reading the reviews posted here. It was really interesting for both me and my husband. It's really well laid out and has lots of commentary, something a lot of the other museums we have visited in Hanoi and HCMC have lacked. This is a great museum for learning all about Vietnamese family life and the tough path many Vietnamese women have to take to earn a living for their families. It opens your eyes to the very important role Vietnamese women have played in their country for decades.
A must see. A good way to learn so much about Vietnamese culture ...from a human perspective...in one spot. They have both English and French descriptions. Spent a good two hours here

So much information!. We spent much longer than we originally planned in the Women's Museum because each exhibit was so interesting we wanted to read all the information that was available. The cost was just 30k Dong (about $1.50) to get in and it was worth every penny. It was so interesting to learn the significant role that women play in Vietnamese society. Definitely worth a visit!

Professional curators at work. I visited again after a couple of years and was amazed at the improvements. Each display has been carefully thought out and has descriptions in english and french. It also seems to keep the nationalist fervour of some museums in Vietnam in check and gives a balanced presentation of life for women in different areas of Vietnam. this deserves a bit of time to visit each floor. I think they should think about expanding their gift shop, perhaps with more crafts women have produced rather than the standard stuff you see everywhere.
Very nice museum. Don't forget to visit this very fine museum when in Hanoi. It has an interesting collection and gives a good picture of the place and role of Vietnamese women in society.

A museum that will take you to the heart of Vietnam. Good variety of exhibits but not too much, and makes one realize how important women have been to a developing communist country like Vietnam. The fashion items are fun as well.
Excellently curated exhibits. Likes: well curated & informativeDislike: the tribes & cultures of the southern parts aren't well represented.

Best museum in Vietnam, hands down. This deserves its position as the #1 attraction in Hanoi, without a doubt. It's by far the best museum in Vietnam - informative, educational, hands on, and really attractively (and thoughtfully!) presented. A far cry for what passes as a museum elsewhere in Hanoi, where you're lucky to get a one line description translated into English and French describing a particular photograph. Make sure you go here!

Interesting. This is museum is an interesting place to visit. It is worth a visit while you are in Hanoi. It depicts and pays tribute for the contributions by women in Vietnam. It is also located within walking distance from the Hoan Kiem Lake. This is not for everyone. In order to appreciate it exhibits, you will need to have some interests in the history of Vietnam.

War heros and textiles. The women's museum was a tribute to war heros combined with a display of minority tribe textiles. Photos nd descriptions of the war heros were in cases and frankly got pretty boring to read after a spell. One woman infiltrated the American offices in Saigon as a clerk and provided "valuable information" to the north. In 1954, according to the museum, "the north was liberated while the south continued to fight for freedom against the aggressor America" or something like this. As the saying goes, winners write history.The display of textiles was more interesting but lacked context with regard to the war heros. Why these two as a focus? I went away wondering what else Vietnamese women contributed to its history. Science? Music? Literature? I guess I should have gone to other museums to find out.Entry fee was about $2. I stayed about 45 minutes
Interesting. We did the with the Hanoi kids, interesting but lots of reading to make the most of it, was good doing it with a guide who knows the history

Disappointing. We'd met several people who had said this was wonderful. It's a big collection of items from minority villages and there are some interesting nuggets of information which help you build your understanding of the different groups. But after a while what you're looking at is just another scarf.

Interesting place. There were good displays and interesting information. The marriage and history sections were my favourite... I had really high expectations of this place that weren't quite met but worth a visit if you have the time.
The women museum. Great time to visit the museum, we had a chance to learn more about some female heroes of Vietnam in the past.

Interesting.... ...it was nice to go to a museum. Lots of money was obviously spent here. But, as in many other museums in Vietnam, one had to wonder about the authenticity of the items -- and some explanation of the geographical relationships and current conditions of the various cultural groups would be interesting...
One of the better Vietnamese museums. After having visited a few vietnamese museums we found this better and more informative. Still some work to do but worth the visit
Nice. Worth to spend an hour on this museum if you have leisure time to wonder around the city, but believe it is a bit overrated because i don't find it as interesting as the ethnic museum.

Not for all. The show is not for everyone. No disrespect meant but, I didn't enjoy the show at all. It was too long. I joined a tour and they brought usto the top most floor. After that, we watched the show. Was excited to leave.
Moving experience. This museum does a great job covering the contribution of women to the war of liberation. We were crying by the time we left.
Great place to visit. After visiting this museum, we now come to understand women's role in Vietnam and its culture. Very interesting and my family members enjoy the visit.

Lacked information. While there were a couple of interesting exhibits, there were a lot that mainly due to lack of info, or very long explanations that really didn't tell you much. I wouldn't suggest this as a must see feature in Hanoi

Best thing to see in Hanoi. I loved the history that was exposed in this one place. Women's voices showing both thier struggle as well as the country's struggle. I found the Godess part really interesting as well.

Okay. It's so sex-role stereotyped . The first and second floor is about marriage and babies. The third floor, however, is a tribute to the women warriors who helped win the American war. That's very interesting, and I wish we had a Women's museum in the US
Not recommended. The guidebooks really recommended this museum. I was disappointed however. There was just not very much to see. Still, the gallery is very modern and nicely presented.
Interesting. It is a very good museum. Very educative and give more explanations on the culture. It is very good to start with this museum and important for the women.
Interesting and modern. Stands out as one of the more interesting museum trips we've made. Lots of money has obviously been spent on making it an engaging place to visit.

Fascinating insights at this museum. This is a museum that draws you into the fascinating history and of Vietnamese women. I spent 3 hours here and didn't want to leave. The experiences depicted on the 3rd floor, which focusses on the Vietnam war, had a profound effect on me.

Power of Vietnamese's women.. Modern and clean presentation. You can find out the culture, costume and everything about women in Vietnam. The war time's heroins histories were impressed. Luckily I made a move to visit.

Important place to visit. The Women's museum in Hanoi is a must visit if you go to Hanoi. While the name could be slightly misleading, the museum is essentially a collection of stories and artefacts about daily lives in Vietnam, told through the tales of women, but is really about all people of Vietnam. Great layout, enough interactive stuff to keep it interesting and handily located in the city, it really is a must see to help get a feel for the Vietnamese people, especially if you are sticking predominantly to the tourist trail.
Worth visiting. Fascinating insights into women and their role in Vietnam's history. Found the images and stories about women during the war particularly interesting.

very special. It was really interesting. The best way to start exploring Hanoi is perhaps, this museum. Well laid out, and I could make out how women play its part in this country, and particularly in Hanoi. It’s commendable to know such museum exists in Hanoi. It tells you how women are admired here in this society. I wish every country has a special museum for women.

The women's Museum in Hanoi. and the 900 heroines - the exhibition of heroines of vietnam, 900 mothers who had all lost their children to the American war was truly the most moving experience. Rated a must see.

Fabulous, don't miss it. Beautifully curated and presented exhibitions, don't miss it! Fantastic review of the role of women in Vietnamese history and their fight for independence from outside invasions to the present day

Very good exhibits. Exhibits included videos. Very informative and well presented. Good temporary exhibits as well. We saw one about the women vendors throughout Hanoi who carry the baskets on their shoulders.
First impression. Before we started our roundtrip in the North, it gave a good impression of what you could see by ethnic minorities and explained more details

Interesting visit!. This museum is worth a visit! It is not very far from the Old Quarter. We walked around the whole museum (about 4 levels) without a guide and it was alright and we could understand everything. This is done via the well designed and detailed English signboards around the museum. Every part of the exhibits have a English signboard. You can get an insight on Vietnamese women and society. There is a level for marriage and birth, a level for history and a level for fashion. Every level gives an interesting viewpoint of how Vietnamese women (be it in the urban city or the hill tribes) contributes to the history and society in Vietnam!We spend about 1hr+ walking around the museum. Got to learn some things too :)We almost didn't want to visit this museum but never regretted doing so :)Entrance fee: 30000 VND
Interesting. It was very interesting to see how they value women. They show the different phases where women were involved with war, hard work and fashion

Really interesting. If you want to get an insight on Vietnamese women and society, do spare a couple of hours of your time and visit this museum! It's quite a large one with many sections that illustrate the various aspects of women's lives. Vietnam is a patriarchal society, yet you won't exit the museum feeling frustrated at all. This museum honors the importance of women in Vietnam's society and I truly was amazed by everything I saw in there. Very enlightening!

Girl Power. This museum was a great way to understand the contribution of Vietnamese women to their society. It was a really interesting insight into their lives - not just their heroic acts during war but also the role of marriage and childbirth in their lives. Would definitely recommend spending a couple of hours here.
Interesting for the buff. Like a lot of museums that chronicle the struggle of this and that, you need a little forbearance to get through it. Nonetheless it is an ok way to spend an hour or so.
Herstory Museum. Amazing collection of textiles and women's weavings. Enlightening history of women's roles in various communities - from urban to hill tribe.
Very interesting worthwhile museum trip. Gives you a feel for the indigenous populations' culture, customs, dress and history. Museum is four floors with interesting and well described displays.

New Insights. We learned so much about about variety of cultures in Vietnam.
Floors were divided into separate areas of interest and were easy to follow with many exhibits that I had no knowledge of previously.
Overlooked Museum. Do not miss this one! Three floors on the history, costumes and role of women in Vietnam. Great gift shop too.

Well worth visiting. Really enjoyed this museum. Its fairly new and modern with great displays. As you travel around the country of Vietnam you find yourself with a great respect of the Vietnamese women and all the work they do. They are so strong and determined. This museum shows off the appreciation of their women. I especially enjoyed the sections on marriage, birth and pregnancy.
Worth a visit. Great to see women honoured for their heroic contributions to their country! Worth a visit only a couple hours out of your day.
Good to see.. This was good to see but I wouldnt go back again. I really enjoyed the women in war and ceremonies floor, but the fashion section I didn't make it to.
Very Interesting. We enjoyed this museum. It was very interesting. Over 40% of the guerilla warfare during the Vietnam/American war were women.
Interesting insight into Vietnamese women.. Well worth a visit. Insightful look into the women of Vietnam. I found the war section particularly interesting and touching.

Interesting history of women in Vietnam. Its a very new building with lots of displays and interesting videos. I think if you were pressed for time you could give it a miss, as for us the most interesting display was about the revolutionaries - the amazingly strong women, many of whom were executed for their beliefs - but this is covered briefly in the prison which isnt a far walk from this museum.

Absolutely wonderful.. I had no idea what to expect. I was truly humbled by the role of the Vietnamese woman throughout history, and into today. First floor was marriage, food, and childbirth. Second floor was dedicated to women and war- incredible. Third was fashion. I only had an hour here. I could have spent at least double that. I did buy some scarves and stuff from the shop. I was lucky to meet the director and she sad proceeds go straight to the women who make the crafts. I asked her why the prices were so low in comparison to most museum shops. She told me that the women would rather sell more and get the money than hold out for a higher priced item. I was happy to hear that the women in villages around Hanoi are truly benefiting. So if you visit there, buy! It will definitely go to the greater good in need.
Great acknowledgement to Vietnamese women. Interesting if you have the time and not too far from the Hanoi Hilton ( prison) the women really carry this country, and I am a man.

A very informative museum.. This museum is great if you like to know more about Vietnam, in term of culture, living, and history. You can spend hours in it, depends on how much interest you like to know about this country. It is air-con and it is not crowd. So you can take your time to slowly go through every single details.
Worth a visit. We loved it and found it extremely informative. Gives a great insight in the cultural side of the Women of Vietnam. A great afternoon spent here.
If you only visit one museum go here.. Fascinating insight into the bravery of women in the American war, and Vietnamese traditions. Very well laid out .
small museum. building has been renovated, gives you an idea of the place of women in current society. War heroines, daily life of tribal women. Would not go out of my way to see this.

Look at this, nightmare on elmstreet.... have a look at this, cause u need to know how the women were treated back then. And it is not something that takes all day, we did it in 1,5 hour. and it is worth visiting.

A good overview. of the role Vietnamese women play within the community.I particularly enjoyed the section dedicated to the women and the roles they played during the war.Their contribution to the army effort was simply amazing.I also left there with a better appreciation of the "street vendors".Those who ply the streets with their baskets of fruit/vegetables/goods of various descriptions, trying to make a living.Most of these ladies are from country areas working the city for money mainly to educate their children and for day to day living expenses.Overall I thought it was very good but a bit too much of the one thing!I think there are five levels of exhibits in this building.There is a lift.
Fantastic displays and info about the real women of Vietnam. Well worth the 30,000 Dong, Very informative and shows the true importance of the Vietnamese woman throughout the centuries.
