An eye opener. I had no idea how much women played a role in the war effort.It was fantastic. They also have an excellent section of how marriage takes place. Men go to live with the girls parents.
Worth a visit.. Good to do to get a bit of culture while in Hanoi. It reminded me of the struggles that Vietnamese women face in caring for themselves and their loved ones.

Somewhat Interesting. It was quite interesting to see how women in Vietnam were portrayed, quite hard it seems for them to get by.This theme is repeated regularly throughout the Museum.The display of costumes, displaying the changes over several decades is charming.Overall forthe equivalent of $1.50 it is reasonable value.

Visit this before you go to Hanoi Hilton. Very informative about the ethnic tribes and their traditional way of life in Vietnam, women's role in the various conflicts with excellent on screen documentaries, well labelled exhibits classed by stages in a women's life and in all a well designed , very reasonable charge for entry and blessedly cool in all sectors.

Its all about the girls. After a good lunch I walked to the Women’s Museum, this has been rated as one of the top tourist attractions of the city and for a mere 30,000 dong provides excellent value for an afternoon of interest. The Museum focuses on the contribution of women in Vietnam’s Culture. It covers the traditional role of women as wives and mothers and showcases the many differences this role embraces, depending on the ethnic background of the woman within Vietnam. There are feature films of female street vendors who talk stoically about the long hours they work. There is also a level devoted to the heroic women who fought side by side with men in the Vietnam/America War, photographs and personal anecdotes, of their frequently short lives, bringing the women to life.
Very Educational. An opportunity to learn about the different ethnic groups in Vietnam how hard a life so many Vietnamese women have had.

Waste of time. Unless you want to see native dresses and women in rice fields, don't waste your time. I don't know what the other reviewers saw, but I didn't see it. The only worthwhile area was the second floor, and most of that is a duplicate to the section on women at the hanoi prison. Really a disappointment, boring.
Vietnamese Girl Power. new modern museum with lots of interesting exhibitions from womens role in the family in various tribes to their pivotal role in vietnamese wars

Great slice of history.. Excellent museum that offers up a well-organized walk through the history of Vietnamese women. Has three floors with different themes. Each floor is packed full of photographs, artifacts, videos and descriptions. Well worth the visit. In fact if there was one museum to visit in Hanoi, I would suggest this one!

Everything is better with Hanoi Kids. I spent several hours with a English-speaking University student who volunteered time to make a visitor welcome. The "Hanoikid" was very admirable and helped me find a camera I lost in downtown Hanoi, with no name or address on it! Go to Hanoikids.com to request a volunteer to show you their city!

Don't miss this!!. This is a fascinating museum, done to the very best Western museum standards. Beautifully presented, with ALL captions in Vietnamese, English and French. You will get an excellent appreciation of Vietnamese cultures, from birth through weddings, and spiritual beliefs. All the various national cultures are represented, and they are quite varied. It was really fascinating, and so well presented, including excellent videos. The top floor is devoted to female heroes of the French and American wars, and was less accessible to,Westerners, and overtly propagandistic, a feeling totally missing in the rest of the museum.
Good place to learn about Vietnam culture. Good place to learn about Vietnam culture, different floors focus on different areas of vietnamese life and culture.
interesting. a nice little musuem with lots of insights into vietnamese culture from females of 'vietnam - the heroes in my opinion!

Worth a visit. We spent nearly 2hours visiting the museum. The photography and the vidoes are very moving and give a good insight into the lives of many women in Vietnam today. There is a good selection of books and gifts at the gift shop and all the staff are friendly and helpful. The displays and amenities are outstanding.

well worth a visit. Gave a real sense of how difficult life is for so many hard-working women in modern day Vietnam. The video interviews with ladies that rise at 2 a.m. to go the markets and finish their working day at 5 p.m. while living away from thier families was eye-opening and saddening.
Good starting point to understand women's role in Vietnam. This museum provides a good review on recent history through the changing role of Vietnamese women and day-to-day life of minority groups.
Worth seeing. This is worth seeing it is simple but read around the room and you get a better idea of how things were

women's involvement in the war with America is most interesting. I found the more contemporary information about women's role in society today and during the war the most interesting. Other parts of the museum I found slight 'dry' and 'worthy'

Worth a visit. Interesting museum in that it is devoted to the women of Vietnam & their contribution to the country. Introduces visitors to the various tribes & groups of people within the country. Provides an insight to the role of women in ordinary life as well as in their country's revolution. Something different.

Felt so proud. Wow, what a moving experience... I thoroughly enjoyed learning about the huge role Vietnamese women have played in the defence forces. I left feeling very proud to be a woman and had new respect for the people of Vietnam.
Enjoyed the museum. great exhibits, very interesting. 5 floors with different topics (fashion, marriage, women in history etc) videos to watch. a well done museum, worth a visit
Women's Museum. Very interesting to learn about the lifestyle and history of Vietnamese women. You also get a different perspective on the American War.

90 minutes at the Women's Museum. Enjoyed this Museum and wished I had more time to spend wandering around. It was amazing so see how strong the Vietnamese women were/are. As we only had 90 minutes, I would recommend that you spend at least 2 hours wandering around.
Interesting displays but English translations atrocious.. Interesting exhibition of paintings by Vietnamese artist who travelled the country on a scooter and did portraits of women war heroes.
Worth a visit. Very quiet when we visited but even my teenage daughters were fascinated particularly by the numerous personal stories and video diaries

Informative and engaging. We visited the women's museum in Hanoi it was very interesting. The exhibits gave an insight into the lives of women in Vietnam. From street venders, tribal women, mothers and soldiers this museum made me think a lot some of the women we had met in here and what their lives must be like. There were some interactive exhibitions were fun and believe that more of this kind of exhibit would improve the experience. Also I was keen to hear about Vietnamese women's journey towards gender equality and political rights (a subject I know little about)I think some people were unhappy that the museum focused on the role of women in communist victory. Well I think that you should expect that considering this is a communist country and as most museums get public support from the party it is a case of "whomever pays the piper calls the tune" remember that history is written by the victors and this is no exception (probably museums in the US, UK or rest of the world are guilty of the same sort of bias)
A must see if visiting Hanoi.. One of the best museum's I have been too. Very well laid out, excellent information and great displays.

Great museum - plenty of general interest. We were a bit sceptical but what a great museum - best display of info about the Vietnam and French wars and although focussed on the female fighters and impact on village life it gave the best context to what the country has been through. Don't miss the poignant video of interviews with the women who sell fruit/flowers/food etc on the streets - it really puts your life in perspective.

Quite interesting. OK, so I'm not a museum sort of person so take my comments with a pinch of salt. I was recommended to go to this "quite amazing place" and after looking up the reviews saw that it did seem to be a must-do. The only merit in submitting a review is if you are honest (can you sense I'm reluctant?) but unless you have particular interest in the creditable work women did in the war, ethnic costumes, traditional handicrafts, old posters and artifacts owned by famous Vietnamese women, it seems a pleasant diversion for an hour or so. I have every admiration for these women, but the museum although good, just didn't rate the raves.

Excellent museum with very good facilities. Very interesting exhibits and nicely laid out. Good for an hour's visit. Lockers available and best of all a playroom for young children with things to occupy them - Lego kept our boys happy for an hour. Worthy visit and can see why it is highly rated on TA.

Great place!. Before travelling to Sapa and Halong, I had one day and one night in Hanoi. I had read on internet that Tripadvisor named Vietnam Women's Museum as the most attractive tourist destination in 2012. I was so confused , don't now interesting it is. So I came to visit it in the afternoon. I saw a beautiful construction and meaningful exhibition. And i knew why it became the most attractive destination in Hanoi.

Powerful women. Loved the museum although still in a state of being completed. Having visited sapa it brought all of our recently acquired knowledge together with greater understanding. Gave an all round view of the contribution that women have made in Vietnam. Spent a couple of hours here and it was pretty quiet.

Insight into the life of Vietnamese women & culture. Give yourself time to soak in and enjoy this interactive insight into the world of Vietnamese women, their courage and resilience in war, their diversity across many ethnic groups, the day to day life and insight into religion and vibrant culture.

Highlights the significant contribution women have made in Vietnam History. We spent a couple of hours absorbing the struggles and victories of women in Vietnamese history. There was a great deal of information presented in an engaging and moving manner. This was a highlight of our visit to Hanoi
Must see. The succinct and respectful way that the way in which women have contributed to Vietnamese history, economics, culture, present and future development was portrayed
Deeper understanding. This visit help me to broaden my minds about so many intresting figuires about women in vietnam in general. I love them more!
Very Interesting!. An amazing insight to the strength of the women of Vietnam; great exhibits and very informative. Well worth a visit.

Definitely worth a visit. We found the exhibits easy to navigate and found them to be highly informative, giving us a real insight into all aspects of women's lives in Vietnam, both now and in the past. Recommended

Informative and interesting. I would recommend this museum to any visitor to Hanoi. It offered insight into so many areas of women's lives and their contributions to history in Vietnam. Definitely worth a visit.
Women's museum. This museum gave us a great insight into the lives of women and especially the street food sellers in Hanoi
A Must Visit. The museums title would put most western tourists off, but this is a great museum full of interest and beautifully laid out. Do go.

Sobering girl Power. Well set up. Everything you want to know about women in Vietnam is here. The fashion section was awesome. Make sure you take the time to watch the video about the street sellers. It will give you a great understanding about what these women go through to support their families.
A Woman's Perspective. This is a fantastic museum and gives an amazing insight into the role of Vietnamese women across all aspects of life.

Worth a visit!. This is a nice, air-conditioned museum about women in Vietnam.
Visitors can learn a lot about local customs and family life here.
It has plenty of English and French explanations.
Interesting place. We spent a morning in the museum and were pleasently surprised with the extent of the exhibits and how well they were presented. It's very interesting place. I like it

...I was expecting more.... It is quite interesting, but it would be sooo much better if it was an outdoor exhibition and/or if the whole place would be in a more traditional facility. It seems somehow too modern for the history it tells, but it certainly tells an interesting history.

An enjoyable must for great background information.. This is a really good museum. In addition to all of the wonderful information and displays about Vietnamese culture from the feminine perspective (birth, marriage, fashion, costumes, rituals, work life and war) for the next several months there is an exhibition of 301 portraits of Heroic Mothers of Vietnam. This is a title bestowed upon women whose husbands or children have died in Vietnam's struggles for freedom. Artist Dang Ai Viet travelled all over Vietnam (35000Km) on her Chally Scooter from Feb 2010 until June 2012 to meet and paint the women. Her scooter is there. Also her notebooks and maps etc.At first it is overwhelming to see walls and walls of unique watercolours. The capturing of the faces, demeanour, and grace of each mother is different. There is a small explanation in English and French beneath each portrait. It might say that Madame was born in 1919 and her 4 sons died for the country or more usually that sons or daughters died in 1952, 1979, 1968 and so on. The artwork is excellent. It is a marvel that one woman could do all this work so well, travelling in all sorts of conditions, often on dodgy roads, getting accommodation where she could, and with small funds. In addition to the practical difficulties of getting to nearly every province, Dang Ai Viet had to manage her emotions when she found many times that she had arrived at a remote village too late. The Mother had died. There are poignant mementoes, mostly parting gifts from sons - one, a tin cup not ever used by the mother, lest it should become damaged or broken! It is very moving to emerse oneself in the space.The exhibition is just near the ticket office ($2 each) and I was glad we saw this first because we could skip parts of the main building even though it was so engaging. Another reviewer nailed it when she said you will never look the same way again, at those women walking around carrying fruits etc. hoping for a sale. They are usually living away from the their family on a farm that requires another income. She works all week, pays rent to sleep in a room with 9 others and travels back to see her husband and children when she can. The section about women and work is really well done.In the section about beliefs we saw a video about the Mother Goddess ceremony and were actually lucky enough to see (and participate) in such a ceremony in Bac Ha several days later. So it's always worth popping in to the local temple! This museum is a must for background information.
Very interesting, dedicate a few hours. Very interesting, modern museum. Gives a great point of view of women in Vietnam. Highly recommended.
Excellent !. We've loved the women museum because it tells a lot about Vietnamese culture, place of women in the society, but also about about history and all they've done during the war.

Well worth a visit. It is well worth making a visit. I'm not normally a museum buff but I found this museum extremely informative and educational, obtained a better understanding of traditions as well as more background on the street sellers.

Good introduction to women's role in Vietnam. The museum covers three main areas - women in family, women in history and women's fashion. The descriptions on the display panels were very informative but the exhibits are quite simple. For me, the most interesting section was the one that covered women's role in the war. It showed how many of them took on high positions in the resistance at a young age as well as their tenacity and sacrifices. The other exhibits showed the lives of women in Vietnam, including the hill tribes, such as marriage and motherhood.

Worth a visit. We found this interesting museum as we were walking the streets of Hanoi; it was not part of our guided tours.It was well worth the visit, there are some amazing and courageous women throughout Vietnamese history that we would know nothing about had we not visited. The region costumes are worth the amazingly cheap entry fee alone.

Appreciate the hard work. You will look at the women who come to Hanoi to sell there wares very differently. They work very hard for their money and send it back for their children. A very humble place and worth a visit for perspective.

Very peaceful and quiet. I am amazed by the way the museum arranged its layout.
There are many photos and documentaries about the hard life of women and women's right and gender equality in Vietnam.
Quite interesting and good place to relieve the hot weather in Ha Noi.
Just about 2 usd for the ticket, totally worth it
Interesting. The museum was interesting and showed cultural dress from different areas. It also showed women in war and mothers who lost loved ones in war.

Worth a visit if you have time.... This would not be one of the top things to do in Hanoi but if you have a couple of hours, 30000 dong and it's really hot or raining then pop in here. I thought the information about the women's involvement in the war was the most interesting.

Interesting and fresh. Museum layout is great, with each section containing an engaging blend of artifacts and photos to accompany text. The video section on women street vendors was particularly poignant, and their stories have stayed with me back in the U.S.

Peeping inside that!. I want to let you know about Vietnam Women's museum. We spent an afternoon in the museum and were pleasently surprised with the extent of the exhibits and how well they were presented. Strange review we wanted to go here more. but, that afternoon, it was shut for work being done. I think it's a must do in Hanoi.
Museum. Very easy to walk around good signage and very interesting lots of information and the costumes are fabulous, the government has obviously researched this museum very well.
women's museum. This gave a really good insight to the struggle of women & their achievements in a country so often at war

Interesting. It was very interesting but very moving.Those women were amazing and brave. The photos and artifcats were well presented
Take a hankie

Well worth a visit. This is a great museum, well presented, fabulous stories and displays. We have so much respect for women in Vietnam, tough yet gentle souls. Critical to the culture of Vietnam. Go and see it you won't be disappointed. It's air conditioned as well which is a bonus!
Interesting. My wife and I visited this museum during our visit to Hanoi, nicely presented and it serves as a good tribute to all women who work tirelessly around the world.

Amazing - be sure to visit. This museum shows, in great depth and colour and detail, the many diverse aspects of one truly amazing story: the story of the strength, diversity, beauty, resilience, and good will of Vietnamese women through the ages.

Great museum to visit. Enjoyed all the exhibits, especially the local costumes and the video about the street traders, amazing women.
Good shop to buy postcards etc

Very Informative. This museum was very informative and unique in perspective--I'm not sure I've ever seen anything like it. I especially found the exhibit/video on the Vietnamese women hawkers to be fascinating and tragic. The exhibit on life cycle rites was also very interesting. Really worth a visit to understand something about the contributions of women to Vietnamese history, and the conditions faced by women in Vietnam at various times.

Well worth the visit. The Women's Museum has continued to evolve since I first visited in 2006. The variety of display material, the clarity of description for each, make it a very worthwhile place to visit. The section on women's contribution to the war efforts also puts the Vietnamese war posters that are now all the rage in tourist shops in perspective.
Nice history. I've been there first time. Very sad to see the Vietnamese women's life in the war. They worked very hard like the men. Anyway, my knowledge is wide now.

OK to kill some time. Too new for people born in the 70s and before, many objects are from the 21st century and are more from the tribal traditions of vietnam. I'd have loved to see more about how the women in the cities evolved to what they are today.
like it. very interesting worth the visit learned alot about the women in Vietnam and the militaryalso about the life of woman in this country
Well done. The museum was really nice, a lot of interesting exhibits about the various cultural groups, and the staff was really friendly

Insight into Life in vietnam. well laid out museum with excellent exhbits, descriptions and video footage with street women. Women who fought in the American war, childbirth, life in the tunnels. Really worth a visit. Plus there is another art exhibition just before you go into the museum of drawings done by a women who travelled all over Vietnam on her motorbike sketching 100s of women who sacrificed their sons and husbands to the war.

Best thing in Hanoi. We did it today and compared with so many other things it is cheaper, really interesting and meaningful. Many floors, pictures and subtitled videos and signs or explanations (French and English). Easy to get there, air conditioning (not really strong may be because was windy and about to rain).

Learnt heaps about women. Women can do anything, the museum was so interesting about the history of Vietnamese women. This is a must to see & take in. Only need 1 hour of your time. Very worth the time.

Worth a visit while in the French quarter. A varied display of items, clothing, and memorabilia, many of ethnic minorities. Maybe a few too many TV shorts to look at, and many only have French subtitles (and hang occasionally). Some of the individual women's stories and achievements are worth making a film of. Impressive!

Interesting museum. This museum is easy to navigate and is set out in different themes. I learnt a lot about Vietnamese culture and traditions. It covers topics such as the role of women in the wars, family life and clothing. The information is written in both English and Vietnamese.

Very informative museum about women's role in Vietnam. This modern museum covers many aspects of women in Vietnam. There are exhibits about clothing, tools, traditions, marriage. There is much about women of different tribes showing pictures and clothing. The museum has many videos and displays. Most impressive is the second floor which has information about women in the army and war--their leadership roles, roles as spies, politics--very informative. Check to make sure when this museum is open--it was somewhat confusing in different literature--we went one day to find it closed so we returned the next day. Do not miss this excellent museum.

Worth a visit. Space and displays perfectly designed and organized with clear explanation in english as well. Very interesting exhibits whcih helps to understand not only the appreciation to women's contribution to Vietnamese society but also the culture. To visit before visiting other museums.
Vietnam women's museum. informative and well worth the visit. Learnt heaps about the role of women in Vietnamese society, including their role in the war with america
really good. I thought this was a very interesting, well laid out museum. I thoroughly enjoyed looking round and reading the articles in this museum.
well worth two hours. This museum is surprisingly well done. Lovely exhibits, especially the costumes of the minority tribes. I enjoyed the visit. It is worth you time
An Undescovered gem. this is a beautiful museum, with well designed displays. It has a wing on the Mother Goddess that is not to be missed.
Eclectic Mix. Very interesting exhibition with a variety of examples of how women have contributed to the growth of the country. For visitors - the labelling in English could be better

Asewome. Its nice and good looking. Everybody can understand the things and kids like it most...Good collection. I am impressed.
Thanks

A nice Museum with convenient access. This museum in a modern building in a very central location in French Quarter so you can go there easily if you stay around Hoan Kiem Lake. They not only display subjects about Vietnamese women but also Vietnam history there, you can get a good knowledge for Vietnam your trip in Vietnam.
A must-see in Hanoi. Great displays, captions - in English too, beautifully arranged in this modern, insightful, interesting and thought-provoking museum.

Worth going to. I was dragged here by my girlfriend but must confess that I enjoyed walking around and reading all of the information. This museum had lots of interesting exhibits based around the role of women in Vietnamese society and the air conditioning was a welcome break from the stifling heat of Hanoi.There are four floors, each with a different theme and you can walk around each in a clockwise direction and browse to your hearts content. There are also video clips with French and English subtitles.

Really informative Ives a good overview of past and present role women play. Seems to confirm womens equality in vietnam and explains the great respect shown to us by men there. lot of info re women during the war and everything in English. Only 30,ooo dong entry for 2 of us and clean toilets

Very informative. I was looking for a break and happend to stumble by the Women's Museum, and thank god. It was very interesting and worth going. A great museum with amazing stories. Just the right size for a museum, not to big and not to small.

Loved it. I was really impressed with the special exhibition they had on a Vietnam woman's paintings of the "Hero women" who lost husbands and children through the Vietnam War. Very moving.Spent several hours there. Interesting insight into women's lives and communist perspective too.Recommend to allbought a few things for friends from the shop. Staff fine, not pushy which I enjoyed.

Well done. We loved this place so well put together It was a hot day and the ac works really good and there is plenty to look at even for men interesting to see how wemon fit in to this society well worth a visit
Very informative. Excellent display. You can easily spend a few hours here. The shop was also good although staff not very helpful.

An eye-opener. An interesting museum with some excellent photographs and videos to watch. There was a great deal of information about women and their role in society; history and within their different tribes.

Bravo Vietnamese women!. This museum is just few minutes by car from my hotel in Hanoi (the Hanoi Emotion Hotel). It was designed by Vietnamese female architect Tran Xuan Diem with two building set amidst an airy, green and beautiful ambiance. It houses more than 3.000 artifacts, including clothes, photos, personal belongings, tools and weapons. Beautiful architecture with grand hall, doomed ceiling and striking statue of Mother Vietnam, dedicated to heroic mothers during Vietnam war. A great hideaway from mid-day heat and a good chance to learn more about Vietnamese women. Also there is a fantastic street vendor cultural exhibition.

Really good modern museum. If you have an interest in women's issues, this museum is worth a look. Some of the stuff is quite routine and worth a quick look (wedding traditions etc) but there are also some more special things - the video interviews with women who leave their families in the country for weeks at a time to make money selling on the streets of hanoi was particularly touching.

Good Airconditioned Place But Not Much to See. The above subject tells you all about this museum. This is not a bad place to visit but do not expect too much from it as there is not much special that you cannot find in other places.

Quiet museum, mostly interesting. I found the exhibits detailing people's stories the most interesting. Some were in video form, such as the stories of the street sellers. the stories of the women who have fought in the two wars was extremely interesting. Some floors will be of little interest to most men such as the fashion section.

Real and powerful. That was a nice and modern museum. An interesting museum and it provides an excellent insight into the role of women in the recent history of Vietnam. Some of it was very nice. but other is not interesting, but all it was a nice experience. Worth for an hour or more to learn history in a very real and powerful way.

The best museum in Hanoi. This is a reasonably-sized museum in the French Quarter, a short walk from everywhere. It presents an unusually well-explained history of Vietnam and its minority groups. From time to time it has special exhibitions. A recent one was on the life of the women coming in from the rural areas, going to the Long Bien market in the early hours, then selling their goods by day and night in the streets of Hanoi, They are the same ones you can see sleeping on every street corner just after mid-day.It also explains the role of religion in Vietnam and the work done by the women in the recent resistance to the French, Japanese and Americans. We regularly revisit this museum just to better understand and to see what's new. It is undoubtedly the best of Hanoi's museums and has a nice handicrafts store attached. Don't miss it.

Outstanding museum. We really enjoyed learning about the women of Vietnam. I gained a lot of insight into the dress, customs, and general lifestyle of these women. A lot of the displays were about ethnic minority women and not the average Viet ethnicity, which I wasn't expecting. This museum should be near the top of your list of museums to visit in Hanoi.
The best Museum in Hanoi!!!. A beautiful museum, with excellent English translation of all text.Very interesting (also for men) to learn about the family life of the Vietnamese.Magnificent fotos!

Informative but more of a time killer than a must-see. We came across this museum while wandering around Hanoi one morning. It was quiet and staff ran around turning on lights every time we approached an exhibit. Some of the exhibits were interesting and it gave a reasonable sense of the role women play in each of the ethnic groups in Vietnam. That said it was a little monotonous at times and in places felt a little too much like a mouthpiece for Socialist state propaganda.

Beautifull exhibition, lots of info, nice ac.. Situated in a nice building. On a warm day highly recommendable cause the good ac. Lots of interesting information. I think it is the best musuem of Vietnam (at least of Hanoi).

Very interesting.. It was a very hot day in Hanoi, and it was at first very nice just to get away from the heat in the air-con house. But as we walked around at the museum we found a lot of interesting information about women life during the Vietnamese history. Some of it was very nice, and some not that interesting, but all in all it was a nice experience.

Intriguing Yet Sometimes Vague. I found the museum intriguing and at first enjoyed looking at the exhibits and learning about the role of women. However, on reaching the women in war section I quickly became desensitised as the exhibit didn't really give any information about women on the other side or the ones that worked outside the Viet Cong or women's general role in society. All there was was a series of pictures of Viet Cong female members, their rank, how many they killed and how they died etc. It seemed to be a top 20 female army commanders exhibit rather than one examining the role of women in the war. The other floors showed exhibits about family life, wedding rituals (which coming from a different culture I found interesting) and the role of women in religion (which although I read every bit of info I still felt a little lost on) as well as a bit about traditional crafts, farming and agricultural roles of women in villages.I found some of the details throughout the museum to vary from vague to non-existent bodering on propoganda so visit the musem with an open mind. The best bit about the museum was a short documentary about the role of women as street vendors, and I felt I learned more about their plight and everyday life in society than anything else in the museum.

Uneasy. At first, I was fascinated by the exhibits and the stories they told about some of Vietnams incredible women. There was an honesty and rawness on show which, being honest, is not too easy to find in Vietnamese museums. But, sadly, when I got to the war section, the governments handprints were all over it and I left feeling lied to. Again. There are two sides to every conflict, and it jarred with me that the only heroic women in the Vietnam war happened to be on the Viet Cong side. There wasn't a single exhibit about any of the women who found themselves on the other side of the conflict. It's like they didn't exist. There weren't any exhibits detailing the pain and suffering endured by Vietnamese women during the war- just medals of Heroic Mothers, propaganda photos of 5 foot nothing Vietnamese women pointing a gun at 6 foot plus US soldiers etc. It was a brutal war. But step into any museum in this country and you'd swear it was a glorious victory parade where anyone who died actually wanted to die. Crass.

Informative. I learned a lot about women in Vietnamese culture, and their role during the war. I found the first few floors very interesting but did start to dwindle toward the top couple of floors, but at $1.50 entry fee, i would highly recommend it.
to gain a better insight. Worth an hour or more to learn history in a very real and powerful way. These women were amazing and have endured so much some of the stories sad, many inspiring.

One of the best Museum's in Vietnam.. Well organised, interesting and modern. Was still undergoing renovations in 2011, but it didn't effect the experience. As with many museums in Vietnam, in can be a little hazy about details. Especially liked the brief documentary about female street-vendors.
It was nice. It had a lot of infomation and there were a lot of interesting things to see. It was so hot the day that were were there is it was nice to be in the air con.

Very interesting. Modern museum with excellent displays with English information. The costumes were wonderful and and the information was very interesting. So welled laid out. I bought a silk scarf which I think is very good quality for £7 from the museum shop
Great museum. Closed on Mondays but return trip was worth it - modern well-presented, lots of photo galleries and video to help explain. Worth a visit!
average museum. Interesting part about women in the resistance during the war, but not detailed enough. The museum had some films about street women and their struggles which were great.

The Hand That Rocks the Cradle. The Women's Museum was easy to get to and not too crowded. The displays were interesting to me as an outsider who wanted to learn more about the subcultures of the counrty. I especially enjoyed the religious ceremonies with the women taking an active role as intermediaries representing the various deities. As a tourist, I saw many women taking on strong roles in the economic progress of the country and the livelihood of their families and the museum helped me to understand their strength and challenges at a deeper level.Some tourists complained about the propanada in the women in war section, but I didn't find this offensive, even as an American. Women always sacrifice their children and husbands and often their own lives during war. The fact that Vietnam fought a long and painful war of independence against France before the civil war and U.S. involvement underscores the pain and sacrifices of several generations of women.
Kids loved it. We went with our three young kids and they realy enjoyed the visit. I especialy loved their great posters!

Worth a look. Four of us went to have a look around the museum after reading the reviews. It was worth it. A big spacious, cool museum. Not very busy. Wander around at your own pace, reading and looking at what catches your eye. Very informative information regarding many issues of Vietnamese women.
Deeper understanding of vietnam. Well presented worth your time These women have done amazing things and bravery for family and country life still is tough for many good insight.

Great Museum!. I am not usually a fan of museums but I thoroughly enjoyed this one. It tells you not just about women's history but it has video's of woman who have come into Hanoi as street sellers. I learned a lot about modern life in Vietnam and the museum was very easy to navigate. It was also air conditioned which was a huge plus on a hot day. At only about $1.5 this was a great deal.

Slightly air conditioned and some interesting parts. The war section was the most interesting to me. Very cool propaganda posters.The first floor is the coolest. Higher floors are cooled more through fans than by AC.Worth a 45 minute visit if you are nearby, but I wouldn't cross the city for it.
worth the visit.. Excellent! Nice to get out of the heat and lots of information very easy to read and follow.

Kudos to Vietnam. I really loved this museum. Our tour of the museum began with having ice cream at the museum restaurant. The vanilla ice-cream dipped in Vietnamese coffee was a real treat. The museum was a great tribute to the contributions of women throughout Vietnamese History. It showcased the strength and determination of women in helping their families and their country. I was glad there was a space to recognize women’s contributions. I was moved by listening to the stories of the street vendors who often leave their hometowns into the cities only to make a few cents a day after ten hours of hard work. A new perspective on hard work.
Great museum.. Modern museum. Not propaganda. Had a great time.Go there!

most excellent museum i've ever been to.. i was at first not excited, due to the specific 'women' nature, but it is absolutely fascinating and covers huge aspects of vietnam history and culture. i was luckily enough to speak briefly to the curator. the set-up of the museum if so modern and sophisticated, it's a work of art.
Allow plenty of time here. We thought it would be political / historical but it had a superb collection of tribal textiles from all over Vietnam.

An essential visit in Hanoi.. This astonishing museum is an essential trip when you in Vietnam. On three floors it shows Vietnamese life through the women's eyes - birth, motherhood and war hero.
We'll be returning later in our stay.
Such an interesting place. Each floor provides an interesting view of the lives of extraordinary and ordinary women living in Vietnam over the past turbulent centuary
Very interesting even for a male. An amazing insight into the life of the Vietnamese women. My husband did not get bored but found it as fascinating as I did.
an honest museum. A lot of museums in Vietnam are in the propaganda business. Not this one: it gives a very honest account of the life of ordinary women, not hesitating even to criticise the police.

Powerful insight into the role of women in Vietnam. Really enjoyed the displays. The video about female street vendors in Hanoi really tugged at a few heart strings, and made me realise that when we get ripped off as tourists the money is often going to someone who needs it a whole lot more than we do. I feel a little more at ease - but I'll still bargain as best I can! Quiet museum, interesting facts. Definitely worth a visit. The wall of photos showing mothers who lost multiple sons in the war was another powerful exhibit, one that will stay in my mind for a long time.

Excellent museum in good location. Loved this museum. I was travelling with 2 boys and a husband who were not keen on visiting a women's museum but once we got inside they all loved it. Engaging, colourful attractions, lots to learn and a lovely air-conditioned building. Only 30,000VND per adult and free for children. Well worth a visit.
modern museum by Vietnam Standards. Very quiet. Interesting artefacts and histories detailed. Worth A visit if you are interested in social history.
Museum interesting. Very interesting and worth a visit. May not agree with politics but it is the perspective of women in north vietnam
Nice to see and learn about the history of women in the country!. It passes an hour orthat and is only 30,000 D (Just over a Euro)
Great museum. I thought this was a very interesting museum and worth a visit.

Amazing museum. I was very impressed with the stories in this museum. The colorful clothes and some head pieces reminded me so much of Peru, I could not believe it!
It was amazing to learn a bit about the Mother Godess too.

Lovely tribute to the hardworking women of Vietnam. Nice modern museum. Most things labeled in Vietnamese, French, and English. It was a lovely tribute to the hardworking women of Vietnam. The exhibit on women during the war was very "interesting"- definitely from a Northern Vietnamese perspective. Only costs 30k dong. Overall, highly recommended.
Good information on the breadth of Vietnam culture. Very informative, well laid out with some colourful displays.

A work in progress. I thought that this was a great idea for a museum and while the exhibits give a good insight into the lives of Vietnamese women, I did think that this museum was a work in progress. I found the exhibit relating to marriage ceremonies and the role of women post-marriage quite interesting. My boyfriend wasn't a fan of the museum at all (despite the fact that he is a museum junky)! He found it boring and uninformative. Just to note as well, there is no air con in this building and there were points where we were quite uncomfortable walking around the museum (which has several stairways).

powerful. Gives a valuable insight into the role of the women in Vietnamese culture and even pore in its history concerning the many wars they had to fight alongside their husbands and sons. Without them, Vietnam wouldn't be as charming as it is today!

Great for cultural awareness. Very easy to get to, and navigate around when inside. It is extremely interesting, the displays are well organised and informative. It could take you about an hour and a half to get through, depending on how much detail you are wanting to read, or maybe watch on the DVDs they have showing.I really enjoyed this museum, and the perspectives (particularly within the war) of Vietnamese women that it showed.

Women Rock! Yeah!!!. This is my first time to come to a museum dedicated to women and I am so glad we went here. War has always been associated with men and here you can actually see how much involved the women of VietNam is to the success of the Vietnamese people. Here you can also see how the modern women of Vietnam are, this is the only country I know were there are women taxi drivers. Equality rules.
An insight into the role of Vietnamese women. Well situated, good exhibits and aninsight into their contribution to the revolution

A must-see!. Very interesting despite the few information you have in tourist informations about it. 3 floors, one about wedding and birthing traditions, depending of the many minorities; one your really need to see, about the role of viet women during the wars and a final one about fashion from ancient minorities to modern ao dai.Good translation in english, some videos, pleasant place.30000 VND in June 2012

very interesting. I didnt have much time to explore but i really wish i did because this place was great! Probably the best museum I have been to in Vietnam (I have been to a lot), in regards to the presentation and layout. I dont think it is for everyone as my male friend was bored to tears but if you may be interested, then please dont hesitate to go here!
Very Interesting. Was impressed with the floor about the women participation in the viatnamise war.
fascinating history. i was so impressed how much respect is shown to the women of vietnam

A 'must see' museum. If you are at all interested in women's history, or even if you aren't, this museum is well worth a visit. It is a museum that I encourage all friends to Hanoi to see.As well as well- designed displays and information about the history of women in Vietnam, there are also social history displays such as marriage and birth amongst some of the 54 ethnic groups who live here, as well as clothing and adornments. The displays are arranged so that they are easy to understand and information is provided in Vietnamese, English and French.The museum also has exhibits. Last time I visited in May, there were exhibits about the life of workers in the night markets at Long Bien, the Mother Goddess and street vendors. All of these encourage a better understanding of life for women in Vietnam.One of the aspects of the museum that I really like is that it doesn't focus on well-known figures in Vietnamese history, although you will find some of these, but it is the views of everyday life and the extraordinary that comes from ordinary lives that makes this museum a great one for me.

Insightful and charming. Well curated, small but charming. Obviously foreign funded but at least cared for, compared to local standards. Nice displays on heroines and above them, their fanciful native dress.
Very nice museum. Lovely newer museum with air conditioning and information about women of Viet Nam--history, wedding customs, homage to the mother goddess, etc.
Presentation of artifacts. Very nicely organized and well maintained. Excellent tribute of contribution by women.

Go to Hoa Lo Prison & Skip this Museum. Hoa Lo Prison (in conjunction with the women's museum) has an excellent feature on the role of women in the war efforts. I loved that exhibit at Hoa Lo.However, the Women's Museum was a let-down in comparison. To me, you can skip this museum if you've already been to Hoa Lo. The other parts of the women's museum just show the traditional clothing, tell about farming, and customs. Unless you are a big museum buff, it's pretty boring.

Definitely worth a visit. An interesting museum and it provides an excellent insight into the role of women in the recent history of Vietnam. The traditional clothes display on the top floor was particularly good.

Worth going, but nothing amazing. I know that's a weird title, but that's sorta how I felt. I was glad to have seen the exhibits and learned a bit more. It was especially interesting to see the video about the women selling items on the street since I had been prone to find them annoying and pushy, but gained a whole new perspective after seeing that. Still, it was a bit of a slow moving and "draggy" museum and nothing so spectacular.

Wonderful museum-how great to have a museum dedicated to women. Exhibits interesting and provide deep insight into Vie. I really liked the several floors of exhibits, well curated, and highlighting Vietnam's experience in the.eras Proceedings during and following occupation and conflict. For those keen to understand more about Vietnam Museum provides a great and informative experience. Very different from any other museum in the world.

Worth it. Like all the other reviews the Women's Museum is a worthwhile experience. I particularly liked the video on the street hawkers, you see these amazing women everywhere in Vietnam & it was great to see a bit of a story behind why they have to do what they do. Such hard work for such little money, all in hope of trying to get their kids through school so that they wont be forced to do the same job.

If you only see one museum in Hanoi, come here. Well worth a visit - this very modern museum offered an eclectic and enticing array of artifacts, stories, clothing and media on the daily lives and cultural practices of Vietnamese women and perspectives on Viet Cong women in the Vietnam war. I particularly enjoyed the traditional costumes (some of which were just beautiful) and the floor on marriage practices in the different ethnic groups. The exhibits are well laid out and there's a gift shop and lockers on the ground floor and an elevator.

is this place a joke?. I was very excited to hear that they have a womens musem in Hanoi but what a let down. It is split into three sections. The first is all about women and their obvious love to get married and have babies, another section is what women like to wear and the middle section arguably the most imformative but still not very indepth was the role women playing during the American war.There was not one word about women authors, painters or political women or women in powerful roles. There was no discussion about the role the modern Veitnamese women are taking in shaping the new Vietnam or about how womens views have changed over the generations.This place was more than a waste of money, time & efffort it was saddening in its wasted opportunity.

Nice modern and interesting museum. This was the most modern-looking museum we've been to in Vietnam. The exhibits were displayed in a fashion where footprints on the floor directed you from start to finish to see the exhibits in the correct order, which was helpful. Interesting personal accounts of hard-working Vietnamese women which provided an insight into their lives. I thought the section about the celebrations/princesses/religion-type things a bit boring. Fashion section was okay but the best was the family-life section and their side-exhibit about domestic abuse, working life, and rehabilitation programmes. Cost only 20,000D which was worth it.

Highly recommend, well curated, inciteful displays. Really enjoyed this museum. It is the best curated Musuem we visited, and for English speakers, the easiest to negotiate. It is bigger than you think, and the different floors tell quite a different story. This included a really interesting perspective on the invovlement of Vietnamese women in the French and American war.

Too much information. So much info here, almost too much to get thru without top grade aircon. Especially liked the Women in history section but the video of the mothers of vietnam never seemed to get to an english translation, always french.Loved it tho'. Spent about 2 hours only 'cos my friend was unwell. Could've spent much longer

Great modern museum-could have more history. My wife and I went to Hanoi and this was the first choice of mine for places to visit. And I loved how the museum mixed the cultural practices of women from the variety of ethnic backgrounds in Vietnam with the history of women in Vietnam. It even had a section on fashion, and interviews with street vendors, which were great.If I had any complaint, it was that the museum was too focused on women from the recent past (Last 100 years or so). This is a problem a lot of Vietnamese museums have, I noticed, but knowing that there were a great number of Vietnamese influential women in history during earlier centuries made me a bit dissapointed that all they got was one paragraph on a wall of text, and aren't mentioned at all in the women of history exhibit.

An eye opener. I was touched by the presentation of women street sellers in Ha Noi. I truly feel for these women. Ehey earn almost nothing and working a lot that they dont see their familys as often as they should. One of Hanoi´s best museums.
Very informative. Great way to spend a couple of hours. Like all Vietnamese tourist attractions very cheap and definitely worth a visit
Top Spot. Best Museum I visited in Hanoi and one of the best ever. Well set out, well labeled, quiet and cool.

A new appreciation for street sellers & Vietnam women in general.. Visited here after 3 days in Hanoi & was taken aback by the presentation on street sellers. So many are from the country & have been displaced by the government or through lack of income at home. One in particular works from 2am til sometimes 7pm selling fruit. She earnt only enough to go home(in the country) once a month with $20 in her pocket for her young family. Her husband made $60 a year raising pigs. In hanoi she stays in a boarding house with 10 others paying .35c a day for the little sleep she gets. Very moving & gave me a new appreciation of hard work. Worth a visit.

Well-Maintained, A Great Dedication To Women Of Vietnam. Likes:1. Cheap admission for something worthwhile: 30000dong (1.5usd)2. I was one of the three people there. Felt like I had the whole place (4 levels' worth) to myself.3. All artifacts had explanations. I mention this because this wasn't the case in the Revolution Museum, which became a frustrating experience after a while. Sometimes they (Women's Museum) even have movie clips for various exhibits, which made the entire experience more relatable and interesting.Dislikes:1. Movie clips were sometimes in French and sometimes in English. Consistency was absent. Quality of clips were sometimes questionable (sound quality, clarity etc)Overall, a great experience not to be missed :)

Interesting. We visited here a few hours after arriving, we were extremely tired so I felt we did not do it justice and rushed it a bit, we wished we had gone another when we had a bit more time. I thought the information on the women fighters was really interesting.

An excellent museum. This museum has been recently renovated and is very modern, has a number of stories with steps and a lift available, and was airconditioned. I thought it had a high standard and excellent displays relating to Vietnamese women and their lives historically and now, which were of great interest to both my husband and myself. It is rather out of the way so likely best to catch a cab there. We went with our Hanoikid guide and she also really enjoyed it as had not been since prior to the renovation.

One of my favorite museums to date. Very informative and well-organized, one could get lost for hours in the 5-level museum. I immensely enjoyed the narratives of the women in the informal economy as well as the women in history (level 3). The videos were interesting, although some of them were not running when I visited. I wish we had something like this in the Philippines.The gallery about the Goddess worship could be improved to be more friendly to foreigners (For instance, I did not understand how the belief related to the performances of the mediums). I am also interested in the sexual and reproductive health of women, perhaps the section from birth to marriage and bearing children life could also be improved? I hope to visit this museum again.

You must see this.. This is possibly the most memorable and unique museum you will see. The museum has recently been renovated and features the lives of Vietnamese Women through history including the War, Family and Fashion.

Great place to learn about Vietnamese culture. Just a few blocks from Hoan Kiem Lake is this very interesting museum, cheap as chips to get in and very interesting. The first hall next to the ticket booth has about 30 stories about varying Vietnamese workers which give you a great overview of how hard the Vietnamese work. Inside the main building they go through various phases in Vietnamese life like, work, marriage etc all very interesting. My only tip, go early because there is a lot of reading to do

Women in War. Visited the museum with my 87 year old mother. I couldn't pull her out of the "Women in War" room. Just and amazing display. But then when I took her to see the ethnic costumes...it was the same thing all over again. She spent more than 2 hours looking at everything. Truly amazing. Highly recommended.
Neat museum - but no real action or centerpiece. Nice museum. However - nothing super special at all.
Lots of interesting stuff. Lots of very interesting material but unfortunately not presented as well as could be.

If you want something done.... Excellent modern museum in purpose-built building. Informative displays of traditional life, with photos, videos, artefacts in highly digestible form. Allow a couple of hours. Best to see this before you go to the countryside so you understand more about what you see there, but you may then wish for a return visit! Loved the videos in particular, e.g the 4 minute insight into the lives of street vendors. Will make a trip to the flower market at 2 am tomorrow to see more of this aspect of life. And blokes - this museum is for everyone.

Well worth a visit!. I visited the womens museum on my trip to Hanoi in May 2012 after Reading the good reviews - I was not disappointed. For 30,000 VND it is well worth a trip. I learnt a lot after walking around the museum and you really start to realise how important the women are in Vietnam. They are very strong women who not only work miles away from home to support their familes now, but played a huge role in the wars. Many have been awarded for their bravery, which I think is not known by many people. It was interesting to also learn about the Mother worship, everyday lives including marriage and childbirth, and also traditional clothing.

A tribute to Vietnamese women. It is very appropriate that there is a Women's museum in Hanoi. During my visit to Vietnam i learned that Vietnamese women are tough, resilient people, who work in the rice fields, manage their families, and added to that, fight in wars when the time is there. Vietnamese women are really the backbone of the country. In the Women's museum are three floors, each floor dedicated to a different topic, family life, costumes trough the ages and women during the wars. During the visit to the museum you get a good impression of the role and influence of women in the Vietnamese society. To be recommended.
Hanoi Hilton. Very interesting at the Hanoi Hilton. Amazing to see the battle from the womens perspective.

Innovative. I enjoyed the whole concept of dedicating a musuem to the role of women in Vietnam very exciting. I enjoyed the displays which were instructive and was surprised to see how much space was give to explaining ethnic minority cultures in the context of women in work, marriage and family. Well worth a visit.

Very thought provoking. There is an exhibition of women (and men) and how their lives are living on 100k VND a day - about £3 working in a market. It really focussed the mind. The rest of the exhibition was ok - interesting to learn more about the culture

This museum is really inspiring. Clean, modern air conditioned building with the display running over 4 floors (lift accessible). Wonderful stories are presented about the role of Vietnamese women from a cultural and historical standpoint - eg. marriage & child birth, work & family, religion & government, as well as some war time stories. I wandered around for nearly 2hrs and could have stayed longer. There's clean toilets and a gift shop downstairs. Can't remember how much entry tix were but it wasn't much.

An amazing insight to the people and their struggle. To see the personalized stories of the women who fought the French and later battled for their freedom against the U.S. was fascinating. It put everything into perspective about how the conditions affected real people and what they went through for self-determination. Very inspiring!

Just go. This is a really wonderful museum that gives huge insight into Vietnamese history and culture. The most compelling section of the museum is the part that tells the story of the roles played by women during the Vietnam war.

Highly recommended museum. I was really looking forward to going to this museum, and was not disappointed! The exhibits were fantastic, very informative and lots of great visual displays. I especially enjoyed the room with video interviews with street vendors, and the costumes exhibition. The marriage and family section was great preparation for my trip to Sapa, introducing me to various hilltribes.I wandered around happily for hours.

Gem of a museum. Wonderful variety of exhibits, from displays of wedding attire and rituals from various ethnic tribes to altars and costumes relating to Mother Goddesses to women's contributions to national liberation to a project on domestic violence at Long Bien market.

Small interesting museum. This is worth a visit, especially if you haven't time to go the the Museum of Ethnology further out of town. Exhibits are well displayed and explained in Vietnamese, English and French. It gives a good introduction to the various ethnic groups, of which there are 54 in Vietnam. The marriage section is interesting with a short film showing the celebrations. There is a good costume display on the fourth floor and a small section on street vendors, again with an interesting short film. The third floor is devoted to the part women played in the many wars Vietnam has fought. Cost 30,000 dong ($1.50) to learn a great deal and in air conditioned comfort. Do try it.

A Place to visit. This newly reopened museum is extremely interesting, for Westerners only, I am told by my local friends. Indeed, very few local people in the neighborhood know about it. It is a well appointed museum with bright, explicit setups, functionning video screens to illustrate the objects in context, and fascinating exhibits. Some may be temporary, like the one on "Street Vendors". Others on Motherhood, on birth, on weddings must be perenial. I strongly recommend it.
well worth a visit. Very informative, not only history but present day.Much better than Ho Chi Minh museum
see the museum. Good museum. Give you a good impression of the culture

Understand the life of Vietnamese Women. Vietnam Women's Museum help me to understand the hard life of the Vietnamese Women especially during the War. They scarify for family when their man died. I respected them very much.
Very informative, worth a look.. There was a small but great exhibition on the street sellers on while we were there. Loved it.

Interesting and Moving. This museum is very well done, with interesting and often very moving exhibitions about the life and place of women in Vietnamese society. The museum also has great air conditioning, so it's comfortable to visit (it was 43 degrees outside the day I was there).
Very informative about the lives of Vietnamese women. I learn't a lot about Vietnamese women's lives both historically and modern day

Nice that women are recognised but they deserve better. Pleasant staff and the museum is worth a visit if you're in the neighbourhood. Don't expect too much however - the exhibitions are rudimentary, and the museum is small.

Worth the Visit. This is an absolutely great museum to see. The exhibits document the tough, difficult, and important role Vietnamese women contribute to family & society. If you are visiting the "Hanoi Hilton" prison, you ought to walk down the street and also visit the Vietnam Women's Musuem.
Excellent Museum of Women's History. Well laid out museum, very informative, excellent displays; especially the floor with women's fashion, which is really the textiles of the various ethnic groups.
A museum worth visiting. Not many places have museums dedicated to the contribution of women in history therefore we need to raise the profile of this one!

Well worth a visit and in the centre of town. Until my wife visited and told me about it, I had lived in Hanoi for ten years and never knew about the Women's Museum. Under, I suppose, new management it has been upgraded and now boasts 3 floors of the history and pursuits (including fashion) of Vietnamese women throughout the ages. Of course, women have a special place in Vietnam. In the past some of the greatest patriots such as Ba Trieu and Hai Ba Trung (look at the road signs) were famous female generals and a whole floor is given over to Vietnamese women in war, especially the long haired army of the American War. The museum teaches you a lot about why Vietnamese women are special and is a good lesson to both women and men. For me, it helped explain why I fell in love with Vietnam and a Vietnamese woman - such romance in this country!

Don't miss this!. An amazing museum showing everyday life of the various cultural groups, both modern and earlier. Beautifully crafted and set out, with clear explanations. I particularly enjoyed the top floor with descriptions of how small amolunts of aid to women have enabled them to start businesses and feed their families. The costumes and video presentations are briilliant.

pretty unique. Less known, but handy location from Hoan Kiem lake side, i.e. easy access. The cafe had reasonably good food, too. Taste of anthropology side, and some touching videos of street vendors.

Really interesting museum. Floor dedicated to information on Vietnamese hill tribes and their costumes was very informative.Section about special religions in Vietnam was also intersting and we saw such a ceremony while we were in Hanoi.
A terrific museum -. Great info and very informative - especially the stuff about women in the various wars and the many tribal groups.The building is really hot though.
Vietnam Women's Museum. It really showed how the women of Vietnam have worked, and really were the backbone of all their successs.
Amazing women of Vietnam. This was amazing how hard the women worked before, during and after the wars. I was surprised how political Vietnamese women were and are

A disappointment after reading the rave reviews. I visited this museum after reading the great reviews on TA. It was only 30,000vnd to enter, but I'm afraid that I found it a little boring. Maybe this is because my partner and I are in our mid-twenties, but if you are short on time I'm give this one a miss.
Better than expected. I wasn't expecting to much but it was better than expected well layed out and planned and modern

Brilliant museum. It only gets a short write up in Lonely Planet but they recommend it as overseen but much better than some of the other museums/sites - and they are right. You'll find fewer tourists here than at the Hanoi Hilton but it's infinitely more worthwhile a trip (and also very near by so you can in fact do both sites). I took my 9 year old and she was gripped. Simple but brilliant mix of media to give a protrait of Vietnamese women from belief systems about childbirth to their role in the 'American War' and what modern day women are achieving in Vietnam's current burgeoning economy. It's modern, colourful, well thought out but feels authentically Vietnamese. A great insight into Vietnamese society: traditional and modern. If you go to Hanoi do not miss it.
Well organised. Well organised with each floor being devoted to one particular topic. It is also fairly well air conditioned.
Must see. Definitely don't miss, such a fascinating insight to women in the Vietnamese culture.
A worth while afternoon. This provides a good understanding of Women in Viet Nam
I found the war section very educational. I liked the war section as it was very educational, as I didn't realise so many woman took part in the war.
Well Worth It. Make sure you watch the video on the street vendors. What amazing women!

Best museum I have been to in ages. This was a really great museum with lots of interesting information about the role that women have played in Vietnam. The photography exhibition about women street vendors was particularly poignant.

A sobering visit but so worthwhile. Interesting and well laid out displays with English, French and Vietnamese captions and explanations.
Found people mentioned and their property displayed who i had read about in books. Almost moved to tears by the stories and courage of these courageous people.

A must for anyone travelling in Vietnam. Wonderful museum - very informative exhibitions with loads of really great information on the role of women in Vietnam not only today but throughout history. For those with an interest in textiles this museum is small in comparison to the Ethnology Museum - but every bit as good (maybe even slightly better as there are not the crowds of people).
womens museaum. Very interesting collection. makes you realise how amazing the Bietnamese women are
Worth a go. Very insightful journey of the women lives in Vietnam. It took me an hour or two... be prepared to spend some time.
Absolutely incredible. Just loved this museum. It was really outstanding really something not to miss. So professionally done
Worth a visit. Excellent displays and interesting history. The war time contribution of many Vietnamese women is nothing short of heroic.

Women's culture revealed. This museum visit was an unexpected delight & revealed a depth & breadth to Vietnamese culture that was both accessible & informative. The style of this renovated museum was particularly pleasing aesthetically, as well as providing clear information in Vietnamese, English & French. While the textiles on display were of particular interest to me, other exhibitions on Street Vendors, Against Violence to Migrants, & the Mother Goddess were also absorbing. Certainly there seems to be a deeply respectful, ethical, & culturally sensitive approach to the subjects & themes being shown. The exhibitions aimed to provide some insight into the past as well as the very contemporary present. While Vietnamese people are well served by this very attractive museum, it is a real gem for the traveller wishing to gain more knowledge & understanding of Vietnamese women who after all, make up half the population! It certainly helps to bridge the cultural divide between different nationalities, ethnicities, genders as well as social classes. It was very inclusive & creative in approach, showing a different face to more traditional museums in this city. Congratulations must go to the director of this museum.

An interesting take on Vietnamese history. A great museum with some very interesting and attractive exhibits. Some of the stories of women's contributions to Vietnamese history are powerful and very moving and it is great that they are honoured in this way. It is however very party oriented and I felt that what is missing is any real recognition of the many dynamic, professional women who are now making an enormous contribution to the country's development in many different sectors. Another small criticism is that some of the information about display is difficult to read because of poor presentation and lighting.

Informative. Really interesting on birth, marriage, child rearing, women's work, with a large section on the ethnic minorities. We happened to be there with a group of school children and because of the structure of the museum it was uncomfortably loud. Still, on our recommended list.

My wife and I thourally enjoyed it as it gives a perspective on the life of women here. We liked the honesty that the museum took in its asessment of womens lives in Vietnam. We bought the book about the Women in AgriculturePropaganda Posters which contains many excellent posters, and it has English explanations, which is great.

Hanoi experience. Hi,The womens museum was by and large similar to the ethnology museum but not as good showing the various costumes of the ethnic tribes and a lot of the rest was nationalistic propaganda which after a number of museums gets so repetitive, it's boring.I wouldn't rate it more than average.It mentions the various sacrifices mothers made by sending their sons off to war and being awarded medals for their losses but that is no different to any war really. Also, how the women stood by their country and took up jobs that men normally did. They could have been talking about British wives in World War II for that matter.Worth an hour if it's raining, I suppose. All attractions in Hanoi are not particularly large nor expensive with the cost being $1 to $1.50 an adult.It was on five floors and there was a lift for disabled visitors who can easily get around with the layout.

Amazing museum! Best in Hanoi. This was such a great museum- especially compared to others in Hanoi. Everything was really well explained, with some great pieces on display. The best bit for me was the floor of women in the army. The staff were lovely and the temporary exhibit was great too. Even the shop was amazing! Some really nice things and some prices lower than after 15 mins haggling in the market! Highly recommended!

Gotta do a museum or two.... I have to admit the name of the museum doesnt inspire too much confidence (and I'd feel the same about a "men's museum"!). It's a well done exhibit, telling you a bit about the history of the country from a womans point of view. Probably the best I can say is that it's a nice way to spend a peaceful hour as a change of pace from a busy bustling city. We stayed in the old town and it's an easy enough walk to an area you'll likely be walking through anyway.

Wonderful museum. Testimonial to the strength, effort and dedication of vietnamese womens' contribution to their country. Includes an exhibition of the ethnic minority groups in Vietnam, the Hmongs, their lifestyle, culture and art. Highly recommended if you are going to Sapa. Only then can you truly appreciate the people, place and culture.
Nice place , good for visit in Ha Noi. The museum is nice . After visit you can understand more about Vietnamese culture . And i hope every tourist when arrived , should visit .. Nice to visit

Best museum in Vietnam. Very professional, well organised museum without masses of propoganda and anti-american literature like other museums in Vietnam. Having visited Sapa I enjoyed learning more about the culture of the ethnic minorities and was found some of the stories regarding the war inspiring. Highly recommended, esp if you want to get off the crazy streets!

Vietnam Womens Musuem. We visited this Museum and spent quite some time here and would recommend a visit to here for tourists, It was so interesting and an insight to the life of Vietnamese women, please make time for this.
seemed okay but not special. It was informative but not particularly interesting.

Good introduction in the rituals of vietnamese people and the various tribes. Very well documented in 3 languages, english, french and vietnamese. It gives you a very good idea about the role of women in Vietnamese culture and history over the past and the present.

The best museum in Hanoi. If you would have to visit only one museum in Hanoi I would recommend the Women's Museum. It was recently renovated and provides a great learning opportunity of women's role in Vietnamese society and of the various Vietnamese ethnic minorities. There are often excellent exhibit on social issues of importance, such as human trafficking, street vendors, etc. This enriches a tourist experience with a better understanding of some of Vietnam current challenges.
Really interesting. Definitely recommend visiting the Women's Museum - particularly take the time to watch the videos about the women street vendors.

Really interesting exhibition. Display and video about the women street vendors of Hanoi, helped us to understand better the difficulties that these women face. Good exhibition of the role that women played in the war, and Vietnamese fashion (mostly minority groups).

Definitely worth spending a couple of hours. This museum although away from the other main tourist attractions is definitely worth a visit. It is a really well planned museum and offers a great insight into history, tradition and culture. It also has a fascinating record of the major part women played during the wars of independence. Another colourful display is around the worship of the mother goddess

Another Impressive museum of Hanoi. A collection of more than 3,000 eye-catching are spread over five floor on every thing which give you a best understanding about women and culture of Vietnam, from the story of contribution to national defense to daily life and fashion. I was really impressed with this museum and would recommend it to anyone interested in women's studies or the culture of Vietnam.

A favourite museum - wonderful changing exhibitions!. I usually visit this museum on my annual visit to Hanoi and while it's always good, the recent renovations have made it even better. Apart from the really interesting permanent exhibitions, there are often special exhibitions highlighting a particular aspect of Vietnamese life. The current exhibition on the life of migrant workers who come to Hanoi to work at one of the markets is excellent and well worth a visit.

Insightful, to an extent. Interesting museum, worth a visit particularly for the section in Vietnamese women's roles during the first and second Indochina wars. Beautiful costumes in the first exhibit, and the museum is also really attentive to women from the ethnic minority groups. Note though that traditional values about women and their roles in society are still present here.
refreshingly professional for southeast asia. really great insight in to the stories behind the stories we all know. i'm talking primarily of the third floor regarding the vietnam war era.
Vibrant & informative. Very informative, covers many aspects of the important roles of women throughout Vietnamese history and culture.
Well worth a visit. Excellent review of women's lives in Vietnam. We enjoyed the museum and recommend it for a visit

Take your daughter - and your son and husband!. Excellent and very different museum in the old quarter, focusing on the role of women in Vietnam through recent history (20th century on). The section on women during the war is inspirational and the temporary exhibition about a self help group in Hanoi for disadvantaged women brought my 10 year old daughter close to tears. Well worth a few hours and a good museum to combine in a day with the military museum not far away

Worth a visit. The role of women during the fight for independence was fascinating - a complete surprise that I'd find it so interesting. The information on the ethnic minorities is also worth looking at
exellent. nice setting is highlited the suffering of vietnam women during the dark time of vietnam and the effort in building this great nation

Beautifully presented. Fab museum - great new building. Fabulous collection of ethnic costumes and a whole floor dedicated to the 'long haired soldiers'- the women of Vietnam who helped to fight the French and the Americans ...all well presented in three languages.

Surprisingly nice and surpisingly inexpensive. As adults, my fiancee and I enjoyed reading and learning about women's roles throughout the history of Vietnam. However, as teachers, it's not a place we'd take a group of students unless we had our own creative lessons and were allowed to implement them. The museum is in a quiet location within Hanoi, contains a ton of information and is presented in a clean manner, but it's not all that interactive.

Well worth a visit. A fascinating insight into the women of Vietnam, in particular their contributions to the liberation struggles and politics of the country. The current Goddess Mother exhibition gives an understanding of the importance of this spirituality to Vietnamese culture
