Loved it!. This gives a really excellent view of not only women's roles in Vietnam but especially the non-American view of the war.

Very informative. Although a lot of the "famous" women wouldn't be very famous outside of Vietnam, the various exhibits were intersting and informative. Signs in Vietnamese and English everywhere, and in some places French. The museum is quite modern, and the admission price is nominal.
A wonderful tribute to Vietnamese Women.. Beautiful displays. It changed how I see women. Vietnamese women are so special.

Good displays and some interesting videos. It's a big place.. My girlfriend and I enjoyed this museum. We were a bit tired by the time we got to the museum after walking around town and that was a shame because the displays were very good...but three floors where too much for us at the time.The museum focuses on women's position in different ethnic groups in Vietnam and also on the role of women during different arm struggles. In a way; this museum is also a great way to know more about the different ethnic groups and history of Vietnam.

More than I expected in terms of economic / social challenges on display. Visited on 18 March 2012. Admission fee was 30,000 Dong ($1.50 USD) . Did not know what to expect. By far, it is the most modern, cleanest, and most professional museums I have visited in Vietnam. Comprised of 2 buildings, the first building is four stories. Top floor was a display on Vietnamese fashion highlighting ceremonial outfits for weddings and funerals. Third floor was role of women during French colonization and the American War (aka Vietnam War). Second floor, which I consider to be the most interesting, highlighted the role of women in Vietnam’s economy and motherhood. First floor was a small gift shop.The second building had a single floor highlighting women in Vietnam’s recent history of economic growth, urbanization, and migration from the countryside to urban areas. A few displays on literacy, economic challenges, drug abuse, etc. Quite surprised at how open the displays were to discuss the “growing pains” of a growing Vietnam.Would not plan my entire day around this museum, but if you have a couple of free hours, it is worth a visit.

Not so special. Nice to watch the video s about the street vendors, the making of the food, the weddings..
The museum itself was a bit average for me. I did not learn that much about Vietnamese women, and the explainations weren t always very clear.
Still worth a visit, but also no big miss if you don t have enough time.

Average. OK.. if you want to look at costumes etc. and womens contribution to Vietnam culture its ok. There are museums and museums.. we feel that there are better things to see including the Museum of of Ethnology we liked.

Relaxing and fairly informative.. It's a nice big building, not exactly overburdened with exhibits and probably more one for the ladies as much of the museum is dedicated to fashion, make up and marriage, guarranteed to scare off most men. There's an interesting section on the female involvement in the various conflicts and a sad video about the hard life of the out of town street sellers that have to peddle their wares on the polluted roads of hanoi all the while separated from their families. I felt so bad I decided to go out and make a purchase but my altruism waned slightly when one of them charged me $2 for a small bunch of bananas! Oh well.Anyway, only 20000VND and worth 45-60 mins of your time if you are in Hanoi.

Well worth a visit. I visited the Womens Museum as something of an afterthought, but it turned out to be one of the most interesting museums I have seen. I have never previously seen a Museum devoted exclusively to Women and their roles, but this was fascinating as it informed much about the Vietnamese family, engagement and marriage rites, childbirth and the raising of children. There was a particularly sad exhihibit detailing women who had fought for the country, many of whom died young.It was a very valuable and informative visit

Interesting museum. We passed by the Women's Museum while looking for Hoa Loa prison and decided to go in on a whim. It was a good decision. There are about five floors of interesting displays, on everything from ethnic outfits (like batik), to the role of Vietnamese women in various wars, and the plight of women from villages who sell goods in Hanoi to provide for their families. It's a nicely designed museum that's worth seeking out.

Vietnam Women's Museum. Interesting overview of women's role in Vietnamese history. There is also a wing with an exhibition about 'Worshipping Mother Goddess' and the top-floor a presentation of Vietnamese fashion. The turist shop in the building sells good handycraft, photobooks, nice silk scarfs and other issues.

Fantastic. Whilst the marriage and fashion floors weren't quite up my street, the stories and facts alongside the traditional costumes proved very interesting. What I loved most was the top floor about military women during the war. It was INCREDIBLE! So interesting I found myself taking notes! It's really worth a visit even just for that floor. I spent a month in Hanoi and found this museum to be one of the most enjoyable activities in the city!

really interesting. Takes about 2 hours to do. lots of information about Vietnam from a womens perspective. Interesting that during the 'American war' 40% of the fighters were women. Goes to show when the chips are down everyone fights for their country.

Moving view of history and culture. Traditional often matriarchal tribal culture, Revolutionary history through the artifacts of the women who hold up half the sky. Woman who lost children in the war. Changes in traditional Au dai dress style. All interesting.
Must See. What a fabulous homage to the women of Vietnam from history to fashion to stories... do yourself a favour...
General experience of Paradise Hotel. Really worth going to see -enjoyed the exhibits and experience
Life, costume, making a living and heroines in war.. A great deal of interesting insight into women's role, now and historically, in Vietnam can be gained here. Each floor expands the story.
Not a must see. I liked the wedding outfits, the clothes. I didn't care for the politically biased propaganda.

Best of the museums. Been to several museums and this is the best one so far.its spread over 3 or 4 floors and depending on yr personal interest,you will find at least one floor that will hold yr interest for longer than u expect.great layout
Women's museum. Well presented displays, and not so much propaganda
Fascinating. A beautiful and fascinating museum. Don't miss it.
Absolutely Fantastic. Stunning place.....misty and magical.... Stayed overnight on a Junk....Will never forget my time in Halong Bay

Pleasant !. The womens museum is well set out and everything is fresh and modern. The entry fee was 30,000 dong, so $1.50 USD. It was a pleasant way to spend a few hours, there is a lot of exhibits and short documentaries around the museum. It was nice to wander about and look at the exhibits and sit for a while to watch a doco.The examples of tools, clothing and textiles is fab !
Lots of learning. I learnt so much from my two hours in the Women's museum, in particular about the role played by women in Vietnam war and about the cultural differents between the ethnic groups.

Family life in Vietnam. The museum is well organised and give some insights in Vietnamese family life of both the Kinh (the main ethnic group in Vietnam ) and ethnic minorities. There is an interesting section on the mother god and the role of women in the war

Delightful gem!. Wonderful to see the ethnic culture garments and learn of their practices. The history section began in 1945 and had a bit of a twist to the American War. Avoid that floor if you have problems with that topic. Definitely worth the visit.
Interesting museum. This museum had a lot of interesting information on women's roles in Vietnamese society. Plan to spend a couple of hours to cover it all.

Extremely interesting museum. We visited this museum while staying in Hanoi. It is a very modern museum and extremely well set out with most interesting displays about the history of women in Vietnam. Associated with the historical aspect of women's role in the war, it also gives an insight into married life, motherhood and also the clothes worn by the different Vietnamese groups.The video displays in the different rooms are really interesting, especially the one relating to street sellers and also handicrafts.Not a museum to be missed.
First Museum to Visit. A rather comprehensive overview of a woman's roll within the Vietnamese society.
Well worth a visit. This is a modern museum has lots of information and is well worth a visit.

Go straight to the section on women in the war. The women's museum was a modern museum with videos and standing displays, but the most intriguing was the floor on the role of women in The American War. We read that 40% of the Viet Cong were women! The photos of the women in uniforma and with guns were riveting. One woman - without a weapon - captured four enemy soldiers. The stories of the individual women were fascinating.

The best museum in Hanoi, hands down!. After visiting many run-down propaganda museums in Hanoi, Women's Museum is like a breath of fresh air. Probably because it's funded by Western organisations, the logistics, setup and design of the exhibitions seem to be very professional and tastefully done by Western standards. What a pleasant surprise!!As a Hong Kong Chinese, I was not very interested in the 1st and 2nd floors dedicated to Vietnamese women's martial rituals, which are very similar to the Chinese. However, I am very impressed by the more upper floors that show the daily lives of women from ethnic minorities such as the Hmongs, with photos that show so much humanity, and informative and eye-opening videos (that show how they cook, and how they dye the clothes with natural sources), this is very interesting to me especially I missed the chance to visit these villages in Northern Thailand the month before. I also learned about the role of Vietnamese women in the society, especially during the Vietnam War, when they picked up their AK-47s and fought just like men. It's very awe-inspiring.You can easily spend three hours or more in this museum, because there's so much to learn and see. Highly recommended, maybe do this on a cloudy day!
It's about the Great Viet Women. It made me feel lucky that I was not born/bred in Vietnam.

Interessting, clean and organised but a litte boring. The museum was quiet and not many visitors came there. There are many different rooms displaying women in Viertnam. Personally I found the history of the women's role during the war most appealing. There is a lot about marriage rituals and other rituals which for me was a little boring. Overall pretty average, but a nice place to spend some time in a busy city.

A great insight into the women of Vietnam. A modern, well set out museum that covers from the tribal to the modern Vietnamese women. I particularly liked reading about the young women that are war heroes. Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Well designed and arranged museum, definitely recommend. Videos were very interesting.
The best part was the temporary Mother Goddes exhibit so go now if you can!
worth while. well designed, lots of English and good information

Excellent presentation of women's role and history in Viet Nam. A well designed layout and an excellent mix of video and static displays made our visit to the Viet Nam's Women's Museum thoroughly enjoyable. Highly recommended. You'll need about 90 minutes.

very nice museum. Well organized and multi-media displays, everything translated into very good English & French. A fascinating museum, especially the 3rd floor Women in History - photos and artifacts from the fascinating and brave women of the independence movement of the 30's and 40's as well as the resistance fighters during the American-Vietnam war.

Interesting but incomprehensive. As a Vietnamese, I find the museum somewhat interesting, but it doesn't offer a comprehensive view of Vietnamese women. It focuses too much on some ethnic minorities while ignoring the others. The History section is very ideological.
However, the current temporary exhibition on the worship of Mother Goddess is truly amazing!
Women's history. To see the part women have played in Vietnamese history so celbrated was great

Something to do- but boring.. After seeing the high rating on Trip Advisor, friend (20 yo male) and I (21 yo female) decided to check it out.At 30,000VND entry, it's a bit pricier than other museums but it's still nothing to complain about. Note- you have to leave large bags in provided locker rooms (free of charge).There are 4 levels, each depicting different aspects of the lives of the Vietnamese women (i.e. marriage, birth, fashion etc.) and there is both an elevator or staircases between each level.While informative, my friend and I found it to be quite boring overall and nothing too special. The best part was hearing the life stories of some of the women street vendors in a documentary (English Subtitles). However, I'm sure you could find that sort of information without a museum. It was only a 7 minute video, but it was the most interesting thing out of the entire exhibition. The colourful costumes of the ethnic tribes on display were also interesting to look at, but if you make the trip out to Lao Cai/Sa Pa, you would see more of the same thing there anyway.The museum is very new still, so maybe they will develop it further yet. Looking around, I noticed the lack of men viewing the exhibition... generally speaking- maybe this might be a place catered more to the interests of women. Friend and I much preferred the Military Museum in Hanoi.
interesting. great walk and interesting information was not sure what all would be included and was not busy at all

This is an excellent place.. Well designed, this museum gives the visitor a quality experience. It does a good job of explaining the prominent roles women have played in Vietnamese history. It is highly recommended.
Quirky, lovely museum. Thi museum has some interesting exhibits that bring to life the real lives of extraordinary women who are fighting for survival in Vietnam. Very moving and well worth visiting.

Nice place to visit. It's an interesting place to visit. A little more expensive then other museums that I visited, but it gives you a lot of information.
The only bad thing was the fact that a lot of the short movies or documentaries did not have English subtitles.
First rate. Excellent museum with very good and informative exhibits detailing the lives and work of Vietnamese women. The special exhibition currently on display (on Mother Goddess) is superb.

It'll change your feelings about street hawkers. Our little family group of five (all adults) left the museum with a tremendous sense of empathy for the women who sell everything from fruit to sandals on the streets of Hanoi. The videos in the exhibits are the best part of the museum. Definitely recommended.

Valuable insight into Vietnamese life. The museum was so well-laid out and informative, I wish I'd got there at the start of my trip rather than at the end as the lives of the people in the streets of Hanoi and Vietnam would have made a lot more sense to me. Give yourself enough time to watch the little videos and films as they are really well made. We spent nearly three hours there and could have spent more if we didnt need to find something to eat.

This is stunning!. Wonderful to get a women's perspective on life in Vietnam. This museum was a real find! Modern, clean with beautifully set out extensive exhibits clearly labelled in English. Each floor represents a different area of the contribution of women to Vietnamese society from childbirth, lifestyle, clothing, handcrafts, customs to wartime contributions. We spent a couple of hours here and found it absolutely fascinating.

Absolutely fabulous. If you have any interest in women's history this is a must see. Three floors of displays with loads of information from family life, women's economics, the mother goddess and textiles and fashion.

Fantastic. Fantastic, modern museum with interesting displays on every facet of Vietnamese life with a specific focus on women (surprise!). The traditional costumes on display provided a nice accompaniment to all the written content
Very Interesting. Gave you an insight into how resilient the vietnamese women are.Well worth the visit
Worthwhile. Excellent museum, interesting information about women's role in the war - recommend a visit

Worth visiting, especially for the war section. An insightful glimpse into the lives of women in Vietnam and the roles they played. The museum has 3 main categories: Fashion, Domestic Life and War. For me, the role women played during the Vietnam war was most fascinating. Worth visiting just for that.
Interesting but probably boring for the kiddies!. Interesting. Four floors of different topics. Best is the women in revolution floor.

Excellent!. This is a particularly interesting museum and well worth a visit. The role of women in Vietnamese society is celebrated through the exhibits and the information provided was very informative.

Well worth a visit - Womens Museum. This is a must - loved it - so interesting to get the female perspective of life in Vietnam. The Cafe adjoining the Museum sells the best spring rolls - have a try of the fruit salad Spring Rolls - really pleasant surprise.

Worth a quick visit: women vital to Vietnamese economy!. This was a 15 minute walk from our hotel in the Old Quarter and worth the trip. It could be called the Family Museum, as the exhibits focus on the family with a spotlight on women's work. The museum gives you a picture of just how much women do to keep the country moving (a lot). There's a nice exhibit on marriage traditions among the different ethnic groups. Throughout the museum we enjoyed the video segments, including an enlightening mini-documentary on street vendors: why they come to the city, their living conditions, etc... It truly informed our understanding of the city and the videos enhanced our appreciation of the country.For history buffs, there's a huge segment on women in the war. Other floors included exhibits on birth and fashion. English signs were terrific. The gift shop is small without much to speak of. Don't be put off by the construction on the sidewalk in front of the museum - it's worth at least 45 minutes and the $1.50 entrance fee.
Off the Beaten Track, but go.. Several blocks south of Hoan Kiem Lake, but worth the walk. Lots of exhibits about women, also video presentations. Historical displays, and dress over the ages.

Informative and interesting!. This museum gives interesting perspectives on the lives and various roles of women in Vietnam. So pleasing to see such a collection dedicated to women. The museum is divided into sections relating to women from different cultural groups as well as artefacts relating to marriage, motherhood, women's roles in the war and the daily struggles to earn a living. Anecdotal videos put a human face to these roles. Really enjoyed our few hours here. (Family - 2 adults, 2 teenagers)

Wonderful collection of Vietnamese dress and local crafts.. My husband and I enjoyed our visit to the women's museum...the collection of indigenous dress (for men and women) is outstanding and displayed very well. The displays of women in war were particularly well done and not overly political. On top floor they had a special exhibit of women and work with a focus on how NGO's had assisted Vietnamese women in gaining financial independence. Well worth the time. But, yes go early as the heat can be a bit much without AC.

fantastic find. well laid out and full of excellent explanations in english shows the role of women in family, life,history and fashion. Good videos of street vendors, costumes from the 54 ethnic groups and their diverse cultures and the position and role of women. Good for men too and will easily fill am until mid morning coffee !

Definitely worth a visit. Hanoi has a lot of museums and this one may not sound that interesting but it is definitely worth visiting. Well laid out with good English labelling, the museum provides a fascinating (if saddening) insight into areas such as the life of Hanoi's women street vendors, and ethnic groups' marriage and wedding customs.

A must, if time allows. Different Hanoi visitors had told us of this museum and it was the best most professional museum we saw in SE Asia. A good combination of interesting items on display and appropriate information: equally interesting for men and women. The coverage is broad: household living, costume, history (though the history is focussed mainly on the 20th century wars). Also a professional welcoming air about the experience.
hill tribe customs. Surprisingly good. Quality exhibits. Inight into Vietnamese culture. Go early as not airconed and whilst legs fresh.

excellent display. this is a recent addition to Hanoi. When we visited Hanoi four years ago the building housed a Street Vendors Exhibition. We were told by some other tourists that a French woman was dominant in putting together the current exhibition which, I hope, will be permanent. There are three floors of exhibits with different themes - family, dress and revolutionary women. Some of the old street vendor exhibits have been included and this includes a video providing background stories from female vendors. Translations are in both French and English.

Videos throughout the Museum Make it Special. Throughout the museum are monitors that play videos about the life of women in Vietnam. Most are in English or captioned in English; some are in French. The video about the street vendors is especially eye-opening. The exhibit about women who helped shaped the future of the country by participating in its wars and revolutions was also fascinating to me (especially as I am American.) One floor shows examples of the traditional dress of some of the ethnic minorities. That floor also has videos and exhibits about traditions surrounding pregnancy and birth.There is a good restaurant next door to the museum.
Peeping inside !. Strange reveiw we wanted to go here but it was shut for work being done but just the out side pictures and what you could see makes you want to go here, so next time !!!

An Insight Into Life in Vietnam. We spent an afternoon in the museum and were pleasently surprised with the extent of the exhibits and how well they were presented. The sections on custumes and daily life were fascinating as was the section on women in history. The staff were very pleasant and helpful. Well worth a visit.

Valuable Insight into Vietnamese Women. I found this museum very interesting. It provides insight into the strength and courage exhibited by the Vietnamese women. Well designed and presented. You'll come away with a better appreciation of the women in this country.

Lots of good information.. Really well done museum with three floors each one focusing on a different aspect of local woman's life. My favorite was the exhibit on the street vendors. It was almost empty when we went and only cost 30,000 dong. Well worth the visit. Only takes an hour or so to go through.
Good Insight to Women in Vietnam. A lot of information. From family life, to different aspects of the different ethnic groups in Vietnam.A section is dedicated to help Single Mothers.

The Women's Museum Hanoi. A must see in Hanoi, spent a few hours just browsing through the most interesting history of the women of Vietnam, the first floor was the history of courtship and wedding ceremony dress and artifacts.The second floor contained women and the birthing process and methods used and the ceremony that is conducted depending on whether its a boy or girl. The third floor I found fascinating it was dedicated to the women who fought in all they're wars along side the men folk, not in a nursing capacity, but in actual hand to hand combat, the women who where tortured and kept in the tiger cages. This was long before western women were allowed alongside men in battle. Truly courageous women.Another floor was dedicated to the traditional women's dress through the ages including the garments of the hill tribes. Last but definitely not least the last floor was dedicated to the human trafficking, which is still happening today true stories of young women lured through various means into this illegal practice. It outlined the work the agencies do to rehabilitate these young women when they return to Vietnam so they can once again lead productive lives.A must see for any women in Hanoi, drag your husbands along for a look also.

Interesting review of dress and fabric. If one is into history and fabric, this would be an interesting place to visit.Not on top of my still though. But if you have time to spare, sure, why not.Pls keep in mind that Vietnam is a communist country. And a very historicAnd interesting city, Hanoi. It seems to be a center of trade and commerce.

Lotus flowers and machine guns. The Vietnam Women's Museum is a very special place. Go on a guided tour so you can ask questions, and then go back and spend longer to have a closer look at what interests you. It is so moving, humbling and inspiring and puts into context and perspective the place women have had in Vietnamese history, particularly confict. Although the displays are not super slick and they are in need of repair, the content is superb. Keep aside a few hours to have a good look at all the photos and artefacts, and make sure you go to all 3 floors to get the breadth of history and contemporary life. Definately will return a visit to this place and recommend it to everyone as it is not just of interest to women.
